column2: Political Declaration on Responsible Military Use of Artificial Intelligence and Autonomy
column3: Political Declaration on Responsible Military Use of AI and Autonomy
column15: Requires military AI use to comply with international law. Mandates accountability and legal reviews. Demands senior oversight and bias minimization. Insists on transparency and training. Prescribes explicit uses and safeguards. Encourages public commitment and international engagement.
column16:
Require States to ensure military AI use complies with international law, particularly international humanitarian law.

Mandate accountability through a responsible human command chain.

Impose legal reviews to align military AI with international obligations and enhance civilian protection.

Demand oversight by senior officials for high-consequence AI applications.

Advocate minimizing unintended bias in military AI.

Insist on transparent, auditable methodologies and documentation for military AI development.

Oblige training for personnel to understand AI capabilities and limitations, preventing automation bias.

Prescribe explicit, well-defined uses for military AI, with rigorous testing for safety and effectiveness.

Implement safeguards to detect and mitigate AI failures, with the ability to deactivate systems if needed.

Encourage States to publicly commit to these measures, support responsible AI use, and engage internationally to refine and promote these standards.

column2: AI Liability Directive
column3: AI Liability Directive
column15: Establishes rules for non-contractual civil claims related to high-risk AI. Requires evidence disclosure. Presumes non-compliance if orders ignored. Allows rebuttal of causal link presumption. Permits favorable national rules. Mandates evaluation by European Commission. Amends Directive (EU) 2020/1828.
column16:
Establishes common rules for non-contractual fault-based civil claims related to damages caused by high-risk AI systems.

Requires disclosure of evidence from AI providers or users to substantiate claims, with courts empowered to order such disclosures.

Presumes non-compliance with duty of care if defendants fail to comply with evidence disclosure orders.

Presumes a causal link between defendant’s fault and AI system's output if certain conditions are met, allowing defendants to rebut the presumption.

Permits Member States to adopt more favorable rules for claimants, compatibility with Union law required.

Mandates evaluation and review by the European Commission within five years, considering the necessity of no-fault liability and insurance for AI operators.

Amends Directive (EU) 2020/1828 to include AI Liability Directive.

Obligates Member States to transpose the Directive into national law within two years and communicate relevant national legislative texts to the Commission.

column2: Council of Europe Framework Convention on Artificial Intelligence and Human Rights, Democracy and the Rule of Law
column3: Council of Europe Framework Convention on AI
column15: Mandates adoption of AI measures aligning with human rights, democracy, and law. Requires transparency and accountability. Obligates privacy protection. Demands risk assessment. Establishes international monitoring. Provides remedies. Calls for public consultation. Allows exceptions for security. Facilitates cooperation. Permits amendments.
column16:
Mandates Parties to adopt measures ensuring AI systems align with human rights, democracy, and the rule of law.

Requires transparency, accountability, and non-discrimination in AI systems' lifecycle.

Obligates implementation of measures to protect privacy, human dignity, and democratic processes.

Demands risk assessment and mitigation strategies for AI, considering human rights impacts.

Establishes a follow-up mechanism for international cooperation and compliance monitoring.

Provides for accessible remedies for human rights violations arising from AI systems.

Calls for public consultation and digital literacy to address AI-related impacts.

Stipulates that Parties must ensure effective procedural safeguards and oversight mechanisms.

Allows exceptions for national security but insists on adherence to international human rights law.

Facilitates international cooperation and information exchange on AI's human rights impacts.

Permits amendments and dispute settlements through negotiation or the Conference of the Parties.

column2: Hiroshima Process International Guiding Principles for Advanced AI Systems
column3: Hiroshima Process International Guiding Principles for Advanced AI Systems
column15: Encourages risk management throughout AI lifecycle. Mandates vulnerability monitoring and third-party issue reporting. Requires public disclosure of AI capabilities. Promotes responsible information sharing. Obligates AI governance policy development. Demands security investment. Advocates content authentication. Urges societal risk research. Supports international standards. Enforces data protection measures.
column16:
Encourages organizations to identify, evaluate, and mitigate risks throughout the AI lifecycle, employing diverse testing methods like red-teaming.

Mandates monitoring for vulnerabilities and misuse post-deployment, facilitating third-party reporting of issues.

Requires public reporting of AI systems’ capabilities, limitations, and appropriate uses to enhance transparency and accountability.

Promotes responsible information sharing among AI developers, including security risks and system capabilities.

Obliges organizations to develop and disclose AI governance and risk management policies, including privacy measures.

Demands investment in robust security controls across the AI lifecycle, encompassing cybersecurity and insider threats.

Advocates for content authentication mechanisms, like watermarking, to identify AI-generated content.

Urges prioritization of research to mitigate societal, safety, and security risks, aligning with global challenges like climate change.

Supports the adoption of international technical standards and best practices.

Enforces appropriate data measures to protect personal data and intellectual property, ensuring data quality and transparency.

column2: Hiroshima Process International Code of Conduct for Organizations Developing Advanced AI Systems
column3: Hiroshima Process International Code of Conduct for Organizations Developing Advanced AI Systems
column15: Promotes safe AI by providing guidance, requiring risk management, and monitoring misuse. Mandates transparency, information sharing, and robust security. Demands AI governance disclosure and content authentication. Prioritizes societal risk mitigation and addressing global challenges. Encourages international standards.
column16:
Promotes safe, secure, and trustworthy AI development by providing voluntary guidance for organizations developing advanced AI systems.

Requires organizations to identify, evaluate, and mitigate risks across the AI lifecycle, employing diverse testing methods and ensuring traceability.

Mandates organizations to monitor for vulnerabilities and misuse post-deployment, encouraging responsible disclosure of weaknesses.

Obligates public reporting of AI systems’ capabilities, limitations, and appropriate use to enhance transparency and accountability.

Encourages information sharing and reporting of incidents among stakeholders to advance safety and trustworthiness.

Demands development and disclosure of AI governance and risk management policies, including privacy protections.

Insists on robust security controls, including cybersecurity and insider threat safeguards, to protect AI systems.

Promotes development of content authentication mechanisms to identify AI-generated content.

Prioritizes research and investment to mitigate societal, safety, and security risks.

Calls for prioritizing AI development to address global challenges like climate crisis and health.

Encourages advancing international technical standards and implementing data protection measures.

column2: Internet Information Service Algorithmic Recommendation Management Provisions
column3: Internet Information Service Algorithmic Recommendation Management Provisions
column7: Chinese law and policy;AGORA Core Collection
column15: Establishes Chinese regulation on algorithmic recommendation services; encompasses topics concerning: general provisions, information service norms, user rights protection, supervision and management, legal liability, and supplemental provisions.
column17: Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Financial loss;Harms: Harm to property;Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Performance requirements;Strategies: Tiering;Strategies: Tiering: Tiering based on planning ability;Strategies: Tiering: Tiering based on impact;Incentives: Criminal liability;Incentives: Fines;Applications: Consumer goods;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Applications: Arts, sports, leisure, travel, and lifestyle

column2: Artificial Intelligence Law of the People’s Republic of China (Draft for Suggestions from Scholars)
column3: Artificial Intelligence Law of the People’s Republic of China (Scholars' Draft)
column7: Chinese law and policy;AGORA Core Collection
column15: Mandates AI regulation affecting Chinese interests. Establishes ethics and accountability principles. Requires oversight and risk prevention. Strengthens infrastructure and data sharing. Protects IP and user rights. Ensures compliance and promotes international cooperation. Provides liability structures for violations.
column16:
Mandates the regulation of AI development, provision, and use activities within and outside China if they affect Chinese national interests.

Establishes principles of ethics, fairness, transparency, safety, and accountability in AI development and use.

Requires human oversight, ethical risk prevention, and innovative development in AI activities.

Strengthens AI infrastructure and supports data sharing, compute resources, and algorithmic innovation.

Protects intellectual property rights and encourages green development in AI.

Ensures user rights, including privacy, the right to explanation, and non-discrimination.

Mandates compliance with safety and security assessments, especially for critical AI systems.

Implements a comprehensive oversight and coordination framework involving multiple government agencies.

Promotes international cooperation in AI governance and allows for countermeasures against discriminatory foreign actions.

Provides legal liability structures for violations, including administrative penalties, tort liability, and public interest litigation.

column2: An Act to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 39, Chapter 14, Part 1 and Title 47, relative to the protection of personal rights.
column3: ELVIS Act (Tennessee)
column7: U.S. state and local laws;AGORA Core Collection
column15: Renames the "Personal Rights Protection Act of 1984" to "Ensuring Likeness, Voice, and Image Security Act of 2024." Grants property rights over personal likeness. Imposes liability for unauthorized commercial use. Exempts fair use. Takes effect July 1, 2024.
column16:
Renames the "Personal Rights Protection Act of 1984" to the "Ensuring Likeness, Voice, and Image Security Act of 2024."

Grants individuals property rights over their name, photograph, voice, or likeness across all mediums.

Defines "voice" to include both actual and simulated sounds identifiable to an individual.

Terminates exclusive commercial rights after two years of non-use following ten years after death.

Imposes liability for unauthorized use of an individual's name, photograph, voice, or likeness in advertising or fundraising without consent.

Prohibits distribution of technology primarily used to produce unauthorized likenesses.

Allows actions to enforce rights by individuals or parties with exclusive contracts for personal services or sound recordings.

Exempts certain uses protected by the First Amendment as fair use, including news, commentary, and satire.

Mandates that individuals should have known about unauthorized uses to be exempt from liability.

Takes effect July 1, 2024, to protect public welfare.

column2: Advancing Governance, Innovation, and Risk Management for Agency Use of Artificial Intelligence
column3: Advancing Governance, Innovation, and Risk Management for Agency Use of Artificial Intelligence
column7: AGORA Core Collection;U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Mandates appointment of a Chief AI Officer within 60 days. Requires development of AI strategies. Imposes risk management requirements. Obligates annual AI use case inventory. Encourages removing innovation barriers while ensuring compliance with federal policies.
column16:
Requires federal agencies to appoint a Chief AI Officer (CAIO) within 60 days to enhance AI governance and innovation while managing risks, particularly those affecting public rights and safety.

Requires agencies to develop AI strategies to responsibly adopt AI, including generative AI, and to facilitate sharing and reuse of AI models, code, and data.

Imposes new requirements for agencies to manage AI-related risks, including following minimum risk management practices for AI impacting public rights and safety.

Obligates agencies to annually inventory AI use cases, identifying those impacting rights and safety, and to report on associated risks and mitigation strategies.

Encourages removing barriers to AI innovation related to IT infrastructure, data, and workforce while ensuring compliance with existing federal policies and risk management practices.

column2: OpenAI Preparedness Framework (Beta)
column3: OpenAI Preparedness Framework (Beta)
column7: Corporate policies and commitments;AGORA Core Collection
column15: Introduces a framework to track and mitigate AI risks. Requires risk evaluation across categories. Establishes a process for identifying unknown risks. Mandates deployment restrictions based on risk scores. Forms a Safety Advisory Group. Implements safety drills and audits.
column16:
Introduces a Preparedness Framework to track, evaluate, forecast, and mitigate catastrophic risks from AI models, emphasizing proactive safety measures.

Requires continual evaluation and monitoring of risks across categories such as cybersecurity, CBRN threats, persuasion, and model autonomy, using a Scorecard to report risk levels.

Establishes a process to identify unknown risks and update the list of risk categories as necessary.

Mandates that only models with a post-mitigation score of "medium" or below can be deployed, and those with a "high" or below can be further developed.

Forms a Safety Advisory Group to coordinate safety efforts and provide recommendations to OpenAI leadership, with an operational structure for decision-making and oversight.

Implements safety drills and third-party audits to ensure preparedness and accountability, with a focus on mitigating bias, hallucination, and misuse.

column2: Advancing the Responsible Acquisition of Artificial Intelligence in Government
column3: OMB Requirements for AI Acquisition in Government
column7: AGORA Core Collection;U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Directs agencies to improve AI acquisition with collaboration and risk management. Requires policy updates and compliance with safety practices. Encourages generative AI experimentation. Applies to federal agencies, excluding specific sectors, with deadlines. Minimizes vendor lock-in to foster competition.
column16:
Directs agencies to improve responsible AI acquisition, emphasizing cross-functional and interagency collaboration, risk management, and market competitiveness.

Requires agencies to update acquisition policies to reflect AI governance responsibilities and share AI acquisition information across the executive branch.

Mandates compliance with risk management practices for AI impacting rights or safety, including privacy, security, and interoperability considerations.

Urges agencies to prevent vendor lock-in by prioritizing interoperability, transparency, and innovative acquisition practices.

Encourages the acquisition of generative AI for experimentation, while emphasizing transparency, risk mitigation, and environmental considerations.

Applies to all federal agencies, excluding the Intelligence Community and National Security Systems, and sets specific deadlines for compliance and reporting. 

Fosters a diverse AI marketplace by minimizing vendor lock-in and promoting competition through strategic contractual requirements.

column2: Provisions on the Administration of Deep Synthesis Internet Information Services
column3: Provisions on the Administration of Deep Synthesis Internet Information Services
column7: Chinese law and policy;AGORA Core Collection
column15: Subjects generative AI systems in China to a variety of regulations, including restrictions on false or otherwise unwanted content; also mandates security assessments and various security measures.
column16:
Prohibits generative AI ("deep synthesis") systems in China from producing a variety of forms of unwanted content, including false information or content that harms "social order."

Requires generative AI systems to ascertain the true identity of each of their users.

Requires generative AI developers to assess the security of their AI systems, including by assessing the systems' cybersecurity attributes and their ability to abide by relevant regulations.

Requires generative AI systems to notify any individuals whose biometric information is edited in the production of AI-generated content.

Requires realistic AI-generated content ("deepfakes") to be labeled as AI-generated.

Requires generative AI developers to register their products with regulators, and requires regulators to carry out inspections of generative AI systems.

column2: An Act concerning consumer protections in interactions with artificial intelligence systems.
column3: Colorado AI Act
column7: U.S. state and local laws;AGORA Core Collection
column15: Establishes consumer protections for high-risk AI in Colorado. Requires reasonable care, documentation, risk management, and consumer disclosure. Compels risk disclosure to the Attorney General. Grants enforcement authority with specific defenses. Excludes certain entities. Empowers rule-making by the Attorney General.
column16:
SENATE BILL 24-205 establishes consumer protections related to interactions with high-risk artificial intelligence (AI) systems in Colorado, effective February 1, 2026.

Requires developers and deployers of high-risk AI systems to use reasonable care to prevent algorithmic discrimination based on protected classifications.

Mandates developers to provide detailed documentation about AI systems, including foreseeable uses and risks, to assist deployers in compliance.

Obligates deployers to implement risk management policies, conduct regular impact assessments, and inform consumers about AI involvement in consequential decisions.

Compels disclosure of known risks of algorithmic discrimination to the Attorney General and other stakeholders.

Grants the Attorney General exclusive enforcement authority, classifying violations as unfair trade practices, with specific defenses available for compliance with recognized frameworks.

Excludes certain entities and AI systems from the law, including those regulated by federal agencies or used in specific government contracts.

Empowers the Attorney General to promulgate rules for implementing these requirements.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Training for the Acquisition Workforce Act
column3: AI Training Act
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to establish an AI training program for the acquisition workforce.
column16:
Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to establish an artificial intelligence training program for the acquisition workforce to garner knowledge of the capabilities and risks associated with AI.

Requires the program to include information relating to AI risks mitigation and the identification of  reliable, safe, and trustworthy AI.

Requires the program to include information relating to future trends in AI, including trends for homeland and national security and innovation.
           
Requires the Director of the AI program to develop an interactive learning portfolio with technologists, scholars and experts from private, public and non profit sectors.

Requires the Director of the AI program to develop an evaluation system to track participation and improve the program
column17: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Education;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified

column2: Stop Spying Bosses Act
column3: Stop Spying Bosses Act
column15: Prohibits employers from using surveillance for non-job-related assessments. Requires disclosure of surveillance practices. Establishes a Privacy and Technology Division for oversight. Allows data access and correction. Grants rights to sue for violations. Mandates annual congressional reports. Prohibits predispute arbitration.
column16:
Prohibits employers from using workplace surveillance to monitor labor activities, ascertain political or religious views, or determine health or immigration status unrelated to job duties.

Requires employers to disclose details about workplace surveillance practices, including data collection methods, frequency, storage locations, business purposes, and third-party transfers, to employees and applicants.

Establishes a Privacy and Technology Division within the Department of Labor to oversee compliance and issue regulations.

Allows employees to access, correct, and request data collected about them and prohibits data transfer to third parties without disclosure and cybersecurity measures.

Grants employees and labor organizations the right to bring civil actions against violations, with potential damages and injunctive relief.

Prohibits predispute arbitration agreements regarding surveillance-related disputes.

Mandates annual reports to Congress on workplace surveillance impacts and recommendations for mitigating harms.

Coordinates with federal and state agencies to ensure consistent regulatory treatment of workplace surveillance.

column2: Countering Communist China Act, Title I ("Matters Related to Trade, Investment, and Economic Relations"), Sec. 101 ("Preventing Adversaries from Developing Critical Capabilities")
column3: Countering Communist China Act, Title I ("Trade, Investment, and Economic Relations"), Sec. 101 ("Preventing Adversaries from Developing Critical Capabilities")
column15: Identify categories of technologies and prohibit certain activities in sectors related to AI development that that poses acute threats to US national security.
column16:
Requires the President to identify, list, and annually update categories of technologies and products in AI related sectors that pose acute threats to U.S. national security if acquired by adversaries.

Requires the President to prescribe regulations prohibiting U.S. persons from engaging in covered activities involving listed technologies and products in the AI development sector.

Directs the President to submit annual reports to Congress detailing notifications of covered activities and assessing the need for regulatory amendments.

Authorizes $25 million for implementation and allows direct hiring to administer the Act.

Encourages multilateral engagement to align with allied countries on similar mechanisms for prohibitions and notifications on technologies in the AI sector.

column2: Countering Communist China Act, Title VI ("Matters Related to Democracy, Human Rights, and Taiwan"), Sec. 615 ("Deterring America's Technological Adversaries Act")
column3: Countering Communist China Act, Title VI ("Democracy, Human Rights, and Taiwan"), Sec. 615 ("DATA Act")
column15: Prohibits transactions involving sensitive personal data with China-influenced entities. Requires sanctions on foreign persons using Chinese-controlled apps for military, espionage, or cyber activities. Mandates sanctions for election interference or policy influence. Directs presidential determination on ByteDance and TikTok. Empowers transaction blocking of sanctioned persons. Allows case-by-case sanction waivers for national security. Terminates authorities five years post-enactment.
column16:
Prohibits U.S. persons from engaging in transactions involving sensitive personal data with entities subject to Chinese influence.

Requires the President to impose sanctions on foreign persons dealing in connected software applications under Chinese control, facilitating military, espionage, or malicious cyber activities.

Mandates sanctions for foreign persons involved in election interference against the U.S. or its allies, or influencing U.S. policy in favor of China.

Directs the President to determine and report on whether entities like ByteDance and TikTok meet criteria for sanctions.

Empowers the President to block all transactions involving property of sanctioned foreign persons within U.S. jurisdiction.

Allows the President to waive sanctions on a case-by-case basis if vital to U.S. national security interests.

Terminates the section's authorities five years after enactment.

column2: 2023 UK AI Safety Summit Response (Meta)
column3: 2023 UK AI Safety Summit Response (Meta)
column15: Commits Meta to responsible AI, prioritizing safety and transparency. Joins White House AI guardrails. Conducts evaluations and external testing. Requires AI vulnerability reporting. Implements security for AI models. Participates in industry initiatives. Invests in AI risk research. Conducts privacy reviews.
column16:
Commits Meta to responsible AI development, prioritizing safety and transparency in AI systems, including the Llama models.

Joins the White House Commitments to establish AI guardrails, focusing on safety, security, and trust.

Conducts extensive model evaluations and red teaming, including external testing at DEFCON, to identify and mitigate risks in AI models.

Requires information sharing and reporting on AI vulnerabilities, establishing feedback mechanisms for continuous improvement.

Implements robust security controls for AI model weights, treating them as core intellectual property.

Participates in industry initiatives like the Synthetic Media Framework to ensure identification and disclosure of AI-generated content.

Invests in research on AI societal, safety, and security risks, and collaborates with policymakers through the Open Loop program.

Conducts privacy reviews for AI data inputs, excluding private user data, and offers users control over data shared with generative AI features.

column2: REGULATION (EU) 2024/1689 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 13 June 2024 laying down harmonised rules on artificial intelligence and amending Regulations (EC) No 300/2008, (EU) No 167/2013, (EU) No 168/2013, (EU) 2018/858, (EU) 2018/1139 and (EU) 2019/2144 and Directives 2014/90/EU, (EU) 2016/797 and (EU) 2020/1828 (Artificial Intelligence Act)
column3: EU AI Act
column15: Implements a risk-based regulatory framework for AI, with specific attention to single-purpose AI systems used in risky contexts and  general-purpose AI systems with significant capability. Bans eight categories of unacceptably risky AI systems. Imposes risk-dependent requirements related to accuracy, cybersecurity, evaluation, monitoring, transparency, and registration. Defines exceptions, penalties, and a governance structure.
column16:
Classifies single-purpose AI systems into unacceptable, high, transparency, and minimal risk categories, defining specific regulatory requirements for each category. Requires strict monitoring and quality management for high-risk systems. Bans eight types of systems altogether as unacceptably risky. 

Imposes transparency and cooperation requirements for general-purpose AI models. Imposes additional risk management and evaluation obligations for general-purpose models with systemic risks.

Applies to AI developers and deployers whose systems are used in the EU market, regardless of their physical location, with exceptions for military, personal use, and scientific research.

Defines exemptions for free and open-source AI systems face fewer regulations, subject to transparency and licensing requirements.

Establishes the European Commission’s AI Office to lead implementation enforce compliance, with significant penalties for violations, including penalties up to EUR 35 million for placing prohibited AI systems on the EU market. Defines additional AI regulatory roles for advisory boards and national-level authorities.

column2: Promoting Responsible Evaluation and Procurement to Advance Readiness for Enterprise-wide Deployment for Artificial Intelligence Act
column3: PREPARED for AI Act
column15: Establishes a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officers Council. Mandates risk classification for AI use. Prohibits specific AI activities, including emotion detection. Directs procurement updates. Requires AI risk evaluation and monitoring. Stipulates documentation and transparency. Establishes annual reporting. Prohibits high-risk AI uses.
column16:
Requires the establishment of a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officers Council to coordinate AI use in federal agencies.

Mandates agencies to develop risk classification systems for AI use cases, categorizing them as unacceptable, high, medium, or low risk.

Prohibits AI use for certain activities, such as mapping facial features for emotion detection or categorizing individuals based on biometric data for sensitive traits.

Directs updates to the Federal Acquisition Regulation to ensure AI procurement includes risk and impact assessments.

Requires agencies to implement processes for evaluating AI risks and to conduct ongoing monitoring, especially for high-risk use cases.

Stipulates comprehensive documentation and transparency requirements for AI models and data.

Establishes annual reporting protocols for obstacles in AI testing and evaluation, promoting interagency collaboration to address challenges.

Prohibits the use of AI for certain high-risk applications and mandates public disclosure of AI inventories and risk classifications.

column2: Political BIAS Emails Act of 2023
column3: Political BIAS Emails Act of 2023
column15: Prohibits email providers from flagging elected political emails as spam without user direction. Requires quarterly transparency reports on flagged political emails. Mandates data disclosure to campaigns upon request. Obliges providers to offer email deliverability best practices. Enforces via FTC. Defines key terms.
column16:
Prohibits email service providers from using filtering algorithms to flag emails from political campaigns that consumers have elected to receive as spam without user direction.

Requires providers to publish quarterly transparency reports detailing instances of political emails flagged as spam, including breakdowns by political party and filtering algorithm usage.

Mandates email providers to disclose specific spam-filtering data to political campaigns upon request, with limitations on request frequency.

Obliges providers to offer best practices to political campaigns for improving email deliverability to primary inboxes.

Enforces these provisions through the Federal Trade Commission, treating violations as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act.

Defines key terms including “filtering algorithm,” “operator,” and “political campaign.”
column17: Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About incidents;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form;Strategies: Disclosure: About incidents;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Incentives: Civil liability

column2: Generative AI Copyright Disclosure Act of 2024
column3: GenAI Copyright Disclosure Act
column15: Requires anyone that creates or alters a training dataset for a generative AI system to submit a notice to the Register of Copyrights detailing copyrighted works used in the dataset 30 days before the model being made available to consumers or 30 days after the Act takes effect. Imposes a $5,000 penalty for non-compliance and instructs the Register to create a public database of filed notices.
column16:
Requires anyone who creates or alters a training dataset used for a generative AI system to submit a notice to the Register of Copyrights with a summary of any copyrighted works used in the dataset and the URL for the dataset.

Requires the notice must be submitted 30 days before the AI system is made available to consumers or within 30 days of the Act taking effect for systems already available.

Imposes a civil penalty of at least $5,000 for non-compliance.

Requires the Register to establish and maintain a public database of filed notices.
column17: Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Harm to property;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Incentives: Civil liability;Incentives: Fines;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form

column2: Better Mental Health Care for Americans Act, Sec. 201
column3: Better Mental Health Care for Americans Act, Sec. 201
column15: Amends Medicare Advantage plans to ensure mental health and substance use benefits parity. Mandates standards-based necessity determination and NQTL analyses. Imposes penalties for non-compliance. Extends parity to drug plans. Directs regulation issuance within 18 months. Allocates $10 million for implementation.
column16:
Amends Medicare Advantage plans to require parity in mental health and substance use disorder benefits, ensuring financial and treatment limitations are no more restrictive than those for medical benefits.

Mandates MA organizations to determine medical necessity for mental health and substance use benefits based on generally accepted standards.

Requires MA organizations to conduct and submit comparative analyses of nonquantitative treatment limitations (NQTLs) for mental health and substance use disorder benefits.

Imposes penalties for failing to comply with the mental health parity requirements.

Extends parity provisions to prescription drug plans, ensuring consistent application across Medicare Advantage and prescription drug plans.

Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue implementing regulations within 18 months.

Sets the effective date for amendments to plan years beginning two years post-enactment, with $10 million allocated for implementation funding through the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.

column2: Better Mental Health Care for Americans Act, Sec. 203
column3: Better Mental Health Care for Americans Act, Sec. 203
column15: Amends the Social Security Act to require behavioral health information disclosure, including provider access, wait times, payment statistics, and denial data. Specifies AI and technology use in denial processes. Aims to enhance transparency and informed choice in behavioral health coverage.
column16:
Amends Section 1851(d)(4) of the Social Security Act to include provisions for behavioral health information starting in 2025.

Requires the provision of information on access to in-network behavioral health providers, including average wait times for new patient appointments and data on provider participation agreements.

Mandates disclosure of payment request statistics for mental health or substance use disorder services, specifying the percentage handled by in-network versus out-of-network providers.

Requires reporting on the number and percentage of denials for prior authorization or payment for mental health services compared to non-mental health services, categorized by denial type and service type.

Specifies the use of decision support, AI, machine learning, clinical decision-making, or other technologies in denial processes, with comparisons to similar physical health conditions.

Aims to promote informed choice by enhancing transparency in behavioral health service coverage.

column2: Child Exploitation and Artificial Intelligence Expert Commission Act of 2024
column3: Child Exploitation and AI Commission Act
column15: Establishes a Commission of Experts to evaluate the existing capabilities of law enforcement to detect and prosecute child exploitation crimes involving AI, and recommend solutions.
column16:
Establishes the Commission of Experts on Child Exploitation and Artificial Intelligence to investigate and recommend solutions for the prevention, detection, and prosecution of child exploitation crimes involving AI.

Directs the Commission to assess the role of AI in child exploitation and evaluate law enforcement's current capabilities to detect and prosecute such crimes.

Requires the Commission to recommend statutory or constitutional amendments to address obstacles to prosecution identified by the Commission and enhance law enforcement's ability to combat AI-facilitated child exploitation.

Mandates the Commission to submit to Congress interim reports as needed and a final report within two years of member appointments.

Details membership of the Commission as composed of 13 appointed experts from various fields, and outlines guidelines on membership qualifications and operational procedures.

Empowers the Commission to hold hearings, obtain official data, and utilize various support services for its operations.

column2: New Jersey Bill A537
column3: New Jersey Bill A537 ("Discrimination in Automobile Insurance")
column15: Require insurers using automated or predictive underwriting to annually document non-discriminatory pricing. Mandate balanced pricing segments. Define automated underwriting systems. Authorize Commissioner to adopt regulations. Specify act effective six months post-enactment, applying to new/renewed policies.
column16:
Require automobile insurers using automated or predictive underwriting systems to annually provide the Department of Banking and Insurance with documentation demonstrating no discriminatory outcomes in pricing based on race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, or religion.

Mandate insurers to show that each pricing segment is balanced and not disproportionate to the overall policyholder population.

Define ‚Äúautomated or predictive underwriting system‚Äù as a computer-generated process, including robotic process automation, artificial intelligence, or other specialized technology, used to evaluate risk and determine insurance rates.

Authorize the Commissioner of Banking and Insurance to adopt rules and regulations to implement the act.

Specify that the act takes effect on the first day of the sixth month following enactment and applies to automobile insurance policies initiated or renewed from that date.

column2: Directive on Automated Decision-Making (Canada)
column3: Directive on Automated Decision-Making (Canada)
column15: Mandates compliance by April 1, 2020, for post-April systems. Requires Algorithmic Impact Assessments. Demands transparency and human intervention. Obligates data governance. Ensures recourse options. Specifies non-compliance consequences. Designates CIO guidance. Excludes certain agencies.
column16:
Mandates compliance with the directive by April 1, 2020, for automated decision systems developed or procured post-April 1, 2020.

Requires Algorithmic Impact Assessments before production, with updates and public releases.

Demands transparency by notifying and explaining decisions made by automated systems.

Calls for testing and monitoring to prevent biases and ensure compliance with laws and directives.

Obligates data governance and quality assurance, including peer reviews and Gender-based Analysis Plus.

Ensures human intervention is possible in automated decision processes.

Provides recourse options for clients to challenge decisions.

Mandates publishing information on system effectiveness and efficiency.

Specifies consequences for non-compliance under the Financial Administration Act.

Designates the Chief Information Officer to provide guidance and maintain the Algorithmic Impact Assessment.

Excludes certain agencies and allows specific agreements for adopting directive requirements.

column2: New Generation Artificial Intelligence Development Plan
column3: New Generation Artificial Intelligence Development Plan
column5: State Council of the People's Republic of China
column15: Aims to establish China as an AI leader by 2030. Promotes AI integration, key technology development, and military-civilian integration. Sets strategic objectives, standards, and regulations. Supports talent cultivation, international cooperation, and governance structures for implementation and evaluation.
column16:
The "New Generation Artificial Intelligence Development Plan" aims to establish China as a global leader in AI by 2030.

Promotes AI integration into economic and social sectors, enhancing national competitiveness and security.

Mandates the development of AI key technologies, including autonomous systems, knowledge computing, and intelligent robots.

Sets strategic objectives to achieve global AI leadership by 2020, 2025, and 2030, with specific economic targets and regulatory frameworks.

Emphasizes building AI innovation systems, fostering high-end AI industries, and upgrading industrial and social intelligentization.

Encourages military-civilian integration of AI technologies and development of AI-related infrastructure.

Establishes standards, regulations, and ethical guidelines to ensure safe, reliable AI development.

Supports talent cultivation and international cooperation to enhance AI R&D and application capabilities.

Outlines governance structures for implementing AI strategies and plans, including task monitoring and evaluation mechanisms.

column2: FinCEN Modernization Act of 2023
column3: FinCEN Modernization Act of 2023
column15: Cites the Act as the "FinCEN Modernization Act of 2023." Requires FinCEN to establish research and information-sharing programs on technological advances. Mandates exploration of beneficial innovations. Obligates adoption of necessary technologies. Enables information exchange. Authorizes non-standard transactions. Compels annual reporting to Congress.
column16:
Cites the Act as the "FinCEN Modernization Act of 2023."

Requires FinCEN to establish research, development, and information-sharing programs focusing on technological advances like machine learning and data analytics.

Mandates FinCEN to explore and evaluate technological innovations beneficial for financial systems and detect illicit activities.

Obligates FinCEN to adopt necessary technologies for monitoring cryptocurrencies and addressing money laundering and cyber threats.

Enables FinCEN to exchange information with other Treasury offices and federal departments.

Authorizes FinCEN to enter into non-standard transactions and accept contributions, gifts, or donations to support technological advancements.

Compels FinCEN to submit an annual report detailing transactions, contributions, and their justifications and purposes to relevant Congressional committees.
column17: Strategies: Government support: For R&D

column2: Federal Improvement in Technology Procurement Act
column3: FIT Procurement Act
column15: Requires the Federal Acquisition Institute to incorporate experiential learning into certification programs within 18 months. Mandates a cross-functional ICT acquisition training program. Encourages off-the-shelf technologies and innovative procurement techniques. Reassigns AI training responsibility to GSA. Expands Commercial Solutions Opening Authority. Increases simplified acquisition threshold to $500,000. Requires Administrator to issue past performance guidance. Establishes a working group to address Federal vendor base issues.
column16:
Requires the Federal Acquisition Institute to incorporate experiential learning into key acquisition certification programs within 18 months.

Mandates the development and implementation of a cross-functional ICT acquisition training program, emphasizing market research, cloud computing, artificial intelligence, and cybersecurity.

Encourages the use of commercially available off-the-shelf technologies and innovative procurement techniques like oral presentations and product demonstrations.

Reassigns the responsibility for AI training requirements from the Office of Management and Budget to the General Services Administration.

Expands the Commercial Solutions Opening Authority to include commercial services and mandates public reporting and data collection on its use.

Increases the simplified acquisition threshold from $250,000 to $500,000.

Requires the Administrator to issue guidance on using past performance from a broader range of projects to increase competition.

Establishes a working group to address the shrinking Federal vendor base and recommends actions to remove barriers to qualified vendors.
column17: Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: New institution

column2: OpenAI's Approach to Frontier Risk (An Update for the UK AI Safety Summit)
column3: OpenAI's Approach to Frontier Risk (An Update for the UK AI Safety Summit)
column15: Describes OpenAI's progress on realizing the company's voluntary commitments to promote safety, security, and trust in AI, initially made in July 2023. Details OpenAI's approach to mitigating frontier risks, which are the focus of the UK AI Safety Summit, and the development of a Preparedness Framework.
column16:
States that OpenAI's is establishing a Preparedness Framework to manage risks from frontier AI models, focusing on a development process governance structure and preemption of catastrophic outcomes; this work will complement existing risk mitigation work and includes a joint Deployment Safety Board with Microsoft. 

States that OpenAI is creating Superalignment and Preparedness teams within the company to align AI systems with human intent and track and prepare for frontier risks, including cybersecurity, CBRN, persuasion, and autonomous replication and adaptation. Notes that OpenAI is also increasing investment into cybersecurity and insider threat safeguards.

States that OpenAI implemened red-teaming and evaluations to assess new models for safety, including GPT-4 and DALL-E 3, focusing on dual-use capabilities, cybersecurity vulnerabilities, and self-replication.

States that OpenAI will include the publication of a system card in every new AI system, which informs users of key factors impacting system behavior.

States that OpenAI has initiated a reporting mechanism for responsible disclosure of dangerous capabilities among AI labs, focusing on national security-related risks.

Details OpenAI's emphasis post-deployment monitoring for misuse, security controls to protect intellectual property and data, and the development progress provenance techniques to identify AI-generated content.

States that OpenAI implemented data input controls and provides mechanisms for users to opt-out of their data being used for AI training.

column2: Kids Online Safety Act, Sec. 13 ("Filter Bubble Transparency Requirements")
column3: Kids Online Safety Act, Sec. 13 ("Filter Bubble Transparency")
column15: Requires covered internet platforms to inform users about opaque algorithm and user data usage and provide detailed algorithm operational information. Mandates offering an input-transparent algorithm alternative and prohibits discrimination against users of this alternative.
column16:
Requires providers of covered internet platforms that use opaque algorithms to notify users about their use and provide detailed information about their operation, including their features, user-specific data collection, and algorithmic inputs in an easily accessible form.

Mandates platforms to offer an easily accessible input-transparent algorithm alternative and prohibits discrimination, via methods like differential pricing, against users who choose the alternative.

Empowers enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission to treat violations as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act.

Exempts small downstream providers and non-profit organizations from certain enforcement provisions.
column17: Risk factors: Privacy;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Differential treatment based on a protected characteristic;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Strategies: Input controls;Strategies: Input controls: Data use;Incentives: Civil liability

column2: Securing Elections From AI Deception Act
column3: Securing Elections From AI Deception Act
column15: Prohibits the use of AI to interfere with elections and deprive individuals of the right to vote. Mandates disclaimers on election-related AI-generated content.
column16:
Prohibits developers and deployers from using AI to intentionally deceive or defraud individuals of their voting rights in federal, state, or local elections.

Requires election-related AI-generated content to include disclaimers, informing the public that the content was created using AI.

Mandates developers to provide mechanisms ensuring such disclaimers are permanent or difficult to remove.

Directs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to issue regulations on disclaimer requirements and enforce compliance.

Obliges developers and deployers to ensure their algorithms meet safety and efficiency standards as outlined.

column2: Executive Order on the Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence
column3: Executive Order on the Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence (EO 14110)
column7: Enacted laws and policies;AGORA Core Collection;U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Requires Federal agencies to ensure AI safety and security through standardized evaluations and monitoring. Promotes responsible AI innovation and competition. Commits to supporting American workers. Advances equity and civil rights in AI applications. Protects consumer interests. Ensures privacy and civil liberties. Strengthens Federal AI governance. Coordinates international AI safety and security efforts.
column16:
Requires Federal agencies to ensure AI is safe and secure by developing standardized evaluations, robust testing, and post-deployment monitoring systems.

Promotes responsible innovation and competition by investing in AI research and education, attracting global AI talent, and ensuring a fair marketplace.

Commits to supporting American workers by adapting job training and ensuring AI does not undermine labor rights or job quality.

Advances equity and civil rights in AI applications, requiring AI to comply with Federal laws and promoting technical evaluations and oversight.

Protects consumer interests by enforcing consumer protection laws and safeguards against AI-related harms in critical fields like healthcare and finance.

Ensures privacy and civil liberties by regulating data collection, use, and retention, and employing privacy-enhancing technologies.

Strengthens Federal AI governance by developing guidelines for AI safety, establishing reporting requirements for dual-use AI models, and monitoring AI's impact on critical infrastructure and cybersecurity.

Coordinates international AI safety and security efforts, engaging with allies to develop a global framework for managing AI risks and benefits.

column2: Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights
column3: Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights
column7: AGORA Core Collection;U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Requires pre-deployment testing, risk mitigation, and ongoing monitoring for automated systems' safety and effectiveness. Mandates independent evaluations, public reporting, and avoiding inappropriate data. Demands protections against algorithmic discrimination and data privacy. Institutes oversight on surveillance technologies. Requires clear user notifications and explanations. Insists on transparency and accountability through independent evaluations.
column16:
Requires automated systems to undergo pre-deployment testing, risk identification, mitigation, and ongoing monitoring to ensure safety and effectiveness.

Requires that systems avoid the use of inappropriate or irrelevant data and that independent evaluations and public reporting confirm system safety and effectiveness.

Demands protections against algorithmic discrimination by incorporating proactive equity assessments, representative data usage, and continuous disparity testing and mitigation.

Enforces data privacy through built-in protections, user consent for data collection, and limitations on data use and sharing, particularly in sensitive domains such as health, education, and finance.

Institutes heightened oversight and limits on surveillance technologies to protect civil liberties, privacy, and democratic values, with specific restrictions on continuous surveillance in sensitive contexts.

Requires designers and deployers of automated systems to provide clear, timely, and accessible notice and explanations of system use, including the rationale behind decisions impacting individuals.

Insists on independent evaluations and public reporting to ensure transparency and accountability in the use of automated systems, with detailed documentation and assessments.

column2: Department of Defense Directive 3000.09 ("Autonomy in weapon systems")
column3: DoDD 3000.09 ("Autonomy in weapon systems")
column7: AGORA Core Collection;U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Establishes Department of Defense policy on the use of autonomous and semi-autonomous weapons systems, including testing & evaluation requirements and requirements that humans be able to intervene should such weaponry begin to operate in unintended ways.

column2: An Act concerning discrimination and automated decision systems and supplementing P.L.1945, c.169 (C.10:5-1 et seq.).
column3: New Jersey SB1402
column15: Prohibits financial lenders, insurance companies and healthcare providers from using automated decision systems to discriminate against protected classes in providing services.
column16:
Bans banks, mortgage companies and other lending institutions from using AI systems which discriminate against members of a protected class; systems are deemed discriminatory if these disproportionately favor or disfavor members of a protected class in the provision of loans and credit terms.

Bans insurance companies from using AI systems which discriminate against members of a protected class; systems are deemed discriminatory if these disproportionately favor or disfavor members of a protected class in providing insurance coverage and setting the terms and rates of such coverage.

Bans health care providers from using AI systems to discriminate against members of a protected class; systems are deemed discriminatory if these disproportionately favor or disfavor members of a protected class in assessing eligibility for healthcare services.

Categorizes the above use of AI systems which discriminate against members of protected classes as unlawful discrimination; such companies and service providers are subject to fines not exceeding $10,000 on the first instance, if these companies have not committed prior violations within five years of the charge, and permits victims to file civil lawsuits against such companies.

column2: An Act preventing a dystopian work environment.
column3: An Act preventing a dystopian work environment.
column15: Mandates that Massachusetts employers inform workers of the use of automated decision systems, requires impact assessments on such systems, and sets conditions under which they can be used.
column16:
Mandates that employers inform workers of data collection and distribution, including inputs for Automated Decision Systems (ADS), bans employers from collecting data for non-necessary business purposes, and mandates security measures to protect worker data.

Requires employers to inform workers before ADS use and annually provide workers with notice of all ADS in use, bans ADS use for employment decisions where there is potential for bias and/or discrimination, and requires third-party impact assessments to be conducted on such systems before and after use.

column2: A bill to amend the South Carolina Code of Laws by adding Section 63-5-380 so as to prohibit operators of internet-based applications from using "automated decision systems" to place content on social media platforms for users under the age of eighteen who are residents of the State of South Carolina, to require operators to perform age-verification practices for certain users, to establish that a violation is an unfair or deceptive act or practice under the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act, and for other purposes.
column3: South Carolina Recommender System Act
column15: Prohibits operators of internet-based applications, including social media platforms, from using automated decision-making (ADM) systems to suggest content for users under 18 in South Carolina. Requires operators who use ADM systems for users 18 or older to perform age verification of users; violation is subject to civil penalties.
column16:
Prohibits operators of internet-based applications, including social media platforms, from using automated decision-making (ADM) systems to suggest content for users under 18 who are residents of South Carolina.

Requires operators using ADM systems to suggest content for those 18 or older to either 1) Perform age verification of users through an independent third-party service or 2) Require users to upload government-issued identification, a current photograph, and personal information so age can be verified through publicly available records. 

Establishes civil penalties for violations of the above.
column17: Strategies: Tiering;Incentives: Civil liability;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Applications: Arts, sports, leisure, travel, and lifestyle

column2: An act to amend the general business law, in relation to requiring advertisements to disclose the use of synthetic media
column3: Synthetic Media Disclosure Act
column15: Requires any person engaged in advertising property or services in New York to disclose when synthetic media is used in advertisements.
column16:
Requires any person advertising property or services in New York to disclose when synthetic media is used in advertisements, including when synthetic media depicts a natural person, without the person’s consent.

Establishes civil penalties and fines if the above is violated.

column2: An Act amending Title 18 (Crimes and Offenses) of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes, in sexual offenses, providing for the offense of unlawful dissemination of artificially generated depiction; and, in minors, further providing for the offense of sexual abuse of children and for the offense of transmission of sexually explicit images by minor.
column3: Creation and Dissemination of Sexually Explicit Content Act
column15: Makes it illegal to disseminate deepfake pornography -- lifelike visual content that depicts sexual scenes which did not occur in reality, including images of nudity and sexual acts -- in the state of Pennsylvania.
column16:
Proscibes disseminating "deepfake pornography" -- lifelike visual content that depicts sexual scenes which did not occur in reality, including images of nudity and sexual acts -- with the intent to harass, annoy, or alarm the depicted individual as a criminal misdemeanor offense in the state of Pennsylvania.

Exempts cases in which deepfake pornography was disseminated with the consent of the depicted individual from punishment under this law.
column17: Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Performance requirements;Incentives: Criminal liability;Applications: Broadcasting and media production

column2: Illinois HB53 2021
column3: AI Video Interview Discrimination Act
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Requires employers that rely solely on AI to analyze video interviews to report the demographic information of candidates who are and are not interviewed in person or hired so the state can identify if there is a racial bias in using AI.
column16:
Requires employers that rely solely on AI to analyze video interviews to collect information on the race and ethnicity of candidates who are and are not consequently interviewed in person or hired and to report this information annually to the Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity.

Requires the Department to analyze the data reported and report annually to the Governor and General Assembly on whether the data discloses a racial bias in using AI.

column2: Artificial Intelligence and Biosecurity Risk Assessment Act
column3: AI Biorisk Assessment Act
column15: Requires the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response to conduct risk assessments and implement strategic initiatives that address threats to public health posed by AI, especially using AI to develop novel pathogens and bioweapons.
column16:
Requires the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response to conduct risk assessments and implement strategic initiatives that address whether AI can develop novel pathogens, viruses, bioweapons, or chemical weapons, including monitoring and researching the global biological catastrophic risk landscape.

Requires the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response to include a summary of the risk assessment above in the National Health Security Strategy.

column2: Sec. 2412. Duty of Care, Digital Consumer Protection Commission Act of 2023
column3: Sec. 2412 of 2023 Consumer Protection Act
column15: Prohibits non-governmental entities from designing or employing AI, or handling data, in ways that will harm people or discriminate either (a) on the basis of protected class or (b) in granting access to important opportunities and services.
column16:
Prohibits non-governmental entities from designing or employing AI, or handling personal data, in a way that will:

(1) Cause physical, psychological, economic, relational, or repetitional injuries to a person;

(2) Discriminate on the basis of standard protected classes, including race and nationality; or

(3) Discriminate in the granting of access to important services and opportunities, including employment, credit, and education.

Exempts private groups not open to the public from the requirements outlined above.

column2: Sec. 2501. Corporate Citizenship and Ownership, Digital Consumer Protection Commission Act of 2023
column3: Sec. 2501 of 2023 Consumer Protection Act
column15: Requires operators of dominant online platforms with owners (including minority owners) who are citizens of foreign adversaries of the U.S. to sequester data and algorithms from agents of any foreign entity.
column16:
Requires operators of dominant online platforms with (a) large numbers of users and (b) ownership groups in which at least 10% of the members are citizens of foreign adversaries of the U.S. to sequester any back-end data or algorithm from agents of any foreign entity.

Also regulates foreign ownership of, and the granting of licenses for foreigners to operate, online platforms featuring large numbers of users, regardless of whether the platform uses AI.
column17: Strategies: Input controls;Strategies: Input controls: Data circulation;Applications: Broadcasting and media production

column2:
An Act to amend the general business law, in relation to the management
 and oversight of personal data (Section 7)
column3: New York Data Privacy Act, Section 7
column15: Requires entities that decline access to important services (e.g. healthcare and financing) on the basis of an AI system's decision to evaluate the system for accuracy & discrimination, to disclose the system's use, and to enable affected individuals to appeal the decision to a human being.
column16:
Requires any entity in New York that uses AI or another automated process as the sole basis of a decision that denies access to financial services, insurance, housing, public accommodation, healthcare, or basic necessities to:

(a) Clearly and conspicuously disclose that the decision was made solely on the basis of an automated process; and

(b) Enable any affected individual to appeal the decision, including by giving them the right to have a human review it.

Requires the above entities, and additionally those that use an automated decision systems to determine access to employment and education, to annually solicit an outside auditor to conduct, and make publicly available, an impact assessment of the system that:

(a) Evaluates the system's objectives, design, and training data, as well as how the system was tested for accuracy and discrimination; and 

(b) Assesses whether the system produces discriminatory results on the basis of race, color, ethnicity, religion, national origin, sex, gender, gender identity, sexual orientation, familial status, biometric information, lawful source of income, or disability.

column2:
An act to amend the labor law, in relation to establishing criteria for
the use of automated employment decision tools
column3: Automated Employment Decision Tools Amendment to NY Labor Law
column15: Makes it unlawful for an employer in New York to use or implement an automated decision tool to  filter employment candidates or prospective candidates for hire that has not undergone a disparate impact assessment annually.
column16:
Makes it unlawful for an employer in New York to use or implement an automated decision tool to filter employment candidates or prospective candidates for hire that has not undergone an disparate impact assessment annually.

Requires employers to provide the department with a summary of their most recent disparate impact analysis annually. Allows the Attorney General and Commissioner to initiate investigations and legal action if violations are suspected or found. Requires a summary of the most recent disparate impact analysis of the automated decision tool and the distribution date of the tool to be made publicly available on the website of the employer prior to implementing the tool.

column2: Artificial Intelligence for California Research Act
column3: Artificial Intelligence for California Research Act
column15: Directs the California Department of Technology to develop and implement a research plan on how AI can improve state and local services, including analysis of the risks and benefits of various use cases, best practices from other governments, guidelines for risk management, monitoring, and evaluation, and privacy. Instructs the Department of Technology to submit a report on its findings to the legislature.
column16:
Directs the California Department of Technology to develop and implement a research plan on the feasibility and risks of advanced technologies, specifically AI, to improve state and local government services.

Requires the research plan to include an analysis of the potential benefits and risks of using AI chatbots/assistance in various government benefit and welfare programs (such as disability insurance or affordable housing), a review of best practices from other governments, a cost-benefit analysis of implementing AI in government services, recommendations for effective integration (including risk management and monitoring and evaluation guidelines), and recommendations for mitigating privacy issues.

Instructs the Department of Technology to report its findings to the legislature before January 1, 2026.

column2: An act to add Chapter 5.9 (commencing with Section 11549.80) to Part 1 of Division 3 of Title 2 of, the Government Code, relating to state government.
column3: California AI-ware Act
column15: Establishes California’s Office of Artificial Intelligence to guide state agencies' design, use, and deployment of automated systems in a manner that minimizes bias and promotes privacy and civil liberties. Requires state agencies to inform users when they interact with an AI system, and provide instructions to reach a non-AI contact.
column16:
Establishes the Office of Artificial Intelligence in the California Department of Technology, which will guide state agencies' design, use, and deployment of automated systems in a manner that minimizes bias and promotes privacy and civil liberties.  

Requires state agencies to inform users they are interacting with an AI system, and provide instructions on how the user can reach a non-AI representative.

column2: An act relating to state affairs and government -- commission to monitor the use of artificial intelligence in state government.
column3: Rhode Island AI Commission Act
column15: Establishes a permanent commission to monitor the use of artificial intelligence in Rhode Island state government and recommend changes to the state’s use of automated decision-making (ADM) systems. Requires the commission to submit an annual, public report detailing their findings.
column16:
Establishes a permanent commission to monitor the use of AI in Rhode Island state government and recommend changes to the state’s use of automated decision-making (ADM) systems that may affect human welfare. 

Instructs the commission to continuously survey the state’s use of ADM systems, including identifying gaps in the procurement, evaluation, and ongoing testing of ADM systems, the training given to individuals using these systems, the transparency, explicability, and auditability of ADM systems, identifying and mitigating disparate outcomes due to protected characteristics, and addressing data security and intellectual property concerns. 

Requires the commission to include representatives from multiple state agencies (commerce, business regulation, children, youth, and families, etc.) and four from academic institutions. 

Requires the commission to submit an annual public report to the Governor and state legislature detailing its activities and findings, regulatory or legislative recommendations–specifically where state offices should or should not use automated decision systems, progress implementing previous recommendations, and the extent of algorithmic decision-making used by the state.

column2: An act to amend the executive law, in relation to creating the office of  algorithmic innovation
column3: NY Office of Algorithmic Innovation Act
column15: Establishes an Office of Algorithmic Innovation in New York to promote algorithmic innovation and ensure algorithms are safe, effective, and ethical.
column16:
Establishes an Office of Algorithmic Innovation in New York to create policies and set standards that ensure algorithms are safe, effective, and ethical, and that the state is conducive to promoting algorithmic innovation. 

Provides the Office the power to set standards, audit, and establish statewide policy on algorithms used in technology.

column2: An act relating to a study on the establishment of a program administered by the Texas Workforce Commission to train individuals in certain skills related to artificial intelligence systems.
column3: Texas Workforce Commission Act
column15: Requires the Texas House of Representatives committee overseeing workforce development to conduct a study on whether to establish an AI-related workforce training program.
column16:
Requires the Texas House of Representatives committee overseeing workforce development to conduct a study on whether to establish a workforce training program, administered by the Texas Workforce Commission, to train individuals currently in the workforce in the use, operation, and creation of AI systems. 

Requires the committee to report the results of the study to the Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Speaker of the House, and corresponding committee in the Senate no later than December 1, 2024.

column2: An Act requiring the Commissioner of Labor and Workforce Development to conduct a study and issue a report on the impact of artificial intelligence on the growth of the State's economy.
column3: New Jersey Bill A168
column15: Requires the New Jersey Commissioner of Labor and Workforce Development to conduct a study and issue a report on the impact of AI on the growth of the State’s economy.
column16:
Requires the New Jersey Commissioner of Labor and Workforce Development to conduct a study on the impact of AI-powered technology and automation on the growth of the State’s economy. 

Requires the Commissioner to issue a report within a year that addresses the predicted impact of AI on the labor market for highly skilled professionals, the occupations most affected by and new professions that may be created due to expanded use of AI, the impact of AI on labor productivity and economic growth, and the implications for long-term workforce education.

column2: An act creating a temporary state commission to  study  and  investigate how  to regulate artificial intelligence, robotics and automation; and providing for the repeal of such provisions upon expiration thereof
column3: Temporary AI Commission Act
column15: Establishes a temporary New York state commission to study the impact of AI, robotics, and automation and how to regulate these technologies.
column16:
Establishes a temporary New York state commission, composed of 13 members appointed by stakeholders in government and academia, to study the impact of and make determinations on how to regulate AI, robotics, and automation.

Requires the commission to study existing state laws and comparative state regulations for AI, the impact of AI on employment and data privacy, public sector AI applications, and the potential impact of AI regulation on industry. Requires the commission to make determinations regarding criminal and civil liability for AI-enabled violations of law and potential restrictions on AI use in weaponry. 

Requires the commission to issue a final report to the governor and other state leaders before December 31, 2024.
column17: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Government: military and public safety

column2: Supercomputing for Safer Chemicals Act
column3: SUPERSAFE Act
column15: Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to establish a consortium that identifies toxic substances and develops safer alternatives through computational toxicology methods based on AI and machine learning.
column16:
Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish a consortium representing federal, state, and academic stakeholders. The consortium will use supercomputing and machine learning to develop models that predict adverse health effects from toxic substances, establishing rapid approaches for large-scale identification of toxic substances and the development of safer alternatives.

Requires the Consortium to recommend how the information produced can be used in risk assessments by the EPA, other federal agencies, and industry.

Appropriates funding to the EPA Administrator to carry out the Consortium and requires the Consortium to make its model predictions public and accessible.

column2: Land Grant Research Prioritization Act of 2023
column3: Land Grant Research Prioritization Act of 2023
column15: Amends the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990 to allow research and extension grants to be made for developing agricultural applications of AI.
column16: Amends the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990 to allow research and extension grants to be made for developing and evaluating agricultural applications of AI, with an emphasis on the use of AI to improve specialty crop production.

column2: Drone Safety and Efficiency Act
column3: Drone Safety and Efficiency Act
column15: Requires the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration to adopt a performance and risk-based approach when reviewing requests for small unmanned aircraft systems (sUAS) to be waived from existing regulations.
column16:
Requires the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration to adopt a performance and risk-based approach when reviewing requests for certificates of waiver under Section 107 of Title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, which establishes rules for the operation of small unmanned aircraft systems (sUAS) for commercial purposes. 

Requires the Administrator to use big data analytics and machine learning to conduct the performance and risk-based approach and refrain from using open-ended descriptive prompts in the waiver application.

column2: Sensible Classification Act of 2023, Sec. 7: Implementation of Technology for Classification and Declassification
column3: Sensible Classification Act of 2023, Sec. 7: Implementation of Technology for Classification and Declassification
column15: Calls for using machine learning and artificial intelligence for both classification and declassification of national security information and security clearance eligibility assessment.
column16:
Requires the Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with various federal actors, to research a technology-based solution to reform the classification system employed by the federal government.

Requires a submission of recommendations to the President.

Mandates the President to submit a report on technology-based solutions to Congress no later than 540 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.

column2: An act to amend Chapter 12 of Title 31 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to the control of hazardous conditions, preventable diseases, and metabolic disorders [...]
column3: Georgia House Bill 203 (2023)
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Regulates the use of artificial intelligence and other technology in eye assessments for medical purposes, including by requiring medical professionals to analyze any data collected or generated by automated systems.
column16:
Requires all eye assessments that utilize artificial intelligence or other advanced technology to conform to the traditional standards of in-person care.

Requires a medical professional to analyze any information collected or generated by an automated system during the eye assessment process.

Requires all eye assessments to involve the collection of a patient's relevant medical information, which must be stored in a medical record for at least 7 years.
