column2: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6505 ("Assessments of production of semiconductors by the People's Republic of China")
column3: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6505 ("Assessments of production of semiconductors by the People's Republic of China")
column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: After this act is passed, the Director of National Intelligence must submit a detailed report about the production of semiconductors in China. The Director must also meet with federal agencies' heads to discuss the report and other findings related to the Chinese production of semiconductors.
column16:
Begins discussing the phrase “appropriate committees of Congress” and what organizations are actually a part of this phrase when benign referred. Also defines the term “legacy semiconductor” in terms of the definition given in another legislation document.

Annually for 3 years after this act is passed, the Director of National Intelligence must submit an unclassified assessment report regarding China’s production of semiconductors through China’s firms and business sectors to the appropriate committees of Congress.

The Director of National Intelligence must meet with the heads of federal agencies to discuss the elements of the assessment. They must discuss the self-sufficiency of China in the fields of artificial intelligence, cloud computing, autonomous vehicles, and other newer-technological areas. They must discuss China’s access to intellectual property related to leading edge process nodes, including electronic design automation technology. They must discuss Chinese firms’s production of semiconductors that are not legacy conductors and stockpiling efforts of semiconductor manufacturing equipment. They must discuss the relative market share and its trends of Chinese semiconductor manufacturers at different process nodes. They must discuss the outside recruitment activity into Chinese semiconductors firms and the capability of the Chinese workforce in developing semiconductors that are not legacy semiconductors and relevant equipment.

column2: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6812 ("Increased intelligence-related engineering, research, and development capabilities of minority institutions")
column3: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6812 ("Increased intelligence-related engineering, research, and development capabilities of minority institutions")
column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Requires the Director of National Intelligence to develop a plan to promote intelligence-related engineering, research, and development activities at institutes of higher education whose students are predominantly of minority ethnicities.
column16:
Requires the Director of National Intelligence to develop and submit to Congress a report and a plan to promote intelligence-related engineering, research, and development activities at institutes of higher education whose students are predominantly of minority ethnicities. 

Requires the plan described above to include an analysis of (a) the opportunities for advancing engineering, research, and development in computer sciences, including artificial intelligence, quantum computing, and machine learning, and synthetic biology, and (b) the investments necessary to do so.

Requires the plan to include metrics of success and actionable recommendations for the Director, Congress, and higher education institutions, and permits the Director to award contracts, grants, or other agreements to support the institutions.

Instructs the Director to establish goals and incentives to encourage the 
Intelligence Advanced Research Projects Activity to develop partnerships between itself, its partner institutions, and institutes of higher education whose students are predominantly of minority ethnicities.

column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Requires the Secretary of State to submit to Congress a report on recent changes made to the Foreign Service entry process, including the use of artificial intelligence and its impact on recruitment.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of State to submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report that describes and justifies any changes made during FY 2022 and 2023 to the Foreign Service entry process.

Includes the use of artificial intelligence, including deep textual analysis, and its impact on recruitment in the scope of the report.

column2: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 9506 ("Cybersecurity recruitment and retention")
column3: FY2023 NDAA, Section 9506 ("Cybersecurity recruitment and retention")
column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Requires the Secretary of State to establish Department of State positions that are solely dedicated to the recruitment and retention of personnel with backgrounds in artificial intelligence and other critical technology fields; authorizes $750,000 for each of the fiscal years 2023 through 2027 to do so.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of State to establish positions within the Bureau of Global Talent Management that are solely dedicated to the recruitment and retention of Department personnel with backgrounds in cybersecurity, engineering, data science, application development, artificial intelligence, critical and emerging technology, and technology and digital policy.

Requires the Secretary to submit a plan to the appropriate congressional committees that describes how the initiative described above will be implemented. 

Authorizes the appropriation of $750,000 for each of the fiscal years 2023 through 2027 to carry out this initiative.

Requires the Secretary to submit to the appropriate congressional committees an annual report, for a period of 5 years, on the implementation of the initiative, including the hiring authorities used to implement it, the number of employees hired through it, and recommendations to enhance the efficacy of the initiative.

Requires the Secretary to include computer programming languages within the Recruitment Language Program and provide appropriate language incentive pay.

Requires the Secretary to provide a list to the appropriate 
congressional committees that identifies (a) the computer programming languages included within the Recruitment Language Program and the language incentive pay 
rate and (b) the number of individuals benefitting from the inclusion of such computer programming languages in the Recruitment Language Program and language incentive pay.

column2: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 11504 ("At-sea recovery operations pilot program")
column3: FY2023 NDAA, Section 11504 ("At-sea recovery operations pilot program")
column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Requires the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security to conduct a pilot program to assess the potential for the autonomous, or remotely controlled, operation and monitoring of certain Coast Guard vessels.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security to conduct a pilot program to assess the potential for the autonomous, or remotely controlled, operation and monitoring of certain Coast Guard vessels.

Requires the pilot program described above to assess the complexities and risks of autonomous or remotely controlled vessel operation, gather data on the practice, and assess the regulatory environment necessary to facilitate the practice going forward. 

Permits the pilot program to include operations relating to the launch and recovery of unmanned spaceflight vessels and components.

Permits the Secretary to modify or waive applicable regulations or guidance that would otherwise interfere with the pilot program.

Requires the Secretary to provide the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology of the House of Representatives with a quarterly briefing on the pilot program.

Requires the Secretary to submit to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and 
Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and 
Infrastructure and the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology of 
the House of Representatives a final report assessing the execution of the pilot program and its implications for preserving safety and environmental quality. 

Requires the Comptroller General of the United States to consult with stakeholders and then submit to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives a report on the commercial availability, barriers to use, safety and security risks, use abroad, and impact on labor of autonomous and remote technologies used in the operation of shipboard equipment.

column2: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 862 ("Key advanced system development industry days")
column3: FY2023 NDAA, Section 862 ("Key advanced system development industry days")
column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Requires each Secretary of a military department to hold an event every 180 days designed to collaborate with the private sector on, and raise awareness of, innovation in autonomous systems with military applications.
column16:
Requires each Secretary of a military department to hold an event every 180 days designed to collaborate with the private sector on, and raise awareness of, innovation in autonomous systems with military applications. 

For each such event, requires the Service Chief concerned to identify military requirements, capability gaps, and opportunities for experimentation or exercises related to the autonomous systems covered at the event. 

For each such event, requires the service acquisition executive of the involved military department to identify acquisition strategies and potential acquisition funding mechanisms for the autonomous systems covered at the event.

Requires Department of Defense officials to draft reviews of each such event, analyze the reviews to identify trends and key takeaways, and distribute the reviews within the Department.

column2: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6513 ("Lead intelligence community coordinator for countering and neutralizing proliferation of Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems")
column3: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6513 ("Lead intelligence community coordinator for countering and neutralizing proliferation of Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems")
column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to appoint a lead coordinator to address the proliferation of Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems, develop a comprehensive action plan, and report findings to Congress. Encourages collaboration among members of the Five Eyes Partnership and Israel in countering these threats.
column16:
Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to designate an official from the intelligence community to serve as the lead coordinator for countering and neutralizing the proliferation of Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems.

Requires this Coordinator to develop a comprehensive plan of action, driven by intelligence information, for countering and neutralizing the threats posed by the proliferation of Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems and submit a briefing of such plans to the Congress.

Requires the Director of National Intelligence to submit a final report on the activities and findings of the Coordinator to the appropriate committees of Congress.

Mandates the report to include an assessment of the threats posed by Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems and a detailed description of intelligence sharing efforts, as well as other joint efforts driven by intelligence information, with allies and partners of the United States, to assist in countering and neutralizing such threats. 

Mandates the report to include recommendations for any changes in United States policy designed to improve the capacity of the intelligence community to assist in countering such threats.

Encourages collaboration and the expansion of existing cooperative efforts among members of the Five Eyes Partnership and Israel for the purpose of countering Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems.
column17: Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Applications: Government: military and public safety

column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Instructs the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to promote the development and use of emerging technologies for research, communication, navigation, and data collection in marine science as part of the Administration's national ocean exploration program.
column16:
Instructs the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to promote the development and use of emerging technologies (e.g., sensors and autonomous vehicles) for research, communication, navigation, and data collection in marine science as part of the Administration's national ocean exploration program. 

Otherwise adjusts the precise parameters of the national ocean exploration program, including with regard to data collection and data sharing practices.

column2: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 11225 ("Establishment of unmanned system program and autonomous control and computer vision technology project")
column3: FY2023 NDAA, Section 11225 ("Establishment of unmanned system program and autonomous control and computer vision technology project")
column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Requires the Coast Guard to implement, and brief Congress on, a program for using unmanned vehicles to improve mission execution.
column16:
Requires the U.S. Coast Guard to establish a program for using unmanned vehicles -- designed to operate in the air, on the water, and/or below the water's surface --  to improve mission execution. 

Requires the Commandant of the Coast Guard to conduct a project that retrofits at least two small boats with the sensors, communication systems, computer vision systems, and autonomous control technology necessary to conduct unmanned search and rescue, surveillance, and interdiction missions. Requires the Commandant to collect and analyze operational data from this project to inform future requirements. 

Requires the Commandant to submit a project briefing including analysis of operational data and projected costs to the congressional transportation committees.

Requires the Commandant to submit to the congressional transportation committees a detailed description of the Coast Guard's strategy for integrating unmanned systems across mission areas, including an estimate of the resources needed to achieve such integration.

column2: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 224 ("Next Generation Air Dominance family of systems development program accountability matrices")
column3: FY2024 NDAA, Section 224 ("Next Generation Air Dominance family of systems development program accountability matrices")
column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15:
Submit matrices that detail engineering, manufacturing, and development for Next Generation Air Dominance and Collaborative Combat Aircraft programs to congressional defense committees as well as the Comptroller General. 

Provide updates on progress and cost estimates every 6 months.

Develops key performance parameters for the program and its objectives to make sure there is transparency and oversight within the system.
column16:
Submit goals for Next Generation Air Dominance and Collaborative Combat Aircraft programs to congressional defense committees and the Comptroller General concurrent with the President's budget submission. Include key milestones, testing events, and performance goals, subdivided into six-month increments. 

Provide information on technology readiness levels, design maturity, software maturity, integration maturity, manufacturing readiness levels, reliability, availability for flight operations, and maintainability.

Provide updates on progress and cost estimates for the program every 6 months. It details progress made toward the goals identified in the matrices and provides updated cost estimates for air vehicles, propulsion, mission systems, software, program management, system test and evaluation, support and training systems, and more.

Develop key performance parameters (cost KPPs) for cost thresholds and objectives for the programs. Specify threshold and objective values for categories such as unit recurring flyaway cost, average procurement unit cost, gross/weapon system unit cost, aircraft cost-per-tail-per-year, and aircraft cost-per-flight-hour. 

Ensure that each Secretary concerned works on these parameters for the respective programs and includes them in the related documents.

Ensure assessment of the sufficiency of matrices by the Comptroller General, who will review them and submit assessments to congressional defense committees, identifying any cost, schedule, or performance trends.
column17: Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Applications: Government: military and public safety

column2: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 1090 ("Conduct of weather reconnaissance in the United States")
column3: FY2024 NDAA, Section 1090 ("Conduct of weather reconnaissance in the United States")

column15: Instructs the 53rd Weather Reconnaissance Squadron of the Air Force Reserve Command to use autonomous platform observations to improve water management decision-making and flood forecasting, if the Squadron uses certain available resources.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Commerce to submit to the congressional science committees a report on the resources necessary for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to invest in emerging technologies that improve weather forecasting.

Permits the 53rd Weather Reconnaissance Squadron of the Air Force Reserve Command and the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to use aircraft, personnel, and equipment necessary to improve the accuracy and efficacy of weather monitoring and water management, including through advanced technological methods.

Instructs the Squadron to use autonomous platform observations to improve water management decision-making and flood forecasting, if it uses the resources named in the above paragraph.

Requires the Secretary of the Air Force to submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report on the resources used and required by the Air Force and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to improve weather monitoring and water management.

column2: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division E ("National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act")
column3: National AI Initiative Act
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Requires the President to establish a National Artificial Intelligence Initiative to support AI-related research, education, workforce development, planning, and international cooperation; creates new AI-related research and funding programs within several federal agencies.
column16:
Requires the President to establish a National Artificial Intelligence Initiative to support AI-related research, education, workforce development, planning, and international cooperation. 

Requires the creation of an office, interagency coordinating committee, external advisory committee, and a task force for a potential National AI Research Resource. Directs the interagency committee to create and periodically update a strategic plan for artificial intelligence.

Requires a National Academies study of the impact of AI on the workforce.

Directs the Director of the National Science Foundation to fund new AI research institutes as well as various activities related to AI research, education, engineering, and ethics.

Amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to give NIST various duties and powers related to AI and data.

Directs the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to establish a Center for Artificial Intelligence.

Directs the Secretary of Energy to carry out an AI research and development program on topics including AI for science and trustworthy AI.

column2: Measures for the Management of Generative Artificial Intelligence Services (Draft for Comment)
column3: Measures for the Management of Generative Artificial Intelligence Services (Draft for Comment)
column15: Requires AI-generated content in China to meet a series of criteria, including accuracy, intellectual property protection, and respect for individual privacy; also requires AI developers to perform security assessments on their generative AI systems and submit those assessments to regulators.
column16:
Requires AI-generated content in China to meet a series of criteria, including accuracy, non-discrimination with regard to an array of protected characteristics, intellectual property protection, exclusion of violent content or content that subverts state power, and respect for individual privacy.

Requires AI developers to conduct a security assessment on generative AI systems that evaluates the cybersecurity of the system and its ability to comply with regulations; the assessment must be submitted to regulators before the system can be released for public use. 

Requires AI developers to prevent their generative AI systems from being used for various purposes, including engaging in unfair economic competition, and requires generative AI systems to make themselves inaccessible to individuals who use the systems for such purposes. 

Describes the legal liability that developers hold for the content generated by their AI systems and the punishments, including fines, they may face for violating these rules.

column15: Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to develop a plan with other heads of the intelligence community regarding the development of a modern digital ecosystem for artificial intelligence; details the minimum requirements of the plan.
column16:
Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to develop a plan with other heads of the intelligence community for a modern digital ecosystem that enables the development and progress of artificial intelligence applications and present it to Congress within one year of the enactment of the Act.

Requires that the plan include policies to allow flexible access to classified facilities to select companies, establishes a system to allow for investments into the ecosystem that would address technical issues including but not limited to common interfaces, authentication, and software, and includes policies to prevent duplication of AI capabilities within the intelligence community.

Requires that the plan establish a governance structure to standardize implementation throughout the intelligence community and adheres to community and federal standards.

column2: AI in Government Act of 2020
column3: AI in Government Act of 2020
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Creates the AI Centre for Excellence( AI CoE) and establishes a Director to manage the affairs of the CoE. Stipulates the functions of the CoE program and establishes collaboration with other departments within the government. Mitigates biases stemming from the use of AI.
column16:
Defines Artificial Intelligence

Creates a program called ‘‘AI Center of Excellence’’, (CoE) which shall facilitate the adoption of AI technologies in the Federal Government and improve cohesion in the adoption of artificial intelligence.

Stipulates certain functions of this program which includes; 
a.  Collaborating with individual agencies, federal laboratories, nonprofit organizations, institutions and other entities to discuss recent developments in AI.

b. Assisting agencies in applying Federal policies on the management and use of data in the use of AI.

c. Consulting with agencies, including the Department of Defense, the Department of Commerce, the Department of Energy, the Department of Homeland Security, the Office of Management and Budget, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, and the National Science Foundation, on issues relating to AI.

Identifies the skills needed for future job positions within the CoE and establishes jobs within the CoE and their duration (2 and 5 years).

Instructs the Director of the CoE to submit a comprehensive plan to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs and the Committee on Oversight and Reform with a timeline to achieve paragraphs a,b,c,d within 120 days of the date of the enactment of the instrument.

Instructs the Director of the AI CoE to recommend approaches to remove barriers for use by agencies of AI technologies in order to promote their innovative application while protecting civil rights, and economic and national security; identify best practices for assessing and mitigating any discriminatory impact or bias on the basis of any classification protected under Federal nondiscrimination laws, or any unintended consequence of the use of AI.

column3: Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act, Title I ("Department of Energy Science for the Future")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Initiates several projects using artificial intelligence and emerging technologies, all directives emphasizing support for artificial intelligence and data science development, establishing technical standards, and creating testbeds for robust systems. Efforts on scholarships, fellowships, and ongoing research to nurture the next generation of artificial intelligence professionals and enhance biometric identification technologies.
column16:
Instructs the Secretary of the Advanced Computing Program to maintain foundational research programs in mathematical and computational sciences, including new and emerging computing needs within the mission of the Department like novel approaches to modelling and simulation, artificial intelligence, and machine learning.

Instructs the Secretary to issue and ensure adherence to guidance for the Department, the National Laboratories, and users. This guidance pertains to how high-performance computing systems, including machine learning algorithms for data analysis and artificial intelligence, should be employed. 

Instructed the Director to prioritize research and development of sustainable chemistry, autonomous chemistry, and materials synthesis, leveraging  advances in artificial intelligence.

Instructs the Director to carry out research and testing to improve the effectiveness of artificial intelligence-enabled cybersecurity. 

Instructs the Director to support the development of artificial intelligence and data science. 

Instructs the Director to support the development of technical standards and guidelines- creating a framework for managing risks associated with artificial intelligence systems. 

Instructs the Director to establish testbeds to support the development of robust and trustworthy artificial intelligence and machine learning systems. These testbeds will examine the vulnerabilities and conditions that may lead to failure, malfunction, or attacks on such systems.

Instructs the Director to establish a report on the need, feasibility, and plans to implement a program to recruit and train the next generation of artificial intelligence professionals. This program is meant to meet the needs of Federal, State, local, and Tribal governments.

Provides scholarships through qualified institutions of higher education to students enrolled in programs related to artificial intelligence. Provides fellowships to masters and doctoral students pursuing degrees or research in artificial intelligence and related fields.

Necessitates research and testing to improve the accuracy, efficacy, and bias of biometric identification technologies.

column3: Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act, Title II ("National Institute of Standards and Technology for the Future"), Subtitle B ("Measurement Research")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Enhances Artificial Intelligence Systems through research and testing, optimizing data sets, and evaluating network architectures. Necessitates measurement research for advanced communications. Supports AI and data science development. Requires a risk management tech framework and publishing cybersecurity tools for trustworthy AI systems. Mandates cover creating testbeds for robust system development and conducting regular testing to improve biometric identification technologies.
column16:
Instructs the Director to carry out research and testing to improve the effectiveness of Artificial Intelligence-enabled cybersecurity, Artificial Intelligence defense systems and evaluating the performance of varying network architectures at strengthening network security.

Requires the Director to carry out a program of measurement research for advanced communications technologies which among others would include Artificial Intelligence systems to enable internet of things networks, immersive technology, and other advanced communications technologies

Instructs the Director to support the development of technical standards and guidelines that promote safe and trustworthy Artificial Intelligence systems, such as enhancing the accuracy, privacy, explanability, reliability, robustness, safety, security, and mitigation of harmful bias in Artificial Intelligence systems

Instructs the Director to create a framework for managing risks associated with Artificial Intelligence systems.

Instructs the Director to develop and publish cybersecurity tools, encryption methods, and best practices for Artificial Intelligence and data science. 

Requires the Director to establish testbeds to support the development of robust and trustworthy Artificial Intelligence and machine learning systems, including testbeds that examine the vulnerabilities and conditions that may lead to failure in, malfunction of, or attacks on such systems.

Requires the Director to conduct regular testing to improve and benchmark the accuracy, efficacy, and bias of biometric identification technologies,

column2: Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act, Title III ("National Science Foundation for the Future")
column3: Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act, Title III ("National Science Foundation for the Future")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Provides scholarships and fellowships for AI-related studies to recruit and train the next generation of AI professionals in US government. Grants competitive grants and fellowships for organizations advancing risk assessment through AI. Adds AI and machine learning to the list of research areas that the Director of the National Science Foundation can award grants to. Makes awards available for supporting basic research to advance critical minerals mining strategies that involve AI. Requires the development and testing of models to inform implementation of government-wide data infrastructure for statistical activities. Requires a study on U.S. higher education's AI research capacity and an annual update to key technology focus areas.
column16:
Instructs the Director of the National Science Foundation (Director) to develop a report on the need and feasibility as well as construct plans to implement a program to recruit and train the next generation of AI professionals in US government. Mandates that the report include statistical data on the federal AI workforce, assessments of current and future demand for AI expertise across the federal government and the ability of higher education institutions to prepare students to meet this demand, and an evaluation of the need for and feasibility of establishing a scholarship-for-service program for AI professionals in US government, as well as the possibility of leveraging existing programs such as the Federal Cyber Scholarship-for-Service Program. 

Authorizes the Director and other appropriate agency heads to establish a Federal AI scholarship-for-service program to recruit and train AI professionals to achieve the missions of US government. Requires the Director, in coordination with other agency heads, to establish criteria such as excellence in AI education and the ability to attract diverse students to designate qualified institutions of higher education that shall be eligible to participate in the program. Requires the program to provide scholarships through qualified higher education institutions to students pursuing fields of study related to AI, provide scholarship recipients with temporary appointments related to work on AI in the federal government, prioritize placement of scholarship recipients in executive agencies, identify opportunities to promote multidisciplinary programs of study, support capacity building for educational institutions to enable them to train the next-generation AI workforce, create courses in technology ethics for scholarship recipients, and award fellowships to masters and doctoral students who are pursuing degrees or research in AI and related fields. Instructs scholarship amounts to cover a student’s tuition and fees for not more than 3 years with an additional stipend, and obligates scholarship recipients to work for a period of time equivalent to the length of the scholarship in the AI mission of the US government entity or affiliated entity.

Instructs the Director to establish competitive awards to institutions to advance knowledge of risk assessment including the utilization of AI in our ability to understand and predict extreme events and natural hazards, create engineered system solutions and develop instrumentation for innovation in resilient infrastructure, and advance research on multidisciplinary wildfire science and behaviors related to increasing resilience.

Amends Section 506(a) of the America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010 by adding AI and machine learning to the list of research areas that fall under information technologies for manufacturing that the Director can award grants to.

Instructs the Director to make competitive awards to institutions to support basic research to advance critical minerals mining strategies to make better use of domestic resources and eliminate national reliance on minerals subject to supply chain disruptions, including the application of AI for geological exploration of critical minerals and the application of machine learning for detection and sorting of critical minerals.

Requires the Director to conduct or support the development of a study on AI research capacity at US institutions of higher education. Requires the study to, at minimum, address which universities are putting out significant peer-reviewed AI research based on quantity and number of citations, which factors of these universities such as computing power enable their research, promising practices at these universities for advancing diversity, equity, and inclusion in AI research programs, geographic diversity of universities that have AI research-enabling factors, and how universities that are not currently top producers of AI research could improve, including potential pilot programs that the federal government could develop or support to help universities produce AI research.

Instructs the Director, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget and the interagency committee established under the National AI Initiative Act of 2020, to develop and test models to inform the implementation of a government-wide data linkage and access infrastructure for statistical activities.

Requires the Director to identify, and annually review and update a list of not more than 10 key technology focus areas, which includes AI, machine learning, autonomy, and related advances.

column15: Establishes the National AI Research Resource to provide computational resources, data, educational tools, and testbeds for AI researchers.

Authorizes the National Science Foundation, in coordination with the NAIRR steering committee, to establish the National AI Research Resource.

Creates a NAIRR Program Management Office to manage the NAIRR's day-to-day operations.

Directs the Program Management Office to solicit bids for an Operating Entity for the NAIRR and to oversee that Entity.

Authorizes the NAIRR to charge fees for users at various tiers, including free and subsidized tiers.

Provides for security requirements to prevent unauthorized access and protect research security.

Directs the Secretary of Transportation to establish an emerging technology research pilot program that will:

Authorizes research and development activities related to using advanced and additive manufacturing technologies to support the integrity and cost-effectiveness of surface transportation infrastructure

Authorized to be appropriated $5,000,000 to carry this out for fiscal years 2022 to 2026

Requires eligible projects to demonstrate focus in directed areas, including the deployment of automated transportation, autonomous vehicles, and intelligent, sensor-based infrastructure.

column16:
Directs the Secretary of Defense to submit an annual report to the congressional defense committees on recommendations made by the National Security Commission on AI about the Department of Defense. The report shall cover the Secretary of Defense's intent to implement recommendations, plans for implementing recommendations including timelines and resources, and justifications for not implementing recommendations, including recommendations that are already being implemented.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to brief the congressional defense committees at least annually on progress in analyzing and implementing recommendations and any activities carried out in pursuit of the recommendations, including funding for each activity.

column2: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022, Section 216 ("Improvements relating to steering committee on emerging technology and national security threats")
column3: FY2022 NDAA, Section 216 ("Improvements relating to steering committee on emerging technology and national security threats")
column7: NDAA provisions;Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Amends Section 236 of the FY 2021 National Defense Authorization Act by changing the structure of a steering committee on emerging technology and national security and featuring the intelligence community more prominently in the steering committee's responsibilities.
column16:
Amends Section 236 of the FY 2021 National Defense Authorization Act by adding the Director of National Intelligence as an official that can, with the Secretary of Defense, establish a steering committee on emerging technology and national security and receive recommendations from the committee. Amends members of the steering committee to consist of the Principal Deputy Director of National Intelligence, the Deputy Sector of Defense, the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staffs, and other appropriate officials. Adds that the Steering Committee shall be chaired by the Deputy Secretary of Defense, the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the Principal Deputy Director of National Intelligence jointly.

Amends the responsibilities of the steering committee by clarifying that the committee's strategy is to maintain the technological superiority of both the US military and intelligence community according to not only the National Defense Strategy, but also the National Intelligence Strategy and the National Security Strategy. Adds that the steering committee is responsible for making recommendations on any changes to the guidance for developing the National Intelligence Program budget and determining whether sufficient resources are available for the intelligence community, in addition to the Department of Defense, to defeat threats to the US.

Adds that the list of technologies classified as emerging technologies is to be determined jointly by the Secretary of Defense and the Director of National Intelligence. Adds the definition of intelligence community from the National Security Act of 1947.

Sets eligibility requirements for enrollment in, and graduation from, the college.

Instructs the chief digital recruiting officer to identify Department of Defense skill gaps relating to artificial intelligence, distributed ledger technologies, cybersecurity, and other digital technology fields. 

Instructs the chief digital recruiting officer to lead the Department's efforts to close those skill gaps. 

Requires the chief digital recruiting officer to provide the congressional defense committees with an annual briefing on the Department's efforts to close those skill gaps.

Requires the Secretary of the Navy to submit to the congressional defense committees a 15-year acquisition, modernization, and sustainment plan for the carrier air wings of the Navy.

Requires the plan to include an analysis of how advanced technologies such as Next Generation Jammer can be utilized to maximize operational use of existing platforms, particularly the EA-18G aircraft and the E-2D aircraft.

column16:
Requires the Secretary of Defense to submit to the congressional defense committees a report on the Department of Defense's efforts to ensure that appropriate military systems can operate autonomously in GPS-denied environments.

Directs the report described above to include a list of systems which can be upgraded with autonomy software; the timelines for doing so; the funding required for doing so; plans to leverage artificial intelligence for such systems; plans for ensuring the safety and security of such systems through testing, evaluation, verification, and validation; and a list of Department policies that would require modification to facilitate this project.

column2: A bill to require the Secretary of Defense to carry out a pilot program on using artificial intelligence-enabled software to optimize the workflow and operations of depots, shipyards, and other manufacturing facilities run by the Department of Defense, and for other purposes.
column3: A bill to require the Secretary of Defense to carry out a pilot program on using artificial intelligence-enabled software to optimize the workflow and operations of depots, shipyards, and other manufacturing facilities run by the Department of Defense, and for other purposes.
column15: Mandates the Secretary of Defense to initiate a $35,000,000 AI pilot program for workflow optimization in defense facilities. Requires contract management assessment and use of best practices. Obligates consultation with key officials and a congressional report within one year.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Defense to initiate a pilot program within 60 days to evaluate artificial intelligence-enabled software for optimizing workflow and operations in Department of Defense facilities, including depots and shipyards.

Requires the assessment of AI software for contract management, particularly by the Defense Contract Management Agency.

Directs the use of best-in-class software platforms and consideration of industry best practices, alongside human-centered design methodologies.

Obligates a minimum expenditure of $35,000,000 for the pilot program.

Requires consultation with the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and Sustainment and the Secretaries of the Army, Navy, and Air Force.

Mandates a report to Congress within one year detailing software evaluations, workflow modifications, and quantitative impacts observed during the pilot.

column2: An act to add Chapter 25 (commencing with Section 22756) to Division 8 of the Business and Professions Code, relating to artificial intelligence.
column3: AB-331 Automated decision tools
column15: Governs the use of artificial intelligence for making consequential decisions that affect others (on education, healthcare, etc.), including by banning tools that exhibit algorithmic discrimination and requiring impact assessments, disclosures, monitoring, and human alternatives.
column16:
Defines an automated decision tool as any tool that uses artificial intelligence to make consequential decisions relating to employment, education, housing, utilities, healthcare and family planning, financial services, criminal justice, legal services, voting, or government benefits.

Bans the use of automated decision tools in ways that result in algorithmic discrimination on the basis of classes protected by state law. 

Requires any entity that develops or deploys an automated decision tool to perform an impact assessment on the tool, covering its purpose, outputs, use cases, inputted data, and potential discriminatory impacts, and the monitoring, safeguard measures, and testing conducted to mitigate adverse consequences. The impact assessment must be updated annually and after any significant update to the tool, and be provided to the state's Civil Rights Department. 

Requires any entity that deploys an automated decision tool to provide individuals affected by the tool's decisions with a notice that the tool was used and information on the tool's purpose. 

Grants all individuals subject to an automated decision tool's decisions the right to instead have those decisions be made by a human, if technically feasible. 

Requires automated decision tool developers to provide the tool's deployers with documentation of the tool's limitations, training data, and testing. 

Requires the developer or deployer of an automated decision tool to implement a program that governs the foreseeable risks of the tool's use, including designating an employee to monitor the tool and report concerns. 

Permits individuals and public attorneys to bring civil action against entities that violate this law, and makes violation of the law punishable by fines.

Exempts entities with fewer than 25 employees using automated decision tools that affect less than 1,000 people per year from some of this law's provisions.

column2: Block Nuclear Launch by Autonomous Artificial Intelligence Act of 2023
column3: Block Nuclear Launch by Autonomous Artificial Intelligence Act
column15: Bans the use of federal funds to operate autonomous weapons systems which launch nuclear weapons or select targets for nuclear weapons without meaningful human control.
column16:
Prohibits the use of federal funds to operate autonomous weapons systems which launch nuclear weapons, or select or engage targets for nuclear weapons, without meaningful human control.

Defines 'meaningful human control' as the ability for humans to control the selection and engagement of targets, as well as the time, location and manner of the use of nuclear weapons.

column2: No CCP Consultants Act
column3: No CCP Consultants Act
column15: Prohibits the Department of State from working with contractors who have previously consulted for or fail to disclose conflicts of interest relating to foreign entities that pose national security or foreign policy concerns, including any Chinese state-owned entity or entity under the ownership and control of the PRC or CCP that is engaged in national security industries, such as producing AI-related products and services.
column16:
Prohibits the Department of State from entering, renewing, or extending a contract to contractors that, in the past year, have consulted for foreign entities that pose national security or foreign policy concerns, including any entity under China’s control engaged in national security industries, such as producing AI-related products and services. 

Requires companies seeking to provide consulting services for the Department of State to disclose any conflict of interest with foreign entities above, or they may face a debarment of up to five years.

Requires the Secretary of the Department of State to issue procurement policies for the Department to implement the above prohibition, clarify disclosure requirements and penalties when soliciting contracts, and share best practices for how companies can avoid accidentally contracting with foreign entities that pose national security or foreign policy concerns.

column2: Online Privacy Act of 2023, Sec. 106 ("Right to individual autonomy")
column3: Online Privacy Act, Sec. 106 ("Individual autonomy")
column15: Prohibits collecting, processing, maintaining, or disclosing personal information for behavioral personalization without consent. Requires annual consent renewals. Mandates non-personalized versions if consent is denied. Allows service denial if non-personalization is infeasible. Exempts small businesses.
column16:
Prohibits covered entities from collecting, processing, maintaining, or disclosing personal information for behavioral personalization without affirmative express consent.

Requires covered entities to obtain express affirmative consent before providing behaviorally personalized products or services, and annually thereafter.

Mandates providing non-personalized versions of products or services if consent is denied, or core aspects if full functionality without personalization is infeasible.

Allows denial of products or services if no core aspect can function without personalization and consent is not given.

Permits processing personal information for usability improvements using aggregated data, provided the output is uniform and independent of individual characteristics.

Excludes optimizations aimed primarily at increasing user engagement time from the definition of "usability."

Exempts small businesses from these requirements.

column2: Deceptive Experiences To Online Users Reduction Act
column3: DETOUR Act
column15: Prohibits online operators from manipulating user interfaces to impair autonomy. Requires express consent for research and bans manipulation targeting minors. Mandates disclosure of research purposes every 90 days. Obligates independent review boards. Directs NIST to develop resources. Empowers FTC enforcement. Provides safe harbor for compliance.
column16:
Prohibits large online operators from manipulating user interfaces to obscure, subvert, or impair user autonomy, decision making, or consent.

Requires affirmative express consent from users for covered research and prohibits manipulation aimed at children or teens to encourage compulsive usage.

Mandates large online operators to disclose the purpose of covered research to users every 90 days and ensure transparency.

Obligates large online operators to establish independent review boards to oversee user interface design and research, ensuring compliance and preventing exploitative practices.

Directs the National Institute of Standards and Technology to develop resources for user interface design promoting user autonomy, choice, and decision making.

Empowers the Federal Trade Commission to enforce compliance, establish regulations for independent review boards, and define acceptable conduct for large online operators.

Provides safe harbor for operators acting in good faith per established guidelines.

column2: Stop Fentanyl at the Border Act
column3: Stop Fentanyl at the Border Act
column15:
Appropriates $1,090,000,000 to U.S. Customs and Border Protection for technology improvements to enhance fentanyl interdiction.

Appropriates $223,000,000 to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to expand fentanyl interdiction and disrupt transnational criminal networks.

Mandates submission of reports by March 31, 2028, on impacts of Border Patrol Processing Coordinator positions and equipment needs.

Creates penalties for damaging or evading border controls, with fines and imprisonment up to 5 years for violations aimed at financial gain or furthering criminal organizations.
column16:
Appropriates $1,090,000,000 to U.S. Customs and Border Protection for technology improvements, including non-intrusive inspection scanning systems and anomaly detection algorithms, to enhance fentanyl interdiction at land borders.

Appropriates $223,000,000 to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to expand efforts to interdict fentanyl and disrupt transnational criminal networks, including funds for additional special agents and joint surge operations.

Mandates submission of reports by March 31, 2028, detailing impacts of Border Patrol Processing Coordinator positions, equipment needs for outbound inspections, and summaries of non-intrusive inspection technology at land ports of entry.

Creates penalties for knowingly damaging or evading border controls, with fines and imprisonment up to 5 years for violations aimed at securing financial gain or furthering criminal organizations.

column2: Water Quality and Environmental Innovation Act
column3: Water Quality and Environmental Innovation Act
column15: Authorizes the EPA Administrator to award grants and contracts for emerging technologies addressing water quality. Mandates the use of AI, quantum information science, and robotics for water quality projects.
column16:
Authorizes the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Administrator to award grants and contracts for projects using emerging technologies to address water quality threats.

Establishes the Water Quality and Environmental Innovation Fund, funding it through fiscal years 2024-2028 using fees from the EPA's Motor Vehicle and Engine Compliance Program.

Mandates the use of technologies, including artificial intelligence, quantum information science, and robotics, among others, for water quality projects.

Requires that project results, including data and statistics, be publicly accessible.

Directs the EPA Administrator to report annually to Congress on the benefits, recipients, goals, and effectiveness of funded projects, starting one year after the Act's enactment.

column2: Ensuring Safe and Ethical AI Development Through SAFE AI Research Grants
column3: SAFE AI Research Grants
column15: Requires the National Academy of Sciences to establish a grant program for the development of safe AI models and AI research; directs and outlines the submission of a proposal for the program in accordance with guiding principles.
column16:
Requires the National Academy of Sciences to establish a grant program for the development of safe AI models and AI research.

Mandates the development of guiding principles and ethical considerations for the grant program.

Directs the Director of the National Academy of Sciences to submit a detailed proposal of the grant program to relevant Congressional committees within one year, including a budget, proposed appropriation request, and an evaluation of existing AI models and methodologies.

column2: Safe and Responsible AI in Australia Consultation, Interim Response
column3: Safe and Responsible AI in Australia Consultation, Interim Response
column15: Proposes strengthening laws for AI risks in high-risk settings. Considers mandatory safety guardrails. Plans industry collaboration on voluntary standards. Emphasizes risk-based regulation. Commits to international collaboration. Supports AI investments. Establishes expert advisory group for AI guardrails.
column16:
Proposes strengthening existing laws and considering new legislation to address AI-related risks, particularly in high-risk settings.

Considers mandatory safety guardrails for AI systems in high-risk contexts, focusing on testing, transparency, and accountability.

Plans to work with industry to develop a voluntary AI Safety Standard and explore options for voluntary labelling and watermarking of AI-generated materials.

Emphasizes a risk-based regulatory framework to ensure proportionality and avoid unnecessary burdens on low-risk AI applications.

Commits to collaborating with international partners, aligning with global standards, and contributing to initiatives like the Bletchley Declaration on AI safety.

Supports investments in AI capability development and aims to maximize AI benefits, including through initiatives funded by the 2023–24 Budget.

Establishes an interim expert advisory group to explore AI guardrail options and harmonizes efforts with state and territory governments.

column2: National Artificial Intelligence Research and Development Strategic Plan 2023 Update
column3: National Artificial Intelligence Research and Development Strategic Plan 2023 Update
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Requires federal coordination in AI R&D for leadership. Reaffirms eight strategies; adds international collaboration. Prioritizes responsible AI research. Advances safety standards. Develops public datasets. Establishes evaluation benchmarks. Addresses workforce training. Expands partnerships. Emphasizes AI governance.
column16:
Requires the federal government to coordinate and focus R&D investments in AI to ensure U.S. leadership in trustworthy AI systems. 

Reaffirms eight strategies and adds a ninth to emphasize international collaboration in AI research.

Prioritizes investments in fundamental and responsible AI research, human-AI collaboration, and understanding ethical, legal, and societal implications.

Advances safety and security standards for AI systems, ensuring they are reliable and secure from vulnerabilities.

Develops shared public datasets and environments for AI training and testing to democratize access to AI resources.

Establishes benchmarks and standards for evaluating AI systems, including fairness, privacy, and bias considerations.

Addresses workforce needs by training and retraining a diverse AI-ready workforce.

Expands public-private partnerships to accelerate AI advances and facilitate global collaborations for responsible AI development.

Emphasizes the importance of AI governance and the development of international guidelines and standards for AI systems.

column2: Farm Tech Act
column3: Farm Tech Act
column15: Mandates the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a program to certify AI software for agricultural use based on the NIST's Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a program to certify AI software for the production of agricultural products. 

Bases the certification program on the  National Institute of Standards and Technology's Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework.

Permits certification only if the software performs accurately and meets or exceeds relevant Federal and State standards for licensure, certification, and permitting.

Details specific licensure and certification requirements for various tasks, including commercial driving, manure application, pesticide application and handling hazardous materials.
column17: Risk factors: Reliability;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Agriculture and resource extraction

column2: AI Training Expansion Act of 2023
column3: AI Training Expansion Act of 2023
column15: Amends the AI Training for the Acquisition Workforce Act to expand executive branch training. Defines key positions to clarify scope. Requires coverage of AI capabilities, risks, and best practices. Mandates inclusion of AI fundamentals and deployment considerations. Allows integration of existing programs. Establishes feedback for continuous improvement.
column16:
Amends the Artificial Intelligence Training for the Acquisition Workforce Act to expand AI training within the executive branch.

Defines "acquisition position," "data or technology position," "management official," and "supervisor" to clarify the scope of the training program.

Requires the AI training program to cover capabilities, risks, best practices, and mitigation strategies associated with AI.

Mandates inclusion of topics such as AI fundamentals, technological features, data roles, and considerations for developing, deploying, and managing AI systems within executive agencies.

Allows incorporation of existing training programs into the AI training program to enhance relevance and efficiency.

Establishes a feedback mechanism for continuous improvement of the AI training program.

column2: Jobs of the Future Act of 2023
column3: Jobs of the Future Act of 2023
column15:
Requires the Secretary of Labor and the NSF Director to submit interim and final reports on AI's workforce impact. 

Mandates identification of necessary data, affected industries, and vulnerable demographics. 

Requires analysis of skills and education needed to work with AI.

Demands recommendations to mitigate displacement and promote equitable AI education. 

Requires collaboration with educational institutions, industry stakeholders, and federal agencies.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Labor and the Director of the National Science Foundation to submit interim and final reports on AI's impact on the U.S. workforce.

Mandates these reports to identify data necessary for analyzing AI's workforce impact, industries most affected by AI, and demographics vulnerable to job displacement.

Requires analysis of skills, expertise, and education needed to work alongside AI and methods to deliver these to the workforce.

Demands recommendations to mitigate workforce displacement, promote knowledge sharing, and ensure underserved demographics have access to necessary AI-related education.

Requires collaboration with educational institutions, industry stakeholders, and federal agencies in preparing the reports.

column2: No ICBMs or Drones for Iran Act of 2023
column3: No ICBMs or Drones for Iran Act of 2023
column15: Expands and incorporates sanctions related to Iranian unmanned aerial systems (UAS). Mandates a strategy against, and reports on support for, Iran’s UAS program.
column16:
Expands sanctions under the Comprehensive Iran Sanctions, Accountability, and Divestment Act of 2010 to include unmanned aerial systems (UAS).

Incorporates UAS under arms embargos of the Countering America’s Adversaries Through Sanctions Act and Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992.

Requires the President to submit a strategy to counter Iran's UAS program including export controls of US materials, identification of actors supporting Iran's UAS program, assessment of compliance with such restrictions, and coordination with US allies in furtherance of these actions

Mandates a report on support for Iran’s UAS program from domestic industries, individuals, or entities in Iran and related technology transfers to foreign actors, to be updated as necessary.

column2: Advisory for AI-Generated Content Act
column3: Advisory for AI-Generated Content Act
column15: Requires all entities that generate AI materials for public consumption to label them with watermarks.
column16:
Requires all AI-generated materials to be labeled with a watermark. 

Authorizes the federal government to establish requirements and standards for watermarks.

Enables the federal government to levy penalties against entities that violate the above stipulation.

Defines key terms including AI-generating entity, AI-generated material, and covered AI-generated material, specifying criteria for materials that must be watermarked.
