column2: ASSESS AI Act
column3: ASSESS AI Act
column15: Establishes a task force to assess AI's privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties implications; outlines duties and responsibilities of task force.
column16:
Establishes a task force to assess privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties implications of artificial intelligence. 

Charges the task force to evaluate existing policy, regulatory, and legal gaps for AI applications and make legislative and regulatory recommendations.

Directs the task force to address the application of federal antidiscrimination laws, disparate impact standards, AI validation, and auditing in federal use of AI.

Instructs the task force to consider institutional changes for ongoing AI governance and the potential creation of a new oversight organization.

Requires the task force to submit an interim report within one year and a final report within 18 months.
column17: Risk factors: Privacy;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Strategies: Convening;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Risk factors: Security;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Adversarial testing;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Government study or report

column2: CONSENT Act
column3: CONSENT Act
column15: Establishes a private right of action against individuals sending unsolicited explicit visual depictions. Defines “machine-manipulated media” as AI-modified. Permits recipients to sue for damages and attorney fees. Exempts third-party providers and certain senders. Allows legal guardians to sue for minors. Permits minors to use initials for privacy. Ensures civil remedies do not supersede criminal laws. Includes severability clause.
column16:
Establishes a private right of action against individuals who send unsolicited visual depictions of sexually explicit conduct.

Defines “machine-manipulated media” as media substantially modified using machine-learning techniques.

Permits recipients to bring civil actions for statutory damages up to $500, compensatory damages for emotional distress, attorney fees, and injunctive relief.

Exempts third-party providers, good faith medical, educational, or law enforcement senders, and lawful adult websites from liability.

Allows legal guardians to sue on behalf of minors, incompetent, or incapacitated individuals.

Permits plaintiffs who were minors at the time of the incident to use initials for privacy in court documents.

Ensures civil remedies do not modify or supersede criminal laws.

Includes a severability clause to maintain the act’s provisions if parts are deemed unconstitutional.

column2: An Act Establishing the Alabama Commission on Artificial Intelligence and Associated Technologies.
column3: Alabama AI Commission Act
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Establishes the Alabama Commission on AI to review and advise on AI in various sectors. Requires qualified membership including expertise in Artificial Intelligence and mandates the disclosure of a report of the findings available to the public.
column16:
Establishes the Alabama Commission on Artificial Intelligence to review and advise on AI growth and use in governance, healthcare, education, transportation, and future industries.

Requires the commission to consider the establishment of a permanent AI commission.

Comprises members appointed by the Governor, Lieutenant Governor, House Speaker, and Senate President Pro Tempore, including experts in AI, workforce development, technology, ethics, privacy, or computer science.

Requires the commission to submit a report by May 1, 2020, with findings and recommendations for administrative or policy actions related to AI, available on the website of the Office of the Governor.
column17: Strategies: New institution;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Applications: Transportation;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Education;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form

column2: To provide for citizen engagement on the development and adoption of Federal civilian agency use of artificial intelligence, and for other purposes.
column3: Citizen Engagement on Development of Federal Civilian Agency Use of AI Act
column15: Mandates listening sessions on AI use by Federal civilian agencies. Requires diverse group inclusion. Encourages independent sessions and reporting. Obligates report submission to Congress within 240 days and annually on public attitudes towards AI use.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security to conduct virtual and in-person listening sessions across the United States for discussing Federal civilian agency use of artificial intelligence.

Requires inclusion of diverse groups in these discussions, such as civil rights organizations, immigrant communities, and academia.

Encourages these groups to hold their own listening sessions and report back on AI development and adoption.

Obligates the Secretary of Homeland Security to submit a report to Congress within 240 days of enactment, and annually thereafter, detailing public attitudes and beliefs on Federal civilian agency use of AI.

column2: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2025, Title V, Section 505 ("Establishment of Artificial Intelligence Security Center")
column3: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2025, Title V, Section 505 ("Establishment of Artificial Intelligence Security Center")
column15: Establishes an AI Security Center within NSA's Cybersecurity Center. Requires AI security research support. Develops counter-AI guidance. Promotes secure AI adoption. Coordinates with NIST. Mandates access terms. Ensures federal access. Leverages resources. Establishes access mechanisms.
column16:
Establishes an Artificial Intelligence Security Center within the National Security Agency's Cybersecurity Collaboration Center.

Requires the provision of a research test bed for AI security research to private sector and academic researchers, including secure access to proprietary third-party models with vendor consent.

Develops guidance to prevent or mitigate counter-artificial intelligence techniques.

Promotes secure AI adoption practices for national security systems and the defense industrial base.

Coordinates with the Artificial Intelligence Safety Institute of the National Institute of Standards and Technology.

Mandates terms of usage for researcher access to the test bed, ensuring limited publication to protect classified or proprietary information.

Ensures test bed availability to federal agencies on a cost-recovery basis.

Leverages existing infrastructure and resources for AI security research.

Establishes mechanisms, including contractual incentives, for providing access to proprietary models for qualified researchers.

column2: American Medical Innovation and Investment Act of 2024 (Sec. 5)
column3: American Medical Innovation and Investment Act of 2024 (Sec. 5)
column15: Mandates guidance on Medicare payment for AI-equipped remote monitoring devices by 2026. Specifies devices, like glucose monitors, must use AI components for continuous adjustment. Requires information transmission to healthcare providers for management and treatment.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue guidance on Medicare payment requirements for remote monitoring devices with AI components by January 1, 2026. 

Specifies that the devices, including continuous glucose monitors, must use AI components like continuous adjustment. 

Requires that these devices transmit information to healthcare providers for management and treatment purposes.

column2: Content Origin Protection and Integrity from Edited and Deepfaked Media Act of 2024
column3: Content Origin Protection and Integrity from Edited and Deepfaked Media Act of 2024
column15: Mandates development of standards for content provenance through public-private partnership. Requires tools to include machine-readable provenance information. Prohibits tampering and non-consensual AI training. Empowers FTC for enforcement. Permits civil actions. Ensures copyright rights remain unchanged.
column16:
Mandates the development of standards for content provenance and detection of synthetic and synthetically-modified content through a public-private partnership.

Requires tools used commercially to create synthetic or synthetically-modified content to provide the option of including machine-readable content provenance information, with security measures to prevent tampering.

Prohibits knowingly removing or altering content provenance information in furtherance of unfair or deceptive acts.

Prohibits the non-consensual use of content with attached provenance information for training AI systems, requiring express consent and adherence to copyright terms.

Empowers the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and state attorneys general to enforce the Act, treating violations as unfair or deceptive acts.

Permits private parties to bring civil actions for violations involving content provenance information.

Ensures the Act does not alter existing copyright rights and includes provisions for severability, maintaining the Act’s effectiveness even if parts are invalidated.

column2: An Act regulating the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in providing mental health services.
column3: Massachusetts AI in Mental Health Act
column15: Requires licensed mental health professionals seeking to offer AI-assisted mental health services to obtain approval from a licensing board, inform patients about AI use, and obtain patient consent; requires AI systems delivering mental health services to prioritize patient safety and well-being. Imposes disciplinary action by a licensing board for violations.
column16:
Instructs licensed mental health professionals who wish to provide mental health services through AI to seek approval from a licensing board, inform patients of the use of AI in their treatment, provide non-AI alternatives, and obtain patient consent.

Requires any AI system used to provide mental health services to prioritize the safety and well-being of patients and be subject to continuous monitoring by a licensed mental health professional. 

Establishes disciplinary action by the relevant professional licensing board for mental health professionals who violate the provisions above.
column17: Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Post-market monitoring;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Licensing, registration, and certification;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health

column2: AI Incident Reporting and Security Enhancement Act
column3: AI Incident Reporting and Security Enhancement Act
column15: Directs NIST to update the National Vulnerability Database for AI security, establish standards, and collaborate on guidelines. Mandates a multi-stakeholder process for AI incident reporting. Obligates a report to Congress. Clarifies no additional enforcement authority for NIST.
column16:
Directs the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to update the National Vulnerability Database to include AI security vulnerabilities.

Requires NIST to establish common definitions and characteristics for AI security vulnerabilities and develop standards for managing these vulnerabilities.

Mandates a multi-stakeholder process to assess voluntary reporting and tracking of substantial AI security and safety incidents.

Instructs NIST to collaborate with industry, academia, and other stakeholders to establish guidelines, best practices, and standardized mechanisms for reporting AI incidents.

Obligates NIST to submit a report to Congress within three years, detailing the findings and recommendations from the multi-stakeholder process on AI incident reporting and tracking.

Clarifies that the Act does not grant NIST any additional enforcement authority beyond existing powers.

column2: SAFE Bet Act
column3: SAFE Bet Act
column15: Establishes the "SAFE Bet Act," setting federal standards for sports wagering. Prohibits AI use for tracking, targeting, or creating products. Mandates compliance, data security, suspicious transaction reporting, and a national self-exclusion list. Allows stricter state/tribal regulations.
column16:
Establishes the "SAFE Bet Act," setting minimum federal standards for sports wagering, which includes restrictions on AI use by sports wagering operators. 

Prohibits operators from using AI to track individual wagers, target specific individuals with promotions, or create gambling products like microbets. 

Mandates state sports wagering programs to ensure compliance with standards, including consumer protections and advertising restrictions, and requires operators to maintain data security and recordkeeping. 

Enforces reporting of suspicious transactions and mandates cooperation with investigations into sports wagering activities. 

Creates a national self-exclusion list to prevent individuals from placing sports wagers across states, and establishes public health initiatives to monitor gambling addiction. 

Permits states and tribes to enact stricter sports wagering regulations and does not preempt their authority to tax sports wagering.

column2: An Act relating to the creation of the artificial intelligence advisory council
column3: Texas AI advisory council
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Establishes an artificial intelligence advisory council to study and monitor AI systems used by Texas state agencies, and requires those agencies to submit inventory reports describing the AI systems they use.
column16:
Establishes an artificial intelligence advisory council -- to be disbanded at the start of 2025 -- to study and monitor AI systems developed, employed, or procured by Texas state agencies.

Instructs the advisory council to assess the need for an AI code of ethics for the state government, review automated decision systems inventory reports submitted by state agencies, and recommend administrative actions as needed. 

Requires the advisory council to submit a report on its activities and findings to the legislature. 

Requires each state agency to submit to the legislature and advisory council an inventory report of all automated decision systems that are being developed,
employed, or procured by the agency.

Requires the inventory reports described above to assess each AI system's purpose, capabilities, data management practices, data output, and fiscal impact, as well as any information available on bias testing conducted on the system and the forms of data inputted into the system.
column17: Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Privacy;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Financial loss;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Differential treatment based on a protected characteristic;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Government: benefits and welfare;Applications: Government: judicial and law enforcement

column2: OpenAI Charter
column3: OpenAI Charter
column15: Commits to ensuring AGI benefits humanity, avoids harm, and minimizes conflict of interest. Promotes AGI safety research, assists similar projects, and stays at AI's forefront. Cooperates with institutions and shares research, acknowledging potential publishing constraints.
column16:
Commits to using influence over AGI deployment to ensure it benefits all of humanity and avoids harm or power concentration.

Requires prioritization of humanity's interests, minimizing conflicts of interest among employees and stakeholders.

Ensures long-term safety by committing to AGI safety research and advocating its adoption across the AI community.

Pledges to assist other safety-conscious AGI projects nearing completion, rather than compete, under specific conditions.

Mandates staying at the forefront of AI capabilities to effectively address AGI's societal impact.

Strives for technical leadership in areas aligned with mission and expertise, acknowledging AI's societal impact before AGI.

Promotes active cooperation with research and policy institutions to tackle AGI's global challenges.

Commits to providing public goods and sharing safety, policy, and standards research, while acknowledging future constraints on traditional AI research publishing due to safety and security concerns.

column2: Fix Our Forests Act, Section 303 ("Public-private wildfire technology deployment and demonstration partnership")
column3: Fix Our Forests Act, Section 303 ("Public-private wildfire technology deployment and demonstration partnership")
column15: Establishes a wildfire technology pilot program, integrates it into a national group, and requires coordination for real-time testing. Prioritizes AI and emerging technologies, mandates annual reports, public outreach, and specifies a seven-year termination.
column16:
Establishes a deployment and demonstration pilot program for innovative wildfire technologies, including AI, within one year.

Incorporates the program into the National Wildfire Coordinating Group and advances key technology areas like remote sensing and interoperable data.

Requires coordination between selected private entities and federal agencies for real-time technology testing during wildfire mitigation.

Prioritizes entities involved in the Fire Weather Testbed or developing emerging technologies like AI and quantum sensing.

Mandates public outreach to invite applications from entities to demonstrate technologies.

Obligates annual reporting to Congress on program participants, technologies demonstrated, costs, outreach, and recommendations for technology adoption.

Specifies the program's authority will terminate seven years after enactment.

column2: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2025, Title V, Section 504 ("National security procedures to address certain risks and threats relating to artificial intelligence")
column3: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2025, Title V, Section 504 ("National security procedures to address certain risks and threats relating to artificial intelligence")
column15: Mandates the President to establish AI risk notification procedures within 180 days. Requires threat briefings for AI vendors. Obligates a congressional briefing on procedures. Utilizes existing laws for research and risk management frameworks.
column16:
Mandates the President to develop procedures within 180 days to enable vendors, users, and researchers to notify the U.S. Government of AI-related security and biosecurity risks, including malicious software development, system compromise, and foreign malign influence.

Requires federal elements to provide threat briefings to AI vendors about foreign exploitation and threats.

Obligates the President to brief Congress on the procedures, specifying responsible federal agencies and outlining industry outreach and public education plans.

Utilizes existing laws and federal guidelines for research, stakeholder engagement, and risk management frameworks related to AI systems.

column2: Health Equity and Accountability Act of 2024, Sec 1013 ("Task Force on Preventing Bias in AI and Algorithms")
column3: Health Equity and Accountability Act of 2024, Sec 1013 ("Task Force on Preventing Bias in AI and Algorithms")
column15: Establishes a Task Force to prevent AI bias in healthcare. Requires examination of risks and a report to Congress within a year. Mandates public report publication and a 90-day comment period. Allows flexible staffing by the Chairperson.
column16:
Establishes the Task Force on Preventing AI and Algorithmic Bias in Health Care within 30 days to guide the development of AI technologies that do not exacerbate health disparities.

Composes the Task Force of various health and public officials, including experts on health equity and minority health.

Mandates the Task Force to examine AI and algorithms in healthcare, identifying risks related to civil rights, civil liberties, and discriminatory bias.

Requires submission of a report to Congress within one year detailing findings and recommendations for safe AI implementation in healthcare.

Obliges the Task Force to publish the report on the Department of Health and Human Services' website.

Initiates a public comment period of at least 90 days on the Task Force’s duties and activities.

Allows the Chairperson to appoint additional staff without adherence to certain civil service laws, ensuring flexibility in task force operations.

column2: An Act to amend the labor law, in relation to automated employment decision tools
column3: New York AB A7859
column15: Requires employers and employment agencies to notify job candidates when automated employment decision tools are used to screen candidates.
column16:
Requires employers and employment agencies that use automated employment decision tools to inform job applicants:
(1) That such a tool is being used to screen candidates.
(2) Of which characteristics and qualifications the automated tool considers.
(3) Of what data is collected by the automated tool, where it is sourced, and how it is managed.

Defines "automated employment decision tool" as any computational process that produces an output which is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-making for employment decisions that impact natural persons.
column17: Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Applications: Business services and analytics

column2: National New Generation AI Standards System Construction Guide
column3: National New Generation AI Standards System Construction Guide
column15: Establishes a national AI standards framework emphasizing ethics, security, and privacy. Aims to develop key standards by 2023, focusing on data, algorithms, and applications. Prioritizes international cooperation, key technologies, cross-industry standardization, and proposes security and ethical guidelines.
column16:
Establishes a comprehensive framework for developing a national AI standards system, emphasizing the integration of ethical, security, and privacy standards.

Aims to clarify top-level design and develop key standards by 2023, focusing on data, algorithms, systems, and industry-specific applications.

Outlines an AI standards architecture, comprising eight categories: basic standards, supporting technologies, software/hardware platforms, general/niche technologies, products/services, industry applications, and security/ethics.

Emphasizes the need for international cooperation and alignment with global standards to ensure high-quality AI development.

Prioritizes the development of standards for key technologies such as machine learning, natural language processing, computer vision, and quantum computing.

Addresses AI applications across various sectors, including healthcare, transportation, finance, and smart cities, ensuring cross-industry standardization.

Focuses on security and ethics, proposing standards for AI data, algorithms, models, and application security, alongside ethical guidelines for impactful AI use.

column2: A bill to establish protections for individual rights with respect to computational algorithms, and for other purposes.
column3: Artificial Intelligence Civil Rights Act of 2024
column15: Prohibits AI discrimination based on protected characteristics. Mandates evaluations and audits. Requires transparency and public disclosures. Grants FTC enforcement authority. Provides private right of action. Establishes federal resources for auditing and FTC personnel expansion.
column16:
Prohibits developers and deployers of AI algorithms from causing or contributing to discrimination based on protected characteristics.

Mandates developers and deployers to conduct pre-deployment evaluations and annual impact assessments of AI algorithms to identify potential harms or disparate impacts.

Requires independent audits of AI algorithms and obligates developers to provide relevant information to deployers for compliance.

Imposes transparency obligations, including public disclosures of AI practices and consumer rights, in multiple languages and accessible formats.

Grants the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) enforcement authority, including rulemaking, with violations treated as unfair or deceptive acts.

Provides a private right of action for individuals, enabling lawsuits for violations and barring pre-dispute arbitration agreements.

Establishes federal resources for algorithm auditing, including a new occupational series and additional personnel for the FTC to handle AI-related issues.

column2: STAND with Taiwan Act of 2024, Section 11 ("Prohibition on investments by United States financial institutions that benefit the Government of the People's Republic of China or the Chinese Communist Party")
column3: STAND with Taiwan Act of 2024, Section 11 ("Prohibition on investments by United States financial institutions that benefit the Government of the People's Republic of China or the Chinese Communist Party")
column15: Prohibits U.S. financial institutions from investing in entities controlled by China's government or military. Mandates Treasury Secretary enforcement within three days. Includes investments in AI, machine learning, and robotics. Defines institutions as U.S. investment entities, private equity, venture capital, and hedge funds.
column16:
Prohibits United States financial institutions from making investments benefiting the Government of the People's Republic of China or the Chinese Communist Party.

Mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to enforce this prohibition within three days of a covered determination.

Defines prohibited investments as monetary investments to entities owned or controlled by the Chinese government or military.

Includes investments that benefit priority industrial sectors identified in Chinese strategic plans, such as "Made in China 2025" and the "14th Five Year Smart Manufacturing Development Plan."

Specifies prohibited sectors including artificial intelligence, machine learning, and robotics.

Defines "United States financial institution" to include investment companies, private equity firms, venture capital companies, and hedge funds that qualify as United States persons.

column2: AI Ads Act
column3: AI Ads Act
column15: Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to include AI-generated content in fraudulent misrepresentation prohibitions. Clarifies and extends these prohibitions to any person misrepresenting candidates or parties. Expands coverage to AI-generated content in political campaign misrepresentation or solicitation.
column16:
Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to include fraudulent misrepresentation through content generated with artificial intelligence (AI) under its prohibitions.

Clarifies that fraudulent misrepresentation of campaign authority or solicitation of funds includes the use of AI-generated content.

Extends the prohibition against fraudulent misrepresentation beyond candidates to any person misrepresenting candidates, political parties, or committees for any purpose.

Broadens the scope of prohibited fraudulent solicitation to encompass any candidate, political party, or fictitious political organization, not just those directly involving a candidate or party employee.

Expands the provisions to cover AI-generated content used in misrepresentation or solicitation within political campaigns, ensuring comprehensive regulation of AI's role in electoral fraud.

column2: To provide for Federal civilian agency laboratory development for testing and certification of artificial intelligence for civilian agency use, and for other purposes.
column3: Federal Civilian Agency AI Testing and Certification Act
column15: Establishes AI testing labs under DHS and FEMA. Mandates AI training centers prioritizing privacy and rights. Prohibits rights-threatening automation. Requires real-world use cases. Creates a digital repository. Establishes AI Incident Reporting Office. Requires biannual DHS reports. Authorizes $20 billion.
column16:
Establishes federal civilian agency laboratories for AI testing and certification under the Secretary of Homeland Security through FEMA.

Mandates development of AI training and testing centers to evaluate AI systems for federal use, prioritizing privacy, transparency, accountability, and protection of individual rights.

Prohibits automated decision-making that threatens due process and constitutional rights.

Requires real-world use cases to inform AI system outcomes in federal settings, ensuring no personal data is used.

Creates a digital repository for use cases, ensuring Federal agencies can train and test AI systems appropriately.

Establishes an Office of Artificial Intelligence Incident Reporting within the Department of Homeland Security for agency collaboration and reporting on AI experiences.

Requires biannual reports from DHS to Congress on implementation, challenges, and resource needs, and agency reports on adverse AI experiences.

Authorizes $20 billion in appropriations to implement these measures.

column2: Fix Our Forests Act, Section 102 ("Fireshed Center")
column3: Fix Our Forests Act, Section 102 ("Fireshed Center")
column15: Establishes a Fireshed Center for fire prediction using AI, appoints a Director, promotes data sharing, reduces fragmentation, streamlines processes, develops accessible data tools, and supports the Fireshed Registry with Geological Survey and Forest Service collaboration.
column16:
Establishes a Fireshed Center through collaboration between the Forest Service and the U.S. Geological Survey, involving multiple federal agencies.

Appoints a Director from the U.S. Geological Survey or the Forest Service for a term of up to seven years.

Utilizes artificial intelligence and data tools to assess and predict fire and smoke at the wildland-urban interface for improved management, risk reduction, and recovery.

Promotes data sharing and coordination across federal, state, local, tribal, and private sectors.

Reduces duplication and fragmentation in predictive services and decision support related to wildland fires.

Streamlines procurement and cybersecurity processes.

Develops and disseminates publicly accessible data, models, and technologies for fire risk reduction and recovery planning.

Maintains the Fireshed Registry and supports its operations with personnel and services from the U.S. Geological Survey and the Forest Service.

column2: Modernizing Wildfire Safety and Prevention Act of 2024, Section 405 ("Joint Office of the Fire Environment Center (Report Recommendations 104, 105, 106)")
column3: Modernizing Wildfire Safety and Prevention Act of 2024, Section 405 ("Joint Office of the Fire Environment Center (Report Recommendations 104, 105, 106)")
column15: Establishes the Joint Office of the Fire Environment Center within one year. Requires testing of AI for fire management. Mandates science-based services. Develops a common operating environment. Forms a 12-member board. Empowers contracting. Authorizes $150 million annually.
column16:
Establishes the Joint Office of the Fire Environment Center within one year, under the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

Requires the Data Services branch to test AI and machine learning technologies to aid fire management, suggesting resources based on real-time fire conditions.

Mandates the provision of science-based, data-rich services for fire management, including predictive and decision-support tools.

Develops a technological common operating environment to integrate air quality data and other public health information.

Forms a 12-member board governing the Joint Office, including federal and non-federal wildfire community representatives.

Empowers the Joint Office to contract with government and private entities for necessary supplies and services.

Authorizes $150 million annually from fiscal years 2025 to 2034 for the Joint Office's operations.

column2: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2025, Title V, Section 510 ("Management of artificial intelligence security risks")
column3: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2025, Title V, Section 510 ("Management of artificial intelligence security risks")
column15: Mandates NIST Director update National Vulnerability Database for AI vulnerabilities in 180 days. Requires voluntary AI incident database with confidentiality. Instructs AI incident evaluation. Directs CISA Director update CVE Program. Initiates multi-stakeholder AI standards evaluation. Requires AI supply chain risk management collaboration.
column16:
Mandates the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to update the National Vulnerability Database to incorporate AI security vulnerabilities within 180 days.

Requires the development of a voluntary database to track AI security and safety incidents, ensuring confidentiality and standardized reporting formats.

Instructs the Director to evaluate AI incidents for potential inclusion in the database, prioritizing critical infrastructure and high-impact cases.

Directs the Director of the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency to update the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures Program to address AI security vulnerabilities.

Initiates a multi-stakeholder evaluation of consensus standards for AI vulnerability reporting, with a report due to Congress within 180 days.

Requires collaboration to develop best practices for managing AI supply chain risks, focusing on data collection, documentation, and the use of open-source and proprietary datasets.

column2: MedShield Act of 2024
column3: MedShield Act of 2024
column15: Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to implement the AI-driven MedShield program for pandemic preparedness. Mandates AI use for pathogen surveillance and vaccine development. Obligates coordination with federal and international partners. Authorizes increasing funding from $300M to $500M by 2029.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to implement the MedShield program, utilizing artificial intelligence for pandemic preparedness and response.

Mandates the use of AI for developing a global pathogen surveillance system, accelerating vaccine development, and optimizing pathogen tracking and therapeutic interventions.

Obligates the Secretary to integrate recommendations from the National Security Commission on Artificial Intelligence and coordinate with federal agencies and international partners.

Directs the development of a plan to enhance public health and medical services as part of the National Response Framework.

Sets funding authorization at increasing annual amounts from $300 million in fiscal year 2025 to $500 million in fiscal year 2029.

Requires submission of a detailed report on the program's plan to relevant Congressional committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment.

column2: Synthetic Biology Advancement Act of 2024
column3: Synthetic Biology Advancement Act of 2024
column15: Establishes the National Synthetic Biology Center to advance synthetic biology in agriculture. Prioritizes cellular biology, gene editing, and digital agriculture research. Mandates AI use for solutions. Provides grants and fosters partnerships. Requires biennial reports. Authorizes funding from 2025-2029.
column16:
Establishes the National Synthetic Biology Center to award grants for advancing synthetic biology in agriculture.

Requires the Center to prioritize research in areas like cellular biology, gene editing, and digital agriculture.

Mandates the use of artificial intelligence to accelerate modeling and measurement for synthetic biological solutions.

Provides grants to eligible institutions, fostering partnerships with entities such as nonprofits and national laboratories.

Sets criteria for grant applications, emphasizing the promotion of synthetic biology technologies and sustainability in agriculture.

Directs the Center to coordinate with technology transfer offices to commercialize innovations.

Requires the Center to maintain a website for disseminating findings and facilitating collaboration.

Obligates the Center to submit biennial reports to Congress on research findings and grant progress.

Authorizes appropriations for the Center's operation and grant awards from 2025 to 2029.

column2: Governance Principles for a New Generation of Artificial Intelligence: Develop Responsible Artificial Intelligence
column3: Governance Principles for a New Generation of Artificial Intelligence: Develop Responsible Artificial Intelligence

column2: Part 170: Health Data, Technology, and Interoperability: Certification Program Updates, Algorithm Transparency, and Information Sharing
column3: Part 170: Health Data, Technology, and Interoperability: Certification Program Updates, Algorithm Transparency, and Information Sharing
column5: Department of Health and Human Services
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Amends health IT certification to include predictive decision support. Mandates demographic recording standards. Requires updated health IT modules. Outlines evidence-based criteria. Establishes risk management practices. Incorporates health information standards for interoperability and accuracy.
column16:
Amends health IT certification criteria to include "Predictive Decision Support Intervention," addressing decision-making support based on algorithms for predictions, classifications, and recommendations.

Mandates that health IT systems enable recording of patient demographics, including race, ethnicity, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, and pronouns, using specified standards.

Requires health IT modules to be updated to meet new certification criteria and provide updates to customers as per defined dates.

Outlines certification criteria for health IT, including decision support interventions that must be evidence-based and use specified data standards.

Establishes risk management practices for predictive decision support interventions, including risk analysis, mitigation, and governance.

Incorporates by reference various health information standards, including HL7, LOINC, and SNOMED CT, to ensure interoperability and accuracy in electronic health information exchange.

column2: Protecting Consumers from Deceptive AI Act
column3: Protecting Consumers from Deceptive AI Act
column15: Directs the NIST to establish task forces to develop standards for identifying AI-generated content. Mandates disclosures of AI origins through robust watermarks and content provenance metadata.
column16:
Directs the NIST to establish task forces focused on the development of technical guidelines for identifying and labeling AI-generated content, including metadata, watermarking, and digital fingerprinting.

Supports the development of standards to provide cryptographically verifiable content provenance metadata and robust watermarks. 

Requires providers of generative AI applications to ensure that content created or modified by such applications includes a disclosure of its AI origin, and to collaborate with providers of covered online platforms to provide these disclosures to users.

Prohibits online platforms from removing such disclosures and mandates clear display of AI origin information to users.

Enforces compliance under the Federal Trade Commission Act.

Defines self-regulatory guidelines approved by the FTC as compliance alternatives.
column17: Risk factors: Transparency;Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Financial loss;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Detrimental content;Applications: Consumer goods;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: New institution;Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Incentives: Access to business opportunities;Risk factors: Transparency

column2: Inventorship Guidance for AI-Assisted Inventions
column3: Inventorship Guidance for AI-Assisted Inventions
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Mandates that inventors on U.S. patents must be natural persons, not AI. Clarifies AI-assisted inventions are patentable if a human contributed significantly. Prohibits AI as inventors in priority claims. Applies to design and plant patents.
column16:
Mandates that inventors named on U.S. patents and applications must be natural persons, reaffirming that AI systems cannot be recognized as inventors.

Clarifies that AI-assisted inventions are not unpatentable due to improper inventorship, provided a natural person significantly contributed to the invention's conception.

Requires that patent applications for AI-assisted inventions name natural persons who meet the Pannu factors as inventors, ensuring each claim has a human contributor.

Outlines the duty of disclosure and reasonable inquiry, emphasizing the importance of factual inventorship claims and compliance with regulations.

Establishes guidelines for correcting inventorship errors and emphasizes that AI systems cannot hold inventorship rights.

Applies guidance to design and plant patents, affirming that significant human contribution is necessary for patent eligibility.

Prohibits naming AI systems as inventors in priority claims for U.S. patents and applications, ensuring compliance with U.S. inventorship requirements.

column2: USDA Framework for State, Local, Tribal, and Territorial Use of Artificial Intelligence for Public Benefit Administration
column3: USDA Framework for State, Local, Tribal, and Territorial Use of Artificial Intelligence for Public Benefit Administration
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Mandates USDA to guide AI use for nutrition benefits, ensure equitable outcomes, transparency, and accountability. Prohibits AI from adverse decisions, requires human appeal options, and stresses collaboration with tribes. Requires reporting, monitoring, and responsible innovation.
column16:
The framework mandates the USDA to guide states, localities, tribes, and territories in the responsible use of AI for administering USDA nutrition benefits, as per Executive Order 14110.

Ensures AI systems maximize access for eligible recipients and comply with merit system requirements.

Requires notification to the Secretary in cases of reliance on AI, allowing appeals to human reviewers and ensuring auditability of AI decisions.

Mandates equitable outcomes from AI systems and prohibits AI from directly making adverse decisions in benefits administration.

Advocates for transparency and accountability, providing opt-out options from AI systems.

Encourages responsible innovation, requiring AI usage only with appropriate training and governance.

Requires SLTT agencies to report AI usage and its impact, with ongoing monitoring to mitigate risks and biases.

Stresses collaboration with tribes to respect data sovereignty.

column2: HHS Public Benefits and AI
column3: HHS Public Benefits and AI
column5: Department of Health and Human Services
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Requires HHS to promote responsible AI use in public benefits by STLTs. Urges alignment with AI frameworks, equitable outcomes, transparency, and privacy safeguards. Supports policy development and collaboration to ensure safe, equitable, and efficient AI systems.
column16:
Requires the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to promote responsible AI use in public benefits administration by State, Local, Tribal, and Territorial Governments (STLTs).

Encourages STLTs to align with the principles of the National Institute of Standards and Technology AI Risk Management Framework and the Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights.

Recommends STLTs assess AI systems for equitable outcomes, notify recipients about AI use, and ensure human oversight and appeal processes.

Supports STLTs in developing AI policies and practices through guidance, technical assistance, and resources.

Urges STLTs to focus on safeguarding privacy, civil rights, and safety, and to provide opt-out options for AI systems.

Emphasizes the need for transparency, public engagement, and governance to manage AI-associated risks.

Directs HHS to work with STLTs and other agencies to ensure AI systems in public benefits programs are safe, equitable, and efficient.

column2: Guidance on Application of the Fair Housing Act to the Advertising of Housing, Credit, and Other Real Estate-Related Transactions through Digital Platforms
column3: Guidance on Application of the Fair Housing Act to the Advertising of Housing, Credit, and Other Real Estate-Related Transactions through Digital Platforms
column5: Department of Housing and Urban Development
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Prohibits discriminatory advertising based on protected characteristics. Warns of unintentional discrimination via AI tools. Requires avoidance of audience segmentation by protected traits. Urges disabling certain targeting functions. Recommends risk management and bias monitoring. Advises transparency through documentation.
column16:
Explains how the Fair Housing Act applies to housing-related advertising via AI and algorithmic systems on digital platforms.

Prohibits discriminatory advertising practices based on protected characteristics such as race, color, religion, sex, national origin, familial status, or disability.

Warns that audience categorization and algorithmic delivery tools can unintentionally lead to discrimination by excluding or targeting groups based on protected characteristics.

Requires advertisers and platforms to avoid using AI tools that segment audiences by protected characteristics or proxies like geographic location.

Urges ad platforms to disable certain targeting functions for housing ads and conduct regular audits to ensure compliance with the Act.

Recommends that advertisers and platforms manage discriminatory risks by utilizing separate processes for housing-related ads and monitoring ad delivery outcomes for bias.

Advises documenting and publicly sharing information on ad targeting functions to ensure transparency and accountability.

column2: Increasing AI Capacity Across the Federal Government: AI Talent Surge Progress and Recommendations
column3: Increasing AI Capacity Across the Federal Government: AI Talent Surge Progress and Recommendations
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Mandates Federal agencies enhance AI safety, security, privacy, equity, and innovation. Launches a National AI Talent Surge. Facilitates AI hiring. Establishes Chief AI Officers. Recommends increased funding. Proposes AI scholarship-for-service. Encourages global talent engagement.
column16:
Mandates Federal agencies strengthen AI safety, security, privacy, equity, civil rights, and innovation through Executive Order 14110, signed by President Biden.

Launches a National AI Talent Surge to recruit AI professionals into the Federal Government, enhancing AI regulatory and policy capacity, government use of AI, and AI R&D ecosystem.

Facilitates AI hiring with Direct Hire Authority and Excepted Service Appointments granted by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM).

Establishes Chief AI Officers and enhances AI competencies with training programs for the Federal workforce.

Recommends funding increases for AI talent, institutionalizing tech talent programs, improving USAJOBS, and piloting skills-based hiring.

Proposes an AI scholarship-for-service program and public service cultivation within the tech ecosystem.

Encourages global AI talent engagement and provides guidance for improving Federal hiring experiences.

column2:
Government-wide Hiring Authorities for Advancing Federal Government
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)
column3:
Government-wide Hiring Authorities for Advancing Federal Government
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Mandates OPM to review AI hiring within 60 days. Authorizes direct hire authority for AI roles until 2028. Permits temporary staffing via Schedule A. Requires quarterly agency reports on hires. Stipulates veterans' preference adherence. Allows OPM to assess authorities.
column16:
Mandates the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to conduct an evidence-based review for hiring and workplace flexibility for AI and data-science roles within 60 days of the Executive Order (EO) 14110.

Authorizes government-wide direct hire authority for specific AI-related positions, effective immediately through December 31, 2028, to address critical hiring needs in AI capabilities.

Permits use of excepted service Schedule A appointments for temporary staffing to support the implementation of EO 14110, with appointments valid for up to two years.

Requires agencies to submit quarterly reports detailing hires made under this direct hire authority, including job announcements and number of hires.

Stipulates agencies must adhere to veterans’ preference and public notice requirements when filling positions under these authorities.

Allows OPM to request information and assess the continued need for these authorities, with the possibility of modification or termination.

column2: Pay Flexibility, Incentive Pay, and Leave and Workforce Flexibility Programs for Artificial Intelligence (AI), AI-enabling, and Other Key Technical Employees (OPM)
column3: Pay Flexibility, Incentive Pay, and Leave and Workforce Flexibility Programs for Artificial Intelligence (AI), AI-enabling, and Other Key Technical Employees (OPM)
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Grants agencies authority to use pay flexibilities and incentives. Allows up to 50% incentives for critical needs. Enables student loan repayments as incentives. Permits higher pay rates and alternative work schedules. Provides service credit for non-Federal experience. Encourages tailored strategies.
column16:
Grants agencies discretionary authority to use various pay flexibilities, incentive pay, and leave and workforce flexibility programs to recruit, relocate, and retain AI and key technical employees.

Allows recruitment, relocation, and retention incentives up to 25% of basic pay, and provides for waivers to increase this limit to 50% based on critical needs.

Enables agencies to repay student loans as an incentive, with limits of $10,000 annually and $60,000 total per employee.

Permits setting higher pay rates for employees with superior qualifications or special needs, and requests OPM approval for special rates and critical position pay.

Authorizes alternative work schedules, telework, and remote work to enhance recruitment and retention.

Provides service credit for non-Federal work experience towards higher annual leave accrual rates.

Encourages collaboration with agency officials to design tailored recruitment and retention strategies utilizing available human resources tools.

column2: Canada Artificial Intelligence and Data Act (Companion document)
column3: Canada Artificial Intelligence and Data Act (Companion document)
column15: Proposes the Artificial Intelligence and Data Act (AIDA) to regulate high-impact AI in Canada. Empowers enforcement by the Minister and AI Commissioner. Prohibits harmful AI use. Aligns with international norms. Mandates risk management and accountability. Introduces penalties for non-compliance.
column16:
Proposes the Artificial Intelligence and Data Act (AIDA) to regulate AI in Canada, focusing on high-impact AI systems.

Empowers the Minister of Innovation, Science, and Industry to enforce AIDA, supported by a new AI and Data Commissioner.

Prohibits the reckless and malicious use of AI that causes harm, introducing new criminal law provisions.

Aligns with international norms, such as the EU AI Act, and integrates with existing Canadian laws.

Mandates businesses to identify, assess, and mitigate risks associated with high-impact AI systems.

Requires transparency, fairness, safety, and accountability in AI systems.

Introduces administrative penalties and criminal offences for non-compliance.

Plans a consultation process for the development of regulations, seeking input from stakeholders.

Establishes mechanisms for human oversight and monitoring of AI systems.

Targets AI systems impacting services, biometric identification, behavior influence, and health and safety.

column2: Australia’s AI Ethics Principles
column3: Australia’s AI Ethics Principles
column15: Prioritizes beneficial AI systems. Requires respect for rights and diversity. Mandates inclusivity, privacy, and security. Ensures reliability and safety. Calls for transparency. Establishes contestability. Holds parties accountable with oversight.
column16:
Prioritizes AI systems that benefit individuals, society, and the environment throughout their lifecycle.

Requires AI systems to respect human rights, diversity, and individual autonomy, promoting an equitable society.

Mandates fairness by ensuring AI inclusivity and accessibility, prohibiting unfair discrimination.

Demands privacy protection and data security, with ongoing data governance and vulnerability assessments.

Ensures AI reliability and safety, mandating operation in line with intended purposes and risk management.

Calls for transparency and explainability, necessitating timely and responsible disclosures of AI impacts.

Establishes contestability, allowing challenges to AI impacts on individuals or communities through clear processes.

Holds relevant parties accountable for AI outcomes, requiring identifiable responsibility and human oversight.

column2: Artificial Intelligence and the Information Privacy Principles
column3: Artificial Intelligence and the Information Privacy Principles
column15: Requires compliance with the Privacy Act 2020 and IPPs. Mandates senior approval and PIAs. Demands transparency and Māori engagement. Ensures human oversight. Checks necessity. Prohibits data retention. Stresses data reliability. Advises on privacy measures. Highlights privacy issues. Encourages data security.
column16:
Requires organisations in New Zealand using AI tools to comply with the Privacy Act 2020 and the 13 information privacy principles (IPPs).

Mandates senior leadership approval for AI tool usage and a privacy impact assessment (PIA) to evaluate privacy risks.

Demands transparency about AI tool usage, including engaging with Māori on potential impacts.

Ensures human oversight to mitigate AI biases and inaccuracies.

Checks the necessity and proportionality of AI tools, considering privacy implications.

Prohibits retention or disclosure of personal information by AI tools.

Stresses the importance of training data provenance and reliability to ensure AI accuracy.

Advises on proactive privacy measures, including developing privacy policies and engaging with affected communities.

Highlights potential privacy issues with AI, such as automation blindness and overseas data disclosure risks.

Encourages organisations to secure personal information and comply with access, correction, and disclosure requirements.

column2: Maintaining American Leadership in Artificial Intelligence (EO 13859)
column3: Maintaining American Leadership in Artificial Intelligence (EO 13859)
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Mandates U.S. leadership in AI via the American AI Initiative. Requires prioritization of AI R&D, data access, and civil liberties protection. Obliges technical standards development. Directs AI skills training. Instructs international standards creation. Tasks Select Committee coordination.
column16:
Mandates the Federal Government to sustain U.S. leadership in AI through a coordinated strategy known as the American AI Initiative.

Requires agencies to prioritize AI R&D, enhance data accessibility, and reduce barriers for AI deployment, ensuring protection of civil liberties and privacy.

Obligates agencies to develop technical standards to minimize vulnerabilities and foster public trust in AI systems.

Directs the training of American workers in AI-related skills to prepare them for future job markets.

Instructs the development of international standards and promotes global collaboration while safeguarding critical AI technologies from foreign adversaries.

Tasks the Select Committee on Artificial Intelligence with coordinating AI R&D efforts across Federal agencies.

Instructs the issuance of guidance for AI regulation and emphasizes the development of trustworthy AI systems.

Develops an action plan to protect U.S. advantages in AI technology against strategic competitors and adversaries.

column2: Bipartisan Framework for U.S. AI Act
column3: Bipartisan Framework for U.S. AI Act
column15: Establishes a licensing regime for A.I. developers. Requires risk management and reporting. Grants audit authority to oversight bodies. Mandates Congress ensure legal accountability for harms. Urges export controls. Promotes transparency and deepfake labeling. Obligates consumer protections.
column16:
Establishes a licensing regime requiring companies developing sophisticated A.I. models to register with an independent oversight body. 

Requires developers to maintain risk management, pre-deployment testing, and reporting programs as part of licensing conditions.

Grants the oversight body authority to audit companies and cooperate with state Attorneys General.

Mandates Congress to ensure A.I. companies are legally accountable for harms caused by their models, including privacy breaches and civil rights violations.

Urges Congress to use export controls and sanctions to limit A.I. technology transfers to adversary nations.

Promotes transparency by requiring companies to disclose A.I. model information and ensure users know they are interacting with A.I.

Requires A.I. system providers to label deepfakes and maintain a public database of A.I. information.

Obliges companies to implement consumer protections, including safety brakes and data usage control, especially concerning children.

column2: Eliminating Bias in Algorithmic Systems Act of 2023
column3: Eliminating Bias in Algorithmic Systems Act of 2023
column15: Requires agencies that use, fund, or oversee algorithms to establish civil rights offices with bias experts. Mandates biennial reports to Congress on algorithmic bias, risks and actions taken to mitigate them.
column16:
Requires agencies which use or oversee a covered algorithm to have an office of civil rights employing experts and technologists on bias, discrimination, and algorithmic harms.

Mandates these offices to submit biennial reports to Congress detailing risks from use of algorithms using artificial intelligence techniques within the agency's jurisdiction, mitigation steps, actions taken to engage stakeholders, and recommendations for further mitigation of algorithmic bias and discrimination.

Establishes an interagency working group on covered algorithms and civil rights, led by the Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Research, Innovation, and Accountability Act of 2023
column3: Artificial Intelligence Research, Innovation, and Accountability Act of 2023
column15: Develops standards for online content verification, mandates best practices for AI detection, reviews government AI use, prohibits generative AI without user notice, requires transparency reports, and establishes oversight, risk assessments, certification, enforcement, and consumer education for AI.
column16:
Requires the Under Secretary of Commerce to develop standards for online content verification. Mandates best practices for detecting AI outputs. Directs review of AI usage in government. Prohibits generative AI without user notification. 
Requires AI transparency reports. Instructs NIST on AI oversight. Obligates risk assessments for critical-impact AI. Establishes AI Certification Advisory Committee. Empowers enforcement of compliance. Establishes consumer education working group.

column2: A Stronger Workforce for America Act, Chapter 3 (Performance Accountability)
column3: A Stronger Workforce for America Act, Chapter 3 (Performance Accountability)
column15: Amends the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act to allow states to use machine learning and advanced analytics in the improvement of state program operations and outcomes.
column16: Amends the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act to allow states to use machine learning and advanced analytics in the improvement of state program operations and outcomes.
column17: Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Strategies: Government support

column2: National Patient Safety Board Act of 2024
column3: National Patient Safety Board Act of 2024
column15: Establishes the National Patient Safety Board (NPSB) to prevent patient safety events. Empowers NPSB to monitor, study, and propose solutions. Grants authority to request changes and review reports. Mandates annual audits. Forms Patient Safety Research Division. Requires privacy and AI compliance. Prohibits use in civil cases.
column16:
Establishes the National Patient Safety Board (NPSB) within the Office of the Secretary of Health and Human Services to prevent and reduce patient safety events.

Empowers the NPSB to support federal agencies in monitoring patient safety, studying causes of patient safety events, and formulating preventive solutions.

Grants the NPSB authority to request changes to patient safety measures, review reports, and make them publicly available within one year of study commencement.

Mandates annual audits and reports to Congress on progress, including detailed solutions and unaddressed needs.

Forms a Patient Safety Research and Development Division to aggregate and analyze patient-level data, identifying and anticipating safety events and disparities.

Requires compliance with privacy laws and AI governance frameworks, including NIST's AI Risk Management Framework and the Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights.

Prohibits the use of NPSB reports as evidence in civil liability cases but allows their use in developing standards of care.

column2: Massachusetts Bill H.64
column3: Massachusetts Bill H.64 ("Automated Decision Making Commission")
column15: Establishes a commission to study and recommend on ADS use in Massachusetts. Requires surveying ADS uses, consulting experts, and examining research and risks. Compels meetings and public hearings. Mandates annual reports to the governor and legislature.
column16:
Establishes a commission within the executive office of technology services and security to study and make recommendations on the use of automated decision systems (ADS) by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

Requires the commission to survey all uses of ADS by Massachusetts offices, including procurement, evaluation, training, validation, transparency, and accountability.

Mandates the commission to consult experts on machine learning, algorithmic bias, and civil rights, and to examine research on disparate impacts of ADS based on group characteristics.

Obligates the commission to examine data protection, intellectual property issues, and other opportunities and risks associated with ADS.

Compels the commission to meet at least 10 times a year and hold public hearings for feedback.

Requires the commission to submit an annual report detailing activities, findings, and regulatory recommendations to the governor and state legislature.

column2: Protect Victims of Digital Exploitation and Manipulation Act of 2024
column3: Protect Victims of Digital Exploitation and Manipulation Act of 2024
column15: Prohibits producing or distributing digital forgeries of intimate visuals without consent, with penalties up to 5 years imprisonment or fines. Exempts good faith distributions for specific purposes. Excludes service providers unless reckless. Defines digital forgery. Establishes extraterritorial jurisdiction. Ensures severability.
column16:
Prohibits the production or distribution of digital forgeries of intimate visual depictions of identifiable individuals without their consent, under penalty of fines or imprisonment up to 5 years.

Exempts distributions made in good faith to law enforcement, during legal proceedings, for medical purposes, or in reporting/investigating unlawful content or conduct.

Excludes communications service providers from liability unless they knowingly or recklessly distribute such content.

Defines "digital forgery" as intimate visual depictions created or altered using software, machine learning, AI, or other computer-generated means to appear authentic.

Establishes extraterritorial jurisdiction if the offender or victim is a U.S. national.

Ensures severability of the Act’s provisions if any part is found unconstitutional.
column17: Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Detrimental content;Incentives: Criminal liability;Incentives: Fines;Incentives: Imprisonment;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Detrimental content;Harms: Detrimental content;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems

column2: Massachusetts Bill S. 31
column3: Massachusetts Bill S. 31 ("Regulate GenAI")
column15: Regulate generative AI models to protect safety, privacy, and IP rights. Define models as those with ‚â•1 billion parameters. Prohibit discriminatory AI use. Mandate AI text watermarks/authentication. Require data security, informed consent, and timely data deletion. Conduct regular risk assessments. Mandate registration with the attorney general, detailing practices. Authorize attorney general to enforce compliance.
column16:
Regulate generative AI models, such as ChatGPT, to protect public safety, privacy, and intellectual property rights.

Define "large-scale generative artificial intelligence model" as those with at least one billion parameters.

Prohibit the use of AI models for discrimination or bias based on protected characteristics.

Mandate AI-generated text to contain a distinctive watermark or offer an authentication process to prevent plagiarism.

Require companies to implement reasonable security measures to protect training data.

Obtain informed consent from individuals before collecting, using, or disclosing their data.

Delete or de-identify data when no longer needed for the intended purpose.

Conduct regular risk assessments to identify and mitigate foreseeable risks and harms.

Mandate companies operating large-scale AI models to register with the attorney general within 90 days, including detailed model and data practices.

Authorize the attorney general to adopt regulations and enforce compliance, including bringing legal action for violations.

column2: A Bill to prohibit certain uses of automated decision systems by employers, and for other purposes.
column3: No Robot Bosses Act
column15: Restricts the use of automated decision systems for employment-related decisions, including by requiring such systems to be tested for efficacy, non-discrimination, and relevant laws & standards.
column16:
Prohibits employers from making any employment-related decisions -- including to fire or discipline an employee -- based solely on the output of an automated decision system.

Requires any automated decision system used to inform employment-related decisions to be tested before deployment for efficacy and compliance with relevant employment laws & the Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework from the National Institute of Standards & Technology. Systems must also be tested both before deployment and annually after deployment for non-discrimination on the basis of protected classes.

Requires employers to disclose to employees the use of automated decision systems for employment-related decisions and information on the workings of the system and the data used to reach its decision.

Establishes new roles and bodies in the Department of Labor to monitor and enforce this policy and to guide the development of future regulations on the use of automated decision systems in employment-related decision-making.

Establishes protections for whistleblowers who call attention to violations of this policy.
column17: Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Reliability;Risk factors: Interpretability and explainability;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Financial loss;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Differential treatment based on a protected characteristic;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: External auditing;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Disclosure: About incidents;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Performance requirements;Strategies: New institution;Incentives: Criminal liability;Incentives: Civil liability;Incentives: Fines;Applications: Business services and analytics

column2: Kids Online Safety Act, Title II (Filter Bubble Transparency)
column3: Kids Online Safety Act, Title II (Filter Bubble Transparency)
column15: Requires platforms using opaque algorithms to notify users about their use and data application and mandates the option to switch to input-transparent algorithms.
column16:
Requires online platforms using opaque algorithms to provide users with clear notice about the use of such algorithms and how user-specific data is utilized. 

Mandates platforms to allow users to easily switch between opaque algorithms and input-transparent algorithms. Prohibits differential pricing or service denial based on a user's choice to use an input-transparent algorithm.

Empowers the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to enforce these requirements as violations of unfair or deceptive practices under the Federal Trade Commission Act. 

Ensures that trade secrets, confidential business information, or privileged data are not required to be disclosed. Preserves the ability of platforms to allow users to personalize content restrictions and interactions.
column17: Risk factors: Interpretability and explainability;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs

column2: Microsoft Responsible AI Standard, v2
column3: Microsoft Responsible AI Standard, v2
column15: Mandates Microsoft to conduct impact assessments for AI systems, update annually, and oversee systems with potential adverse effects. Requires data governance, human oversight, intelligibility, transparency, fairness, reliability, safety, and compliance with privacy, security, and accessibility standards.
column16:
Mandates Microsoft to conduct Impact Assessments for AI systems early in development to evaluate societal impacts, requiring annual updates and reviews for significant adverse impacts.

Requires identifying and overseeing AI systems with potential adverse effects, alongside applying additional oversight for Sensitive and Restricted Uses.

Ensures AI systems are fit for purpose, with detailed documentation and ongoing evaluation of performance metrics and error types.

Imposes data governance, requiring documentation of data requirements and processes, and evaluation of datasets for inclusivity.

Demands human oversight capabilities, identifying stakeholders responsible for system control and providing necessary tools and documentation.

Requires systems to be intelligible for decision-making, supporting stakeholders' understanding of system outputs and discouraging automation bias.

Mandates transparency and communication about system capabilities, limitations, and any AI-generated content.

Ensures fairness, focusing on quality of service and opportunities, minimizing disparities for demographic groups in AI system outputs. 

Emphasizes reliability and safety, requiring evaluation for safe performance within operational ranges, and ongoing monitoring and feedback. 

Insists on compliance with Microsoft’s Privacy, Security, and Accessibility Standards to ensure inclusive, secure, and private AI system design.

column2: NSF AI Education Act of 2024
column3: NSF AI Education Act of 2024
column15: Establishes the NSF AI Education Act of 2024 to provide AI education scholarships. Mandates NSF prioritize underserved institutions. Directs professional development and agricultural training. Authorizes AI Excellence Centers. Advises on AI guidelines. Prohibits funding for discriminatory institutions. Develops workforce frameworks.
column16:
Establishes the NSF AI Education Act of 2024 to provide scholarships and fellowships for AI education at various educational levels, including undergraduate and graduate studies. 

Mandates the Director of the National Science Foundation (NSF) to award scholarships for AI studies in fields such as agriculture, education, and advanced manufacturing, prioritizing institutions in underserved areas.

Directs the NSF to create professional development fellowships for AI and related emerging technologies, fostering collaboration between academia and industry.

Requires grants for AI training at land-grant colleges and universities, focusing on agricultural applications.

Authorizes the establishment of Centers of AI Excellence at community colleges and vocational schools to advance AI education and training.

Advises on guidelines for AI use in primary and secondary education and supports AI education research.

Prohibits funding to institutions in violation of anti-discrimination laws.

Directs the development of workforce frameworks for AI and other emerging technologies.

column2: 2023 UK AI Safety Summit Response (Microsoft)
column3: 2023 UK AI Safety Summit Response (Microsoft)
column15: Commits Microsoft to responsible AI development with OpenAI collaboration. Establishes a safety board for model review. Implements AI governance and risk evaluation. Advances transparency and invests in safety research. Supports licensing, introduces watermarking, and offers vulnerability disclosure rewards.
column16:
Commits Microsoft to the responsible development and deployment of AI technologies, emphasizing collaboration with OpenAI and adherence to the National Institute of Standards and Technology AI Risk Management Framework.

Establishes a joint Microsoft-OpenAI Deployment Safety Board for pre-release AI model review, focusing on safety and capability thresholds.

Implements multi-layered AI governance and continuous risk evaluation, including red teaming for security and misuse detection.

Advances transparency through documentation and stakeholder engagement, informing on AI system capabilities and limitations.

Invests in AI safety research and collaborates globally on best practices for AI governance.

Supports a coordinated licensing regime for frontier models to enhance oversight and risk management.

Introduces initiatives like watermarking and metadata-based provenance for identifying AI-generated content.

Provides a framework for vulnerability disclosure and mitigation, offering rewards through bug bounty programs.

column2: Workforce of the Future Act of 2024
column3: Workforce of the Future Act of 2024
column15: Mandates reports on AI's workforce impact. Authorizes grants for K-12 tech education inclusivity. Requires upskilling funds for AI-affected industries. Prescribes evaluation of grant activities. Demands biannual usage reports. Amends laws for AI skills competency.
column16:
Mandates the preparation of reports by the Secretary of Labor, the National Science Foundation, and the Secretary of Education on AI's workforce impact, identifying data needs, affected industries, and opportunities for stakeholder influence.

Authorizes the Department of Education to award grants to enhance emerging and advanced technology education from prekindergarten through grade 12, focusing on inclusivity for underrepresented communities.

Requires the Department of Labor to grant funds for upskilling workers in industries significantly impacted by AI, promoting lifelong learning and skill certifications.

Prescribes continuous evaluation and monitoring of grant-funded activities, with a focus on sustaining project activities post-grant.

Demands biannual reporting by grantees on fund usage, disaggregated by demographic factors, and a comprehensive report to Congress within five years.

Amends existing education laws to integrate emerging technology education data, emphasizing competency in AI-related skills among students.

column2: Transformational Artificial intelligence to Modernize the Economy against Extreme Weather Act
column3: TAME Extreme Weather Act
column15: Mandates AI-driven weather forecasting datasets and collaboration with experts. Directs AI use for wildfire modeling and emissions monitoring. Encourages partnerships and diverse workforce development. Allows public access to data with safeguards. Supports research and data acquisition for weather prediction.
column16:
Mandates the development of comprehensive weather forecasting training datasets using AI to improve Earth system modeling and weather forecasts.

Requires collaboration with federal agencies and experts to enhance AI weather models and explore AI's role in public preparedness and resilience.

Directs the use of AI for fire environment modeling to predict, detect, and forecast wildfires and associated hazards.

Establishes an emissions monitoring program using AI to analyze global atmospheric data and improve greenhouse gas emission models.

Encourages partnerships with private and academic entities to advance AI in weather forecasting and environmental predictions.

Calls for recruitment and development of a diverse workforce skilled in AI applications for weather forecasting.

Allows public access to data and code developed under this Act, with safeguards for national security and intellectual property.

Supports ongoing research and data acquisition for AI and numerical weather models, ensuring continued advancement in weather prediction technologies.
