column2: Secure Artificial Intelligence Act of 2024
column3: Secure A.I. Act
column15: Establishes a voluntary database for AI incidents. Mandates NIST to update databases for AI vulnerabilities. Prohibits employer retaliation against incident reporters. Requires updates to AI vulnerability programs. Directs AI supply chain risk practices. Creates an AI Security Center. Ensures secure AI research test-bed availability.
column16:
Establishes a voluntary database to track AI security and safety incidents, requiring the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to develop mechanisms for sharing incident information while preserving confidentiality.

Mandates NIST to update the National Vulnerability Database to incorporate AI security vulnerabilities and identify characteristics that make the database unsuitable for certain AI vulnerabilities.

Prohibits employer retaliation against employees who report AI incidents, allowing legal recourse for aggrieved parties.

Requires the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency to update the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures Program for AI vulnerabilities.

Directs the establishment of best practices for addressing AI supply chain risks, involving multiple stakeholders.

Creates an Artificial Intelligence Security Center within the National Security Agency to facilitate AI security research, guidance development, and secure AI adoption practices.

Ensures the availability of a research test-bed for secure AI research, leveraging existing infrastructure and coordinating with other federal agencies.

column2: Department of Energy Artificial Intelligence Act of 2024
column3: Department of Energy AI Act
column15: Establishes an AI R&D program within the Department of Energy. Mandates coordination across offices and provides financial assistance. Supports technology transfer and testbeds. Encourages partnerships. Emphasizes ethics and security. Allocates $300 million annually. Requires energy security assessment.
column16:
Establishes a cross-cutting AI research and development program within the Department of Energy to advance AI tools, systems, and capabilities.

Mandates coordination across relevant offices such as the Office of Science and the Office of Energy Efficiency to carry out this program.

Requires financial assistance for research in areas like AI application in simulations, data analysis, and energy-efficient computing.

Supports technology transfer and the use of high-performance computing infrastructure to develop advanced AI systems.

Establishes data center testbeds to improve energy efficiency in AI training and inference.

Encourages partnerships with federal and private entities to enhance AI research and development.

Emphasizes ethical considerations, cybersecurity, and data privacy in AI projects.

Allocates $300 million annually from 2025 to 2030 for these initiatives.

Requires an assessment of energy security related to data centers and computing resources, with recommendations for policy changes.

column2: Public Act 103-0804
column3: Illinois Public Act 103-0804
column15: Amends the Illinois Human Rights Act to regulate AI in employment. Prohibits discriminatory AI use. Requires employee notification. Mandates rule adoption by the Illinois Department of Human Rights. Defines AI and generative AI. Takes effect on January 1, 2026.
column16:
Amends the Illinois Human Rights Act to regulate the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in employment-related decisions.

Prohibits employers from using AI in recruitment, hiring, promotion, or other employment practices if it results in discrimination based on protected classes.

Requires employers to notify employees if AI is used in employment decisions.

Mandates the Illinois Department of Human Rights to adopt rules for implementing these AI-related provisions, including specifying conditions and timelines for providing notice.

Defines "artificial intelligence" as a machine-based system generating outputs like predictions or decisions that can influence environments.

Includes "generative artificial intelligence" as systems producing content simulating human-produced content based on prompts.

Takes effect on January 1, 2026.

column2: AI Safety Summit - Enhancing Frontier AI Safety (Amazon)
column3: AI Safety Summit - Enhancing Frontier AI Safety (Amazon)
column15: Facilitates AI development via AWS services like Amazon Bedrock. Implements risk management with evaluations and security assessments. Protects models with encryption and access controls. Shares AI details via Service Cards. Encourages responsible use. Invests in research. Monitors misuse.
column16:
Facilitates AI development and deployment through Amazon Web Services (AWS), offering a comprehensive suite of AI and ML services, including Amazon Bedrock and Amazon Titan Foundation Models, which support generative AI applications.

Implements risk management and safety protocols, including systematic model evaluation, red teaming, and ongoing security assessments, to mitigate potential AI risks.

Protects AI models and data using robust logical and physical security measures, such as encryption, access controls, and least privilege principles.

Shares AI service information transparently through AI Service Cards, detailing intended use cases, limitations, and responsible AI design considerations.

Encourages responsible AI use and prohibits misuse through the AWS Responsible AI Policy, which addresses concerns like disinformation and privacy violations.

Invests in research and academic partnerships to advance responsible AI practices and develop tools for bias mitigation and human oversight.

Monitors AI misuse post-release, employing classifier guardrails and automated abuse detection to identify and address harmful content and misuse patterns.

column2: Our Policy on Frontier Safety (Inflection)
column3: Our Policy on Frontier Safety (Inflection)
column15: Commits Inflection to scale AI with phased safety measures, requiring evaluations and audits. Ensures security controls and monitoring. Publishes capabilities, advocates for vulnerability reporting, and prioritizes AI risk research. Promotes cross-industry collaboration for safety and watermarking.
column16:
Commits Inflection to a disciplined, phased approach to scaling AI models, emphasizing pre-deployment safety, post-launch monitoring, and global governance.

Requires robust evaluations and third-party red-teaming before public launch to ensure models do not provide harmful information or engage in discriminatory conduct.

Implements strict data input controls and audits, involving executive review and legal evaluations of training data for compliance with legal and ethical standards.

Ensures high-level security controls to prevent unauthorized access and misuse of AI models, including internal restrictions and a bug bounty program.

Maintains around-the-clock monitoring to detect and mitigate model misuse, employing frontier AI to enhance situational awareness.

Publishes model capabilities and limitations, supporting transparency and enabling risk assessment by users and regulators.

Advocates for standardized vulnerability reporting structures and participates in a pilot bug bounty program to encourage third-party disclosures.

Prioritizes research on AI risks and supports the creation of an International Panel on AI Safety.

Promotes cross-industry collaboration for identifying AI-generated material, focusing on child safety and standardized watermarking.

column2: Sensible Classification Act of 2023
column3: Sensible Classification Act of 2023
column15: Mandates research and recommendation of AI solutions for interoperable classification systems. Requires consultation with defense agencies and a report. Obligates clearance agencies to study necessity. Instructs training improvements. Calls for board enhancements. Demands independent review of clearance studies.
column16:
Mandates the research and recommendation of AI and machine learning solutions for efficient classification and declassification systems, to be interoperable across the Federal Government.

Requires the Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government to consult with key defense and intelligence agencies for technology implementation and submit a report on the recommended solution.

Obliges agencies granting security clearances to study and report on the necessity of such clearances, aiming to minimize personnel with access to classified information.

Instructs agency heads to ensure classification training promotes sensible classification and discourages over-classification.

Calls for the Public Interest Declassification Board to improve its operations, including staff expansion, to enhance declassification processes.

Demands independent reviews of agency studies and reports on security clearances by the Information Security Oversight Office, the Director of National Intelligence, and the Public Interest Declassification Board.

column2: Train Crew Size Safety Requirements (New Technology and Automated Operations)
column3: Train Crew Size Safety Requirements (New Technology and Automated Operations)
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Require railroads to file for rulemaking or waivers for non-compliant automation. Mandate risk assessments before operations. Emphasize rail safety over reduced crew sizes. Disagree with claims that PTC justifies crew reduction. Support AI research. Permit petitions ensuring safety.
column16:
Require railroads seeking to use automation technology non-compliant with FRA safety regulations to file a petition for rulemaking or a waiver.

Mandate a risk assessment before initiating operations under special approval processes.

Acknowledge freight rail industry's concerns about competition with automated trucking but emphasize rail safety hazards from reduced crew sizes.

Disagree with assertions that labor-saving technologies like PTC justify removal of crew members, stating such technologies are not fully developed.

Support technological advancement in rail through research on AI and automation, including drones and real-time safety systems.

Permit railroads to petition for rulemaking or waivers to use technology that doesn't meet existing regulatory requirements, ensuring safety justifications are provided.

Clarify that the rule does not impede innovation but requires description of technology used to support tasks typically performed by a second crew member.

column2: Modernizing Data Practices to Improve Government Act
column3: Modernizing Data Practices to Improve Government Act
column15: Amends section 3520A to extend Chief Data Officer Council's authority. Requires identification of data governance opportunities, mandates AI officer appointment, obligates biennial reports, instructs role clarification, requires data ownership recommendations, directs guidance issuance, mandates annual report, sunsets in seven years.
column16:
Amends section 3520A of title 44, United States Code, to extend the Chief Data Officer Council's authority to improve Federal data governance.

Requires the Council to identify opportunities to enhance data governance for reliable and secure adoption of emerging technologies and AI.

Mandates appointment of a representative from Chief Artificial Intelligence Officers to the Council.

Obligates the Council to submit biennial reports detailing recommendations for developing datasets and data governance policies to support AI adoption.

Instructs the Council to assess data governance challenges, clarify roles among senior agency leaders, and recommend best practices for AI data use.

Requires recommendations for data ownership policies to ensure government rights and pre-procurement AI reviews.

Directs the Director to issue guidance based on Council reports.

Mandates an annual data management report to Congress clarifying Chief Data Officers' roles in AI governance.

Sunsets the amendments seven years after enactment.

column2: AI Leadership To Enable Accountable Deployment Act
column3: AI LEAD Act
column15: Establishes the Chief AI Officers Council to promote innovation and compliance. Requires agency AI Officers and Coordination Boards. Mandates AI strategy development. Requires Comptroller General and bias impact reports. Directs OMB guidance. Sunsets Act 90 days post-guidance.
column16:
Establishes the Chief Artificial Intelligence Officers Council to promote AI innovation, oversee compliance, and advise on best practices for AI technologies.

Requires agencies to designate a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer responsible for promoting AI use, managing risks, and ensuring transparency and privacy.

Mandates the creation of Artificial Intelligence Coordination Boards within agencies to coordinate AI issues and publish principles and goals.

Directs agencies to develop an AI strategy focusing on responsible and trustworthy adoption, public trust, risk mitigation, and interagency coordination.

Requires the Comptroller General to report on the effectiveness of AI Coordination Boards, evaluate Chief AI Officers, and assess AI costs, benefits, and risks, including job impacts.

Mandates a report on the impact of biased datasets on federal AI use.

Directs the Office of Management and Budget Director to issue updated AI governance guidance within five years.

Sunsets the Act 90 days after the issuance of updated guidance.

column2: Section 106.11 Application: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance
column3: Section 106.11 Application: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance
column7: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
column15: Requires recipients to address sex-based harassment in all settings, including AI use. Clarifies institutional responsibility for controlled contexts. Confirms obligations for events and digital platforms. Deletes references to harassment outside the U.S. but maintains obligations for external conduct.
column16:
Requires recipients to address sex-based harassment within their education programs or activities, including off-campus and remote settings, aligning with recent court decisions.

Clarifies that institutions are responsible for discrimination within contexts they control, such as AI technologies used in educational settings.

Acknowledges requests for examples involving AI and other specific circumstances but declines to provide additional examples or exhaustive lists.

Confirms obligations for conduct during institution-sponsored events, online classes, and use of digital platforms, including AI technologies.

Deletes references to sex-based harassment occurring outside the U.S. but maintains the obligation to address contributing conduct external to the program or activity.

column2: Digital Social Platform Transparency Act
column3: Digital Social Platform Transparency Act
column15: Mandates digital platforms post terms of service within 180 days. Requires translation into all supported languages. Obligates semiannual reports to the Attorney General. Establishes penalties up to $15,000 daily. Creates a public report repository. Excludes certain platforms. Defines terms.
column16:
Mandates digital social companies to post terms of service for each platform within 180 days, detailing contact information, content flagging processes, and potential actions like banning or demonetization.

Requires translation of terms into all supported languages.

Obligates companies to submit semiannual terms of service reports to the Attorney General, detailing content moderation practices and AI involvement, including flagged content statistics and appeal outcomes.

Establishes penalties up to $15,000 per day for non-compliance, managed by the Attorney General, who can take legal action.

Specifies the creation of a public repository of reports for transparency.

Excludes platforms limited to direct messaging or transactions from the Act's scope and protects end-to-end encryption.

Defines key terms and grants the Attorney General interpretive authority.

Ensures Act's obligations and penalties are additional to existing laws.

column2: Consumer Literacy and Empowerment to Advance Responsible Navigation of Artificial Intelligence Act
column3: Consumers LEARN AI Act
column15: Mandates the Secretary of Commerce to develop a national AI literacy strategy and public campaign. Requires multilingual, domain-specific resources. Instructs coordination with agencies. Directs material dissemination and updates. Requires annual and GAO reports. Authorizes appropriations through 2034.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Commerce to develop a national strategy and public service campaign to enhance artificial intelligence (AI) consumer literacy.

Requires the strategy to be multilingual, promote understanding of AI capabilities and limitations, and support informed decisions on AI use.

Instructs the Secretary to coordinate with various federal agencies, local governments, and private organizations to ensure comprehensive strategy development.

Obliges the creation of specialized use cases for AI literacy in domains like healthcare, finance, and communication.

Directs the dissemination of educational materials through multiple communication channels, including a dedicated website, and mandates periodic updates to these materials.

Requires the Government Accountability Office to report on existing federal AI literacy programs and the Secretary to annually report on the strategy's progress and effectiveness.

Authorizes necessary appropriations for fiscal years 2025 through 2034 to implement the Act's activities.

column2: Department of Energy AI Act
column3: Department of Energy AI Act
column15: Establishes the "Department of Energy AI Act" to enhance AI within DOE. Requires centralized AI program creation, eight R&D centers, and risk mitigation. Allocates funds for AI education. Initiates rulemaking for grid interconnection. Requires data center impact report.
column16:
Establishes the "Department of Energy AI Act" to advance AI capabilities within the Department of Energy (DOE).

Requires the Secretary of Energy to create a centralized AI program focused on research and deployment of AI for science, security, and technology.

Mandates the development of AI training datasets, next-generation computing infrastructure, and safe AI models.

Directs the establishment of at least eight multidisciplinary AI Research and Development Centers to enhance U.S. leadership in AI.

Implements an AI Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Program to address safety and security concerns.

Allocates funds for STEM education and workforce development, emphasizing AI skill training and diversity.

Establishes a program to use AI to improve federal permitting processes for energy projects.

Initiates rulemaking to standardize AI use in grid interconnection.

Requires a report on the impact of AI on data centers and energy security.

Creates the Office of Critical and Emerging Technology to coordinate AI efforts across the DOE and assess technological impacts on national security.

column2: Richard L. Trumka Protecting the Right to Organize Act of 2023, Sec. 309 (GAO Report)
column3: Richard L. Trumka Protecting the Right to Organize Act of 2023, Sec. 309 (GAO Report)
column15: Mandates the GAO to study Sections 101(a) and 101(b)'s impact on employee coverage under the NLRA. Requires analysis of flexibility, compensation, grievance resolution, and AI use. Directs stakeholder input. Obligates public reporting. Instructs presidential consideration and potential recommendations.
column16:
Mandates the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to study the impact of Sections 101(a) and 101(b) on employee coverage under the National Labor Relations Act, focusing on union formation and collective bargaining.

Requires the study to analyze impacts on employee flexibility, compensation, grievance resolution, and technology use, including AI and algorithms.

Directs the GAO to gather input from stakeholders, including business enterprises and labor organizations, consulting relevant congressional committees.

Obliges the GAO to report its findings to the House and Senate committees six months after the study begins and make the report public.

Instructs the President, after the report's release, to consider its findings and potentially recommend modifications to Sections 101(a) or 101(b) within 60 days.

Expresses the House's intent to evaluate any presidential recommendations regarding the modifications.

column2: International Artificial Intelligence Research Partnership Act of 2024
column3: International Artificial Intelligence Research Partnership Act of 2024
column15: Establishes international AI research partnerships, encourages public-private collaboration, and requires NSF coordination. Prohibits partnerships with security-risk countries. Limits research scope, authorizes State contracts, allocates $20M annually, and mandates annual reporting to Congress.
column16:
Establishes international artificial intelligence research partnerships between U.S. cities and their international counterparts to promote AI leadership, economic cooperation, and workforce development.

Encourages public-private partnerships, including nonprofits and academic institutions, to support these AI research collaborations.

Requires coordination with the National Science Foundation to align activities with U.S. AI research priorities and leverage existing resources.

Prohibits partnerships with cities in countries deemed a national security concern or detrimental to U.S. foreign policy.

Limits research to non-national security AI areas and mandates adherence to export control regulations.

Authorizes the Secretary of State to enter contracts to facilitate partnerships and allocates $20 million annually from 2025 to 2028 for implementation.

Mandates annual reporting on partnerships, research scope, city participation, coordination efforts, and implementation challenges to relevant congressional committees.

column2: Frontier AI Safety Commitments, AI Seoul Summit 2024
column3: Frontier AI Safety Commitments, AI Seoul Summit 2024
column15: Commit organizations to responsibly develop and deploy frontier AI. Mandate safety framework publication by the AI Summit in France. Require transparency and public updates. Affirm best practices. Oblige public reporting. Prioritize societal risk research. Define clear risk management, accountability, and transparency outcomes.
column16:
Commit organisations to responsibly develop and deploy frontier AI models in line with voluntary safety commitments.

Mandate publishing a safety framework focused on severe risks by the upcoming AI Summit in France.

Require transparency on evolving safety approaches and reasons for changes through public updates.

Affirm commitment to best practices, including red-teaming, information sharing, cybersecurity, third-party issue reporting, and user awareness of AI-generated content.

Oblige public reporting on model capabilities, limitations, and appropriate use domains.

Prioritize research on societal risks and use frontier AI for global challenges.

Define Outcome 1: Organisations must identify, assess, and manage AI risks, establish risk thresholds, and implement mitigations.

Define Outcome 2: Ensure accountability through governance frameworks.

Define Outcome 3: Ensure transparency to external actors, including governments, while protecting sensitive information.

column2: S.4306, Five AIs Act 2024
column3: Five AIs Act 2024
column15: Establishes the "Five AIs Strategic Artificial Intelligence Working Group" to coordinate AI efforts among Five Eyes nations. Requires strategy development, testing, and leveraging commercial AI. Mandates reporting and knowledge control. Allows termination by September 30, 2028.
column16:
Establishes the "Five AIs Strategic Artificial Intelligence Working Group" within 90 days to coordinate AI initiatives among the Five Eyes countries (Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the UK, and the US).

Requires the Secretary of Defense and Director of National Intelligence to lead and designate a head for the Working Group.

Mandates the Working Group to develop strategies for AI interoperability, ethical frameworks, and innovation among the Five Eyes countries.

Instructs testing and evaluation of AI systems for intelligence sharing and battlespace awareness.

Emphasizes leveraging commercial AI technologies and managing data-informed AI systems.

Requires submission of a plan within 60 days and biannual reports on the Working Group's activities.

Specifies control of knowledge and technical data by individual countries under their export laws.

Allows termination of the Working Group on September 30, 2028, with possible extension for national security interests.

column2: Social Media and AI Resiliency Toolkits in Schools Act
column3: SMART in Schools Act
column15: Mandates development and updates of AI and social media impact toolkits on youth. Requires stakeholder consultation. Specifies evidence-based content on digital resilience. Directs tailored guidance inclusion. Instructs dissemination through institutions. Authorizes $2,000,000 for implementation.
column16:
Mandates the Secretaries of Education and Health and Human Services to develop and update toolkits about artificial intelligence (AI) and social media's impact on youth, focusing on mental health.

Requires consultation with various stakeholders, including students, educators, and health professionals, to create tailored toolkits for specific audiences like students, educators, healthcare providers, and parents.

Specifies that toolkits should include accessible, evidence-based information, addressing digital resilience, responsible technology use, and mental health implications.

Directs the inclusion of guidance on recognizing and managing unhealthy AI and social media use, with content tailored to audience needs and age groups.

Instructs dissemination of toolkits through educational and health institutions, including schools and community health centers.

Authorizes $2,000,000 for the implementation of these toolkits and related activities.

column2: AI Grand Challenges Act of 2024
column3: AI Grand Challenges Act of 2024
column15: Establishes the AI Grand Challenges Program for AI research via prize competitions. Requires coordination by the NSF Director. Addresses national security, health, energy, and bias. Designates AI-enabled cancer breakthroughs. Sets eligibility for U.S. entities. Obliges progress reporting.
column16:
Establishes the AI Grand Challenges Program to incentivize AI research, development, and commercialization through prize competitions.

Mandates the Director of the National Science Foundation to coordinate with federal agencies and stakeholders, consulting public input, to identify and select AI grand challenges.

Requires the program to address categories such as national security, health, energy, and AI-specific issues like bias mitigation.

Designates a specific grand challenge for AI-enabled cancer breakthroughs, mandating a minimum $10 million prize.

Sets eligibility for participants as U.S.-based entities or citizens/permanent residents, with prize amounts starting at $1 million and potentially exceeding $50 million.

Allows the Director to fund the program through contributions from various governmental and private entities, ensuring funds do not influence prize decisions.

Obligates regular reporting to Congress on the program’s progress and results, ensuring public accessibility of reports and competition information via Challenge.gov.

column2: Validation and Evaluation for Trustworthy (VET) Artificial Intelligence Act
column3: VET Artificial Intelligence Act
column15: Establishes the "VET Artificial Intelligence Act" to create voluntary AI guidelines. Mandates NIST to develop these, focusing on privacy and harm. Requires an advisory committee and a study on AI assurance capabilities. Involves stakeholder collaboration and guideline publication.
column16:
Establishes the "VET Artificial Intelligence Act" to create voluntary guidelines for the testing, evaluation, validation, and verification of AI systems, aiming to enhance trust, adoption, and governance.

Mandates the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to develop and update these guidelines, addressing consumer privacy, harm mitigation, dataset quality, and governance.

Requires the establishment of an Artificial Intelligence Assurance Qualifications Advisory Committee to provide recommendations on qualifications and accreditation for AI assurance processes.

Directs a study to evaluate the capabilities of entities conducting AI assurances, assessing their resources, methodologies, and market demand, and exploring the use of existing accredited facilities for these purposes.

Obliges the publication of guidelines and recommendations for assurance qualifications, ensuring alignment with international standards, without mandating specific technologies. 

Involves stakeholder outreach, public comment, and collaboration with various sectors to refine guidelines.

column2: AI Advancement and Reliability Act of 2024
column3: AI Advancement and Reliability Act of 2024
column15: Establishes the Center for AI Advancement and Reliability to ensure U.S. AI leadership. Requires collaboration on AI standards. Mandates Under Secretary coordination. Instructs evaluation and risk management. Creates stakeholder consortium. Prohibits regulatory use. Authorizes $10 million, sunsetting after six years.
column16:
Establishes the Center for AI Advancement and Reliability to ensure U.S. leadership in AI research, development, and evaluation.

Requires the Center to advance AI measurement science and collaborate with various sectors to develop best practices and standards for AI reliability, robustness, resilience, security, and safety.

Mandates the Under Secretary of Commerce for Standards and Technology to coordinate with federal agencies and consult broadly in establishing the Center.

Instructs the Center to evaluate AI capabilities and develop methods for risk management, including AI red teaming.

Creates a consortium of stakeholders to support the Center and the National Institute of Standards and Technology in AI-related activities.

Prohibits using shared information for regulatory purposes and confers no new regulatory authority.

Authorizes $10 million for fiscal year 2025, with a sunset provision after six years.

column2: Improving Seniors’ Timely Access to Care Act of 2024
column3: Improving Seniors’ Timely Access to Care Act of 2024
column15: Mandates Medicare Advantage plans to implement electronic prior authorization by 2027. Requires transparency and data submission by 2026. Obligates access to authorization criteria. Empowers response timeframe establishment. Tasks analysis and improvement recommendations. Directs study on AI impact.
column16:
Mandates Medicare Advantage plans, starting January 1, 2027, to implement an electronic prior authorization program for secure electronic transmission of requests and responses, excluding certain formats like facsimiles.

Requires plans, beginning January 1, 2026, to meet transparency requirements, including submitting annual data on prior authorization requests, appeals, and the use of AI technologies in decision-making.

Obligates plans to provide access to authorization criteria and documentation requirements to providers, suppliers, and enrollees upon request.

Empowers the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish response timeframes for prior authorization requests, potentially as short as 24 hours.

Tasks the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission with analyzing and reporting on prior authorization use and recommending improvements.

Directs the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to study and report on real-time decision processes and the impact of AI on patient access, especially for rural and low-income beneficiaries.

column2: Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Securing AI Task Force Act
column3: CISA Securing AI Task Force Act
column15: Establishes a Task Force for AI safety within the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency. Requires coordination, collaboration, and assessment of AI safety efforts. Promotes secure AI adoption. Ensures privacy standards. Mandates biannual congressional briefings. Sunsets after 5 years.
column16:
Establishes a Task Force within the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency to coordinate efforts related to AI safety and security.

Requires coordination of Agency efforts to improve the safe and secure design, development, adoption, and deployment of AI.

Ensures Agency collaboration in interagency and nongovernment AI-related initiatives.

Mandates assessment and evaluation of Agency safety initiatives to address AI challenges.

Leverages expertise to use AI in defending against cyber threats.

Coordinates efforts to advise stakeholders on AI-related cyber risks.

Identifies AI workforce gaps and proposes solutions.

Promotes secure adoption of AI-based software.

Recommends new initiatives for AI safety and security.

Ensures AI efforts meet privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties standards.

Supports publication and accuracy of the Agency’s AI use inventory.

Mandates biannual briefings to Congress on Task Force activities.

Sunsets the Act 5 years after enactment.

column2: Unleashing AI Innovation in Financial Services Act
column3: Unleashing AI Innovation in Financial Services Act
column15: Establishes regulatory sandboxes for financial AI test projects. Requires application detailing compliance and benefits. Mandates risk assessments. Obligates 90-day application review. Allows joint applications. Stipulates data security. Directs regulation promulgation. Mandates annual Congress reporting. Permits additional projects after consultation.
column16:
Establishes regulatory sandboxes allowing financial entities to experiment with AI test projects under reduced regulatory burdens.

Requires financial entities to apply for sandbox participation by detailing their AI project, compliance strategies, and potential public benefits.

Mandates applications include risk assessments for systemic financial stability and national security.

Obligates financial regulatory agencies to review applications within 90 days, with provisions for approval, denial, or extension.

Allows joint applications by multiple entities and necessitates notification to all relevant regulatory bodies.

Stipulates data security measures for information provided by AI project sponsors.

Directs each financial regulatory agency to promulgate regulations, including modification procedures and confidentiality protocols, within 180 days of the Act’s enactment.

Mandates annual reporting to Congress on AI test project outcomes.

Permits regulatory agencies to establish additional AI projects as qualifying test projects after public consultation.

column2: Veterans Online Information and Cybersecurity Empowerment Act of 2024
column3: VOICE Act of 2024
column15: Establishes a grant program to promote digital citizenship and media literacy among veterans. Requires recipients to develop cybersecurity practices and report effectiveness. Obligates Secretary to report to Congress. Authorizes $20 million funding. Defines key terms, encourages communication, and acknowledges foreign influence threats.
column16:
Establishes a grant program to promote digital citizenship and media literacy among veterans, requiring the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to award grants to eligible entities.

Mandates grant recipients to develop cybersecurity best practices and improve veterans' competencies in digital and media literacy.

Requires grant recipients to submit a report on their activities and effectiveness one year after receiving funds.

Obliges the Secretary to report to Congress on the program's overall activities and effectiveness after receiving the last report from grant recipients.

Authorizes $20 million in appropriations for fiscal years 2023, 2025, and 2027 to fund the program.

Defines key terms such as "cybersecurity best practices," "digital citizenship," "media literacy," and "eligible entity."

Encourages the Secretary to maintain a list of grant recipients and promote communication among them.

Acknowledges the role of foreign influence campaigns and online scams targeting veterans as critical issues that need addressing.

column2: AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024
column3: AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024
column15: Enacts the "AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024." Requires AI-generated political ads to include disclaimers. Mandates FEC to regulate within 90 days. Imposes fines up to $50,000 for non-compliance. Includes severability clause for unconstitutional provisions.
column16:
Enacts the "AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024."

Requires disclaimers on political advertisements with content generated by AI, defining "covered communications" and "substantially generated by artificial intelligence."

Mandates clear disclosure in ads using AI-generated images, audio, or video, specifying format requirements for visibility and audibility.

Imposes penalties for non-compliance, with fines up to $50,000 per violation, considering factors like previous violations and distribution scope.

Defines "qualified disclaimer requirement" and expedites judicial review for related complaints.

Obliges the Federal Election Commission (FEC) to issue regulations within 90 days, outlining criteria for AI content identification and statement requirements.

Applies provisions to communications post-enactment, regardless of FEC regulation status.

Requires FEC to report biannually on compliance and enforcement, providing recommendations for improvements.

Includes a severability clause ensuring the act's continuity if parts are deemed unconstitutional.

column2: Atomic Supply Chain Solutions Act
column3: Atomic Supply Chain Solutions Act
column15: Mandates evaluation of U.S. nuclear supply chain, including past efforts and future needs. Analyzes regulatory challenges and considers advanced technologies. Describes U.S.-Canada cooperation. Assesses demand impact. Establishes policy prioritizing HALEU market for energy independence.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Energy to evaluate the U.S. nuclear supply chain within 270 days, including past efforts, future needs, and lessons from projects like Vogtle 3 and 4.

Analyzes regulatory challenges, including the necessity of N-stamps for nuclear components, cost implications, and potential certification streamlining.

Considers advanced manufacturing and innovative technologies like AI, 3D printing, and robotics for enhancing the nuclear supply chain, with attention to cybersecurity, efficiency, and workforce training.

Describes U.S.-Canada cooperation on nuclear components, assessing competitiveness and recommending collaboration to enhance North American nuclear leadership.

Assesses the impact of anticipated demand for advanced nuclear technology on the supply chain, proposing strategies for resilience.

Establishes U.S. policy to prioritize a robust HALEU market to strengthen energy independence and national security, addressing risks associated with increased nuclear technology demand.

column2: Preventing the Algorithmic Facilitation of Rental Housing Cartels Act of 2024
column3: Preventing the Algorithmic Facilitation of Rental Housing Cartels Act of 2024
column15: Prohibits rental property owners from algorithmic price coordination. Bars coordinators from non-competitive agreements and anti-competitive acquisitions. Empowers enforcement by FTC and legal authorities. Allows treble damages for injured parties. Clarifies non-preemption of local laws. Ensures severability.
column16:
Prohibits rental property owners from using coordinators for algorithmic price coordination, deeming such actions per se violations of the Sherman Act.

Prohibits coordinators from facilitating non-competitive agreements among rental property owners or performing coordinating functions.

Prohibits coordinators from acquiring another coordinator if it lessens competition, violating the Clayton Act.

Empowers the Federal Trade Commission, the Attorney General, and State Attorneys General to enforce the Act with the same powers and duties as the FTC Act, Sherman Act, and Clayton Act.

Allows civil actions by injured persons to recover treble damages and litigation costs, with the option to invalidate pre-dispute arbitration agreements.

Clarifies that the Act does not preempt State, Tribal, or local laws that supplement its provisions.

Ensures severability of the Act if any provision is deemed unconstitutional, maintaining the effectiveness of remaining provisions.

column2: American Privacy Rights Act of 2024, Sec. 114-5
column3: American Privacy Rights Act of 2024, Sec. 114-5
column15: Establishes a pilot program for privacy-enhancing technologies within one year. Requires auditing and compliance checks. Allows legal compliance presumption. Obligates progress study by Comptroller General. Creates FTC bureau for enforcement. Establishes relief fund and mandates FTC reporting.
column16:
Establishes a pilot program to encourage private sector use of privacy-enhancing technologies within one year of the Act's enactment to protect covered data.

Requires the Commission to develop a petition process for entities to join the pilot program and implement an auditing system using privacy-enhancing technologies for enforcement purposes.

Mandates ongoing audits of participating entities to ensure compliance with privacy-enhancing technologies.

Allows covered entities deemed compliant to be considered in compliance with section 109, with a rebuttable presumption in certain legal actions.

Obligates the Comptroller General to study the pilot program's progress and effectiveness, with an initial briefing and a final report to Congress.

Creates a new bureau within the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to enforce the title with experts, including technologists experienced with AI.

Establishes a Privacy and Security Victims Relief Fund for consumer redress and technological research.

Requires the FTC to report to Congress on investigations and future plans related to the title.

column2: State Industrial Competitiveness Act of 2024
column3: State Industrial Competitiveness Act of 2024
column15: Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to establish the Flex-Tech Energy Program. Requires financial assistance for flex-tech programs, including AI. Mandates energy studies. Allocates 5% for Indian Tribes. Caps expenses. Encourages mixed financing. Authorizes $100 million annually.
column16:
Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to establish the Flex-Tech Energy Program aimed at enhancing manufacturing competitiveness.

Requires the Secretary to provide financial assistance to State energy agencies or Indian Tribes for developing and implementing flex-tech programs, including measures related to advanced manufacturing technologies and artificial intelligence.

Mandates that energy studies of manufacturing facilities evaluate systems, emissions, and potential efficiency measures, including AI applications.

Allocates at least 5% of funds specifically for Indian Tribes or manufacturers in Indian Country.

Limits financial assistance usage, capping administrative expenses at 10% and individual facility funding at $100,000 or 5% of total assistance.

Encourages the use of both public and private financing in program implementation.

Authorizes $100 million annually from 2025 to 2029 for the program.

column2: Supercritical Geothermal Research and Development Act
column3: Supercritical Geothermal Research and Development Act
column15: Amends the Energy Independence and Security Act to include machine learning in geothermal R&D. Establishes programs, data repositories, and a center of excellence. Authorizes $5 million annually (2026-2030). Requires progress reports and updates assessments quadrennially.
column16:
Amends the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 to include machine learning algorithms in geothermal research and development.

Establishes a supercritical geothermal research and development program within the Geothermal Technologies Office, focusing on well completion, permeability, materials, sensors, and water-rock geochemistry.

Requires the creation of a repository for geothermal data, with periodic updates for data standardization and accessibility.

Mandates a memorandum of understanding for data sharing regarding geothermal development among federal departments.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior to drill deep exploration boreholes for geothermal mapping.

Establishes a next-generation geothermal center of excellence to coordinate research, development, and workforce initiatives.

Authorizes $5 million annually from 2026 to 2030 for these activities.

Updates geothermal resource assessments quadrennially to include supercritical geothermal regions.

Requires progress reports on geothermal resource potential and commercialization barriers.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Acquisitions Act of 2024
column3: Artificial Intelligence Acquisitions Act of 2024
column15: Mandates creating a list of AI products posing security risks, updated annually. Prohibits federal agency procurement of listed items. Obligates contractor divestment. Allows intelligence exceptions. Defines key terms. Sets timeline for publication within one year.
column16:
Mandates the development of a list of artificial intelligence products or services posing national security risks, focusing on those associated with foreign entities of concern.

Requires the Executive Director, alongside the Under Secretary of Commerce and the Federal Acquisition Security Council, to publish and annually update this list.

Prohibits federal agencies from purchasing or procuring AI products or services included on this list.

Obligates contractors with federal agencies to divest from listed AI products within specified timeframes.

Allows exceptions for intelligence activities and specific Department of Defense operations related to defense intelligence and adversarial AI research.

Defines key terms including "artificial intelligence," "foreign person of concern," and "country of concern," specifying entities like China, Russia, and Iran as countries of concern.

Sets a timeline for initial list publication within one year of the Act's enactment and mandates public notification if no updates are made annually.

column2: AI Innovation and Development for Efficiency Act of 2024
column3: AI Innovation and Development for Efficiency Act of 2024
column15: Mandates NSF Director to support AI research on efficient technologies. Requires impact assessments and prioritizes EPSCoR institutions. Directs reporting within 18 months and a results report within four years to relevant committees.
column16:
Mandates the National Science Foundation Director to support research on AI-enabled efficient technologies through merit-reviewed and competitively awarded projects.

Requires consideration of projects focusing on smart technologies for infrastructure efficiency, pollution minimization, and upgrading existing constructions.

Obliges researchers to conduct impact assessments of energy consumption for AI-enabled technologies.

Prioritizes research conducted at EPSCoR institutions.

Directs the Director to report findings and recommendations on research opportunities and coordination with federal agencies and the private sector within 18 months of enactment.

Requires a report on research results within four years to relevant Senate and House committees.

column2: Small Business Artificial Intelligence Training Act of 2024
column3: Small Business Artificial Intelligence Training Act of 2024
column15: Mandates development of AI training resources for small businesses. Requires coverage of key topics and annual updates. Coordinates distribution with the Small Business Administration. Allows grants for training providers. Demands annual reports. Establishes program termination after three years.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Commerce, in coordination with various agencies, to develop AI training resources for small businesses, including those in rural, Tribal, or underserved areas.

Requires these resources to cover topics such as prompt engineering, financial management, cybersecurity, and government contracting.

Obligates the review and update of these resources every year to ensure relevance and effectiveness.

Coordinates with the Small Business Administration for the distribution of these resources through its network, including development centers and business opportunity centers.

Allows for a grants program to fund training providers using the developed resources.

Demands initial and annual reports to Congress on the progress and impact of the training resources.

Establishes a sunset clause terminating the program three years after the Act's enactment.

column2: Tools to Address Known Exploitation by Immobilizing Technological Deepfakes on Websites and Networks Act
column3: TAKE IT DOWN Act
column15: Amends the Communications Act to criminalize nonconsensual intimate deepfakes. Requires platforms to remove depictions within 48 hours. Limits liability for good faith removals. Grants FTC enforcement authority. Defines terms including "deepfake" and "covered platform."
column16:
Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to criminalize the intentional disclosure of nonconsensual intimate visual depictions, including those created using AI-generated deepfakes, when intended to cause harm or when involving minors.

Requires covered platforms to establish a notice and removal process for such depictions, mandating removal within 48 hours upon valid request.

Limits liability for platforms acting in good faith to remove nonconsensual depictions.

Grants enforcement authority to the Federal Trade Commission to treat violations as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act.

Defines key terms, including "deepfake" and "covered platform," specifying platforms that primarily provide user-generated content and excluding certain services like email and non-user-generated content sites.

column2: S.4862, A bill to ensure that new advances in artificial intelligence are ethically adopted to improve the health of all individuals, and for other purposes.
column3: S.4862, A bill to ensure that new advances in artificial intelligence are ethically adopted to improve the health of all individuals, and for other purposes.
column15: Amends the Public Health Service Act to mandate NIH AI resources and datasets. Authorizes $400 million for NIH AI initiatives. Directs health IT standards and interoperability. Appropriates funds for data collection. Requires patient consent for record use. Mandates data-sharing facilities.
column16:
Amends the Public Health Service Act to mandate the NIH Director develop AI resources and datasets for health research, provide AI expertise, and maintain data access resources.

Authorizes $400 million for NIH AI initiatives in fiscal year 2025.

Directs the National Coordinator for Health IT to utilize electronic health records for research, establish data standards, and align with national interoperability frameworks.

Appropriates $10 million for data collection and $50 million for data standards.

Requires hospitals to request patient consent to use health records for research, contingent upon patient approval.

Expresses the Senate's view that NIH representation is crucial in steering committees for national AI research resources.

Mandates the National Library of Medicine to establish data-sharing facilities and create a core data science program.

Appropriates $100 million each for these library initiatives in fiscal year 2025.

column2: Sec. 103, Supporting Affordability and Fairness with Every Bet Act
column3: Sec. 103, Supporting Affordability and Fairness with Every Bet Act
column15: Prohibits AI use for tracking, targeting, and product creation. Requires data security and real-time data sharing. Imposes consumer protections and licensing standards. Mandates cooperation with investigations. Prohibits certain advertising and enforces contest integrity restrictions.
column16:
Prohibits sports wagering operators from using artificial intelligence to track individual wagers, target specific individuals with offers or promotions, or create gambling products like microbets.

Requires sports wagering operators to ensure data security and to take reasonable steps to prevent unauthorized access or dissemination of wagering and customer data.

Mandates real-time or near-real-time sharing of anonymized sports wagering data with the State regulatory entity.

Imposes strict consumer protections, including restrictions on AI use, limits on deposits, and mandatory affordability checks for high-value wagers.

Establishes comprehensive standards for licensing, recordkeeping, and employee background checks to ensure the integrity and accountability of sports wagering operators.

Requires cooperation with investigations by regulatory authorities and sports organizations, and mandates robust internal controls for operators.

Prohibits advertising targeting problem gamblers or individuals ineligible to wager, and restricts broadcast times and content. 

Enforces restrictions to maintain contest integrity and prevent betting on certain events and by prohibited individuals.

column2: Fraudulent Artificial Intelligence Regulations (FAIR) Elections Act of 2024
column3: Fraudulent Artificial Intelligence Regulations (FAIR) Elections Act of 2024
column15: Prohibits distributing false AI-generated election media and depictions to impede voting or intimidate officials. Exempts bona fide news with disclosure. Empowers Attorney General for enforcement. Amends voter registration laws to require verified data. Ensures severability of provisions.
column16:
Prohibits the distribution of false AI-generated election media containing materially false information about election details or voter eligibility with the intent to impede voting in federal elections.

Prohibits the distribution of false AI-generated depictions of election officials intended to intimidate or harass officials or deter voting.

Exempts bona fide news entities from these prohibitions if they clearly disclose the falsity of the AI-generated content.

Empowers the Attorney General to enforce these prohibitions through civil actions in U.S. District Courts.

Amends the National Voter Registration Act to prevent states from using unverified databases to remove voters from official lists, requiring government-verified information approved by the Attorney General.

Sets criteria for source information, including monthly updates and non-violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

Ensures severability of the Act’s provisions, maintaining the validity of remaining sections if any part is invalidated.

column2: Protecting Patients from Deceptive Drug Ads Online Act
column3: Protecting Patients from Deceptive Drug Ads Online Act
column15: Amends the Act to penalize false drug claims by influencers and healthcare providers. Mandates guidance on communication compliance. Expands telehealth provider definition. Requires promotion payment reporting. Authorizes AI surveillance. Allocates funding. Establishes notification process. Ensures severability.
column16:
Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to impose civil penalties on social media influencers and healthcare providers who make false or misleading communications about prescription drugs.

Mandates the issuance of guidance within 180 days to define false or misleading communications and outline compliance procedures.

Expands the definition of "manufacturer, packer, or distributor" to include telehealth providers involved in drug advertising.

Requires reporting of payments related to drug promotion to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

Authorizes market surveillance activities using AI to monitor prescription drug promotions on social media and coordinate efforts with the Federal Trade Commission.

Allocates $15 million annually for fiscal years 2025 to 2029 to support these activities.

Establishes a process for notifying drug manufacturers of non-compliant communications by influencers or healthcare providers.

Ensures the severability of the Act's provisions, maintaining validity even if parts are invalidated.

column2: Forecasting Optimization for Robust Earth Climate Analysis and Subseasonal-to-Seasonal Tracking Act of 2024
column3: FORECASTS Tracking Act of 2024
column15: Amends the Food Security Act to enhance weather forecasting by requiring NOAA to improve research and modeling. Mandates multi-model systems and an Internet clearinghouse. Establishes a workforce program emphasizing AI. Requires a workforce plan. Authorizes funding.
column16:
Amends the Food Security Act of 1985 to improve subseasonal-to-seasonal weather forecasting by requiring the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to enhance research, data collection, and model development.

Mandates the development of multi-model ensemble forecast systems and data management strategies, and the operationalization of new modeling technologies.

Establishes an Internet clearinghouse for forecasts and related information.

Creates the Weather and Earth System Modeling and Data Assimilation Workforce Innovation Program to support education, recruitment, and workforce development in weather modeling and data assimilation, emphasizing artificial intelligence and machine learning.

Requires the Under Secretary to develop and update a workforce human capital plan and report on the program's effectiveness.

Authorizes appropriations for these initiatives, including $40 million annually from 2025 to 2030 for the workforce program and additional funding for NOAA's weather research activities.

column2: Detection Equipment and Technology Evaluation to Counter the Threat of Fentanyl and Xylazine Act of 2024
column3: DETECT Fentanyl and Xylazine Act of 2024
column15: Amends the Homeland Security Act to enhance drug detection using advanced technologies. Mandates R&D for minimal handling equipment. Incorporates AI for substance prediction. Requires adherence to NIST AI Framework. Ensures law enforcement access to improved technologies.
column16:
Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enhance the detection and disruption of drugs like fentanyl and xylazine using advanced technologies.

Mandates research and development of equipment for drug detection and trafficking disruption, emphasizing minimal handling and separation of complex mixtures.

Incorporates machine learning and artificial intelligence to predict controlled substance analogues and new psychoactive substances.

Requires the Under Secretary for Science and Technology to adhere to the NIST AI Risk Management Framework or its successor.

Establishes research and evaluation priorities using the latest information from reports on drug threats by the Drug Enforcement Administration.

Ensures federal, state, local, tribal, and territorial law enforcement agencies have access to improved detection technologies.

column2: Technology in the Parks Act of 2024
column3: Technology in the Parks Act of 2024
column15: Amends the Communications Act to extend E-rate support to local parks. Requires internet safety regulations and allows equipment transfers. Mandates a grant program for technology training, covering up to 10% of costs, targeting vulnerable individuals. Defines "covered local park."
column16:
Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to extend E-rate support to local parks, allowing them to access discounted telecommunications services for technology training programs.

Requires the creation of internet safety regulations for parks receiving such services to ensure cybersecurity standards similar to those for schools and libraries.

Defines "covered local park" as one that contracts with entities for technology training programs funded by grants.

Permits the transfer of excess research equipment to local parks under the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act.

Mandates the Secretary of Labor to initiate a grant program for technology training in local parks, focusing on skills like coding, cybersecurity, and artificial intelligence.

Specifies that grants cover up to 10% of program costs and must supplement existing funds.

Targets vulnerable individuals, including those receiving unemployment benefits or other social assistance, for participation in these training programs.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Bug Bounty Act of 2023
column3: Artificial Intelligence Bug Bounty Act of 2023
column15: Mandates development of a bug bounty program for AI products within 180 days. Allows collaboration with other agencies. Authorizes implementation. Ensures contract participation. Clarifies non-mandatory use of AI products. Requires briefing to congressional defense committees within one year.
column16:
Mandates the Chief Data and Artificial Intelligence Officer of the Department of Defense to develop a bug bounty program for AI products within 180 days of enactment.

Allows collaboration with other government agencies possessing cybersecurity and AI expertise during program development.

Authorizes the implementation of the developed bug bounty program.

Ensures that Department of Defense contracts permit participation in the bug bounty program.

Clarifies that the use of foundational AI products or the implementation of the program is not mandatory for incorporating such products.

Requires the Chief to brief congressional defense committees within one year on the development, implementation, and long-term plans of relevant bug bounty programs.

column2: AI Development Practices Act of 2024
column3: AI Development Practices Act of 2024
column15: Amends the NIST Act to develop voluntary AI guidelines. Mandates collaboration on AI risk and system characteristics. Requires categorization of AI practices. Obligates framework updates. Prohibits prescribing technologies. Demands a congressional report. Defines key AI terms.
column16:
Amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to require the development of voluntary guidelines for AI system development, release, and assessment.

Mandates the Director of NIST to collaborate with public and private organizations to create guidance on AI risk tolerances and communication of system characteristics.

Requires categorization of practices related to security, safety, fairness, privacy, and other attributes of AI systems.

Obligates the Director to update the voluntary risk management framework for trustworthy AI systems.

Prohibits prescribing specific technologies; mandates reliance on international standards and industry best practices.

Requires collaboration with public, industry, and academic entities for guidance development.

Demands a report to Congress within 18 months on new materials or systems produced and policy recommendations for private-public sector coordination.

Defines "artificial intelligence red teaming" and "artificial intelligence system" for clarity.

column2: Maintaining Innovation and Safe Technologies Act
column3: Maintaining Innovation and Safe Technologies Act
column15: Directs issuing guidance by January 1, 2026, on Medicare payment for AI-incorporated remote monitoring devices under part B of the Social Security Act. Mandates device information transmission to healthcare providers for management and treatment to qualify.
column16:
Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue guidance by January 1, 2026, on Medicare payment requirements under part B of title XVIII of the Social Security Act for remote monitoring devices.

Mandates that the guidance specifically address devices that incorporate artificial intelligence components, such as continuous adjustment features.

Requires that these devices must transmit information to healthcare providers for the management and treatment of individuals to qualify for payment.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Allied Collaboration for Crucial Operations, Research, and Development Act of 2024
column3: AI ACCORD Act of 2024
column15: Mandates the Secretary of Defense to submit a strategy to Congress in 180 days for enhancing cooperation with Middle Eastern allies. Directs the establishment of a forum for AI coordination. Obligates progress reporting and legislative recommendations within one year.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Defense to submit a strategy to Congress within 180 days to enhance cooperation with Middle Eastern allies using partner-sharing network capabilities for joint defense.

Requires the strategy to include a summary of ongoing efforts, challenges, and recommended actions for implementing joint partner-sharing networks.

Directs the Chief Data and Artificial Intelligence Officer of the Department of Defense to establish a forum for warfighters to coordinate on AI tools, methodologies, and training within 180 days.

Specifies that the forum should identify AI use cases, categorize risks, and prioritize AI tools while considering training shortfalls and opportunities for cooperation with allies.

Obligates the Secretary of Defense to report progress on the forum's establishment and recommend legislative actions to Congress within one year.

column2: Literacy in Future Technologies Artificial Intelligence Act
column3: LIFT AI Act
column15: Establishes the "LIFT AI Act" to enhance K–12 AI literacy. Empowers NSF to grant funds for curriculum development. Mandates AI education for workforce readiness. Engages stakeholders in professional learning. Develops evaluation tools and courses. Encourages responsible AI use.
column16:
Establishes the "LIFT AI Act" to advance AI literacy in K–12 education.

Empowers the Director of the National Science Foundation to award competitive grants to higher education institutions or nonprofits for developing AI literacy curricula and evaluation methods.

Mandates AI literacy education to prepare a skilled workforce and maintain U.S. leadership in AI.

Recognizes the importance of AI literacy in mitigating ethical challenges and adapting to rapidly evolving AI technologies.

Supports curriculum development focused on essential AI abilities and competencies, including project-based, personalized learning.

Engages educational stakeholders in professional learning to enhance AI literacy and establish best practices.

Develops evaluation tools for assessing AI literacy proficiency.

Designs professional development courses for educators integrating various learning experiences.

Encourages incorporating AI literacy in existing curricula, emphasizing responsible AI use.

column2: NSF and USDA Interagency Research Act
column3: NSF and USDA Interagency Research Act
column15: Mandates collaborative AI and digital agriculture research by the Secretary of Agriculture and NSF. Requires memoranda for coordination. Permits key area research. Encourages data sharing. Supports infrastructure. Facilitates partnerships. Authorizes reimbursable agreements. Ensures security per CHIPS Act.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Agriculture and the Director of the National Science Foundation to conduct collaborative research and development activities, including those involving artificial intelligence and digital agriculture, to advance their mission priorities.

Requires the establishment of memoranda of understanding to coordinate these activities through competitive, merit-based processes.

Permits collaborative research in key areas, such as AI, machine learning, automation, and digital agriculture.

Encourages data sharing and collaboration among federal agencies, educational institutions, and nonprofit entities.

Supports research infrastructure and the development of translational technologies for commercial use.

Facilitates public-private partnerships and awards grants to educational institutions to establish a Center for Agricultural Research, Education, and Workforce Development.

Authorizes reimbursable agreements to enhance research effectiveness and mandates a report to Congress on interagency coordination and future collaboration opportunities.

Ensures research security consistent with the CHIPS Act of 2022.

column2: PATHS Act
column3: PATHS Act
column15: Extends the Homeland Security Act pilot program to 2027. Mandates briefing Congress within 72 hours on AI transaction authority use. Reduces contract award threshold from $4 million to $1 million under the 2023 Defense Authorization Act.
column16:
Extends the research and development acquisition pilot program under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to September 30, 2027.

Mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security to notify and brief Congress within 72 hours regarding the use or extension of transaction authority involving artificial intelligence technology.

Reduces the threshold for covered contract awards from $4,000,000 to $1,000,000 under the James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023.

column2: Lummis-Gillibrand Payment Stablecoin Act (Sec. 1-3)
column3: Lummis-Gillibrand Payment Stablecoin Act (Sec. 1-3)
column15: Prohibits unregistered creation of algorithmic payment stablecoins in the U.S. Mandates issuance by registered entities only. Requires U.S. residency for offering stablecoins. Adjusts issuance threshold every four years. Establishes safe harbor regulations. Extends extraterritorially.
column16:
Prohibits any person from issuing, creating, or originating an algorithmic payment stablecoin in the United States.

Mandates that payment stablecoins can only be issued by a registered non-depository trust company with a limit on nominal value or an authorized depository institution as a national payment stablecoin issuer.

Prohibits the offer or sale of payment stablecoins in the United States except by a U.S. person living in the U.S.

Requires the Board to adjust the issuance threshold for inflation every four years.

Directs the Board to establish safe harbor regulations, allowing limited issuance of payment stablecoins under specific conditions and fostering innovation and competition.

Allows safe harbor status for issuers regulated by equivalent foreign authorities.

Intends the section to have extraterritorial effect, extending its reach beyond U.S. borders.

column2: National Windstorm Impact Reduction Program Reauthorization Act of 2024
column3: National Windstorm Impact Reduction Program Reauthorization Act of 2024
column15: Amends the National Windstorm Impact Reduction Act to include climate variability. Supports machine learning in windstorm mitigation. Encourages interdisciplinary research. Promotes advanced construction methods. Mandates tornado research analysis. Requires public response research. Allocates funding. Sets report deadlines.
column16:
Amends the National Windstorm Impact Reduction Act of 2004 to include provisions for understanding climate variability and its impact on windstorms, aiming to inform future building codes.

Supports the integration of emerging technologies, such as machine learning, in research and engineering activities related to windstorm mitigation.

Encourages interdisciplinary research, including collaborations between social scientists and engineers, to enhance atmospheric measurements relevant to building engineering.

Promotes the use of advanced construction methods and materials to strengthen properties against windstorms and related impacts.

Mandates an analysis of the need for a tornado research facility to study tornado impacts on buildings.

Requires research into public response to windstorm risks and factors influencing risk communication and reduction measures.

Allocates specific funding amounts for the program from fiscal years 2025 to 2029.

Sets deadlines for reports and analyses, including future research infrastructure needs, to be completed by specified dates.

column2: Small Business Artificial Intelligence Advancement Act
column3: Small Business Artificial Intelligence Advancement Act
column15: Amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to mandate AI resources for small businesses. Requires resources to include standards, practices, and case studies. Obligates biennial updates and coordination with the Small Business Administration. Compels a Congressional report within four years.
column16:
Amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to mandate the development and dissemination of AI resources for small businesses.

Requires these resources to include technical standards, best practices, benchmarks, methodologies, and case studies, ensuring they are widely applicable and technology-neutral.

Mandates that resources promote understanding and adoption of AI, adhere to international standards, and incorporate federal educational resources.

Obligates the Director to review and update these resources every two years.

Coordinates with the Small Business Administration for the distribution and utilization of AI resources through its partners, emphasizing voluntary use.

Compels a report to Congress within four years, detailing resources, feedback, and recommendations for enhancing AI utilization by small businesses.

column2: H.R. 9626, To direct the Department of Defense to develop a plan for the establishment of a secure computing and data storage environment for the testing of artificial intelligence trained on biological data, and for other purposes.
column3: H.R. 9626, DOD Secure Computing and Data Storage Plan Development
column15: Mandates the Under Secretary to develop the AIxBio sandbox for testing AI on biological data. Utilizes existing infrastructure. Selects defense-related projects. Establishes collaboration mechanisms. Obligates reporting to Congress within one year.
column16:
Mandates the Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering to develop a plan for a secure computing and data storage environment, termed the "AIxBio sandbox," to facilitate the testing of AI models trained on biological data.

Requires the AIxBio sandbox to utilize existing Department of Defense infrastructure when feasible and designates the Under Secretary of Defense for managing and overseeing its activities.

Directs the Under Secretary to select projects for the sandbox that demonstrate potential defense applications at the intersection of AI and biotechnology, such as medical countermeasures and biomanufacturing.

Establishes mechanisms for collaboration between Department of Defense laboratories and academic institutions to support AIxBio projects, with streamlined processes for efficient partnerships.

Obligates the Under Secretary to report and brief Congress on the plan within one year of the Act's enactment.

column2: Expanding AI Voices Act
column3: Expanding AI Voices Act
column15: Amends the National AI Initiative Act to expand AI capacity. Mandates competitive awards for eligible institutions. Specifies eligibility for certain colleges. Encourages collaborations. Allows diverse fund uses. Requires outreach. Ensures project complementarity. Considers diversity and resources in decisions.
column16:
Amends the National AI Initiative Act by introducing a new subsection focused on expanding AI capacity.

Mandates the Director of the National Science Foundation to competitively award eligible higher education institutions and nonprofit organizations to enhance AI research, education, and workforce development.

Specifies eligibility for institutions not among the top 100 in federal R&D spending, historically Black colleges, minority-serving institutions, Tribal colleges, and their consortia.

Encourages collaborations with various stakeholders, including AI research institutes and private sector entities.

Allows use of funds for AI research programs, faculty development, resource access, community building, workshops, and ethical AI education.

Requires outreach to eligible entities, emphasizing underserved and underrepresented communities.

Ensures awarded projects complement existing programs without duplication.

Considers diversity, geographic distribution, and resource constraints in award decisions.

column2: Bureau of Industry and Security Information Technology Modernization Act
column3: BIS IT Modernization Act
column15: Mandates the Bureau of Industry and Security to integrate AI into export control processes, automate data sharing, and modernize IT systems for enhanced security. Authorizes $25 million annually from 2025 to 2028. Requires reassessment of staffing and consultation with Congress.
column16:
Mandates the Bureau of Industry and Security to adopt advanced data fusion, analytics, and AI capabilities to enhance export control processes and identify evasive trade patterns.

Requires the integration of AI and machine learning into Bureau IT systems to improve decision-making and enforce export controls effectively.

Obligates the Bureau to automate and streamline data sharing with industry, federal agencies, and international partners.

Demands the modernization of IT systems to support seamless data management, enhance security, and facilitate the use of cutting-edge technology.

Stipulates objectives for technology adoption, including productivity enhancement, cost reduction, and improved user experience for U.S. exporters.

Instructs the Under Secretary to reassess staffing needs and consult Congress on personnel adjustments during the modernization.

Authorizes $25 million annually from 2025 to 2028 for these initiatives.

column2: Workforce for AI Trust Act
column3: Workforce for AI Trust Act
column15: Amends the National AI Initiative Act to authorize NSF to support interdisciplinary AI fellowships. Mandates outreach to underrepresented groups. Directs AI training promotion. Requires diverse perspectives in peer reviews. Instructs NIST on AI workforce education and risk management standards.
column16:
Amends the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020 to authorize the National Science Foundation (NSF) to support interdisciplinary AI fellowships, encouraging ethical AI practices.

Mandates the NSF to conduct outreach to diverse institutions and groups underrepresented in STEM fields for fellowship applicants.

Directs the NSF to promote AI-based training and workshops across STEM fields to accelerate scientific discovery and technology development.

Requires the integration of diverse disciplinary perspectives in AI research peer review panels.

Instructs the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to support education and workforce development to expand the AI governance workforce, focusing on managing AI-related risks.

Mandates NIST to develop technical standards and guidance for AI risk management careers, including mapping, measuring, and validating AI systems.

column2: Nucleic Acid Standards for Biosecurity Act
column3: Nucleic Acid Standards for Biosecurity Act
column15: Amends the Act to include AI-related best practices. Requires measurement research for biosecurity. Mandates testing for screening accuracy. Directs technical guidance development. Establishes a consortium for best practices. Requires reporting to Congress. Authorizes $5 million annually until 2029.
