column16:
Amends the Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act to include best practices and technical standards for managing risks in engineering biology and biomanufacturing, specifically addressing artificial intelligence.

Requires the Director, in consultation with Federal agencies, to conduct measurement research supporting biosecurity measures related to nucleic acid synthesis.

Mandates testing to improve screening accuracy, efficacy, and reliability, along with best practices for operational security and database management.

Directs the development of technical guidance for effective and secure screening and conformity-assessment standards.

Establishes a consortium of stakeholders to develop and update best practices and roadmaps for synthetic nucleic acid procurement screening.

Requires the consortium to report its findings to Congress within 18 months of its first meeting.

Authorizes $5,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2025 through 2029 for scientific and technical research activities under this initiative.

column2: AI Grand Challenges Act of 2024
column3: AI Grand Challenges Act of 2024
column15: Establishes the AI Grand Challenges Program for prize competitions in sectors like national security, health, and environment. Requires NSF Director oversight. Mandates AI cancer challenge. Sets participant criteria. Allows diverse funding and high prize amounts. Requires congressional reporting.
column16:
Establishes the AI Grand Challenges Program to stimulate AI research, development, and commercialization through prize competitions addressing grand challenges in various sectors like national security, health, and environment.

Requires the Director of the National Science Foundation, in coordination with other federal agencies, to oversee the program and consult with public and private entities.

Mandates the creation of a specific grand challenge for AI-enabled cancer breakthroughs, with prize awards of at least $10,000,000.

Sets eligibility criteria for participants, requiring private entities to be U.S.-based and individuals to be U.S. citizens or permanent residents.

Allows for substantial prize amounts, with minimum awards of $1,000,000 and potential for awards exceeding $50,000,000.

Permits funding from various governmental and non-governmental sources and mandates reporting to Congress on the program's progress and outcomes.

Ensures prize competitions are publicly accessible via Challenge.gov.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Public Awareness and Education Campaign Act
column3: Artificial Intelligence Public Awareness and Education Campaign Act
column15: Mandates a public AI awareness campaign. Requires evaluation metrics and baseline data. Facilitates AI knowledge exchange and best practices detection. Conducts public outreach, targeting vulnerable groups. Promotes AI workforce roles. Consults stakeholders. Requires a Congressional report. Prohibits additional funding.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Commerce to conduct a public awareness and education campaign on artificial intelligence within 180 days of the Act's enactment, in coordination with relevant Federal agencies.

Requires determination of key performance indicators for evaluating the AI Campaign’s effectiveness and gathering baseline data for comparison.

Facilitates information exchange on AI to promote knowledge and rights awareness, and identifies best practices for detecting AI-generated media like deepfakes.

Conducts outreach to the public about AI's prevalence and applications in daily life and commercial settings.

Targets outreach to vulnerable groups, such as senior citizens, to prevent AI-enabled fraud.

Promotes workforce opportunities in AI, including Federal Government roles, and engages with educational institutions.

Consults with stakeholders from academia, industry, and community organizations on AI usage.

Requires a report to Congress within one year on the AI Campaign’s activities, key performance indicators, and recommendations for future actions.

Prohibits authorization of additional funds for implementing this Act.

column2: Ending FCC Meddling in Our Elections Act
column3: Ending FCC Meddling in Our Elections Act
column15: Prohibits the FCC from creating or enforcing rules on AI-generated content disclosure in political ads. Restricts action on the draft notice from May 22, 2024. Bars enacting any substantially similar rules to the proposal.
column16:
Prohibits the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) from promulgating or enforcing any rules related to the disclosure of artificial intelligence-generated content in political advertisements.

Restricts the FCC specifically from acting on the draft notice of proposed rulemaking circulated by the Chairwoman on May 22, 2024, concerning AI-generated content disclosure in political ads across television, radio, or other services.

Bars the FCC from enacting any rules substantially similar to the aforementioned proposal.

column2: Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review Act
column3: Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review Act
column15: Requires the OMB Director to report on machine-readable regulations progress. Mandates guidance on tech use for retrospective reviews. Instructs agencies to use tech for identifying regulations and train staff. Obliges detailed implementation plans and strategy execution.
column16:
Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to report on the progress of making agency regulations available in machine-readable format within 180 days.

Mandates the issuance of guidance within 18 months on using technology, including AI, for conducting retrospective reviews of agency regulations.

Instructs agencies to use technology to identify obsolete, ineffective, or problematic regulations and adequately train personnel in its use.

Obliges agency heads to submit a detailed plan within two years for implementing the guidance, including identifying regulations for review.

Compels agency heads to implement the strategy for retrospective review within 180 days after plan submission.

column2: Civilian Agency AI Watermark Act
column3: Civilian Agency AI Watermark Act
column15: Mandates consultation with key directors to develop an AI watermark and trademark system within eight months. Authorizes necessary funds annually for the Secretary of Homeland Security to implement this system.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security to consult with the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology and the Director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office within eight months to develop an AI watermark and trademark system for identifying Federal agency-approved AI applications for civilian agency use.

Authorizes the appropriation of necessary funds each fiscal year to the Secretary of Homeland Security to implement this AI watermark system.

column2: S.4870, A bill to require reports on artificial intelligence regulation in the financial services industry.
column3: S.4870, A bill to require reports on artificial intelligence regulation in the financial services industry.
column15: Require financial regulatory agencies to report on AI knowledge gaps, analyze AI-assisted tasks, assess governance standards, identify needed regulatory authorities, clarify overlaps, evaluate AI use over three years, and determine necessary resources, excluding confidential information.
column16:
Require the Federal Reserve, FDIC, OCC, NCUA, and CFPB to report on AI knowledge gaps in financial services within 90 days.

Mandate analysis on AI-assisted tasks in regulated institutions.

Assess current AI governance and oversight standards.

Identify additional regulatory authorities needed for effective mission execution.

Clarify overlapping AI regulatory issues between agencies.

Evaluate current and planned agency use of AI over the next three years, including fiscal and staffing impacts.

Determine necessary resources to adapt to AI changes and oversee its use.

Ensure reports exclude confidential or nonpublic information.

column2: Investing in Tomorrow's Workforce Act of 2023
column3: Investing in Tomorrow's Workforce Act of 2023

column2: Creating Resources for Every American To Experiment with Artificial Intelligence Act of 2023
column3: CREATE AI Act of 2023

column2: An act to add Section 11546.45.5 to the Government Code, relating to automated decision systems
column3: California AB 302 (2023)
column15: Requires the California Department of Technology to assess the purpose, benefits, and accuracy of all high-risk automated decision systems in use (or proposed for use) by the state government, as well as the data used by the systems and any measures taken to mitigate risks stemming from their use.
column16:
Requires the California Department of Technology to conduct a comprehensive inventory of all automated decision systems that are being used, developed, or procured (or have been proposed for use) by any state agency for legally or otherwise significant purposes, including managing access to essential services.

Requires the inventory described above to assess the purpose, benefits, and efficacy of all decision systems as well as the data they consider, alternatives to their use, and any measures -- including cybersecurity controls, privacy controls, risk assessments, and mechanisms for contesting the systems' decisions -- taken to mitigate risks stemming from their use. 

Requires the Department to submit an annual report on the inventory to the state legislature.

column2: AI Foundation Model Transparency Act of 2023
column3: AI Foundation Model Transparency Act of 2023
column15: Directs the Federal Trade Commission to issue transparency regulations for AI model training data and algorithms in consultation with relevant stakeholders within 9 months. Specifies the information categories to be publicly disclosed and updated annually.
column16:
Directs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to establish and routinely update standards for making training data and algorithms of AI foundation models publicly available.

Requires the FTC to promulgate regulations within 9 months and specifies information to be disclosed, including sources of training data and model performance evaluations.

Mandates consultation with relevant stakeholders, including NIST, OSTP, and the Register of Copyrights, in establishing these standards.

Treats violations of these regulations as violations under the FTC Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts or practices.

Authorizes $10 million for fiscal year 2025 and $3 million annually thereafter for implementation.
column17: Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Government support;Incentives: Civil liability;Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity

column2: Preventing Deep Fake Scams Act
column3: Preventing Deep Fake Scams Act
column15: Establishes the Task Force on AI in Financial Services. Mandates inclusion of key financial regulators. Requires a report to Congress within one year. Instructs public feedback and expert consultations. Requires detailed AI fraud protection measures. Terminates Task Force post-report.
column16:
Establishes the Task Force on Artificial Intelligence in the Financial Services Sector.

Mandates the Task Force to consist of key financial regulatory leaders or their designees, including the Secretary of the Treasury as Chair.

Requires the Task Force to issue a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment.

Instructs the Task Force to solicit public feedback and consult with industry and expert stakeholders, including depository institutions, credit unions, third-party vendors, and AI experts.

Requires the report to include descriptions of AI fraud protection measures, definitions of AI-related terms, potential risks from AI misuse, best practices for fraud prevention, and legislative and regulatory recommendations.

Terminates the Task Force 90 days after issuing the final report.

column2: Disincentivizing Internet Service Censorship of Online Users and Restrictions on Speech and Expression Act
column3: DISCOURSE Act
column15: Amends Section 230 to limit liability protections for dominant service providers. Deems providers as content creators if they manage content or use targeted algorithms with a discernible viewpoint. Excludes protections for actions against religious material. Mandates public disclosure of content management practices. Reclassifies immunity as an affirmative defense.
column16:
Amends Section 230 of the Communications Act of 1934 to limit liability protections for dominant interactive computer service providers based on their content management practices.

Deems providers as content creators if they engage in content moderation or use targeted algorithmic amplification that expresses, promotes, or suppresses a discernible viewpoint.

Excludes liability protections for actions against religious material that burden the exercise of religion.

Mandates public disclosure of content management mechanisms and practices by providers to enable informed consumer choices and entrepreneurial activities.

Reclassifies immunity under Section 230 as an affirmative defense, requiring providers or users to prove they are not information content providers in legal actions.
column17: Incentives: Civil liability

column2: Protecting the Information of our Vulnerable Adolescents, Children, and Youth Act
column3: Kids PRIVACY Act
column15: Defines "process" as an operation, potentially automated, performed on "covered information" including collecting, disclosing, inferring, etc. Mandates "verifiable consent" before processing of data, data minimization, data access transparency, security measures, and limits to harmful practices.
column16:
Defines "process" as an operation, potentially automated, performed on "covered information" including collecting, disclosing, inferring, etc.

Mandates obtaining "verifiable consent" from teenagers or parents before processing their data.

Requires operators to minimize data collection and retain data only as necessary.

Obligates transparency and the provision of a clear privacy policy detailing data practices.

Prohibits targeted advertising and harmful data processing practices.

Establishes rights for teenagers and parents to access, correct, and delete data.

Imposes strict security measures for processing children's and teenagers' data.

column2: An Act Concerning Artificial Intelligence, Automated Decision-Making and Personal Data Privacy
column3: Artificial Intelligence, Automated Decision-Making and Personal Data Privacy Act
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Requires the state government to establish a public inventory of its use of artificial intelligence systems and to mandate impact assessments of its AI systems to prevent unlawful discrimination; establishes a working group to make recommendations on the state government's use of AI systems
column16:
Requires the Department of Administrative Services to establish a public inventory of state agencies' existing use of AI systems; this inventory should include whether the system was employed to independently make or inform decisions, and whether it undergone an impact assessment before implementation

Requires the Office of Policy and Management to develop policies to govern state agencies' procurement and use of AI systems; this includes requiring state agencies to conduct impact assessments for these systems and to ensure systems do not unlawfully discriminate against individuals or groups

Bans state agencies from implementing any AI system unless it had performed an impact assessment to prevent unlawful discrimination, effective February 1 2024

Requires the Judicial Department to establish a public inventory of its systems that employ AI, including whether the AI system had undergone impact assessments and was used to make or support conclusions; also requires the department to introduce policies to govern the use of AI, and to prevent unlawful discrimination

Establishes a working group comprising industry representatives and academics to engage stakeholders and experts and make recommendations on the state government's use of AI; this includes recommendations on the adoption of a Connecticut artificial intelligence bill of rights based on the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy's 'Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights'
column17: Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Differential treatment based on a protected characteristic;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Government: judicial and law enforcement;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified

column2: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to automated employment decision tools
column3: NYC Local Law 144
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Requires AI-powered tools used in employment decisions to undergo bias audits; requires related public disclosures and notices to affected employees and job candidates.
column16:
Defines "automated employment decision tools" as computational processes used in discretionary employment decision making, including AI- and machine learning-derived processes.

Requires businesses using automated employment decision tools in New York City to obtain impartial bias audits of the tools from independent auditors, and to disclose the results of the audits to the public online.

Requires businesses using automated employment decision tools in New York City to notify and disclose specified information to job candidates for whom such tools are used.

Establishes civil penalties for violations of the law and empowers the city corporation counsel to enforce the law.
column17: Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Differential treatment based on a protected characteristic;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: External auditing;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: New institution;Incentives: Civil liability;Incentives: Fines;Applications: Business services and analytics

column2: An Act concerning the use of automated tools to assist with hiring decisions and supplementing Title 34 of the Revised Statutes.
column3: New Jersey act against discrimination in automated hiring
column15: Mandates automated decision tools sold in New Jersey to undergo a bias audit before sale, offer annual free audits, and disclose these requirements; it also requires users of these tools to notify screened candidates within 30 days. Imposes civil penalties (fines) for violations.
column16:
Prohibits the sale of automated decision tools in New Jersey unless they have been subject to a bias audit in the past year, include a free annual bias audit service that provides results to the purchaser, and discloses that the tool is subject to this bill.

Requires anyone who uses an automated employment decision tool to screen candidates to notify each candidate of using the tool within 30 days.

Provides for collecting civil penalties (fines) if the provisions above are violated.

column2: An act to add Section 11546.45.5 to the Government Code, relating to automated decision systems
column3: California AB 302 (2023)
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Requires the California Department of Technology to analyze the benefits and risks of all high-risk automated decision systems that are in use by, or have been proposed for use by, state agencies.
column16:
Requires the California Department of Technology, in coordination with other agencies, to analyze the benefits and risks of all high-risk automated decision systems that have been proposed for use, development, or procurement by, or are being used, developed, or procured by, state agencies. 

Requires the analysis to include a description of, among other things, the categories of data and personal information the automated decision system uses to make its decisions. 

Requires the Department of Technology to submit an annual report on the above-described comprehensive analysis to specified committees of the California Legislature.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Video Interview Act
column3: Artificial Intelligence Video Interview Act
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Requires employers who use AI to analyze video interviews of applicants in Illinois to notify and receive consent from the applicant, and explain the AI evaluation process.
column16:
Requires employers who use AI to analyze video interviews of applicants in Illinois to notify and receive consent from the applicant before the interview and provide information explaining how the AI system works and what characteristics it uses to evaluate applicants.

Requires employers to refrain from sharing applicant videos except what’s necessary to evaluate the applicant and delete videos, including any copies shared with other actors, upon applicant request within 30 days.

column2: An act to amend and reenact subsection 8 of section 1-01-49 of the North Dakota Century Code, relating to the definition of person; and to declare an emergency
column3: North Dakota HB 1361 (2023)
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Clarifies that artificial intelligence cannot qualify as a "person" for the purpose of North Dakota state law.
column16: Clarifies that artificial intelligence cannot qualify as a "person" for the purpose of North Dakota state law.

column2: TEST AI Act of 2023
column3: TEST AI Act of 2023
column15: Requires the NIST Director to establish testbeds to support the development of trustworthy AI systems, examine vulnerabilities in existing systems, and build guardrails for harm prevention.
column16:
Requires the Director of the National Institute on Standards and Technology (NIST) to work with other heads of federal agencies and private/public sector stakeholders to build testbeds for supporting the development of trustworthy AI systems and AI guardrails.

Mandates the Secretary of Commerce and Secretary of Energy to enter into a memorandum of understanding that allows relevant agencies across the federal government access to AI-related personnel, facilities, and research at the Department of Energy.

column2: ASK Act
column3: ASK Act
column15: Directs the FCC, in consultation with the FTC, to issue rules prohibiting the offer of artificial intelligence products to minors without parental consent.
column16:
Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), in consultation with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), to issue rules prohibiting the offer of artificial intelligence products to minors without parental consent.

Mandates the rule to include a provision allowing parents and guardians to revoke consent at any time.
column17: Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Detrimental content;Applications: Consumer goods;Applications: Consumer goods;Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Detrimental content;Incentives: Civil liability;Applications: Consumer goods

column2: R U REAL Act
column3: R U REAL Act
column15: Directs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to amend the Telemarketing Sales Rule to require the disclosure of artificial intelligence usage in telemarketing.
column16:
Directs the FTC to revise the Telemarketing Sales Rule to require the disclosure of AI usage to impersonate a human being in telemarketing.

Mandates the FTC to impose financial penalties on violators of this new rule, especially towards individuals and entities with the intent to defraud, cause harm, or wrongfully obtain anything of value through AI telemarketing techniques.

column2: Voluntary Commitments from Leading Artificial Intelligence Companies
column3: Voluntary Commitments from Leading Artificial Intelligence Companies
column15:
Establishes the commitments of leading artificial intelligence companies to manage risks posed by AI.

Announces the Biden-Harris Administration's development of an executive order and intent to pursue bipartisan legislation in these matters.
column16:
Acknowledges the voluntary commitments received from Amazon, Anthropic, Google, Inflection, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI to the Biden-Harris Administration to help move toward the safe, secure, and transparent development of AI technology.   

Specifies various actionable commitments that will support three broad goals: ensuring products are safe before public release, building systems that put security first, and earning public trust. Commitments include internal and external security testing, sharing information across the industry and with governments, civil society, and academia, and investing in cybersecurity and insider threat safeguards.

Announces the Biden-Harris Administration's development of an executive order and intent to pursue bipartisan legislation in these matters.

column2: Living Wage for Musicians Act of 2024
column3: Living Wage for Musicians Act of 2024
column15: Prohibits AI entities from being classified as artists and requires the Federal Register to establish the Artist Compensation Royalty Fund.
column16:
Prohibits artificial intelligence entities from being classified as artists under this act.

Requires the establishment of the Artist Compensation Royalty Fund to help provide financial support to those whose employment was negatively impacted by AI.

Mandates service providers to collect and deposit a living wage royalty fee and a percentage of non-subscription revenue into the Fund.

Authorizes the Fund Administrator to impose penalties for violations and non-compliance by service providers.

column2: New York S7422
column3: New York S7422 ("AI Displacing Actors")
column15: Exclude film productions using AI, which displaces existing employees, from tax credits provided to "qualified films" under the Empire State Film Production Credit.
column16:
Exclude productions using AI that displace employees from being considered a "qualified film" for the Empire State Film Production Credit.

Carves out an exception to the above for films covered by current collective bargaining agreements that allow for AI to displace employees.

column2: Rhode Island HB 6286
column3: Rhode Island HB 6286 ("GenAI Operating Standards")
column15: Authorizes the Rhode Island Attorney General's Office to regulate large-scale generative AI models, ensuring that they meet disclosure, informed consent, and data management standards.
column16:
Prohibits companies from using large-scale generative AI models to engage in targeted bias and discrimination.

Mandates companies to label outputs created using large-scale generative AI models with a distinctive watermark.

Requires companies to secure informed consent from consumers before using their data for training models.

Requires companies, to the best of the their extent, to protect the security of collected data from individuals and shield their identities.

Requires companies to conduct regular risk assessments that identify and mitigate reasonably foreseeable risks and harms.

Mandates companies using large-scale generative AI models to register them with the Rhode Island Attorney General's Office. 

Requires the Rhode Island Attorney General's Office to maintain a public registry of all companies that have registered under the above stipulation.

column2: AI CONSENT Act
column3: AI CONSENT Act
column15: Requires companies to obtain informed consent from consumers before using their data for training AI systems.
column16:
Requires companies to obtain informed consent from consumers before using their data to train AI systems.

Requires companies to explain clearly and concisely how consumer data will be used for AI training.

Mandates disclosure of further data usage, including transfers to third-party entities.

Directs the FTC to issue a report on the progress of converting covered data to de-identified data (for Congress' evaluation).

Treats violations as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act and subjects violators to penalties.

column2: AI for National Security Act
column3: AI for National Security Act
column15: Amends Section 1521 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022 to expand the Department of Defense's procurement of cyber data products and services to include AI-driven endpoint security and to strengthen software supply chain security.
column16:
Amends Section 1521 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022 to expand the Department of Defense's procurement of cyber data products and services to include AI-driven endpoint security and to strengthen software supply chain security.

Inserts a provision to enhance the security of the software supply chain of the Department of Defense using AI.
column17: Applications: Government: military and public safety;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Strategies: Government support

column2: United States-Israel Health Technologies Cooperation Act
column3: US-Israel Health Technologies Act
column15: Authorizes $4,000,000 annually (2024-2026) for a bilateral health tech program with Israel emphasizing AI, drugs, vaccinations, and telemedicine. Requires matching Israeli contributions.
column16:
Authorizes $4,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2024 through 2026 to fund a bilateral cooperative program with Israel for developing health technologies. Emphasizes advancing technology, personalized medicine, and data usage in relation to emerging infectious diseases.

Includes artificial intelligence, drugs, vaccinations, respiratory assist devices, diagnostic tests, and telemedicine as eligible health technologies. Requires matching contributions from the Government of Israel to access funding. Allows funding for existing bilateral programs or the establishment of new programs in consultation with the Secretary of State under the 2008 Science and Technology Cooperation Agreement.
column17: Strategies: Government support;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: New institution

column2: AI Disclosure Act of 2023
column3: AI Disclosure Act of 2023
column15: Requires generative AI to include a disclaimer on outputs and subjects violators to penalties and grants privileges.
column16:
Requires generative artificial intelligence to include a disclaimer on any output. Mandates the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to enforce this disclosure requirement.

Classifies violations of the disclosure requirement as unfair or deceptive acts or practices under the Federal Trade Commission Act.Empowers the FTC to enforce the disclosure requirement using the same means, jurisdiction, powers, and duties as provided in the Federal Trade Commission Act. Subjects violators to penalties and grants them privileges and immunities in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission Act.
column17: Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Incentives: Fines;Incentives: Civil liability

column2: Government Surveillance Reform Act of 2023, Title VII (Protection of Car Data from Warrantless Searches)
column3: Government Surveillance Reform Act of 2023, Title VII (Protection of Car Data from Warrantless Searches)
column15: Prohibits law enforcement from accessing vehicle data without a warrant, except with operator consent or in emergencies.
column16:
Prohibits law enforcement from accessing vehicle data without a warrant, except with operator consent or in emergencies. 

Defines "covered vehicle data" to include all onboard and telematics data in noncommercial vehicles, excluding certain data types like automotive software and geolocation data for traffic enforcement.
Prohibits the use of any vehicle data obtained in violation of these provisions as evidence in any legal proceedings. Amends the Driver Privacy Act of 2015 to align with these new restrictions on accessing vehicle data.

column2: Disrupt Explicit Forged Images And Non-Consensual Edits Act of 2024
column3: DEFIANCE Act of 2024
column15: Amends the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2022, to define "digital forgery" as AI-created intimate visual depictions. Allows civil action for non-consensual digital forgeries. Specifies damages and relief. Permits privacy protections. Establishes a 10-year statute of limitations. Ensures non-preemption.
column16:
Amends the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2022, to include "digital forgery" as any intimate visual depiction created via AI or other technological means to appear indistinguishable from an authentic visual depiction.

Allows identifiable individuals to bring civil action against those who produce, possess, disclose, or solicit digital forgeries without consent, with knowledge or reckless disregard of the lack of consent.

Specifies relief for plaintiffs, including actual or liquidated damages of $150,000, attorney’s fees, and equitable relief such as injunctions.

Permits courts to issue orders to protect plaintiffs' privacy, including the use of pseudonyms and sealing personal identifying information.

Establishes a 10-year statute of limitations for actions, starting from the discovery of the violation or the individual reaching 18 years of age.

Ensures the Act does not preempt state, federal, or tribal laws that provide at least as much protection.

column2: Illinois HB 3563
column3: Illinois HB 3563 ("GenAI Task Force")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Amends the Department of Innovation and Technology Act to establish the Generative AI and Natural Language Processing Task Force. Tasks the Task Force with investigation, public meetings, recommendations, and a comprehensive report by December 31, 2024.
column16:
Amends the Department of Innovation and Technology Act to establish the Generative AI and Natural Language Processing Task Force.

Requires the Task Force to investigate and report on generative AI and natural language processing software.

Comprises the Task Force of appointed members from various government, educational, and expert backgrounds.

Mandates the Task Force to hold at least five public meetings across different regions of Illinois.

Tasks the Task Force with recommending legislation for consumer information protection, model policies for schools, and assessing AI's impact on public services, civil rights, employment, and cybersecurity.

Obligates the Department to provide administrative and technical support to the Task Force.

Requires the Task Force to file a comprehensive report by December 31, 2024, with the Governor and the General Assembly.

column2: California SJR 6
column3: California SJR 6 ("Artificial Intelligence")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Urges President and Congress to develop an AI Advisory Committee. Highlights need for AI policy, ethical standards, workforce planning, and innovation. Notes California's AI investment. Calls for bridging tech-regulation gaps. Directs resolution to federal and state officials.
column16:
Urges the President and Congress to develop a comprehensive Artificial Intelligence Advisory Committee.

Urges the adoption of a comprehensive artificial intelligence policy.

Highlights the importance of federal government planning for workforce changes due to AI.

Emphasizes the need for ethical standards in AI development and employment.

Encourages promoting innovation to help American companies grow.

Notes that California has attracted significant global AI investment.

Calls for bridging the gap between technological change and regulatory response.

Directs transmission of the resolution to key federal officials and California representatives.

column2: Illinois HB 0645
column3: Illinois HB 0645 ("Future of Work Act")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Creates the Illinois Future of Work Task Force to plan for future labor needs. Requires assessment of emerging technologies like AI. Mandates job standards development. Instructs identification of future job opportunities. Proposes workforce training programs. Submits report by May 1, 2022.
column16:
Creates the Illinois Future of Work Task Force to proactively plan for the future of work and address current labor issues.

Requires the Task Force to identify and assess emerging technologies, particularly automation and AI, that significantly impact employment, wages, and skills.

Mandates the development of job standards and working conditions to build a vibrant middle class.

Instructs the Task Force to identify future job opportunities and shape them to improve life in Illinois.

Compiles research and best practices from other regions on deploying technology for the public good.

Develops tools to evaluate the impact of proposed technologies on workers, employers, and the state.

Proposes workforce development and training programs for future jobs.

Requires the Task Force to submit a report with findings to the Governor and General Assembly by May 1, 2022, and dissolves upon report submission.

column2: Virginia HB 2154
column3: Virginia HB 2154 ("Patient Access to Intelligent Personal Assistant")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Requires hospitals and nursing facilities to establish policies for patient access to intelligent personal assistants. Ensures HIPAA compliance. Defines intelligent personal assistants as devices using AI and natural language processing. Mandates facility compliance with privacy and security standards.
column16:
Requires hospitals, nursing homes, and certified nursing facilities to establish and implement policies for patient access to intelligent personal assistants while receiving inpatient services.

Ensures policies protect health information in accordance with the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA).

Defines "intelligent personal assistant" as a combination of an electronic device and specialized software application that assists users with tasks using natural language processing and artificial intelligence.

Mandates that these facilities allow the use of intelligent personal assistants for patients, ensuring compliance with privacy and security standards.

Includes intelligent personal assistants like "digital assistants" or "virtual assistants" in the definition provided.
column17: Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health

column2: Arkansas SB 656
column3: Arkansas SB 656 ("Data-Driven Decision-Making Task Force")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Establishes a task force composed of twelve legislative members to study and recommend a shared services model for statewide data sharing, including necessary legislation and funding mechanisms.
column16:
Creates the Data-Sharing and Data-Driven Decision-Making Task Force, comprised of twelve members appointed from the Senate and House of Representatives.

Mandates the task force to study and recommend the implementation of a statewide data-sharing system across state agencies.

Requires the task force to evaluate current data management inefficiencies, and propose necessary legislation and funding mechanisms for system implementation. Empowers the task force to hire external consultants if necessary.

Requires the task force to meet at least monthly and report findings to the Governor and legislative leaders by December 31, 2019; expires the task force on January 1, 2020.

column2: Closing Loopholes for the Overseas Use and Development of Artificial Intelligence Act
column3: CLOUD AI Act
column15: Prohibits US persons and subsidiaries from supporting the use of remote or cloud integrated circuits by entities in China.
column16: Grants authority to the Secretary of Commerce to prohibit US persons and subsidiaries from supporting the use of remote or cloud integrated circuits listed under Export Control Classification Number 3A090 and 4A090 of the Export Administration Regulations by entities located in the People’s Republic of China or Macau.
column17: Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Security;Applications: Government: military and public safety

column2: Secure Artificial Intelligence Act of 2024
column3: Secure A.I. Act
column15:
Requires the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to improve accounting for AI security vulnerabilities in their existing databases.

Establishes an AI Security Center within NSA for research and secure AI practices.
column16:
Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to update the National Vulnerability Database to include AI security vulnerabilities.

Establishes a voluntary, comprehensive database to track AI security and safety incidents, ensuring confidentiality and standardized reporting.

Requires the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to update the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures Program for AI vulnerabilities.

Establishes an Artificial Intelligence Security Center within NSA to facilitate AI security research, develop counter-AI techniques, and promote secure AI practices.

column2: No AI FRAUD Act
column3: No AI FRAUD Act
column15: Establishes property rights in likeness and voice, transferable post-mortem for ten years. Prohibits unauthorized cloning and replicas, imposing liabilities. Specifies damages per violation. Allows punitive damages and attorney fees. Provides First Amendment defense. Exempts negligible harm. Sets four-year limitations period.
column16:
Establishes property rights for individuals in their likeness and voice, treating them as intellectual property that is transferable and descendible for ten years post-mortem.

Prohibits unauthorized distribution, transmission, or availability of personalized cloning services, digital voice replicas, or digital depictions without the individual’s consent, imposing liabilities for violations.

Specifies that unauthorized use incurs damages of $50,000 per violation for cloning services and $5,000 per violation for voice replicas or depictions, plus actual damages and profits.

Allows for punitive damages and attorney fees for injured parties and invalidates disclaimers as a defense.

Provides a First Amendment defense, balancing public interest with intellectual property rights, and considers commercial use and impact on the value of the original work.

Exempts negligible harm from liability and defines harm to include financial, physical, and severe emotional distress.

Sets a four-year limitations period for civil actions and ensures no preemption of other rights or laws.

column2: Justice in Forensic Algorithms Act of 2024
column3: Justice in Forensic Algorithms Act of 2024
column15: Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to establish a program to create and maintain testing standards for computational forensic software, including AI-enabled software for evidence analysis.
column16:
Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to establish a program (“Testing Standards”) to create and maintain testing standards for computational forensic software, which includes software that relies on AI-enabled automated or semiautomated computational processes to analyze or interpret evidence.

Requires Testing Standards to solicit public input, address the potential for disparate impacts on protected groups, and specify requirements for publicly available documentation by developers, validation processes by those using computational forensic software, reports provided to defendants regarding software used, and how to test software and report results. 

Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to establish a program (“Testing Program”) that tests computational forensic algorithms according to the testing standards, using realistic and representative sample data and adversarial examples, and publishing results. Requires software to be re-tested after significant changes. 

Requires Federal law enforcement agencies only to use computational forensic software tested by NIST’s Testing Program and only after conducting an internal validation and making results publicly available. 

Requires evidence from computational forensic software to be admissible only if it has been submitted to NIST’s Testing Program and the developers waive legal claims against the defense analyzing or testing it. Requires information about the software (e.g., source code) and results from analyses by the software to be shared with the defendant.

column2: AI LEAD Act
column3: AI LEAD Act
column15: Establishes the CAIO Council to coordinate federal AI practices and risk management. Mandates each agency appoint a CAIO and requires AI Governance Boards in agencies.
column16:
Establishes the Chief Artificial Intelligence Officers (CAIO) Council to coordinate federal AI practices, interagency activities, and risk management. Mandates each federal agency to appoint a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer responsible for promoting AI innovation, policy development, and risk management.

Requires the creation of Artificial Intelligence Governance Boards within each agency to oversee AI issues and ensure compliance with relevant laws and standards. Obligates agencies to develop AI strategies emphasizing trustworthy adoption, risk mitigation, transparency, and the protection of individual rights. Directs the Comptroller General to report on the effectiveness of the AI Governance Boards and CAIOs within two years of enactment.

column2: Texas HB 4695
column3: Texas HB 4695 ("AI and Mental Health")
column15: Requires commission approval for AI mental health applications and mandates licensed supervision, informed consent, and clear AI disclosure.
column16:
Requires commission approval for AI mental health applications and mandates licensed supervision, informed consent, and clear AI disclosure. Permits liability-free testing with specialized consent. 

Mandates that licensed mental health professionals supervise AI mental health services, ensuring availability for review, communication, and intervention. Obliges providers to obtain informed consent and clearly inform users about the use of AI technology.
Subjects AI mental health service providers to the same disciplinary actions and record-keeping requirements as licensed mental health professionals.

column2: DATA Privacy Act
column3: DATA Privacy Act
column15: Establishes national data privacy standards for covered entities. Requires clear privacy notices. Mandates FTC regulations within one year. Imposes data minimization requirements. Empowers individuals with data rights. Mandates privacy officers for large entities. Grants FTC and state enforcement authority. Allocates FTC resources.
column16:
Establishes national data privacy standards for covered entities handling personal data.

Requires covered entities to post clear, accessible privacy notices detailing data collection, processing, storage, and disclosure practices.

Mandates the FTC to create regulations within one year for reasonable, equitable, and non-deceptive data practices, including opt-out and affirmative consent mechanisms.

Imposes data minimization requirements, limiting data collection to what is necessary for specified purposes and ensuring timely deletion.

Empowers individuals with rights to access, correct, delete, and transfer their data.

Mandates large entities to appoint privacy protection officers to oversee compliance and advocate for privacy policies.

Directs the National Science Foundation to support research on privacy-enhancing technologies.

Grants enforcement authority to the FTC and state attorneys general, with civil penalties for violations.

Allocates resources to the FTC for enforcement and compliance activities.

column2: New Mexico SM 63
column3: New Mexico SM 63 ("Structured Decision-making in Child Abuse")
column15: Requests the Attorney General to convene a task force to study AI tools in the Children, Youth, and Families Department. Mandates efficacy assessment. Requires decision-making evaluation. Directs training and data analysis. Instructs outcome review. Obligates improvement recommendations. Involves diverse stakeholders. Requires academic collaboration. Demands findings by August 1, 2024.
column16:
Requests the Attorney General to convene a task force to study the Children, Youth, and Families Department's use of structured decision-making tools and philosophy.

Mandates the task force to assess the efficacy, impact, and results of these AI-based tools.

Requires the task force to determine if structured decision-making tools lead to better decisions in child abuse and neglect cases.

Directs the task force to analyze staff training, understanding, and data on repeat maltreatment rates since the tool’s introduction.

Instructs the task force to review the outcomes of voluntary placement agreements and safety plans under this new philosophy.

Obligates the task force to make recommendations for improvements and the future use of these tools.

Involves input from diverse stakeholders, including experts in law enforcement, child maltreatment, behavioral health, and representatives from various departments and communities.

Requires collaboration with a post-secondary institution for research.

Demands findings and recommendations be presented to the legislative health and human services committee by August 1, 2024.

column2: Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act
column3: Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act
column15: Cites the Act as the “Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act.” Requires the Election Assistance Commission to submit a report with voluntary guidelines within 60 days. Includes guidelines on AI risks, cybersecurity, accurate information sharing, and countering disinformation.
column16:
Cites the Act as the “Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act”.

Requires the Election Assistance Commission to submit a report with voluntary guidelines to Congress, State and local election offices, and the public within 60 days of enactment.

Includes guidelines addressing the risks and benefits of using AI in election administration.

Addresses the cybersecurity risks posed by AI technologies in elections.

Guides on managing AI-generated information to ensure the sharing of accurate election information.

Provides strategies for countering AI-driven election disinformation that undermines public trust.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Advancement Act of 2023
column3: AI Advancement Act of 2023
column15: Requires a report on AI regulation in finance, establishes AI bug bounty programs, mandates vulnerability analysis for military AI, requires a report on data sharing, and for other purposes.
column16: Requires a report on artificial intelligence regulation in the financial services industry, establishes artificial intelligence bug bounty programs, requires a vulnerability analysis study for artificial intelligence-enabled military applications, and requires a report on data sharing and coordination.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Environmental Impacts Act of 2024
column3: Artificial Intelligence Environmental Impacts Act of 2024
column15: Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to submit a report to Congress on the environmental impacts of artificial intelligence
column16:
Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to study  the environmental impacts of artificial intelligence, with a report on its findings submitted to Congress within two years of the Act's enactment.

Mandates that the EPA study examine the energy, water consumption, and pollution throughout the full lifecycle of AI models, hardware, and data centers, considering the effects of location, power sources, and AI model design on these environmental impacts.

Requires that the EPA study assess the positive environmental impacts associated with the use of AI, such as optimizing systems for energy efficiency or automatically monitoring environmental changes.

Directs the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to work with other government officials to form a consortium comprising academic, civil society, and industry representatives to assess and report on AI's environmental impacts, including the feasibility of open-source tools for measurement and recommendations to mitigate negative environmental effects.

Instructs the Director of NIST to work with other government officials and the consortium to establish a voluntary reporting system for entities to report on their AI systems' environmental impact.

Requires the Administrator of EPA, Secretary of Energy and Director of NIST to submit a joint report on the consortium's findings and its proposed voluntary reporting system within four years of the Act's enactment.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Accountability Act
column3: Artificial Intelligence Accountability Act
column15: Requires the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information to conduct a study on accountability mechanisms to provide assurances that an artificial intelligence (AI) system is trustworthy and hold public meetings to gather feedback on the disclosure of information about AI systems.
column16:
Requires the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information to study accountability mechanisms (e.g., audits, certifications, and assessments) that provide assurances that an AI system is trustworthy. This includes defining terms around AI “trustworthiness,” examining how mechanisms are incorporated into AI systems, and assessing their ability to reduce risks related to AI systems, such as cybersecurity threats. 

Requires the Assistant Secretary to solicit stakeholder feedback through public meetings while carrying out the study above and to report the study’s findings to Congress, including recommendations on effective accountability measures for AI systems. 

Requires the Assistant Secretary to consult with stakeholders through public meetings and report to Congress on what information should be disclosed to those who interact with, are affected by, or study AI systems, and the most effective methods for doing so.

column2: Future of Artificial Intelligence Innovation Act of 2024
column3: Future of Artificial Intelligence Innovation Act of 2024
column15: Establishes the "Artificial Intelligence Safety Institute" to assist sectors in AI best practices and innovation. Requires AI research and standards development and mandates an international coalition for AI standards. Directs reporting on regulatory barriers and orders prioritized AI training data and Federal AI challenges.
column16:
Establishes the "Artificial Intelligence Safety Institute" to assist private and public sectors in developing best practices for AI assessment, provide technical assistance, and promote AI innovation, with a director appointed by the Under Secretary of Commerce for Standards and Technology.
Requires the Institute to conduct AI research, develop standards, and create guidelines for safe AI development and deployment, including generative AI and foundation models.

Mandates the formation of an international coalition to harmonize AI standards and support bilateral and multilateral AI research collaborations. Directs the Comptroller General to report on regulatory barriers affecting AI innovation and recommend legislative or administrative actions to enhance AI development.
Orders the development of prioritized public data sets for AI training and evaluation, and the establishment of Federal grand challenges in AI to stimulate research and commercialization in key areas.

column2: Protecting Kids on Social Media Act
column3: Protecting Kids on Social Media Act
column15: Requires social media platforms to verify user ages beyond attestations, using current technologies. Prohibits access for individuals under 13. Mandates parental consent for users under 18. Prohibits algorithmic recommendations for minors. Establishes a Pilot Program for secure digital IDs. Empowers FTC and state attorneys general for enforcement. Grants extraterritorial jurisdiction for U.S. individuals.
column16:
Requires social media platforms to verify the age of users beyond simple attestations, using current age verification technologies.

Prohibits social media platforms from allowing individuals under 13 from accessing their services.

Mandates parental or guardian consent for users under 18, requiring platforms to take reasonable steps to verify this consent.

Prohibits the use of algorithmic recommendation systems on individuals under 18, except for contextual suggestions or advertising.

Establishes a Pilot Program for secure digital identification credentials to facilitate age and parental consent verification, overseen by the Secretary of Commerce.

Empowers the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and state attorneys general to enforce compliance, with civil penalties for violations.

Grants extraterritorial jurisdiction for violations involving individuals in the United States.

column2: An Act to amend the general business law, the executive law, the state finance law and the education law, in relation to enacting the "digital fairness act" - Sections 7-9 ("AUTOMATED DECISION SYSTEM IMPACT ASSESSMENTS," etc.)
column3: Digital Fairness Act - Sections 7-9 ("AUTOMATED DECISION SYSTEM IMPACT ASSESSMENTS," etc.)
column15: Require the state to conduct ADS Impact Assessments before use. Mandate neutral third-party evaluations on impacts. Prohibit ADS purchase/use without publishing the assessment and public comments. Obligate a list of qualified assessors. Demand plain-language notifications and human review mechanisms. Ban payments for non-compliant ADS.
column16:
Require the state and its entities to conduct Automated Decision System (ADS) Impact Assessments before using any ADS.

Mandate the engagement of a neutral third party to evaluate the ADS, focusing on statistical impacts on protected classes, privacy, and security.

Prohibit purchasing or using ADS without publishing the assessment and considering public comments.

Obligate the state to maintain a list of qualified neutral third parties for conducting assessments.

Require a comprehensive study on the impacts of ADS, particularly on protected classes, to be published within two years.

Demand plain-language notifications to individuals affected by ADS decisions and provide mechanisms for human review.

Ban payments for ADS that do not use open-source software or comply with assessment and policy requirements.

column2: Federal Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Act of 2023
column3: Federal Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Act of 2023
column15: Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to issue guidance on how federal agencies can use NIST’s AI Risk Management Framework to reduce risks.
column16:
Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to issue guidance on how federal agencies can use NIST’s AI Risk Management Framework (RMF) to reduce risks, covering cybersecurity for AI systems, requirements for AI suppliers, and training for agencies.

Requires the Comptroller General of the United States to assess the impact of NIST's AI RMF on agencies' AI use within a year, and requires the Director of OMB to report to Congress on agency implementation and adherence to NIST’s AI RMF within a year, and subsequently, at least once every three years.

Excludes national security systems from the requirements above to adhere to NIST’s AI RMF.

Requires the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council to issue guidance on agency AI procurement within a year, to ensure compliance with NIST’s AI RMF.

Requires the Director of OMB to establish an initiative to build agencies’ AI expertise, focusing on hiring interdisciplinary experts and incorporating best practices from existing initiatives.

Requires the Director of NIST to conduct a study on and convene stakeholders to develop voluntary consensus standards to test and evaluate AI acquisitions, develop methods and conduct evaluations, monitor evaluations and adjust methods, and make recommendations to each agency on risks from relevant AI acquisitions.
column17: Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Strategies: Governance development;Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: External auditing;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Risk factors: Safety;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development

column2: Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act
column3: Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act
column15: Prohibits knowingly distributing materially deceptive AI-generated media related to Federal elections.
column16:
Prohibits knowingly distributing materially deceptive AI-generated audio or visual media related to Federal election activities or candidates. Exempts broadcasters, streaming services, and periodicals if they disclose authenticity concerns and covers bona fide news or satire. 

Allows affected candidates to seek injunctive relief or damages, including attorney's fees, for violations. Requires plaintiffs to prove violations with clear and convincing evidence.
column17: Harms: Detrimental content;Risk factors: Reliability;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Harms: Detrimental content;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Incentives: Civil liability;Incentives: Fines

column2: Black Maternal Health Omnibus Act, Sec. 904 (Report on the Use of Technology in Maternity Care)
column3: Black Maternal Health Omnibus Act, Sec. 904 (Report on the Use of Technology in Maternity Care)
column15: Mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to commission a study on technology in maternity care. Requires examination of AI's impact on racial and ethnic biases. Includes patient monitoring devices. Specifies identification of bias reduction practices. Directs completion within 24 months.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to enter an agreement with the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine to study the use of technology in maternity care.

Requires the study to examine the use of innovative technology, including artificial intelligence, and its impact on racial or ethnic biases in maternal health care.

Includes patient monitoring devices, such as pulse oximeters, in the scope of the study, with a focus on their effect on racial or ethnic biases.

Outlines identification of best practices for reducing and preventing biases in the use of technology and monitoring devices in maternity care.

Requires the study to recommend best practices for using technology and monitoring devices for pregnant and postpartum individuals from minority groups.

Mandates the inclusion of best practices regarding privacy and security safeguards in the use of such technologies.

Directs the National Academies to complete the study and submit a report to Congress within 24 months of the Act's enactment.
column17: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Post-market monitoring;Harms: Differential treatment based on a protected characteristic;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Privacy;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Safety;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Applications: Security;Strategies: Government study or report

column2: New Jersey SB 3876
column3: New Jersey SB 3876 ("Artificial Intelligence Officer")
column15: Establishes Artificial Intelligence Officer to develop/update procedures for state agencies' automated systems. Mandates agency compliance and system inventories. Creates NJ AI Advisory Board for advice, hearings, and reports. Forms AI Bill of Rights task force. Subjects officers/board to public records laws.
column16:
Establishes the position of Artificial Intelligence Officer to develop and update procedures regulating automated systems used by state agencies for critical decisions.

Mandates state agencies to comply with these procedures and submit inventories of their automated systems, which will be published online.

Creates the New Jersey Artificial Intelligence Advisory Board to advise state agencies, hold public hearings on preliminary procedures, and issue reports and recommendations.

Establishes the position of Artificial Intelligence Implementation Officer to review and approve or deny new automated systems based on compliance with procedures, and conduct periodic reevaluations.

Forms a task force to study AI and create an AI Bill of Rights, with a report due within one year.

Subjects officers and the board to open public records laws while protecting trade secrets and work product protections.

column2: New York Bill A5309
column3: New York Bill A5309 ("Responsible AI Standards")
column15: Amend state finance law to require purchases of AI systems adhering to responsible standards. Mandate harm avoidance, transparency, and fairness. Conduct comprehensive impact evaluations. Amend executive law to define unlawful discrimination via AI. Require regulatory adoption by the commissioner.
column16:
Amend the state finance law to require state units to purchase products or services containing algorithmic decision systems that adhere to responsible artificial intelligence standards.

Mandate the avoidance of harm, including minimizing risks of physical or mental injury, unjustified information deletion or disclosure, and unwarranted damage to property, reputation, or the environment.

Require a commitment to transparency, including full disclosure of the algorithmic decision system's capabilities, limitations, and potential problems.

Prioritize fairness by eliminating discrimination, promoting equality, tolerance, respect, and justice, and providing feedback mechanisms to redress harms.

Conduct comprehensive evaluations and analyses of the algorithmic decision system's impact and potential risks.

Amend the executive law to define "unlawful discriminatory practice" to include actions performed through algorithmic decision systems.

Require the commissioner of taxation and finance to adopt regulations to implement these provisions.

column2: New York A7106
column3: New York A7106 ("PAID Act")
column15: Amends election law to mandate synthetic media disclosure in political communications. Requires printed/digital communications to state AI assistance. Mandates non-printed communications to display or speak the statement. Defines synthetic media. Effective January 1, 2024.
column16:
Amends the election law to mandate disclosure of synthetic media in political communications.

Requires disclosure for printed or digital political communications to state: "This political communication was created with the assistance of artificial intelligence."

Mandates non-printed or digital political communications to clearly display or speak the same statement.

Defines "synthetic media" as any media created or modified using artificial intelligence algorithms.

Sets the effective date of this act to January 1, 2024.

column2: California AB 1282
column3: California AB 1282 ("AI and mental health")
column15: Requires the Mental Health Services Oversight and Accountability Commission to report a statewide strategy on mitigating mental health risks from social media by July 1, 2025. Mandates data and recommendations. Obligates exploration of social media types and associated risks. Includes AI assessment. Prioritizes engagement with at-risk youth. Repeals provisions on January 1, 2029.
column16:
Requires the Mental Health Services Oversight and Accountability Commission to report a statewide strategy on mitigating mental health risks from social media use among children and youth by July 1, 2025.

Mandates the report to include data on access to mental health services by those negatively impacted by social media and recommendations to enhance resiliency strategies and service utilization.

Obligates the commission to explore social media types, user populations, and associated mental health risks, including suicide, eating disorders, and substance abuse.

Includes artificial intelligence in the assessment of negative health risks.

Prioritizes engagement with children and youth, especially at-risk and underserved populations, in the report formulation.

Repeals the provisions on January 1, 2029.

column2: New York A7838
column3: New York A7838 ("Long-term impact of AI on workforce")
column15: Mandates the Department of Labor to study AI's long-term workforce impact within six months. Requires consultation with Civil Service and Information Technology Services. Obligates interim reports every five years and final report by January 1, 2035. Prohibits AI displacement of employees until final report. Ensures immediate effect.
column16:
Mandates the Department of Labor to begin a study on the long-term impact of artificial intelligence on the state workforce within six months.

Requires consultation with the Department of Civil Service and the Office of Information Technology Services.

Calls for examination of job performance, productivity, training, education requirements, privacy, and security.

Obligates the Department of Labor to issue an interim report every five years and a final report by January 1, 2035, with recommendations for legislative action.

Prohibits all state departments and governmental entities from using AI to displace any natural person from their employment until the final report and recommendations are received.

Ensures immediate effect upon enactment.

column2: North Carolina SB 460
column3: North Carolina SB 460 ("Automation and Workforce")
column15:
Establishes a committee to analyze automation's impact on North Carolina's workforce, focusing on low-income and minority workers. 

Requires 11 voting members and seven nonvoting ex officio members. 

Mandates review of automation technologies and assessment of educational needs. 

Requires biennial reporting to the Governor and Legislative Commission.
column16:
Establishes the Study Committee on Automation and the Workforce to analyze the impact of automation on North Carolina's workforce, with a focus on low-income and minority workers.

Requires the Committee to include 11 voting members representing labor organizations, employers, and state legislators, appointed by the Governor and legislative leaders.

Designates seven nonvoting ex officio members from key state departments and educational institutions.

Mandates the Committee to review the effects of automation technologies such as AI, industrial robotics, and self-service technologies on employment.

Instructs the Committee to assess educational and training requirements for workers to adapt to automation.

Requires the Committee to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and Joint Legislative Commission on Governmental Operations before the 2025 General Assembly and biennially thereafter.

column2: Pennsylvania HB 49
column3: Pennsylvania HB 49 ("AI Business Registry")
column15: Establishes a registry for AI-operating businesses in Pennsylvania. Requires creation of paper and online forms. Mandates collection of specific business information. Prohibits commercial use of data. Maintains public database. Obligates annual reporting. Defines AI. Enacts in 60 days.
column16:
Establishes a registry of businesses operating artificial intelligence (AI) systems in Pennsylvania.

Requires the Department of State to coordinate with other state agencies to create paper and online registry forms.

Mandates the collection of specific information from businesses, including business name, IP address, type of AI code, software intent, and contact details.

Prohibits the sale or commercial use of collected information and exempts it from Right-to-Know Law disclosure.

Maintains a searchable online database for businesses operating AI systems.

Obligates the Department of State to submit an annual report on the registry to legislative committees, detailing the number of registered businesses, registrant distribution by agency, and incurred expenses.

Defines "artificial intelligence" as computer systems performing tasks requiring human intelligence.

Sets the act to take effect 60 days post-enactment.

column2: Pennsylvania HB 1380
column3: Pennsylvania HB 1380 ("Administration of Assistance Programs")
column15: Authorizes the department to use AI for eligibility verification and fraud detection. Permits data access from state agencies. Empowers rule establishment for program administration. Requires expenditure control and federal approvals. Allows health savings accounts. Mandates claims data sharing.
column16:
Authorizes the department to utilize data analytics and artificial intelligence for eligibility verification and fraud detection in public assistance programs.

Permits the department to access data from other state agencies to verify residency and eligibility of applicants.

Empowers the department to establish rules, regulations, and standards for assistance program administration, including eligibility criteria and benefit modifications.

Requires the department to ensure expenditures do not exceed appropriations and to seek necessary federal waivers or approvals.

Allows the establishment of health savings accounts and medical assistance premiums to aid residents transitioning out of assistance programs.

Mandates physical health managed care organizations to share medical assistance claims data with providers.

column2: Rhode Island SB 146
column3: Rhode Island SB 146 ("Consumer Protection Gaming Act")
column15: Prohibits facial recognition and biometric technology in gambling apps. Prohibits algorithms increasing wagers based on betting history. Prohibits AI promoting increased play using cognitive-behavioral data. Applies to Rhode Island sports betting and gambling vendors. Excludes standardized rewards. Effective upon passage.
column16:
Prohibits the use of facial recognition technology and biometric recognition programs in video-lottery terminals and online betting applications.

Prohibits the use of algorithmic programs that modify gaming based on a consumer's betting history to increase wagers.

Prohibits the use of artificial intelligence or automated decision systems to promote increased play through intermittent reinforcement based on cognitive-behavioral algorithms and prior gaming data.

Applies these prohibitions to sports betting applications and vendors of gambling products licensed by Rhode Island.

Excludes standardized rewards programs from these prohibitions.

Takes effect upon passage.

column2: Alabama SB 78
column3: Alabama SB 78 ("Council on Advanced Technology")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Establishes the Alabama Council on Advanced Technology and Artificial Intelligence. Requires the council to advise the Governor and Legislature. Composes 22 members with expertise in relevant fields. Mandates biannual meetings. Obligates annual reporting. Enforces diversity. Prohibits salary but allows expense reimbursement. Sets effective date to one year post-approval.
column16:
Establishes the Alabama Council on Advanced Technology and Artificial Intelligence.

Requires the council to review and advise the Governor and Legislature on the use and development of advanced technology and artificial intelligence.

Composes the council of 22 members, including appointees from the Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Speaker of the House, and Senate President Pro Tempore, and ex officio members from commerce and information technology departments.

Mandates that non-legislative appointees have expertise in AI, technology, ethics, privacy, workforce development, or computer science.

Stipulates that the council meets at least twice a year and allows virtual participation.

Obliges the council to submit an annual report with recommendations on AI and advanced technology to the Governor and Legislature.

Enforces diversity in appointments regarding gender, race, and geography.

Prohibits salary for non-legislative members but allows expense reimbursement; provides legislative members with regular compensation for meeting attendance.

Sets the act’s effective date to one year post-approval.

column2: New Jersey S 2723
column3: New Jersey S 2723 ("Integrated Digital Experience Act")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. state and local laws
column15: Requires each state agency to submit an IT modernization plan within one year. Mandates inclusion of strategies for digital services and accessibility. Authorizes review by Chief Technology and Innovation Officers. Mandates annual AI feasibility evaluations and development of assessment metrics.
column16:
Requires each state agency to develop and submit an information technology modernization and improvement plan to the Chief Technology Officer within one year of request.

Mandates the plan to include strategies for improving digital services using data analytics, cloud computing, electronic forms, and digitized workflows, ensuring mobile-friendly and accessible websites.

Authorizes the Chief Technology Officer to review these plans in collaboration with the Chief Innovation Officer.

Mandates the Chief Technology Officer to annually evaluate the feasibility of using AI, machine learning, and cloud services for public services, and to develop data analytics capabilities for policy development.

Requires the development of metrics to assess each agency's implementation of a modern digital experience, updated at least every two years and reevaluated every three years.
