column2: A bill to specify control and management of Department of Defense data and to establish the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council, and for other purposes.
column3: S. 3004 (Chief AI Officer Governing Council)
column15: Establishes the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council to oversee AI and data policies in the DoD. Requires ethical and coordinated AI use, streamlines AI oversight, improves industry coordination, and ensures compliance. Submits periodic updates and reports.
column16:
Establishes the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council to oversee AI and data policies within the Department of Defense.

Requires the Council to ensure responsible, coordinated, and ethical use of AI across DoD missions.

Mandates the Council to streamline AI development, implementation, and oversight within the DoD.

Improves coordination on AI governance with the defense industry.

Oversees ethical requirements and protections for AI usage, mitigating unintended bias in AI algorithms.

Monitors and updates recommendations for AI operational usage.

Reviews AI program funding to ensure compliance with DoD AI policies.

Provides periodic updates on AI development and implementation efforts.

Guides access and distribution restrictions for data and AI tools.

Implements educational programs on AI applications for all DoD levels.

Submits periodic reports to the Secretary of Defense and congressional defense committees.

column2: To direct the Secretary of Defense to establish a working group to develop and coordinate an artificial intelligence initiative among the Five Eyes countries, and for other purposes.
column3: H. R. 6425 (Five Eyes countries AI initiative)
column15: Directs the Secretary of Defense to establish the “Five AIs Strategic Artificial Intelligence Working Group” within 90 days. Mandates the development of an AI initiative among Five Eyes countries. Requires a senior leader. Obligates plan submission and biannual reports.
column16:
Directs the Secretary of Defense to establish a working group named “Five AIs Strategic Artificial Intelligence Working Group” within 90 days of enactment.

Mandates the working group to develop and coordinate an AI initiative among the Five Eyes countries.

Requires designation of a senior civilian or military officer to lead the working group.

Encourages participation of Five Eyes Intelligence Oversight and Review Council members.

Tasks the working group with comparing AI systems, identifying interoperability solutions, and testing AI model redundancy.

Instructs the development of shared strategies for AI research, development, and data management.

Promotes the comparison and use of ethical frameworks and the acceleration of AI technology procurement.

Obligates the submission of a plan within 60 days and biannual reports to congressional committees.

Sets the termination date for the working group on September 30, 2028, with an option for extension.

column2: Artificial Intelligence Literacy Act of 2023
column3: H. R. 6791 (AI Literacy Act of 2023)
column15: Amends the Digital Equity Act to include AI literacy within digital literacy. Defines AI literacy comprehensively. Requires grants for AI literacy in schools and teacher training. Supports community colleges and higher education institutions. Provides grants to community anchor institutions. Mandates annual reports to Congress.
column16:
Amends the Digital Equity Act of 2021 to include artificial intelligence (AI) literacy within the scope of digital literacy.

Defines "artificial intelligence literacy" as understanding basic AI principles, applications, implications, limitations, and ethical considerations.

Requires grants to support AI literacy initiatives in public elementary and secondary schools, including teacher training, professional development, resource development, and partnerships with the private sector.

Supports community colleges by funding interdisciplinary AI literacy programs, lab development, and virtual learning platforms.

Funds higher education institutions to develop AI learning labs, virtual platforms, and educational tools for teachers and community educators.

Provides grants to community anchor institutions for AI education and training programs.

Mandates an annual report to Congress summarizing and analyzing the progress and impact of AI literacy initiatives, with recommendations for expansion or modification.

column2: Strategy for Public Health Preparedness and Response to Artificial Intelligence Threats
column3: S. 2346 (Public Health Response to AI)
column15: Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop an AI threat strategy within 180 days. Mandates stakeholder consultation. Includes misuse risk mitigation framework. Identifies and addresses capability gaps. Focuses on biological weapon and virus risks. Submits strategy to Congress. Amends Public Health Service Act.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop a strategy for public health preparedness and response to artificial intelligence (AI) threats within 180 days of enactment.

Mandates consultation with stakeholders, including those developing countermeasures and those with AI expertise, for strategy formulation.

Includes a framework for mitigating AI misuse risks threatening national health security and outlines duties, functions, and metrics for preparedness and response.

Identifies gaps in public health capabilities and proposes strategies to address these gaps and strengthen emergency preparedness against AI threats.

Focuses on mitigating risks such as the development of biological weapons and drug-resistant viruses and bacteria.

Requires the strategy to be submitted to relevant congressional committees without compromising national security.

Amends the Public Health Service Act to integrate this AI threat strategy into the broader federal response to public health emergencies.

column2: To direct the Director of the National Institutes of Health to establish a grant program to facilitate research regarding the use of generative artificial intelligence in health care, and for other purposes.
column3: H.R. 7381 (Health AI)
column15: Establishes a grant program by the National Institutes of Health Director to fund generative AI research in health care. Permits research on note-taking, claims, and customer service. Prioritizes AI adoption, workforce development, and reducing health disparities. Defines eligible entities.
column16:
Establishes a grant program by the Director of the National Institutes of Health to fund research on the use of generative AI in health care.

Permits research to include enhancing note-taking, reducing administrative burdens, expediting insurance claims, improving customer service efficiency, and other health care improvements.

Prioritizes grants for entities promoting AI adoption in health care, investing in workforce development, mitigating workforce burnout, reducing health disparities, and improving care for medically underserved populations.

Defines eligible entities to include higher education institutions, nonprofit organizations, and various governmental agencies.

Defines "generative artificial intelligence" as AI producing content in response to prompts.

column2: A bill to promote United States leadership in technical standards by directing the National Institute of Standards and Technology and the Department of State to take certain actions to encourage and enable United States participation in developing standards and specifications for artificial intelligence and other critical and emerging technologies, and for other purposes.
column3: S. 3849 (US Leadership in AI Standards)
column15: Requires NIST Director to brief Congress on federal AI standards participation within one year. Directs federal agencies to notify NIST of AI standards activities. Mandates NIST to create a reporting mechanism and establish a web portal. Establishes a pilot program for U.S.-based standards meetings. Obligates annual NIST briefings to Congress on the pilot program. Authorizes $10 million for the pilot program from 2024 to 2028.
column16:
Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to brief Congress within one year on federal participation opportunities in AI and emerging technology standards development.

Directs federal agencies to notify NIST of their involvement in AI standards activities and mandates NIST to create a reporting mechanism for this purpose.

Mandates NIST to establish a web portal to inform U.S. industry and federal agencies about international standards efforts and participation opportunities.

Establishes a pilot program for supporting U.S.-based standards meetings, including prestandardization and coordination meetings, through grants to eligible entities.

Obligates NIST to brief Congress annually on the pilot program’s effectiveness and provide recommendations for permanent implementation if deemed feasible.

Authorizes $10 million for the pilot program from fiscal years 2024 through 2028.

column2: Advanced Weather Model Computing Development Act
column3: Advanced Weather Model Computing Development Act
column15: Directs DOE and NOAA to research AI and high-performance computing for climate and weather. Requires an MOU for collaboration. Authorizes research on advanced techniques. Mandates data sharing across agencies. Instructs a report in two years. Sunsets in five years. Ensures CHIPS Act compliance.
column16:
Directs the Department of Energy (DOE) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to collaborate on AI and high-performance computing research to improve climate models and weather prediction.

Requires the establishment of a memorandum of understanding to facilitate this collaboration through a competitive, merit-reviewed process.

Authorizes the Secretary of Energy and NOAA Administrator to conduct research on modeling, simulation, machine learning, data assimilation, and predictive analysis techniques.

Mandates the promotion of collaboration and data sharing among federal agencies, National Laboratories, educational institutions, and nonprofits, while ensuring compliance with national security policies.

Instructs the submission of a report within two years detailing interagency coordination, research achievements, and future opportunities.

Initiates a high-performance computing project to enhance weather prediction models, requiring a comparative analysis with current forecasts.

Sunsets the authority for this initiative five years post-enactment.

Ensures compliance with research security provisions under the CHIPS Act of 2022.

column2: DOE and NSF Interagency Research Act
column3: DOE and NSF Interagency Research Act
column15: Requires DOE and NSF to coordinate R&D activities. Mandates memorandum of understanding for competitive, merit-reviewed project applications. Authorizes collaborative research in AI, machine learning, data analytics, quantum computing, and computational sciences. Promotes interagency collaboration and data sharing. Supports research infrastructure and STEM education. Allows reimbursable agreements. Obligates reporting within two years. Ensures compliance with research security provisions.
column16:
Requires the Department of Energy (DOE) and the National Science Foundation (NSF) to coordinate research and development activities.

Mandates the establishment of a memorandum of understanding between the DOE and NSF, utilizing a competitive, merit-reviewed process for project applications.

Authorizes collaborative research in key areas including artificial intelligence, machine learning, data analytics, quantum computing, and computational sciences.

Promotes interagency collaboration and data sharing among Federal agencies, National Laboratories, and other institutions.

Supports research infrastructure development and STEM education initiatives, including internships and professional development.

Allows reimbursable agreements between the DOE and NSF to enhance research effectiveness.

Obligates the DOE and NSF to report on interagency coordination, research achievements, and future opportunities within two years of enactment.

Ensures activities comply with research security provisions under existing law.

column2: FAIRR Act
column3: FAIRR Act
column15: Amends the Financial Stability Act of 2010 to assign AI oversight duties. Requires coordination on AI risks and directs research on AI use. Obligates threat identification and mandates a report on regulatory gaps. Calls for disruption defense exercises. Expands oversight authority. Increases penalties for AI-related securities violations. Imposes developer liability for AI outcomes.
column16:
Amends the Financial Stability Act of 2010 to assign the Financial Stability Oversight Council duties regarding AI in the financial sector.

Requires the Council to coordinate with member agencies on AI-related financial system risks and direct the Office of Financial Research to study AI use by financial institutions.

Obligates the Council to identify AI-related threats to financial stability, including market manipulation and disruption by malign actors.

Mandates submission of a report within 180 days identifying regulatory gaps and recommending solutions, including referencing the NSA's September 2023 Cybersecurity Information Sheet.

Calls for scenario-based exercises to test AI-related financial disruption defenses.

Expands authority to oversee third-party AI service providers to financial institutions.

Increases penalties for securities violations involving machine-manipulated media to three times the standard amount.

Imposes liability on developers for AI model outcomes under Federal securities laws, with limited potential for waivers.

column2: Candidate Voice Fraud Prohibition Act
column3: Candidate Voice Fraud Prohibition Act
column15: Prohibits materially deceptive AI-generated audio impersonating candidates with actual malice. Applies within 90 days of general elections, 60 days for others. Excludes specific media entities. Defines key terms. Mandates fines or imprisonment. Requires FEC regulations and reports.
column16:
Prohibits the distribution of political communications containing materially deceptive AI-generated audio that impersonates a candidate’s voice, with actual malice, intended to harm the candidate’s reputation or deceive voters.

Applies to communications distributed within 90 days of a general election or 60 days of a primary, special, or runoff election.

Excludes radio/television stations, bona fide news broadcasts, satire or parody, and certain internet and media entities from this prohibition.

Defines "materially deceptive audio" as AI-generated impersonation of a candidate’s voice without approval and lacking a clear disclaimer.

Defines "actual malice" as knowingly or recklessly using AI to create false representations.

Mandates criminal penalties of fines or up to 2 years imprisonment for violators.

Requires the Federal Election Commission (FEC) to issue regulations and provide annual compliance reports.

column2: Small Business Broadband and Emerging Information Technology Enhancement Act of 2023
column3: S. 2677 Small Business Technology Enhancement Act
column15: Designates a senior employee as the broadband and emerging technologies coordinator. Requires collaboration with SBA officials and federal agencies. Mandates identification of best practices and training. Requires biennial reports. Instructs the Chief Counsel for Advocacy to study impacts. Amends the Small Business Act.
column16:
Designates a senior employee of the Office of Investment and Innovation as the broadband and emerging information technology coordinator to assist small businesses in adopting broadband and emerging technologies.

Requires the coordinator to work with the SBA's chief information officer, chief technology officer, and other relevant federal agencies.

Mandates the coordinator to identify best practices and catalog tools and training for small businesses on broadband and emerging technologies.

Obligates the coordinator to provide training to SBA employees on these technologies and relevant federal programs.

Requires biennial reports on the SBA's activities related to broadband and emerging technologies.

Instructs the Chief Counsel for Advocacy to study and report on the impact of broadband availability, speed, and price, and the deployment of emerging technologies on small businesses.

Amends the Small Business Act to include provisions for increasing small business access to broadband and emerging technologies.

column2: Digital Platform Commission Act of 2023
column3: Digital Platform Commission Act of 2023
column15: Establishes the Federal Digital Platform Commission to regulate digital platforms. Mandates oversight of AI for fairness, transparency, and safety. Requires data portability and interoperability standards. Obligates bias-free algorithms. Introduces transparency and public risk assessments. Allows enforcement through complaints and penalties.
column16:
Establishes the Federal Digital Platform Commission to regulate digital platforms.

Mandates oversight of algorithmic processes, including those using AI, for fairness, transparency, and safety.

Requires systemically important digital platforms to meet commercial and technical standards for data portability and interoperability.

Obligates platforms to ensure recommendation systems and other algorithmic processes are free from harmful, abusive, anticompetitive, or deceptive biases.

Introduces transparency requirements for terms of service and content moderation policies.

Imposes regular public risk assessments for harmful content distribution and steps to mitigate such harms, including those from algorithmic processes.

Provides for inter-agency consultation and support, including with the FTC and DOJ, on matters related to digital platforms.

Allows private persons and governmental entities to enforce the Act through complaints, civil actions, and penalties.

column2: RESTRICT Act
column3: RESTRICT Act
column15: Authorizes the Secretary of Commerce to review and prohibit certain ICT transactions with foreign adversaries. Empowers the Secretary to mitigate risks from covered transactions. Defines "covered transactions" broadly. Establishes referral procedures to the President. Prioritizes critical ICT areas. Exempts actions from standard reviews. Imposes penalties for violations.
column16:
Authorizes the Secretary of Commerce to review and prohibit certain transactions involving information and communications technology (ICT) between U.S. persons and foreign adversaries.

Empowers the Secretary to identify, deter, disrupt, prevent, prohibit, investigate, or mitigate risks arising from covered transactions.

Defines "covered transactions" broadly, including those involving foreign adversaries or entities under their jurisdiction.

Establishes procedures for the Secretary to refer covered holdings posing national security risks to the President, who can then compel divestment or take other actions to mitigate risks.

Prioritizes critical ICT areas such as AI, quantum computing, and telecommunications for evaluation.

Exempts actions from standard administrative and judicial reviews, limiting legal challenges to specific high courts.

Imposes civil and criminal penalties for violations, including fines, imprisonment, and forfeiture.

column2: Next Generation Pipelines Research and Development Act
column3: H. R. 7073 Pipelines R&D Act
column15: Creates a demonstration initiative to advance pipeline technologies through competitive financial assistance. Establishes a joint R&D program within the DOE, DOT, and NIST. Forms the National Pipeline Modernization Center. Mandates NIST standardization programs. Authorizes significant funding for 2024-2028.
column16:
Creates a demonstration initiative to advance next-generation pipeline technologies, awarding financial assistance to eligible entities through a competitive process.

Establishes a joint research and development program within the Department of Energy, coordinated with the Department of Transportation and the National Institute of Standards and Technology, to develop advanced materials and technologies for pipeline systems.

Forms the National Pipeline Modernization Center to collaborate on research, development, and demonstration projects for commercializing cost-effective pipeline products and procedures.

Mandates the development of measurement research, testing, and standardization programs by the National Institute of Standards and Technology to ensure pipeline integrity and support safety, security, and efficiency.

Authorizes significant appropriations for fiscal years 2024 through 2028 to support these initiatives.

column2: Advanced Weather Model Computing Development Act
column3: S. 3642 Weather Model Computing Act
column15: Directs collaborative research using AI to improve weather models. Requires a memorandum of understanding through a merit-reviewed process. Mandates exploration of code portability. Supports infrastructure and data sharing. Initiates a computing research initiative. Permits up to three centers of excellence. Prioritizes AI-enabled Labs. Mandates reports to Congress.
column16:
Directs the Secretary of Energy and the NOAA Administrator to conduct collaborative research using advanced computing techniques, including AI, to improve weather models.

Requires establishment of a memorandum of understanding to facilitate this collaboration through a competitive, merit-reviewed process.

Mandates exploration of performance portability of weather model codes between operational and high-performance computing systems.

Supports maintenance and improvement of scientific computing infrastructure, data sharing, and collaboration among federal entities and institutions.

Initiates a computing research initiative to develop advanced weather models, leveraging data and efforts from relevant interagency entities.

Permits establishment of up to three centers of excellence at National Laboratories to support advanced weather models through public-private partnerships and high-performance computing.

Prioritizes selection of Laboratories with AI-enabled computing systems and expertise in weather and climate modeling.

Mandates submission of reports to Congress detailing interagency coordination, achievements, and future opportunities for collaboration in advanced computing techniques.

column2: Technology Workforce Framework Act of 2024
column3: S. 3792 Technology Workforce Framework Act
column15: Expands NIST functions to develop workforce frameworks for critical technologies, including AI. Requires Director to update AI workforce framework triennially. Mandates inclusion of diverse skills. Instructs stakeholder consultation. Obligates multilingual resources. Requires periodic Congressional reports. Directs additional frameworks development.
column16:
Expands the functions of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to include developing workforce frameworks for critical and emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence (AI).

Requires the Director of NIST to develop, maintain, and update an AI workforce framework and review it at least every three years.

Mandates the inclusion of professional, support, and operational skills in AI workforce frameworks, considering nontraditional backgrounds.

Instructs the Director to consult with various stakeholders, including federal agencies and educational institutions, in developing these frameworks.

Obliges the Director to produce multilingual resources to support global adoption of these frameworks.

Requires periodic reports to Congress on updates and the process of reviewing workforce frameworks, including the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education Workforce Framework for Cybersecurity.

Directs the development and publication of additional workforce frameworks for other critical technologies, such as quantum information science.

column2: MEANS Act
column3: MEANS Act
column15: Establishes an Office of Manufacturing Security and Resilience within the Department of Commerce. Mandates the Under Secretary to develop a supply chain strategy. Requires federal agency collaboration. Incentivizes domestic manufacturing relocation. Prioritizes supply chain resilience. Allocates $35 billion.
column16:
Establishes an Office of Manufacturing Security and Resilience within the Department of Commerce to oversee the Manufacturing Security and Resilience Program.

Mandates the Under Secretary to develop and implement a strategy to strengthen supply chains for critical goods, reducing reliance on concentrated supply chains, particularly from countries of concern.

Requires collaboration with other federal agencies to support allies and key international partners in building manufacturing capacity for critical goods.

Incentivizes domestic manufacturers to relocate production from countries of concern and increase production capacity, using loans, loan guarantees, and other financial supports.

Prioritizes support for activities that enhance the resilience, security, and diversity of supply chains and address supply chain shocks.

Mandates periodic submission of strategy reports and program evaluations to Congress, with updates every four years.

Allocates $35 billion for fiscal years 2024-2028 to fund the program, with specific allocations for loans, loan guarantees, and administrative costs.

column2: Data Science and Literacy Act of 2023
column3: Data Science and Literacy Act
column15: Directs the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to enhance data literacy education. Requires detailed plans in applications. Mandates developing curricula, professional development, and industry collaboration. Limits equipment purchases. Obligates biannual reporting. Tasks Secretary with reporting to Congress. Authorizes $10 million annually.
column16:
Directs the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to eligible entities to enhance data literacy education from pre-kindergarten through postsecondary levels.

Requires grant applications to detail plans for increasing access to data literacy and STEM education, evaluating project activities, and continuing efforts post-grant.

Mandates the use of grant funds for developing data literacy curricula, providing professional development for educators, and collaborating with industry and educational institutions.

Limits equipment purchases to 15% of grant funds annually.

Obligates recipients to submit biannual reports on grant fund usage, with data disaggregated by race, ethnicity, gender, and eligibility for free/reduced lunch.

Tasks the Secretary with submitting a comprehensive report to Congress within five years, including recommendations for program expansion.

Authorizes $10 million annually for fiscal years 2024-2028, with caps on administrative expenses and program evaluation costs.

column2: To establish in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration a program to improve precipitation forecasts, and for other purposes.
column3: H. R. 4913 NOAA Precipitation Forecasts
column15: Establishes a NOAA program to improve precipitation forecasts using Earth System Models, high performance computing, machine learning, and AI. Supports R&D with partners. Enhances prediction accuracy, reliability, and communication. Coordinates with various entities. Authorizes $15 million annually (2024-2028).
column16:
Establishes a program within the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to improve precipitation forecasts.

Requires the use of fully coupled Earth System Models to enhance precipitation prediction.

Mandates the utilization of high performance computing and other technologies, including machine learning and artificial intelligence, to advance precipitation forecasts.

Supports research and development in collaboration with academic and private sector partners to test and evaluate emerging technologies.

Improves the accuracy, reliability, and timeliness of precipitation predictions across various timescales.

Incorporates social and behavioral sciences to enhance precipitation forecast products and communication.

Coordinates efforts with Federal, State, local, Tribal, and academic entities.

Authorizes appropriations of $15 million annually from fiscal year 2024 through fiscal year 2028 for the program.

column2: DOE and NASA Interagency Research Coordination Act
column3: DOE and NASA Research Coordination Act
column15: Requires DOE and NASA to coordinate AI-related R&D activities. Mandates memoranda of understanding for coordination. Allows competitive awards for collaboration. Directs development of large data handling methods. Promotes secure data sharing. Authorizes agreements. Obligates biannual reporting. Ensures research security compliance.
column16:
Requires the Department of Energy (DOE) and NASA to coordinate research and development activities, including AI-related areas such as machine learning, data analytics, and predictive analysis.

Mandates the use of memoranda of understanding for coordination.

Allows for competitive awards to support collaborative R&D activities.

Directs the development of methods to handle large data sets on high-performance computing systems.

Promotes data sharing between DOE, NASA, National Laboratories, and other entities, ensuring secure data transfer.

Authorizes reimbursable and non-reimbursable agreements between DOE and NASA.

Ensures competitive awards follow merit-review processes and consider applications from various entities.

Obligates a report within two years on coordination activities, achievements, and future plans.

Requires consistency with research security laws.

column2: Weather Information for Agriculture Act
column3: Weather Information for Agriculture Act
column15: Reauthorizes the National Integrated Drought Information System. Requires AI and machine learning for drought forecasting. Mandates improved observational networks and soil moisture monitoring. Establishes memoranda with the National Mesonet Program. Authorizes funds from $15M to $17M (2024-2028).
column16:
Reauthorizes the National Integrated Drought Information System.

Requires advancement and deployment of AI, machine learning, and cloud technologies for drought forecasting.

Mandates strengthening observational networks and drought indicators, addressing gaps in snowpack and soil moisture monitoring.

Establishes memoranda of understanding with the National Mesonet Program for coordinated drought information.

Requires migration to probabilistic forecasts and incorporation of new modeling tools with the Climate Prediction Center.

Authorizes appropriations from $15,000,000 in fiscal year 2024 to $17,000,000 in fiscal year 2028 for these activities.

Mandates development, deployment, and maintenance of the National Coordinated Soil Moisture Monitoring Network.

Requires establishment of a user-friendly website, high-quality data criteria, and increased in situ soil moisture monitoring stations.

Promotes research, data sharing, and engagement with the citizen science community for soil moisture monitoring.

Allows partnerships to provide nationwide soil moisture information.

column2: Integrating New Technologies to Empower Law Enforcement at Our Borders Act
column3: New Technologies at Borders Act
column15: Requires the Department of Homeland Security to develop a comprehensive plan within 180 days for border technology integration. Mandates inclusion of advanced technologies and assessments of current CBP usage. Requires cost estimates, impact metrics, and coordination with the Science and Technology Directorate.
column16:
Requires the Department of Homeland Security to develop a comprehensive plan within 180 days to identify, deploy, and integrate emerging and advanced technologies to enhance situational awareness along the northern and southern borders of the United States.

Mandates the inclusion of artificial intelligence, machine learning, automation, fiber-optic sensing, nanotechnology, optical and cognitive radar, modeling and simulation technology, hyperspectral and LIDAR sensors, and other similar technologies.

Includes an assessment of current technology utilization by U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and how capability gaps can be addressed through technology integration.

Requires cost estimates for technology acquisition and maintenance, metrics for measuring technology impact, and an assessment of multi-domain awareness improvements.

Mandates an analysis of other Federal technologies, procurement authorities, and the transition of new technology systems.

Requires coordination with the Department of Homeland Security's Science and Technology Directorate for research, development, and incentivizing private sector innovation.

column2: Digital Defense Content Provenance Act of 2023
column3: Digital Defense Content Provenance Act
column15:
Establishes a course at the Defense Information School on digital content provenance for DoD media.

Requires coverage of content forgery challenges, industry standards, and secure documentation techniques.

Mandates a report on curriculum development and resource needs.

Initiates a pilot program to assess industry standards for digital content provenance.

Directs the program to verify provenance, apply technology, assess records, and measure effectiveness.

Allows consultation with research centers, industry, and educational institutions.

Terminates the pilot on January 1, 2027.

Requires a report by January 1, 2026, on findings, consultations, effectiveness, and recommendations.
column16:
Establishes a course at the Defense Information School to educate on digital content provenance for Department of Defense (DoD) media content.

Requires the course to cover challenges from digital content forgery, industry open technical standards, and techniques for secure digital content documentation.

Mandates a report on the curriculum development and implementation plan for the course, including resource needs.

Initiates a pilot program to assess the feasibility of using industry open technical standards for digital content provenance in DoD media.

Directs the pilot program to verify digital content provenance, apply technology solutions, assess historical records, and develop effectiveness measures.

Allows the Director to consult with research centers, private industry, and educational institutions.

Terminates the pilot program on January 1, 2027.

Requires a report by January 1, 2026, detailing findings, consultations, effectiveness, and recommendations on the pilot program's permanence.

column2: Advancing Nuclear Regulatory Oversight Act
column3: Advancing Nuclear Regulatory Oversight Act
column15: Requires the NRC to report to Congress within 180 days on COVID-19 regulatory changes. Mandates a report within one year on oversight improvements using AI. Instructs stakeholder input. Requires assessment of modifications and improvements. Obligates actions based on assessments.
column16:
Requires the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to report to Congress within 180 days on regulatory changes made during the COVID-19 emergency, examining their impact on licensing and safety.

Mandates the NRC to develop and submit a report within one year identifying specific improvements in oversight and inspection programs, emphasizing risk-informed, performance-based procedures and the use of advanced technologies, including AI and machine learning.

Instructs the NRC to seek input from stakeholders including the Secretary of Energy, National Laboratories, the nuclear energy industry, and relevant NGOs in developing the report.

Requires assessment of potential modifications to oversight and inspections, improvement measures, and incorporation of advanced technologies to enhance operational efficiency and safety.

Obligates the NRC to identify and implement actions based on assessments and recommendations to improve training, inspection, oversight, and licensing activities without compromising its mission.

column2: Shifting Forward Vehicle Technologies Research and Development Act
column3: Vehicle Technologies R&D Act
column15: Requires the Secretary of Energy to advance vehicle technologies for emission reduction and cost efficiency. Mandates coordination with federal agencies. Supports battery and electrification tech development. Establishes security measures. Emphasizes commercial vehicle energy efficiency. Authorizes over $2.9 billion funding.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Energy to conduct a research, development, and demonstration program for advanced vehicle technologies, focusing on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and vehicle manufacturing costs.

Mandates coordination with other federal agencies and existing programs on electric vehicle integration and critical material recycling.

Supports the development of advanced batteries, power electronics, electric drive systems, and vehicle electrification technologies.

Includes provisions for cybersecurity and physical security of vehicle interconnections with the electric grid and other infrastructure.

Establishes a program for medium- and heavy-duty commercial and transit vehicles, emphasizing advanced energy technologies and efficiency improvements.

Authorizes the creation of Graduate Automotive Technology Education Centers of Research Excellence to foster advancements in automotive energy technologies.

Allocates substantial funding for these initiatives through fiscal year 2028, with a total authorization exceeding $2.9 billion.

column2: Promoting Digital Privacy Technologies Act
column3: Promoting Digital Privacy Technologies Act
column15: Introduces the "Promoting Digital Privacy Technologies Act." Requires the National Science Foundation to support research on privacy enhancing technologies. Mandates integration into the Computer and Network Security Program. Obliges interagency coordination. Demands stakeholder outreach. Requires a progress report within three years.
column16:
Introduces the "Promoting Digital Privacy Technologies Act."

Requires the National Science Foundation to support research on privacy enhancing technologies, including de-identification, pseudonymization, and algorithms for data privacy.

Mandates integration of privacy enhancing technologies into the Computer and Network Security Program as per the Cyber Security Research and Development Act.

Obliges coordination among the Office of Science and Technology Policy, National Science Foundation, National Institute of Standards and Technology, and Federal Trade Commission to expedite development and use of privacy enhancing technologies.

Demands outreach by the National Institute of Standards and Technology to gather stakeholder input and promote private and public sector engagement.

Requires submission of a report within three years on research progress, development of voluntary resources, and policy recommendations to improve communication and coordination among stakeholders.

column2: Exploitative Workplace Surveillance and Technologies Task Force Act of 2023
column3: Exploitative Workplace Technologies Task Force Act
column15: Establishes the White House Task Force on Workplace Surveillance and Technologies within 180 days. Mandates study and evaluation of workplace surveillance and automated decision systems. Requires analysis of prevalence, types, and impacts across industries. Necessitates examination of effects on worker compensation, performance reviews, scheduling, career advancement, safety, health coverage, and discipline. Obligates consideration of impacts on vulnerable populations. Orders submission of initial, interim, and final reports to Congress. Terminates the Task Force 60 days after the final report.
column16:
Establishes the White House Task Force on Workplace Surveillance and Technologies within 180 days of enactment.

Mandates the Task Force to study and evaluate the use of workplace surveillance and automated decision systems by employers.

Requires the Task Force to analyze the prevalence, types, and impacts of workplace surveillance across industries, including data collection, storage, security, and transfer practices.

Necessitates examination of the effects of workplace surveillance on worker compensation, performance reviews, scheduling, career advancement, safety, health coverage, and discipline.

Obligates the Task Force to consider the impact on vulnerable populations, including workers with disabilities, low-wage workers, and workers of color.

Orders the Task Force to submit initial, interim, and final reports to Congress, detailing findings and providing recommendations on addressing workplace surveillance and related technologies.

Terminates the Task Force 60 days after submitting the final report.

column2: National Strategy to Utilize Microreactors for Natural Disaster Response Efforts Act
column3: Microreactors for Natural Disaster Response Act
column15: Mandates the President develop a national microreactor strategy for disaster response. Requires consultation with key agencies. Obligates submission to Congress within one year and biennially. Includes environmental assessment. Recommends expedited approval. Encourages AI use. Evaluates strategic considerations and partnerships.
column16:
Mandates the President develop a national strategy for utilizing microreactors to assist with natural disaster response efforts.

Requires consultation with FEMA, DOE, National Guard, Army Corps of Engineers, and Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

Obligates submission of the strategy to Congress within one year and biennially thereafter.

Includes an assessment of current diesel generator usage and environmental impacts compared to microreactors.

Outlines goals and objectives for replacing diesel generators with microreactors.

Calls for a Department of Defense analysis on translating operational microreactor technology for disaster response.

Recommends expedited design approval and licensing for microreactors.

Assesses strategic considerations, including storage, transportation, and integration into existing grids.

Evaluates partnership opportunities for effective deployment.

Encourages the use of AI and predictive tools for disaster preparation involving microreactors.

column2: Promoting Resilient Supply Chains Act of 2023
column3: Promoting Resilient Supply Chains Act
column15: Requires the Assistant Secretary of Commerce to promote U.S. leadership in AI and strengthen supply chains. Mandates a resiliency program. Requires coordination with agencies. Promotes domestic manufacturing. Supports best practices. Mandates regular reporting on AI supply chains.
column16:
Requires the Assistant Secretary of Commerce to promote U.S. leadership in emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence (AI), and strengthen critical supply chains and national security.

Mandates the establishment of a critical supply chain resiliency and crisis response program within the Department of Commerce, which includes mapping and monitoring AI supply chains.

Requires coordination with other agencies, industry, and international partners to identify vulnerabilities and prepare for supply chain shocks affecting AI technologies.

Promotes the growth of domestic manufacturing capacities for AI and other emerging technologies and encourages the relocation of manufacturing facilities to the U.S. or allied countries.

Supports the development and dissemination of best practices for supply chain resilience, including the use of blockchain and other technologies to authenticate and trace critical goods.

Mandates regular reporting on the state of AI and other emerging technology supply chains, including assessments of vulnerabilities and recommendations for enhancing resilience.

column2: Do Not Disturb Act
column3: Do Not Disturb Act
column15: Requires disclosure at the start of AI-emulated robocalls or texts. Enhances penalties for AI impersonation violations, doubling fines for fraudulent AI calls. Mandates FCC to offer free robocall-blocking and track top 100 illegal campaigns. Obligates VoIP providers to verify identities and report violations. Directs FCC and FTC to study and regulate AI in robocalls and telemarketing.
column16:
Requires disclosure at the beginning of robocalls or text messages if artificial intelligence is used to emulate a human being.

Enhances penalties for robocall and telemarketing violations involving AI impersonation, doubling fines for fraudulent or harmful AI-generated calls or messages.

Mandates the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to offer robocall-blocking services at no charge and to develop a tracking system for the top 100 illegal robocall campaigns.

Obligates Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) providers to verify customer identities, monitor robocall patterns, and report violations.

Directs both the FCC and Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to study and regulate AI usage in robocalls and telemarketing, including text message authentication and inbound call restrictions.

column2: Novel, Advanced Spectrum and Communications Technology Networks Promotion Act
column3: Advanced Communications Technology Networks Act
column15: Directs the Assistant Secretary of Commerce to support common models for spectrum management. Requires development of RF emission control technologies. Mandates AI system prototyping for advanced antennas. Encourages skilled workforce development. Supports institutional partnerships. Amends NTIA responsibilities.
column16:
Directs the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information to support the establishment, prototyping, and implementation of common models and methodologies to inform electromagnetic spectrum management decisions.

Requires the development of technologies and techniques to control radio frequency emissions and interference.

Mandates the prototyping of artificial intelligence systems and technologies capable of operating advanced antenna arrays and dynamic spectrum access.

Encourages the development and participation of a skilled workforce to prototype advanced communications technologies.

Supports partnerships among institutions for workforce development in advanced communications technologies.

Identifies and implements technologies that promote dynamic spectrum access, network sensing, monitoring, and optical and quantum communications.

Amends section 104 of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to include these additional responsibilities for the Assistant Secretary.

column2: Oversee Emerging Technology Act
column3: Oversee Emerging Technology Act
column15: Requires federal agency heads to appoint a Senior Executive Service individual as an emerging technology lead. Mandates these leads to advise on responsible use, provide expertise, collaborate interagency, and guide procurement. Instructs President to inform Congress within 180 days.
column16:
Requires the head of each covered federal agency engaged in emerging technologies to appoint or designate a Senior Executive Service individual or equivalent as an emerging technology lead.

Mandates that these leads advise agencies on the responsible use of emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence.

Obliges these leads to provide expertise on responsible policies and practices, collaborate with interagency bodies, and input on procurement policies.

Instructs the President to inform Congress within 180 days of enactment about the appointed leads and their authorities and responsibilities.

column2: Diversify Tech Act
column3: Diversify Tech Act
column15: Establishes a DEIA Task Force within the Department of Commerce. Mandates audits on minority representation, hiring policies, and layoff trends. Requires initial and annual reports to Congress. Obligates promotion of DEIA, stakeholder consultations, and advice on outreach and investment.
column16:
Establishes a Tech Industry Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility (DEIA) Task Force within the Department of Commerce.

Mandates the Task Force to conduct audits on minority representation, hiring policies, and layoff trends in the tech industry.

Requires submission of an initial audit report to Congress within 60 days of the Task Force’s establishment.

Obliges the Task Force to promote DEIA, offer guidance to tech entities, and consult with stakeholders on DEIA issues.

Tasks the Task Force with advising on outreach programs and encouraging venture capital investment in minority-owned startups.

Mandates annual reports evaluating tech industry progress on DEIA goals, the impact of AI on discrimination, and proposing policy solutions for accountability.

Requires a special report on how 2023 tech layoffs affected DEIA, including potential violations of federal laws.

column2: Water Infrastructure Modernization Act of 2023
column3: Water Infrastructure Modernization Act
column15: Amends water laws to authorize grants for AI-based smart water infrastructure. Requires EPA to fund AI wastewater and drinking water systems. Specifies funding allocations for rural and Tribal communities. Mandates EPA guidance and funding decisions. Authorizes $25 million through 2028.
column16:
Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act and the Safe Drinking Water Act to authorize grants for smart water infrastructure technology.

Requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to provide grants for intelligent wastewater treatment systems using AI for predictive maintenance and real-time monitoring.

Mandates grants for smart drinking water systems with AI tools to reduce water loss, improve decision-making, and enhance operational efficiency.

Specifies that 25% of the grant funds are set aside for rural communities and 10% for Tribal communities.

Obligates the EPA to issue guidance for grant applications within 30 days of enactment and make funding decisions within 60 days.

Requires annual reports to Congress on the projects funded and their impacts.

Authorizes $25 million for fiscal years 2024 through 2028 for both wastewater and drinking water infrastructure projects.

column2: HEARTS Act of 2022
column3: HEARTS Act
column15: Prioritizes nonanimal methods in NIH research proposals. Establishes a National Center for Alternatives to Animals. Requires the center to develop, promote, and fund nonanimal research, including AI. Mandates researcher training. Obligates federal reporting on animal use. Ensures expert review. Implements incentives. Requires alternative searches.
column16:
Prioritizes nonanimal methods in NIH-supported research proposals.

Establishes the National Center for Alternatives to Animals in Research and Testing within NIH.

Requires the new center to develop, promote, and fund nonanimal research methods, including AI.

Mandates the center to provide training and resources to researchers on nonanimal methods.

Obligates federally funded research entities to report the number and species of animals used and plans to reduce their use.

Ensures research proposals are reviewed by experts in nonanimal methods.

Implements a system of incentives to encourage the use of humane and scientifically satisfactory nonanimal methods.

Requires thorough searches for nonanimal alternatives before approving animal use in research.

column2: Counseling for Career Choice Act
column3: Counseling for Career Choice Act
column15: Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to expand career counseling opportunities. Requires leveraging AI and emerging technologies. Mandates professional training certification. Encourages partnerships with workforce entities. Promotes postsecondary opportunities. Requires assessment of counseling activities. Mandates outcome evaluations.
column16:
Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to expand career counseling opportunities.

Requires career counseling programs to leverage resources and emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence.

Mandates the development of professional development or career development training certification programs for counselors and educators.

Encourages partnerships with one-stop centers and integration with local and state workforce entities.

Promotes the establishment and coordination of postsecondary opportunities such as internships, apprenticeships, and dual enrollment programs.

Requires the identification and assessment of school counseling activities and postsecondary options within and outside the state.

Mandates the evaluation of secondary and postsecondary outcomes for individuals served by career counseling programs.

column2: Wildfire Technology Demonstration, Evaluation, Modernization, and Optimization Act
column3: Wildfire Technology DEMO Act
column15: Establishes a wildfire technology testbed pilot program within 60 days. Incorporates the program into an interagency group on wildfires. Identifies key technology priorities. Partners private entities with federal agencies. Prioritizes emerging technologies. Requires applications. Mandates annual reports. Terminates in four years.
column16:
Establishes a wildfire technology testbed pilot program within 60 days of the Act's enactment, coordinated by the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior.

Incorporates the program into an existing interagency coordinating group on wildfires.

Identifies key technology priority areas, including hazardous fuels reduction, dispatch communications, remote sensing, safety equipment, and operational dashboards.

Partners selected private entities, nonprofits, and higher education institutions with federal agencies for real-time testing during wildfire mitigation.

Prioritizes emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, quantum sensing, augmented reality, and advanced communications for wildfire mitigation.

Requires covered entities to submit applications, including technology testing proposals.

Mandates annual reports to Congress on participating entities, tested technologies, costs, outreach efforts, and technology assessments.

Terminates the program four years after establishment.

column2: Outbound Investment Transparency Act of 2023
column3: Outbound Investment Transparency Act
column15: Requires mandatory notification of specific foreign investments in advanced sectors, including AI, to the Secretary of the Treasury. Defines covered activities and establishes penalties for non-compliance. Mandates regulation creation, international coordination, and annual reporting to Congress.
column16:
Requires mandatory notification by U.S. persons engaging in specific foreign investments related to advanced sectors, including artificial intelligence, to the Secretary of the Treasury.

Defines covered activities involving equity interests, debt obligations with governance rights, and joint ventures in countries of concern, with specific focus on AI and other advanced technologies.

Establishes penalties for non-compliance, including failure to notify or providing false information.

Mandates the creation of regulations to ensure clarity and minimize compliance burdens, with a focus on transparency and stakeholder involvement.

Directs the Secretary of State to engage with allied countries to coordinate investment screening mechanisms and share information on covered activities.

Requires annual reporting to Congress on trends, national security risks, and recommendations related to these foreign investments in AI and other sectors.

column2: Forest Data Modernization Act of 2023
column3: Forest Data Modernization Act
column15: Amends the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Research Act to include forest carbon in assessments. Requires timber output studies and woodland surveys. Mandates bi-decadal forest carbon data reviews. Updates strategic plan for data collection, transparency, and technology integration.
column16:
Amends the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Research Act to include forest carbon in resource assessments.

Requires the Secretary to conduct timber products output studies and national woodland owner surveys.

Mandates the integration of forest carbon data in bi-decadal reviews.

Specifies the need for clear definitions of "forest" in reporting data.

Updates strategic plan to include consistent data collection protocols, integration of new technologies, and enhanced transparency.

Ensures collected data is accessible while maintaining confidentiality of sensitive information.

Compiles and publishes biennial national forest statistics.

Establishes an office or platform to handle complex data requests, with possible fees imposed on requestors.

Publishes annual reports detailing progress on strategic plan implementation, including costs and priorities.

Amends Agriculture Improvement Act to utilize advanced remote sensing and machine learning technologies for data collection and modeling.

column2: SAFE from PRC Investments Act
column3: SAFE from PRC Investments Act
column15: Requires public companies and ETFs investing in PRC-linked firms to disclose PRC/CPC officials on boards or in executive roles. Mandates disclosure of PRC cash holdings, repatriation restrictions, assets, liabilities, and technology transfers. Obligates reporting on CPC interactions, PRC expenditures, and U.S. lobbying. Compels ETFs to reveal ownership, CPC branches, contracts, and PRC industrial/military involvement. Requires disclosure of PRC companies' products, U.S. defense contracts, and involvement in AI, telecommunications, and semiconductors.
column16:
Requires public companies and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) investing in companies with ties to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) to disclose whether senior officials of the PRC government or Communist Party of China (CPC) sit on their boards or have executive roles.

Mandates disclosure of cash held in PRC operations, restrictions on cash repatriation, and details of assets, liabilities, and technology transfers.

Obligates reporting on interactions with CPC officials, expenditures on PRC operations, and any lobbying activities in the United States.

Compels ETFs to reveal ownership, CPC branches, contractual agreements, and involvement in PRC industrial policies or military contracts of invested PRC companies.

Requires disclosure of PRC companies’ products and services, U.S. defense contracts, and involvement in sectors like AI, telecommunications, and semiconductors.

column2: Preventing Adversaries from Developing Critical Capabilities Act
column3: Preventing Adversaries from Developing Critical Capabilities Act
column15: Prohibits U.S. persons from engaging in certain technologies and products in countries of concern if posing national security threats. Requires the President to identify and publish critical technologies annually. Empowers the President to impose penalties and delegate enforcement.
column16:
Prohibits U.S. persons from engaging in covered activities involving certain technologies and products in countries of concern, particularly in sectors like AI, if they pose acute national security threats.

Requires the President to annually identify and publish lists of such critical technologies and products.

Mandates U.S. persons to notify the President of any covered activities that may threaten national security.

Empowers the President to impose civil penalties for violations and to delegate enforcement authority to federal agencies.

Encourages bilateral and multilateral engagements to promote compliance with these prohibitions and notifications.

Allocates $25 million annually for implementation and allows direct hiring to support administration.

Permits the President to issue waivers for activities deemed in the national interest, with required congressional notification.

column2: Strengthening Consumer Protections and Medical Debt Transparency Act
column3: Medical Debt Transparency Act
column15: Amends the Public Health Service Act to prohibit extraordinary collection actions if a health insurance appeal is pending. Mandates eligibility checks for assistance programs before collection. Prohibits collections until 180 days post-billing. Requires itemized statements and language assistance information. Establishes a public medical debt collection database with annual reporting. Imposes penalties for non-compliance. Requires the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to report on medical debt collections.
column16:
Amends the Public Health Service Act to prohibit health care entities and their debt collectors from initiating extraordinary collection actions if a health insurance appeal is pending.

Mandates health care entities to determine patients' eligibility for assistance programs before commencing extraordinary collection actions.

Prohibits extraordinary collection actions until 180 days after the initial bill is sent to the patient.

Requires health care entities to provide patients with itemized statements and detailed payment receipts, and information on language assistance services.

Establishes a public database for medical debt collection, requiring health care entities to submit detailed annual reports, including data on debt collection practices and patient demographics.

Imposes penalties for non-compliance, including actual damages and additional court-permitted amounts.

Requires the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to report on medical debt collections, incorporating data from the public database and other sources.

column2: Facial Recognition Act of 2023
column3: Facial Recognition Act
column15: Prohibits law enforcement from using facial recognition without a court order, except in emergencies. Mandates removal of photos of minors and uncharged individuals. Requires prosecutor and court approval. Prohibits use with body cameras and for immigration. Enforces annual accuracy testing. Requires public reporting and audits. Allows civil actions for violations. Ensures public transparency.
column16:
Prohibits law enforcement from using facial recognition without a court order, except in emergencies.

Mandates the removal of photos of minors and individuals not charged or acquitted from databases used for facial recognition.

Requires prosecutors to approve and courts to authorize the use of facial recognition with detailed applications.

Prohibits the use of facial recognition with body cameras, for face surveillance, or for immigration enforcement.

Enforces annual accuracy and bias testing of facial recognition systems by independent entities.

Requires public reporting and logging of facial recognition use, including demographic data.

Mandates audits of law enforcement agencies' use of facial recognition to ensure compliance and prevent misuse.

Allows civil actions and administrative discipline for violations of the Act.

Ensures public notice and transparency regarding the use of facial recognition by law enforcement.

column2: National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research and Development Act, Title II ("National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research Institutes")
column3: Drone R&D Act, Title II ("National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research Institutes")
column15: Establishes a program for financial assistance to create National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research Institutes. Requires collaboration among public and private sectors. Mandates focus on economic, ethical, and safety aspects. Supports interdisciplinary research and workforce development. Authorizes $5 million annually for FY 2024-2028.
column16:
Establishes a program to award financial assistance for creating and supporting a network of National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research Institutes.

Requires collaboration among public and private organizations, including Federal agencies, academic institutions, and industry, to form these Institutes.

Mandates the Institutes to focus on economic or social sectors and address ethical, societal, safety, and security implications of unmanned aircraft systems.

Supports interdisciplinary research, education, and workforce development, including broadening participation of underrepresented communities.

Provides funds for managing data sets, developing testbeds, conducting research, and supporting AI and machine learning related to advanced air mobility systems.

Imposes a competitive merit review process for awarding financial assistance and prohibits duplication of efforts.

Authorizes $5 million annually for fiscal years 2024-2028 to support these activities.

column2: National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research and Development Act, Title IV ("National Science Foundation Activities")
column3: Drone R&D Act, Title IV ("NSF Activities")
column15:
Mandates NSF to support research and STEM education in advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems. 

Funds AI, safety, and autonomous control research.

Encourages middle and high school STEM education.

Promotes undergraduate and graduate education.

Develops a skilled technical workforce.

Facilitates public-private partnerships.

Authorizes appropriations increasing from $50 million in 2024 to $61 million in 2028.
column16:
Mandates the National Science Foundation (NSF) to support research and STEM education in advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems.

Supports fundamental research on technologies including AI, safety, autonomous control, materials, and communications systems.

Funds research on practical applications such as weather prediction, disaster response, and infrastructure monitoring.

Supports research on data modeling, validation, security, and ethical use, including privacy concerns.

Encourages middle and high school STEM education related to unmanned aircraft systems through curriculum development and student engagement activities.

Promotes undergraduate and graduate education through curriculum development, hands-on research opportunities, and scholarships.

Develops a skilled technical workforce, including veterans, through national centers and community college programs.

Facilitates public-private partnerships and interagency coordination to avoid research duplication.

Authorizes appropriations increasing from $50 million in 2024 to nearly $61 million in 2028.

column2: National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research and Development Act, Title VI ("Department of Energy Activities")
column3: Drone R&D Act, Title VI ("DOE Activities")
column15: Mandates the Secretary of Energy to execute a UAS technology program. Requires coordination across DOE offices. Formulates UAS research goals. Establishes a data management strategy. Supports institutes. Awards financial assistance. Promotes technology transfer. Makes available DOE facilities. Coordinates with federal departments. Authorizes $276,282,638 from 2024 to 2028.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Energy to execute a cross-cutting research, development, and demonstration program for unmanned aircraft system (UAS) technologies, including artificial intelligence.

Requires coordination across relevant DOE offices, including the Artificial Intelligence Technology Office.

Formulates goals for UAS research, leveraging existing research and providing training in AI, machine learning, and related fields.

Establishes a data management strategy ensuring digital access, interoperability, and machine-readability.

Supports institutes to advance UAS and DOE missions.

Awards financial assistance for research in areas such as AI, autonomous operation, advanced algorithms, and multi-sensor fusion.

Promotes technology transfer by partnering with industry.

Makes available DOE research facilities and high-performance computing infrastructure.

Coordinates with other federal departments to avoid duplication and ensure complementary activities.

Authorizes appropriations totaling $276,282,638 from fiscal years 2024 to 2028.

column2: National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research and Development Act, Title VII ("Department of Homeland Security Activities")
column3: Drone R&D Act, Title VII ("DHS Activities")
column15: Mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security to support research and testing of advanced air mobility and UAS systems. Directs coordination with relevant DHS offices. Requires standardized, secure data sets. Establishes Institutes and a Counter-UAS Center of Excellence. Specifies selection criteria. Permits use of funds for research and training. Sets federal grant share at 75%. Authorizes $30 million to $36.5 million from 2024 to 2028.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security to support research, development, evaluation, and testing of advanced air mobility, unmanned aircraft systems (UAS), and counter-UAS systems.

Directs coordination with relevant Department of Homeland Security offices and programs, including the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency and U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

Requires production of standardized, secure, and privacy-protected data sets for advanced air mobility and UAS systems.

Supports establishing one or more Institutes to advance research in these fields.

Establishes a Counter-UAS Center of Excellence within the Department of Homeland Security.

Specifies selection criteria for host institutions, emphasizing past performance, geographic proximity to federal facilities, and capabilities in AI and machine learning.

Permits use of funds for fundamental research, evaluation, education, and training related to counter-UAS systems.

Sets the federal share of grants at no more than 75% of costs.

Authorizes appropriations totaling $30 million to $36.5 million from fiscal years 2024 to 2028.

column2: Fair Trade with China Enforcement Act, Sec. 101 ("Establishment of list of certain products receiving support from government of People's Republic of China pursuant to Made in China 2025 policy")
column3: Fair Trade with China Enforcement Act, Sec. 101 ("List of products supported by PRC's Made in China 2025 policy")
column15: Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to establish a list of Chinese government-supported products under Made in China 2025. Requires the U.S. Trade Representative to compile and annually update this list, including specified products and industries that displace U.S. exports.
column16:
Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to establish a list of products supported by the Chinese government under the Made in China 2025 policy.

Requires the United States Trade Representative to compile this list within 120 days of the enactment and update it annually.

Mandates inclusion of products specified in key Chinese government documents related to Made in China 2025.

Includes products that displace net exports of similar U.S. products.

Enumerates specific industries such as civil aircraft, motor vehicles, advanced medical equipment, agricultural machinery, semiconductors, lithium batteries, artificial intelligence, high-capacity computing, quantum computing, robotics, and biotechnology for inclusion.

column2: Fair Trade with China Enforcement Act, Sec. 102 ("Prohibition on export to People's Republic of China of national security sensitive technology and intellectual property")
column3: Fair Trade with China Enforcement Act, Sec. 102 ("Prohibit export of national security sensitive technology and IP to PRC")
column15: Prohibits the Secretary of Commerce from exporting national security sensitive technology or intellectual property to China. Defines "intellectual property" and "national security sensitive technology or intellectual property." Includes various technology sectors such as AI, robotics, and biotechnology.
column16:
Prohibits the Secretary of Commerce from exporting any national security sensitive technology or intellectual property to the People's Republic of China.

Defines "intellectual property" to include patents, copyrights, trademarks, or trade secrets.

Defines "national security sensitive technology or intellectual property" to include contributions to China's military, protection of U.S. economic security, and components of key products listed under the Trade Act of 1974.

Includes in "technology" goods or services related to information systems, internet-based services, production-enhancing logistics, robotics, artificial intelligence, biotechnology, or computing.

column2: FAA Research and Development Act of 2023, Sec. 210 ("Technology review of artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies")
column3: FAA R&D Act, Sec. 210 ("Review of AI and ML")
column15: Requires the Administrator to review AI and machine learning in airport operations. Mandates coverage of jet bridges, service vehicles, and taxiing. Allows inclusion of other relevant areas. Obligates a report to Congress within one year. Examines China's AI applications.
column16:
Requires the Administrator to conduct a review of current and planned AI and machine learning technologies to enhance airport efficiency and safety.

Mandates the review to cover applications of AI and machine learning in jet bridges, airport service vehicles, and aircraft taxiing.

Allows the Administrator to include other relevant areas that can improve airport efficiency and safety.

Obligates the Administrator to submit a report to Congress within one year, detailing the review's findings.

Includes a required examination of China's domestic application of AI and machine learning technologies in the report.

column2: FAA Research and Development Act of 2023, Sec. 215 ("Air Traffic Control Training")
column3: FAA R&D Act, Sec. 215 ("Air Traffic Control Training")
column15: Requires the Administrator to modernize air traffic control training. Mandates assessment of AI, machine learning, and VR/AR. Develops deployment timeline for proven technologies. Includes stakeholder collaboration. Obligates a report to Congress within one year.
column16:
Requires the Administrator to carry out a research program to modernize and streamline air traffic control training, subject to available appropriations.

Mandates the assessment of advanced technologies, including AI, machine learning, and virtual/augmented reality, to enhance knowledge retention and training effectiveness.

Develops a timeline for deploying proven advanced technologies and processes for accreditation in training programs and facilities.

Includes collaboration with labor organizations and other stakeholders in the research process.

Obligates the Administrator to submit a report to Congress on the research findings within one year of the Act's enactment.

column2: Weather Act Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 108 ("Computing Resources Prioritization")
column3: Weather Act Reauthorization, Sec. 108 ("Computing Resources Prioritization")
column15: Mandates collaboration between Under Secretary and Secretary of Energy for AI-driven weather forecasting. Requires merit-reviewed application process. Coordinates NOAA's AI research. Directs sharing of model innovations. Authorizes AI infrastructure enhancement. Allows AI centers. Permits multi-year contracts. Requires biennial congressional report.
column16:
Amends the Weather Research and Forecasting Innovation Act to mandate collaboration between the Under Secretary and the Secretary of Energy in leveraging high-performance computing and AI for advanced weather forecasting.

Requires a competitive, merit-reviewed process for initiative applications, including Federal agencies, National Laboratories, and higher education institutions.

Mandates coordination of AI and computing research across NOAA to avoid duplication and enhance predictive analysis.

Directs sharing of model innovations through community-based activities and interagency coordination.

Authorizes leveraging AI to enhance NOAA’s computing infrastructure for critical missions.

Allows establishment of centers of excellence for AI and machine learning in weather forecasting.

Permits multi-year contracts for high-performance and cloud computing systems.

Requires a report to Congress evaluating the initiative’s effectiveness and future computing needs within two years.

column2: Weather Act Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 116(f) ("National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Observing Network")
column3: Weather Act Reauthorization, Sec. 116(f) ("Algal Bloom Observing Network")
column15: Amends Section 606 to establish a national harmful algal bloom observing network. Requires integration of observing capabilities at all levels. Mandates use of AI for monitoring. Instructs coordination for data integration. Establishes a Data Assembly Center for ecological forecasting.
column16:
Amends Section 606 of the Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Research and Control Act to establish a national harmful algal bloom observing network.

Requires the Under Secretary, via NCCOS and IOOS, to integrate Federal, State, regional, and local observing capabilities.

Mandates the use of emerging technologies and data integration methods, including artificial intelligence, for monitoring, detecting, and forecasting harmful algal blooms.

Instructs the IOOS Program Office to coordinate with NCCOS for observations, data integration, and information dissemination.

Establishes a Harmful Algal Bloom Data Assembly Center to integrate, disseminate, and support ecological forecasting.

column2: Weather Act Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 304 ("Data Assimilation, Management, and Sharing Practices")
column3: Weather Act Reauthorization, Sec. 304 ("Data Assimilation, Management, and Sharing")
column15: Establishes requirements for consistent data standards. Mandates efficient data infrastructure and commercial cloud use. Authorizes federal partnerships for cloud transitions. Ensures long-term archival data management. Requires data sharing with conditions. Instructs a data assimilation program. Mandates a NOAA data practices study.
column16:
Establishes the requirement for the Under Secretary, in collaboration with the weather enterprise, to develop consistent and open data and metadata standards to support open science.

Mandates the consolidation and efficient arrangement of data infrastructure, considering commercial cloud technologies, to ensure effective data transfer between National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) offices.

Authorizes the Under Secretary to partner with other federal agencies to support cloud architecture transitions and data collocation.

Ensures the long-term management and stewardship of archival data acquired through the Commercial Data Program.

Requires the Under Secretary to facilitate data sharing with the weather enterprise, making data accessible to U.S. persons under certain conditions.

Instructs the establishment of a program to advance data assimilation methods, including AI and machine learning, and the creation of a university consortium to address research challenges in data assimilation.

Mandates a study on NOAA's data practices and management needs, assessing costs, benefits, and recommending improvements.

column2: Weather Act Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 402 ("Hazardous Weather or Water Event Risk Communication")
column3: Weather Act Reauthorization, Sec. 402 ("Hazardous Weather Risk Communication")
column15: Amends Section 406 to enhance communication on hazardous weather or water events. Requires maintaining NOAA’s system. Mandates a program for simplifying communications. Directs elimination of confusing terms. Instructs developing evaluation metrics. Ensures partner coordination and establishes best practices.
column16:
