Amends Section 406 of the Weather Research and Forecasting Innovation Act of 2017 to enhance communication about hazardous weather or water events.

Requires the Under Secretary to maintain and improve NOAA's system for communicating risks of hazardous weather or water events to the public.

Mandates the creation of a social, behavioral, risk, communication, and economic sciences program to simplify and improve communication of hazardous weather or water events.

Directs the program to eliminate or modify confusing terms and improve communication methods.

Instructs the program to develop metrics for evaluating the effectiveness of these communications.

Mandates the development of a support plan informed by research and communications evaluation.

Requires recommendations to be based on the latest social, behavioral, economic, risk, and communications science research, validated using rigorous methods, including AI and machine learning.

Ensures coordination with federal, state, local, tribal, educational, and media partners.

Establishes best practices for timely and consistent communications across public platforms.

column2: Weather Act Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 502 ("National Integrated Drought Information System")
column3: Weather Act Reauthorization, Sec. 502 ("National Integrated Drought Information System")
column15: Amends the National Integrated Drought Information System Act to include AI, machine learning, and cloud technologies. Requires flash drought research. Mandates observational networks and refined indicators. Establishes coordination with the National Mesonet Program. Directs transition to probabilistic forecasts. Authorizes annual funding increases.
column16:
Amends the National Integrated Drought Information System Act of 2006 to advance and deploy next-generation technologies related to drought, including artificial intelligence, machine learning, and cloud technologies.

Requires incorporation of flash drought research and tools to enhance timely response.

Mandates utilization of observational networks and refinement of drought indicators for decision-support products by optimizing data from across the Federal Government.

Establishes memoranda of understanding with the National Mesonet Program to provide coordinated, high-quality, nationwide drought information.

Directs the transition of existing drought products to probabilistic forecasts and incorporation of new dynamical and statistical forecast modeling tools.

Authorizes appropriations increasing annually from $15,000,000 in fiscal year 2024 to $17,000,000 in fiscal year 2028.

column2: National Quantum Initiative Reauthorization Act, Sec. 16 ("Department of Energy Quantum Information Science Research Program")
column3: National Quantum Initiative Reauthorization Act, Sec. 16 ("DOE Quantum Information Science Research Program")
column15: Amends the National Quantum Initiative Act to mandate quantum research programs. Establishes National Quantum Information Science Research Centers. Requires cooperative research initiatives. Mandates student training in quantum fields. Directs a 10-year strategic plan. Supports industry outreach. Allocates $130 million annually.
column16:
Amends the National Quantum Initiative Act to mandate the Secretary of Energy to implement a quantum information science, engineering, and technology research program.

Establishes National Quantum Information Science Research Centers to enhance quantum technology and infrastructure.

Requires cooperative research initiatives with industry, National Laboratories, and academic institutions, covering AI, machine learning, quantum communications, sensing, and other quantum technologies.

Mandates providing research experiences and training for students in quantum fields.

Directs the creation of a 10-year strategic plan for quantum high-performance computing, integrating AI and machine learning, to be submitted to Congress.

Supports industry outreach to promote quantum technology commercialization and advancements in the energy sector.

Allocates up to $130 million annually from 2024 to 2027 for these activities.

column2: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Sec. 906 ("Programs for Next-Generation Microelectronics in Support of Artificial Intelligence")
column3: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2024, Sec. 906 ("Next-Generation Microelectronics for AI")
column15: Establishes a program to advance microelectronics research overseen by the Director of National Intelligence. Focuses on computing models, materials, devices, and algorithms. Requires collaboration with government, academia, and industry. Mandates congressional briefings. Authorizes appropriations for support.
column16:
Establishes a program to advance microelectronics research, overseen by the Director of National Intelligence through the Intelligence Advanced Research Projects Activity.

Focuses research on next-generation computing models, materials, devices, architectures, and algorithms to enhance artificial intelligence and machine learning.

Addresses challenges in microelectronics engineering, including physical limits on transistors, interconnects, and memory elements.

Promotes advancements in computing technologies through multidisciplinary research, encompassing algorithm design, compute capability, generative AI, photonics-based microprocessors, new materials, optical networks, and AI safety for the intelligence community.

Requires active collaboration with government agencies, academic institutions, and private industry.

Authorizes appropriations for contracts, grants, and other transactions to support the program.

Mandates regular briefings to congressional intelligence committees on program progress, partnerships, and future research priorities.

column2: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Sec. 909 ("Requirement to Ensure Intelligence Community Directives Appropriately Account for Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Tools in Intelligence Products")
column3: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2024, Sec. 909 ("Ensure IC Directives Account for AI and ML Tools in Intelligence Products")
column15: Requires the Director of National Intelligence to brief congressional intelligence committees within 120 days on AI guidance sufficiency. Mandates evaluation of Intelligence Community Directives 203 and 206. Requires assessment of needed updates or explanation of current adequacy.
column16:
Requires the Director of National Intelligence to brief congressional intelligence committees within 120 days on whether current intelligence community directives provide sufficient guidance on the use of AI and machine learning tools in intelligence products.

Mandates the briefing to include a determination of whether Intelligence Community Directives 203 and 206, and other relevant directives, offer adequate guidance on using, sourcing, and providing transparency for AI and machine learning tools.

Requires the Director to assess if these directives need updates to enhance guidance and direction.

Obligates the Director to explain why no updates are needed if deemed sufficient, or to provide a plan and timeline for necessary updates if improvements are required.

column2: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Title V ("Matters Pertaining to United States Economic and Emerging Technology Competition with United States Adversaries"), Subtitle B ("Next Generation Energy, Biotechnology, and Artificial Intelligence")
column3: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2024, Title V ("Emerging Technology Competition"), Subtitle B ("Next Generation AI")
column15:
**Subtitle B—Next-Generation Energy, Biotechnology, And Artificial Intelligence**

**SEC. 511. Expanded Annual Assessment of Economic and Technological Capabilities of the People's Republic of China.**

Requires a detailed assessment of China’s AI, next-generation energy, and biotechnology investments. Identifies competitive practices and countermeasures. Determines U.S. supply chain vulnerabilities.

**SEC. 514. Policies Established by Director of National Intelligence for Artificial Intelligence Capabilities.**

Mandates policies for AI acquisition, adoption, development, use, coordination, and maintenance. Requires performance evaluation guidelines, continuous monitoring, and documentation. Calls for standards on imputed, augmented, or synthetic data in AI training.

**SEC. 515. Strategy for Submittal of Notice by Private Persons to Federal Agencies Regarding Certain Risks and Threats Relating to Artificial Intelligence.**

Directs the President to establish a strategy for vendors and users to notify the government of AI-related risks. Includes information security, biosecurity risks, foreign malign influence, and unlawful AI activities. Outlines public education plans on AI risks.
column16:
**Subtitle B—Next-Generation Energy, Biotechnology, And Artificial Intelligence**

**SEC. 511. Expanded Annual Assessment of Economic and Technological Capabilities of the People's Republic of China.**

Requires a detailed assessment of China’s investments in AI, next-generation energy technologies, and biotechnology.

Identifies competitive practices and opportunities to counter them.

Determines U.S. vulnerabilities in the supply chain of these technologies.

**SEC. 514. Policies Established by Director of National Intelligence for Artificial Intelligence Capabilities.**

Mandates the establishment of policies for AI acquisition, adoption, development, use, coordination, and maintenance.

Requires guidelines for evaluating AI model performance, continuous monitoring, and documentation.

Calls for standards on imputed, augmented, or synthetic data used in AI training.

**SEC. 515. Strategy for Submittal of Notice by Private Persons to Federal Agencies Regarding Certain Risks and Threats Relating to Artificial Intelligence.**

Directs the President to establish a strategy for vendors and users to notify the government of AI-related risks.

Includes information security, biosecurity risks, foreign malign influence, and other unlawful activities related to AI.

Outlines a plan for Federal agencies to engage in public education on AI risks.

column2: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Sec. 758 ("Implementation of Technology for Classification and Declassification")
column3: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2024, Sec. 758 ("Technology for Classification and Declassification")
column15: Requires the Administrator to research an AI-based classification system within 1 year. Mandates consultation with key agencies. Calls for interoperability across the government. Obligates a recommendation to the President. Permits hiring staff. Directs a classified report to Congress.
column16:
Requires the Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government to research a technology-based solution using machine learning and artificial intelligence for efficient classification and declassification systems within 1 year.

Mandates consultation with various key agencies, including the Secretary of Defense and CIA Director, to ensure a comprehensive approach.

Calls for the solution to be interoperable and federated across the Federal Government.

Obligates the Administrator to submit a recommendation to the President regarding the adoption of the researched technology-based solution.

Permits the Administrator to hire sufficient staff to execute the tasks outlined.

Directs the President to submit a classified report to Congress within 540 days, detailing the recommended solution and the decision on its adoption.

column2: Department of State Authorization Act of 2023, Sec. 303 ("Task force to address artificial intelligence-enabled influence operations")
column3: Department of State Authorization Act, Sec. 303 ("AI-enabled influence operations task force")
column15: Establishes a Countering AI-Enabled Disinformation Task Force within 180 days. Requires collaboration with private industry and academia. Mandates internal coordination within the Department. Directs a unified international approach. Mandates a report to Congress within one year. Defines key terms.
column16:
Establishes a Countering AI-Enabled Disinformation Task Force within 180 days to identify responses to AI-enabled disinformation threats.

Requires the Task Force to collaborate with private industry and academia to develop digital content provenance detection techniques.

Mandates internal coordination within the Department on AI-enabled disinformation issues.

Directs the Task Force to create a unified international approach for standards and frameworks to counter AI-enabled disinformation.

Requires the Task Force to identify necessary tools and resources for detecting AI-enabled disinformation, producing counter-messaging, expanding digital literacy, and coordinating with various stakeholders.

Mandates a report to Congress within one year on the Task Force’s establishment and progress.

Involves representatives from various relevant offices in the Task Force.

Defines key terms including "artificial intelligence" and "digital content provenance."

column2: Department of State Authorization Act of 2023, Sec. 304 ("Establishment of the Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer of the Department of State")
column3: Department of State Authorization Act, Sec. 304 ("DOS Chief AI Officer")
column15: Establishes a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer (CAIO) within the Department of State. Requires the CAIO to oversee AI adoption, advise the Secretary on ethical AI use, and possess expertise in AI and data analytics. Defines “artificial intelligence” per section 238(g).
column16:
Establishes within the Department of State a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer (CAIO), potentially dual-hatted as the Department’s Chief Data Officer, and a member of the Senior Executive Service.

Requires the CAIO to evaluate, oversee, and facilitate the responsible adoption of AI and machine learning to inform decisions and support programs and operations.

Designates the CAIO as the principal advisor to the Secretary of State on the ethical use of AI and advanced analytics in diplomacy.

Mandates the CAIO to possess skills in data analytics, AI, machine learning, and organizational change management.

Requires the Chief Information Officer to consult with the CAIO on scaling AI capabilities across software applications.

Defines “artificial intelligence” as per section 238(g) of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2019.

column2: Department of State Authorization Act of 2023, Sec. 931 ("Priority for Australia and the United Kingdom in Foreign Military Sales and Direct Commercial Sales")
column3: Department of State Authorization Act, Sec. 931 ("Priority for Australia and UK in Military Sales")
column15: Requires the President to expedite defense requests from Australia and the UK under AUKUS. Mandates prioritization over all but Taiwan and Ukraine. Instructs anticipatory release policies for tech transfers to Australia, UK, and Canada. Specifies advanced technologies. Expedites decision-making. Directs policy updates.
column16:
Requires the President to institute expedited policies for defense article and service requests from Australia and the United Kingdom under the AUKUS partnership.

Mandates prioritization of these requests over all others, except those from Taiwan and Ukraine.

Instructs the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, to establish an anticipatory release policy for technology transfers to Australia, the UK, and Canada.

Specifies the inclusion of technologies related to submarines, combat systems, hypersonic missiles, cyber capabilities, artificial intelligence, quantum technologies, and other advanced technologies.

Subjects technology transfer reviews to an expedited decision-making process.

Directs the Secretary and the Secretary of Defense to update interagency policies and guidance to incorporate these anticipatory release provisions.

column2: Department of State Authorization Act of 2023, Sec. 941 ("Reporting Related to the AUKUS Partnership")
column3: Department of State Authorization Act, Sec. 941 ("Reporting Related to AUKUS")
column15: Mandates the President to submit AUKUS non-binding texts to congressional committees within 30 days. Excludes resubmission of previously submitted texts. Defines "text" inclusively. Requires biennial AUKUS reports on defense gaps, costs, contributions, benefits, and Australia's nuclear submarine progress and collaboration efforts.
column16:
Mandates the President to submit the text of any non-binding instrument related to the AUKUS partnership to appropriate congressional committees within 30 days of finalization.

Excludes the need to resubmit texts already submitted under other legal provisions, while not relieving other legal submission requirements.

Defines "text" to include all related annexes, appendices, side agreements, and implementing documents.

Requires the Secretary, in coordination with other officials, to submit a biennial report on the AUKUS partnership starting one year after enactment.

Specifies that reports must cover defensive capability gaps, costs, industrial base contributions, military benefits, and assessments of Australia’s nuclear submarine contributions.

Demands updates on progress for Australia’s nuclear submarine development, infrastructure, workforce training, and support facilities.

Requires assessments of trilateral collaboration efforts in areas including underseas capabilities, quantum technologies, AI and autonomy, advanced cyber capabilities, hypersonic technologies, electronic warfare, innovation, and information sharing.

column2: Advanced Safe Testing at Residence Telehealth Act of 2023, Sec. 2 ("Coverage and Payment for Certain Tests and Assistive Telehealth Consultations; Demonstration Program Under Certain State Medicaid Programs")
column3: Testing at Residence Telehealth Act, Sec. 2 ("Tests and Assistive Telehealth Consultations Demonstration")
column15: Establishes a VBID demonstration program for Medicare beneficiaries' telehealth and home-based care. Requires MA plans to cover AI-based medical tests. Limits VBID to 25 MA plans, includes rural areas. Mandates demographic data collection. Administers grants for state Medicaid programs.
column16:
Establishes a Value-Based Insurance Design Model (VBID) demonstration program to provide Medicare beneficiaries with assistive telehealth consultations and home-based care.

Requires eligible Medicare Advantage (MA) plans to cover medical tests, including those utilizing adaptive AI and machine learning, for various diseases and conditions.

Limits the VBID program to a maximum of 25 MA plans, with at least 10 plans serving rural or underserved areas.

Mandates demographic data collection for reimbursement claims, including age, race, ethnicity, gender, and chronic conditions.

Administers a grant program for state Medicaid programs to cover similar tests and telehealth consultations, with grants awarded to 5-10 states or territories for a 4-year period, not exceeding $12 million per state.

column2: Coast Guard Authorization Act of 2023, Sec. 212 ("Report on Establishment of an Unmanned Systems Capabilities Office")
column3: Coast Guard Authorization Act, Sec. 212 ("Unmanned Systems Capabilities Office")
column15: Requires the Commandant to report on establishing an unmanned systems office. Mandates management, coordination, and contracting strategies for technology development. Lists inventory needs and cross-agency collaboration. Encourages data sharing and mandates a concept for integrating unmanned systems with AI.
column16:
Requires the Commandant to submit a report within one year outlining a plan for establishing an unmanned systems capabilities office within the Coast Guard.

Mandates inclusion of a management strategy for acquiring, developing, and deploying unmanned system and counter-unmanned system technologies.

Demands a coordination strategy to synchronize efforts across the Coast Guard and pursue expanded research, development, testing, and evaluation opportunities.

Requires identification of contracting and acquisition authorities needed for expedited technology development and deployment.

Lists the need for a detailed inventory of commercially available unmanned and counter-unmanned systems useful to the Coast Guard.

Calls for a cross-agency collaboration plan with the Department of Homeland Security, Department of Defense, and other relevant agencies.

Encourages opportunities to obtain and share unmanned system data to enhance maritime domain awareness.

Mandates the development of a concept of operations for a data ecosystem integrating unmanned system technologies with AI, machine learning, and information-sharing capabilities.

column2: Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness and Response Act, Sec. 407 ("Assessment of Artificial Intelligence Threats to Health Security")
column3: Pandemic Preparedness and Response Act, Sec. 407 ("AI Threats to Health Security")
column15: Requires the Secretary of HHS to contract the National Academies for a study on AI-related health security vulnerabilities within 45 days. Mandates risk assessment, Federal roles, activities, gaps, and recommendations. Requires reports to Congress within specified timelines.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to seek a contract with the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine to conduct a study on AI-related health security vulnerabilities within 45 days of enactment.

Mandates the study to assess risks posed by AI advancements, including chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear threats.

Describes roles and capabilities of HHS agencies and other Federal entities in identifying and mitigating these vulnerabilities.

Summarizes ongoing Federal activities related to these risks.

Identifies current or anticipated gaps in roles, responsibilities, and capabilities regarding AI-related health security.

Provides recommendations for improving Federal efforts to address these vulnerabilities.

Requires the National Academies to submit a report on the study to relevant Senate and House committees within 2 years.

Mandates the Secretary of HHS to submit a follow-up report on actions taken to mitigate AI-related health security risks within 1 year after the National Academies' report.

column2: NTIA Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 203 ("Spectrum management improvements")
column3: NTIA Reauthorization Act, Sec. 203 ("Spectrum management improvements")
column15: Requires the Under Secretary to develop and support models for spectrum management involving AI. Mandates AI systems for dynamic spectrum access. Amends Section 104 to identify technologies for dynamic spectrum access. Encourages workforce development for advanced communications technologies. Supports institutional partnerships.
column16:
Requires the Under Secretary, in coordination with the Commission and in consultation with other relevant Federal agencies, to develop, establish, prototype, and support the implementation of models, methodologies, and inputs for spectrum management decisions involving AI systems, advanced antenna arrays, and dynamic spectrum access technologies.

Mandates the development of AI systems to enable dynamic spectrum access, Internet of Things networks, and other advanced communications technologies.

Amends Section 104 of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to require the identification and facilitation of technologies that promote dynamic spectrum access, network sensing and monitoring, and optical and quantum communications.

Encourages the development of a skilled workforce for prototyping advanced communications technologies.

Supports partnerships among institutions for workforce development in advanced communications technology prototyping.

column2: Atomic Energy Advancement Act, Sec. 123 ("Advancement of Nuclear Regulatory Oversight")
column3: Atomic Energy Advancement Act, Sec. 123 ("Nuclear Regulatory Oversight")
column15: Requires NRC to report to Congress on COVID-19 actions, including policy impacts. Mandates NRC develop a report on improving nuclear oversight using AI within one year. Obligates NRC to seek stakeholder input. Directs NRC to assess AI use. Instructs NRC to incorporate advanced technologies without compromising their mission.
column16:
Requires the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to report to Congress on actions taken during the COVID-19 emergency, including revised or suspended regulatory policies and their impacts.

Mandates NRC to develop a report within one year identifying improvements in nuclear oversight and inspections using risk-informed, performance-based procedures, information technologies, and AI.

Obligates NRC to seek input from stakeholders like the Secretary of Energy, National Laboratories, and the nuclear energy industry.

Directs NRC to assess the use of AI and machine learning to enhance oversight and inspection decisions.

Instructs NRC to identify specific actions for incorporating advanced technologies into their activities without compromising their mission.

column2: DEEPFAKES Accountability Act, Sec. 2 ("Transparency Requirements")
column3: DEEPFAKES Accountability Act, Sec. 2 ("Transparency Requirements")
column15: Amends Title 18, U.S. Code, to add transparency requirements for deepfakes. Requires content provenance technologies and specific disclosure formats. Imposes criminal and civil penalties for non-compliance. Establishes deepfake coordinators and mandates an enforcement trends report.
column16:
Amends Title 18, U.S. Code, to add transparency requirements for advanced technological false personation records (deepfakes).

Requires producers of such records to include content provenance technologies to identify alterations and disclosures detailing the extent of alterations.

Mandates specific disclosure formats for audiovisual, visual, and audio records.

Imposes criminal penalties, including fines and imprisonment up to 5 years, for non-compliance, especially in cases involving harassment, violence, fraud, or foreign influence.

Imposes civil penalties up to $150,000 per violation and allows for private rights of action for damages and injunctive relief.

Defines advanced technological false personation records and includes provisions for privacy protections and advisory opinions.

Establishes coordinators for deepfake-related violations in each U.S. Attorney’s Office.

Requires a report on enforcement trends and the impact of deepfakes on public policy and marginalized communities.

column2: AREA Act, Part B ("National Center for Education Research"), Sec. 133 ("Duties")
column3: AREA Act, Part B ("National Center for Education Research"), Sec. 133 ("Duties")
column15: Amends the Research Commissioner's duties to include maintaining peer-review standards. Requires proposing and implementing a relevant research plan. Mandates support of evidence-based practices and dissemination. Grants authority for research on underrepresented students. Obligates inclusion in the National Education Research Database. Allows technical assistance to underrepresented researchers. Supports research on educational technology, including AI and digital literacy.
column16:
Amends the duties of the Research Commissioner to include maintaining peer-review standards and supporting scientifically valid research.

Requires the Commissioner to propose and implement a research plan, ensuring the research is relevant and informs decision-making.

Mandates the support of evidence-based practices and the dissemination of research findings.

Grants authority to conduct research on underrepresented student populations and to support research-practice partnerships.

Obligates the Commissioner to ensure research is reviewed for inclusion in the National Education Research Database.

Allows for the provision of technical assistance to underrepresented researchers and institutions.

Supports research on educational technology, including artificial intelligence, digital literacy, and other significant educational topics.

column2: Health Care Price Transparency Act of 2023, Sec. 301 ("Establishing Requirements With Respect to the Use of Prior Authorization Under Medicare Advantage Plans")
column3: Health Care Price Transparency Act, Sec. 301 ("Requirements Regarding Prior Authorization Under Medicare Advantage Plans")
column15:
Requires Medicare Advantage plans to implement an electronic prior authorization program by the third plan year.

Mandates enrollee protection and transparency by the fourth plan year.

Establishes a secure electronic transmission system excluding facsimiles and non-compliant portals.

Specifies real-time decisions for certain prior authorizations, with exceptions.

Demands annual reporting of prior authorization data, including AI use, and publication by the Secretary.

Calls for GAO and HHS to report to Congress on implementation and impact.
column16:
Requires Medicare Advantage plans to establish an electronic prior authorization program by the third plan year after the enactment date.

Mandates that plans meet enrollee protection standards and transparency requirements by the fourth plan year.

Establishes a secure electronic transmission system for prior authorization requests and responses, excluding certain forms like facsimiles and non-compliant payer portals.

Specifies that real-time decisions must be made for certain prior authorization requests, with exceptions for extenuating circumstances.

Demands detailed annual reporting of prior authorization data, including the use of AI and decision-support technologies, and the publication of this information by the Secretary.

Calls for GAO and HHS to submit reports to Congress evaluating the implementation and impact of these requirements.

column2: Securing Growth and Robust Leadership in American Aviation Act, Sec. 1024 ("Technology Review of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Technologies")
column3: American Aviation Act, Sec. 1024 ("Review of AI and ML Technologies")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Requires the Administrator to review AI and machine learning technologies for airport efficiency and safety. Allows consideration of best practices. Permits coordination with Federal agencies on China's AI use. Mandates inclusion of specific applications. Obligates a report to Congress within one year.
column16:
Requires the Administrator to conduct a review of current and planned AI and machine learning technologies to enhance airport efficiency and safety.

Allows the Administrator to consider best practices and lessons learned from domestic and international AI and machine learning applications.

Permits coordination with other Federal agencies to identify China's use of AI and machine learning in airport operations.

Mandates the review to include AI and machine learning applications in jet bridges, airport service vehicles, aircraft taxi, air traffic control operations, and other areas deemed necessary by the Administrator.

Obligates the Administrator to submit a report to Congress within one year detailing the review's findings.

column2: Securing Growth and Robust Leadership in American Aviation Act, Sec. 1028 ("Air Traffic Control Training")
column3: American Aviation Act, Sec. 1028 ("Air Traffic Control Training")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Mandates the Administrator to modernize FAA air traffic controller training using advanced technologies like AI and VR. Requires collaboration with stakeholders and reporting to Congress within 1 year. Clarifies no delay in tower simulation system installations.
column16:
Mandates the Administrator to carry out a research program to modernize, enhance, and streamline on-the-job training for FAA air traffic controllers.

Requires the assessment of benefits from advanced technologies, including AI, machine learning, adaptive computer-based simulation, virtual reality, and augmented reality, for improving training effectiveness, knowledge retention, and safety.

Includes collaboration with labor organizations and other stakeholders in the research program.

Obligates the Administrator to report findings to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment.

Clarifies that the section does not delay the installation of tower simulation systems at FAA air traffic facilities.

column2: Securing Growth and Robust Leadership in American Aviation Act, Sec. 908 ("Part 107 Waiver Improvements")
column3: American Aviation Act, Sec. 908 ("Part 107 Waiver Improvements")
column7: Enacted laws and policies;U.S. federal laws
column15: Adopts a performance- and risk-based approach for waiver requests. Improves the application process and prohibits open-ended descriptive prompts except for unusual operations. Leverages data analytics. Requires consideration of property control. Publishes waivers online. Allows streamlined and expedited reviews.
column16:
Adopts a performance- and risk-based approach for reviewing waiver requests under section 107.200 of title 14, CFR.

Improves the waiver application process and prohibits the use of open-ended descriptive prompts, except for unusual or irregular operations.

Leverages data, including big data analytics and machine learning, from previous waiver requests.

Requires consideration of control over access to real property within the operation area and recognizes safety enhancements from such control.

Publishes all issued certificates of waiver on the FAA website, including terms, conditions, limitations, and airspace class, while protecting proprietary information.

Allows streamlined approval for waiver applications substantially similar to previously approved ones.

Establishes an expedited review process for modifying or renewing previously issued waivers.

column2: Lummis-Gillibrand Responsible Financial Innovation Act, Sec. 1001 ("Executive Office of the President Appropriations")
column3: Responsible Financial Innovation Act, Sec. 1001 ("EOP Appropriations")
column15: Authorize annual appropriations of $2,500,000 from 2023 to 2027 to the Office of Science and Technology Policy and the National Economic Council for hiring specialists in AI, crypto assets, and distributed ledger technology, supporting Federal coordination and presidential advisement.
column16:
Authorize appropriations of $2,500,000 annually from fiscal years 2023 to 2027 to the Office of Science and Technology Policy for hiring specialists in AI, crypto assets, and distributed ledger technology, available until the end of the subsequent fiscal year.

Require these funds to support positions coordinating Federal activities and advising the President on research and development strategies related to these technologies.

Authorize similar appropriations of $2,500,000 annually from fiscal years 2023 to 2027 to the National Economic Council for hiring specialists in AI, crypto assets, and distributed ledger technology, also available until the end of the subsequent fiscal year.

Require these funds to support positions coordinating Federal activities and advising the President on financial and economic policies related to these technologies.

column2: ENFORCE Act
column3: ENFORCE Act
column15: Amends the Export Control Reform Act of 2018 to prevent exploitation of U.S. AI by foreign adversaries. Defines AI terms per the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020. Authorizes and empowers the President to control and license AI exports.
column16:
Amends the Export Control Reform Act of 2018 to prevent foreign adversaries from exploiting U.S. artificial intelligence and other critical technologies.

Defines "artificial intelligence" and "artificial intelligence system" as per the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020.

Specifies an interim and final definition of "covered artificial intelligence system," focusing on AI systems posing serious national security risks.

Authorizes the President to control the activities of U.S. persons related to critical AI systems and emerging technologies essential to national security.

Empowers the President to require U.S. persons to obtain licenses for exporting or transferring critical AI systems and technologies.

Amends the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to align with the updated export control provisions.

column2: GRIData Act of 2024
column3: GRIData Act
column15: Requires the Secretary of Energy to improve electric grid reliability by analyzing and sharing data. Mandates collaboration with relevant agencies and the use of AI. Establishes a steering committee. Requires a report to Congress. Authorizes $10 million.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Energy to identify, analyze, and share data to improve the reliability and resilience of the electric grid.

Mandates the Secretary to consider data types, temporal frequency, and spatial resolution, especially in rural, low-income, and disadvantaged communities.

Requires collaboration with National Laboratories, NOAA, and other agencies for weather data relevant to grid reliability and resilience.

Considers the use of emerging technologies, including AI and machine learning, to enhance grid reliability and resilience.

Establishes a steering committee with stakeholders from federal agencies, regulators, and the electric power sector to guide data-related activities.

Mandates the submission of a report to Congress within one year, detailing findings and recommendations for data collection and sharing.

Authorizes $10 million for the first fiscal year to support these activities.

column2: Export Controls Enforcement Improvement Act of 2024
column3: Export Controls Enforcement Improvement Act
column15: Establishes the Export Enforcement Coordination Center within DHS to coordinate export enforcement. Focuses on sensitive technologies like AI, semiconductors, and quantum tech. Designates the Center as the primary forum for export control. Requires development of best practices and information dissemination. Mandates reports to Congress on enforcement logistics. Authorizes $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2025.
column16:
Establishes the Export Enforcement Coordination Center within the Department of Homeland Security to coordinate export enforcement among various federal departments and agencies.

Focuses the Center's efforts on sensitive technologies, including advanced artificial intelligence capabilities, semiconductors, and quantum technology.

Designates the Center as the primary forum for coordinating efforts against unlawful transshipment and diversion of exports, particularly to countries like China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea.

Requires the Center to develop best practices and disseminate actionable information to the private sector about export control risks.

Mandates the submission of reports to Congress on the value and logistics of posting U.S. and foreign law enforcement officials to enhance export control enforcement. 

Authorizes $25,000,000 for the establishment of the Center for fiscal year 2025.

column2: Emerging Innovative Border Technologies Act
column3: Emerging Innovative Border Technologies Act
column15: Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to develop a plan for advanced technologies in border security within 180 days. Mandates inclusion of CBP Innovation Teams' utilization, technology assessments, non-utilized technologies, procurement analysis, privacy impacts, coordination with DHS, and annual reporting.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to develop and submit a plan within 180 days to identify, integrate, and deploy advanced technologies, including AI and machine learning, to enhance border security operations.

Mandates inclusion of information on how CBP utilizes its Innovation Teams and other mechanisms to achieve these goals.

Requires assessments of technology contributions, team compositions, and coordination efforts within CBP and DHS.

Identifies non-utilized technologies from other federal agencies that could enhance border security.

Includes an analysis of procurement authorities and whether additional ones are needed.

Demands explanations on scaling existing programs and descriptions of planned security technology programs with objectives, goals, and timelines.

Assesses the privacy and security impact on border communities and legacy technology phase-outs.

Requires coordination with DHS's Science and Technology Directorate to develop and incentivize new technologies.

Specifies metrics for evaluating effectiveness and identifies recent technological advancements in various surveillance and inspection technologies.

Authorizes CBP Innovation Teams to research and adapt commercial technologies, establishing procedures and strategic goals.

Requires annual reporting on Innovation Team activities, including successful technology transitions.

column2: American Economic Independence Act of 2024
column3: American Economic Independence Act
column15: Requires the President to report to Congress every three years on U.S.-China economic integration and national security risks for 15 years. Mandates risk analysis in AI and other priority sectors. Requires mitigation recommendations. Permits unclassified reports.
column16:
Requires the President, through the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, to submit a report to Congress on the state of economic integration between the U.S. and China, and the national security risks posed by this integration, every three years for 15 years.

Mandates each report to assess the level of economic integration and its changes since 2000, with predictions for the next three years, specifically in priority sectors including artificial intelligence.

Includes analysis of risks such as reliance on Chinese entities, supply chain dependencies, intellectual property theft, and impacts on the U.S. defense industrial base, particularly in the AI sector.

Requires recommendations for mitigating identified risks.

Permits consultation with nongovernmental entities and submission of the report in an unclassified form, potentially with a classified annex.

column2: Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act
column3: Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act
column15: Requires the Election Assistance Commission to develop voluntary AI guidelines for election offices within 60 days. Mandates inclusion of AI risks, benefits, and disinformation. Obligates a study on AI in 2024 elections by November 2025. Requires guideline updates accordingly.
column16:
Requires the Election Assistance Commission to develop and issue voluntary guidelines for election offices addressing the use and risks of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies in election administration within 60 days of enactment.

Mandates inclusion of guidelines on the risks and benefits of AI in election activities, cybersecurity risks, the impact of AI-generated information on sharing accurate election information, and the spread of election disinformation.

Obligates the Election Assistance Commission to study and report on the use and impacts of AI technologies in the 2024 federal elections by November 5, 2025, including the sharing of AI-generated information and the use of AI by election offices.

Requires the Election Assistance Commission to review and update the voluntary guidelines based on the study's findings.

column2: Department of Defense Financial Audits Using Artificial Intelligence Act
column3: DoD Financial Audits Using AI Act
column15: Directs the Secretary of Defense to use AI in the FY 2024 audit. Requires the Under Secretary of Defense and Inspector General to develop this AI. Mandates AI to retire outdated systems. Orders surplus funds to Treasury. Obligates briefing Congress.
column16:
Directs the Secretary of Defense to ensure the fiscal year 2024 audit of the Department of Defense's financial statements uses AI technology.

Requires the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) and the Inspector General to jointly develop the necessary AI technology for facilitating these audits.

Mandates the use of this AI technology to accelerate the retirement of older financial management systems without compromising essential controls or auditing standards.

Orders the rescission and deposit of any identified surplus funds from the audit into the General Fund of the Treasury for deficit reduction.

Obliges the Secretary of Defense to brief the Senate and House Committees on Armed Services within 180 days on the audit's progress and the AI technology development.

column2: Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review
column3: Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review
column15: Requires the OMB Director to report on agency regulations in machine-readable format within 180 days. Mandates issuing guidance on using AI for retrospective reviews within 18 months. Obligates agency heads to submit and implement detailed plans within two years.
column16:
Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to report on the Federal Government's progress in making agency regulations available in machine-readable format within 180 days after enactment.

Mandates the OMB Director to issue guidance within 18 months on using technology, including AI, for efficient and accurate retrospective reviews of regulations.

Obliges agency heads to submit a detailed plan within two years for implementing OMB guidance on retrospective reviews, identifying regulations for review, and including necessary data and analysis.

Directs agency heads to implement the submitted plan within 180 days of submission, focusing on retrospective regulatory reviews.

column2: Federal AI Governance and Transparency Act
column3: Federal AI Governance and Transparency Act
column15:
Amends chapter 35 of title 44, United States Code, to establish Federal AI system governance requirements.

Requires Federal AI actions to align with the Constitution, laws, and policies on civil rights and privacy.

Mandates the assessment and responsible management of AI risks, ensuring fair and impartial treatment.

Ensures AI applications are accurate, ethical, reliable, and secure.

Demands transparency and explainability of AI systems' purpose, operations, and outcomes.

Imposes accountability for human roles in AI management and documentation of AI actions.

Obligates regular testing and oversight of AI applications, including mechanisms to deactivate inconsistent AI systems.

Instructs agencies to publicly disclose AI use and establish notification and appeal processes for AI-based decisions.

Sets up a Federal AI System Inventory for cataloging agency AI governance charters.

Requires independent evaluations of AI governance compliance every two years.
column16:
Amends chapter 35 of title 44, United States Code, to establish Federal AI system governance requirements.

Requires Federal AI actions to align with the Constitution, laws, and policies on civil rights and privacy.

Mandates the assessment and responsible management of AI risks, ensuring fair and impartial treatment.

Ensures AI applications are accurate, ethical, reliable, and secure.

Demands transparency and explainability of AI systems' purpose, operations, and outcomes.

Imposes accountability for human roles in AI management and documentation of AI actions.

Obligates regular testing and oversight of AI applications, including mechanisms to deactivate inconsistent AI systems.

Instructs agencies to publicly disclose AI use and establish notification and appeal processes for AI-based decisions.

Sets up a Federal AI System Inventory for cataloging agency AI governance charters.

Requires independent evaluations of AI governance compliance every two years.

column2: Comment Integrity and Management Act of 2024
column3: Comment Integrity and Management Act
column15: Amends the E-Government Act to improve handling of mass and computer-generated comments. Requires agencies to verify human-submitted comments. Mandates identification and labeling of mass comments. Directs OMB to issue guidance. Obligates agencies to post handling policies. Compels GAO reporting.
column16:
Amends the E-Government Act of 2002 to improve the handling of mass and computer-generated comments in the regulatory review process.

Requires agencies to verify whether electronic comments are submitted by humans.

Mandates agencies to identify and label mass comments and allows agencies to post representative samples of these comments.

Directs the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to issue guidance on verifying human submissions and managing mass comments, including the use of technology tools.

Obliges agencies to establish and publicly post policies on handling computer-generated and mass comments within one year of enactment.

Compels the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to report on the identification and impact of computer-generated comments within two years.

column2: Promoting United States Leadership in Standards Act of 2024
column3: US Leadership in Standards Act
column15: Directs NIST to brief Congress on U.S. AI standards participation opportunities within a year. Requires a web portal for industry and federal agencies. Mandates federal agencies to report AI standards activities. Initiates a pilot program for AI standards meetings. Authorizes $10 million from 2024-2028.
column16:
Directs the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to brief Congress on opportunities for U.S. participation in developing AI standards within one year.

Requires the establishment of a web portal to inform U.S. industry and federal agencies about international AI standards efforts and participation opportunities.

Mandates federal agencies to report their participation in AI standards activities using a mechanism developed by the NIST.

Initiates a pilot program to support U.S.-based AI standards meetings through grants to eligible entities, with funding covering up to 50% of meeting costs.

Authorizes $10 million for the pilot program from fiscal years 2024 through 2028.

column2: Americas Act, Title II ("Trade and Investment for the Americas"), Sec. 255 ("Transformational Energy Development")
column3: Americas Act, Title II ("Trade and Investment"), Sec. 255 ("Energy Development")
column15: Amends the BUILD Act to define "transformational energy technology," including AI for energy efficiency and grid operation. Inserts a Chief Energy Officer in the DFC to promote such exports. Requires reporting on these projects. Establishes an Office of Energy in the Export-Import Bank. Mandates a Joint Energy Export Database. Increases DFC’s liability and adjusts Export-Import Bank’s authority limits.
column16:
Amends the BUILD Act of 2018 to define "transformational energy technology," including AI applications for energy efficiency and grid operation.

Inserts a Chief Energy Officer position within the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) to promote transformational energy technology exports and ensure at least 30% of DFC support targets such projects.

Requires annual and quarterly reports on transformational energy technology projects and international finance of energy generation.

Establishes an Office of Energy in the Export-Import Bank to promote and finance exports of eligible technologies, including those involving AI.

Mandates the creation of a Joint Energy Export, Development, and Trade Database to coordinate inter-agency efforts.

Increases the DFC's maximum contingent liability and adjusts the Export-Import Bank’s loan, guarantee, and insurance authority limits.

column2: Countering Communist China Act, Title I ("Matters Related to Trade, Investment, and Economic Relations"), Sec. 102 ("Sanctions with Respect to Communist Chinese Military and Surveillance Companies")
column3: Countering Communist China Act, Title I ("Trade, Investment, and Economic Relations"), Sec. 102 ("Sanctions for Chinese Military and Surveillance Companies")
column15: Requires the President to sanction foreign persons in China's defense or surveillance sectors. Mandates annual Treasury reports on involved foreign persons. Directs assessments for sanctions on U.S. government lists. Focuses on advanced technologies. Utilizes IEEPA to block transactions. Allows presidential waivers with Congressional certification. Exempts specific intelligence, law enforcement, and humanitarian activities.
column16:
Requires the President to impose sanctions on foreign persons engaged in significant operations in China's defense or surveillance technology sectors.

Mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to annually determine and report on foreign persons involved in these sectors.

Directs assessments on whether sanctions should be imposed on foreign persons listed on various U.S. government lists related to military and export controls.

Focuses particular attention on foreign persons engaged in AI, machine learning, robotics, quantum information science, and other advanced technologies.

Utilizes the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to block and prohibit transactions involving sanctioned foreign persons' property within U.S. jurisdiction.

Allows the President to waive sanctions if deemed in the national interest, with a required certification to Congress.

Exempts intelligence, law enforcement, and certain humanitarian activities from the sanctions.

column2: Countering Communist China Act, Title VII ("Matters Related to Defense"), Sec. 701 ("Modifications to Use of Emergency Sanctions Authorities Regarding Communist Chinese Military Companies")
column3: Countering Communist China Act, Title VII ("Defense"), Sec. 701 ("Emergency Sanctions Regarding Chinese Military Companies")
column15: Mandates emergency sanctions on Chinese military companies. Defines affected companies broadly. Expands criteria to include those affiliated with the Chinese Communist Party. Includes sectors like AI and 5G. Extends listing requirement until December 31, 2026.
column16:
Mandates the exercise of emergency sanctions authorities regarding Communist Chinese military companies.

Defines affected companies as those engaged in commercial services, manufacturing, producing, or exporting.

Expands criteria to include companies owned, controlled by, or affiliated with the Chinese Communist Party or its delegates.

Includes companies significantly investing in sectors such as artificial intelligence, fifth-generation wireless communications, advanced computing, big data analytics, autonomy, robotics, directed energy, hypersonics, or biotechnology.

Extends the requirement for maintaining a list of such companies until December 31, 2026.

column2: Farm, Food, and National Security Act of 2024, Title VI ("Rural Development"), Sec. 6303 ("Promoting Precision Agriculture")
column3: Farm, Food, and National Security Act, Title VI ("Rural Development"), Sec. 6303 ("Precision Agriculture")
column15: Promotes U.S. leadership in precision agriculture standards. Mandates the Secretary develop voluntary interconnectivity standards within two years. Requires consultation with NIST, FCC, and stakeholders. Considers AI and wireless tech impacts. Addresses cybersecurity. Directs biennial assessments and reporting.
column16:
Promotes United States leadership in developing standards for precision agriculture.

Mandates the Secretary to develop voluntary, consensus-based interconnectivity standards for precision agriculture within two years.

Requires consultation with NIST, FCC, public, and private stakeholders, including voluntary consensus standards development organizations.

Considers the impact of advanced wireless communications technology and artificial intelligence on precision agriculture.

Addresses cybersecurity challenges and connectivity needs of precision agriculture technology.

Directs the Comptroller General to assess the developed standards one year after implementation and biennially for eight years.

Obligates the Comptroller General to report findings to relevant Senate and House committees.

column2: Farm, Food, and National Security Act of 2024, Title VII ("Research, Extension, and Related Matters"), Sec. 7208 ("Centers of Excellence")
column3: Farm, Food, and National Security Act, Title VII ("Research and Extension"), Sec. 7208 ("Centers of Excellence")
column15: Mandates the Secretary of Agriculture to establish research centers. Designates eligible institutions and requires geographic diversity. Limits each institution to one center. Requires partnerships. Focuses on diverse agricultural technologies. Prohibits new construction. Requires annual reports. Expands centers to 8. Extends authorization to 2029.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Agriculture to establish at least one center of excellence to conduct research, extension, and education activities.

Designates eligible host institutions, including land-grant colleges and accredited veterinary schools, and requires geographic diversity in selection.

Limits each institution to host or co-host only one center at a time.

Requires partnerships with federal agencies, state governments, higher education institutions, and agricultural industry groups to enhance coordination and cost-effectiveness.

Focuses on multiple areas, including digital agriculture, artificial intelligence, agricultural biosecurity, cybersecurity, precision agriculture technologies, biotechnology, and crop protection.

Prohibits using funds for new construction or facility alterations.

Requires an annual report on projects, funding, institutional participation, cost-sharing, and intellectual property actions to relevant Congressional committees.

Expands the number of centers from 3 to 8 and extends the program's authorization to 2029.

column2: Farm, Food, and National Security Act of 2024, Title VIII ("Forestry"), Sec. 8414 ("Public-Private Wildfire Technology Deployment and Testbed Partnership")
column3: Farm, Food, and National Security Act, Title VIII ("Forestry"), Sec. 8414 ("Wildfire Technology Deployment and Testbed Partnership")
column15: Establishes a pilot program for wildfire prevention technologies. Requires integration into an interagency group. Mandates consultation with agencies. Partners with entities for real-time testing. Prioritizes emerging technologies. Requires annual reports. Expires on September 30, 2029.
column16:
Establishes a deployment and testbed pilot program for new and innovative wildfire prevention, detection, communication, and mitigation technologies.

Requires incorporation of the Pilot Program into an existing interagency coordinating group on wildfires.

Mandates consultation with covered agencies to identify key technology priority areas.

Partners with selected covered entities for real-time and on-the-ground testing of technology during wildfire mitigation activities.

Prioritizes emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence, quantum sensing, and augmented reality, for wildfire mitigation.

Requires submission of annual reports to appropriate committees, detailing participating entities, tested technologies, costs, outreach efforts, and assessments.

Expires the Pilot Program on September 30, 2029.

column2: Coast Guard Authorization Act of 2024, Title II ("Coast Guard"), Sec. 207 ("Report on establishment of unmanned systems capabilities office")
column3: Coast Guard Authorization Act, Title II ("Coast Guard"), Sec. 207 ("unmanned systems capabilities office")
column15: Mandates the Commandant to report on establishing an unmanned systems office. Requires management, acquisition, and deployment strategies. Specifies service-wide coordination. Identifies necessary contracting authorities. Lists useful technologies. Calls for cross-agency collaboration. Highlights data-sharing opportunities. Requires a concept of operations.
column16:
Mandates the Commandant to submit a report within one year outlining a plan for establishing an unmanned systems capabilities office within the Coast Guard.

Requires the report to include a management strategy for the acquisition, development, and deployment of unmanned and counter-unmanned system technologies.

Specifies the need for a service-wide coordination strategy to synchronize efforts across the Coast Guard.

Identifies contracting and acquisition authorities necessary to expedite technology development and deployment.

Lists commercially available technologies useful for the Coast Guard.

Calls for a cross-agency collaboration plan with the Department of Homeland Security, the Department of Defense, and other relevant agencies.

Highlights opportunities to share unmanned system data to improve maritime domain awareness.

Requires the development of a concept of operations for a data ecosystem supporting unmanned systems, including AI and machine learning tools.

column2: Coast Guard Authorization Act of 2024, Title III ("Shipping and Navigation"), Sec. 342 ("Establishment of National Advisory Committee on Autonomous Maritime Systems")
column3: Coast Guard Authorization Act, Title III ("Shipping and Navigation"), Sec. 342 ("Advisory Committee on Autonomous Maritime Systems")
column15: Establishes the National Advisory Committee on Autonomous Maritime Systems. Advises the Secretary on regulation and use within U.S. waters. Comprises 9 expert members. Ensures diverse representation. Mandates establishment within 90 days post-enactment.
column16:
Establishes the National Advisory Committee on Autonomous Maritime Systems.

Advises the Secretary on regulation and use of Autonomous Systems within U.S. territorial waters.

Comprises 9 members appointed by the Secretary with relevant expertise.

Ensures representation from various groups, including marine safety, vessel design, unmanned vehicle production, port authorities, vessel operators, labor unions, maritime pilots, commercial space operators, and academic institutions.

Mandates establishment of the Committee within 90 days post-enactment.

column2: 21st Century Peace through Strength Act, Division D ("Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act")
column3: 21st Century Peace through Strength Act, Division D ("Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications")
column15: Prohibits distributing, maintaining, or updating foreign adversary-controlled applications in the U.S. Requires data portability in a machine-readable format. Exempts "qualified divestiture" applications. Enforces penalties up to $5,000 per user. Mandates Attorney General investigation and enforcement. Grants judicial review to D.C. Circuit Court.
column16:
Prohibits entities from distributing, maintaining, or updating foreign adversary controlled applications within the U.S.

Requires data portability for users before prohibitions apply, enabling users to access their data in a machine-readable format.

Exempts applications undergoing "qualified divestiture" from prohibitions.

Enforces penalties up to $5,000 per user for distribution violations and $500 per user for data portability violations.

Mandates the Attorney General to investigate and enforce compliance through civil penalties or court actions.

Defines "foreign adversary controlled applications" and "qualified divestiture" to ensure clarity in application and exemptions.

Grants judicial review exclusively to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, with specified time limits for challenges.

column2: Department of Peacebuilding Act of 2023, Sec. 107 ("Office of Technology for Peace")
column3: Department of Peacebuilding Act, Sec. 107 ("Office of Technology for Peace")
column15: Establishes an Office of Technology for Peace. Tasks the Assistant Secretary with overseeing ethical implications of technologies. Mandates policy dissemination with the Department of State. Requires nonviolent technology grants. Encourages conservation grants. Promotes a green, peaceful economy.
column16:
Establishes an Office of Technology for Peace within the Department, headed by the Assistant Secretary for Technology for Peace.

Tasks the Assistant Secretary with overseeing awareness, study, and ethical implications of technologies, including artificial intelligence, on domestic and international peace.

Mandates the dissemination of applicable policies and research in consultation with the Department of State.

Requires the Assistant Secretary to provide grants for technologies in transportation, communications, agriculture, medicine, and energy that are nonviolent.

Encourages grants that promote conservation and sustainability of natural resources to prevent future conflicts.

Promotes the development of a green, peaceful economy through these grants.

column2: Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs Appropriations Act 2024, Title VII ("General Provisions"), Sec. 7032 ("Democracy Programs")
column3: DOS Foreign Operations Appropriations Act, Title VII ("General Provisions"), Sec. 7032 ("Democracy Programs")
column15: Allocates $2.9 billion for democracy programs, including $159.24 million for the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor. Mandates a five-year strategy submission within 180 days. Prohibits foreign government approval. Allocates $50 million for activists, journalists, and media. Requires regular updates to the National Endowment for Democracy.
column16:
Requires the allocation of $2,900,000,000 for democracy programs from various appropriations, including $159,240,000 for the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor.

Mandates the submission of a comprehensive five-year strategy for democracy promotion abroad within 180 days, addressing digital security, countering disinformation, and AI-related challenges.

Prohibits foreign governments from having prior approval over the implementation of democracy programs and protects the confidentiality of implementing partners in undemocratic countries.

Allocates $30,000,000 to protect civil society activists and journalists and $20,000,000 for international freedom of expression and independent media.

Requires the regular informing of the National Endowment for Democracy about planned and supported democracy programs.

column2: A bill to waive immunity under section 230 of the Communications Act of 1934 for claims and charges related to generative artificial intelligence.
column3: General AI Communications Act Immunity
column15: Removes Section 230 protection (federal liability protection) for providers of interactive computer services if the conduct giving rise to liability involves generative artificial intelligence.
column16: Amends Section 230 of the Communications Act of 1934 (which prevents providers of an interactive computer service from being held legally liable for third-party content) to remove this protection for claims involving the use or provision of generative artificial intelligence.

column2: National AI Commission Act
column3: National AI Commission Act
column15: Establishes the National AI Commission, an independent and bi-partisan commission in the legislative branch responsible for reviewing and recommending measures to mitigate AI risks and protect US leadership in AI development
column16:
Establishes the National AI Commission, an independent and bi-partisan commission in the legislative branch responsible for reviewing and recommending measures for the US to mitigate the risks and possible harms of AI, and to ensure US leadership in AI innovation and development.

Directs the National AI Commission to review the Federal Government's existing approach to AI oversight and regulation, including the existing distribution of oversight and regulatory authorities across various agencies, and to recommend governmental structures that may be needed to regulate powerful general-purpose AI systems.

Instruct the National AI Commission to submit an interim report to Congress and the President within six months, a final report with its findings and recommendations for a binding regulatory framework no later than six months after the interim report, and a follow-up report within one year of the final report's submission.

Requires the National AI Commission to comprise twenty commissioners appointed by the President and by Congressional leadership, with ten appointed by each party and co-chaired by a Democratic appointee and a Republican appointee.
column17: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: New institution

column2: QUIET Act
column3: QUIET Act
column15: Directs Congress to amend the Communications Act of 1934 to require disclosure of the use of artificial intelligence in voice call or text message impersonations.
column16:
Directs Congress to amend the Communications Act of 1934 to mandate the disclosure of artificial intelligence usage in voice call or text message impersonations.

Mandates the imposition of financial penalties on those who fail to complete the required disclosure of artificial intelligence usage during robocalls.
column17: Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Financial loss;Harms: Detrimental content;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Applications: Networking and telecommunications;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Financial loss;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Detrimental content;Applications: Networking and telecommunications;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Financial loss;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Detrimental content;Applications: Networking and telecommunications;Incentives: Fines;Incentives: Civil liability

column2: Building Resilient Supply Chains Act
column3: Building Resilient Supply Chains Act
column15: Directs the Department of Commerce to establish a Supply Chain Resilience and Crisis Response Office to administer grants and loans to support domestic manufacturing and supply chain diversification for in key technology areas, including artificial intelligence.
column16:
Directs the Department of Commerce to establish a Supply Chain Resiliency and Crisis Response Office, responsible for awarding grants, loans, and loan guarantees to critical industry and supply chain stakeholders that integrate artificial intelligence into manufacturing.

Mandates the DOC to improve the competitiveness of the advanced tech manufacturing sector, minimize supply chain shocks, and support the creation of related jobs in key technology focus areas such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, and quantum computing.

Directs the Inspector General of the DOC to audit activities supported by the Supply Chain Resiliency and Crisis Response Office's grants, loans, and loan guarantees every four years.
column17: Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation

column2: STOP HATE Act of 2023
column3: STOP HATE Act
column15: Mandates social media companies to submit terms of service reports to the Attorney General's office that provide data on how artificial intelligence is being used to flag content and manage disinformation.
column16:
Requires social media companies to make their terms of service publicly available.

Requires social media companies to disclose content moderation data, including the total number of flagged items, actioned items, user engagement, and how artificial intelligence is used to support content moderation efforts.

Allows Attorney General's office to bring a civil penalty of $5,000,000 per violation per day against social media companies who fail to meet these requirements
column17: Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Disclosure;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Disclosure;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Incentives: Civil liability;Incentives: Fines;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Violation of human rights, civil liberties, civil rights, or democratic norms and systems;Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Harms: Detrimental content;Applications: Broadcasting and media production

column2: CONSULT Act of 2023
column3: CONSULT Act
column15: Prohibits the Department of Defense from awarding contracts to any individual or entity, including those producing AI-powered products and services, that has entered into working agreements with any organization from a blacklist of national security threats.
column16:
Requires the Department of Defense to refrain from awarding contracts to any individual or entity, including those producing AI-powered products and services, that has worked with any organization from a blacklist of national security threats.

Authorizes the DOD to punish any contractor of the Department who has a proven conflict of interest with the DOD and fails to disclose that conflict of interest.
column17: Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Dissemination;Strategies: Governance development;Incentives: Access to business opportunities;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Dissemination;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Governance development;Incentives: Access to business opportunities;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Dissemination;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Governance development;Incentives: Access to business opportunities;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: military and public safety

column2: Preventing Algorithmic Collusion Act of 2024
column3: Preventing Algorithmic Collusion Act of 2024
column15: Prohibits use of pricing algorithms with nonpublic competitor data. Requires detailed reports to FTC or Attorney General. Mandates corporate officer certification. Ensures report confidentiality. Imposes civil penalties. Presumes collusion in antitrust cases. Obligates customer and employee disclosure. Directs FTC study.
column16:
Prohibits the use of pricing algorithms incorporating nonpublic competitor data.

Requires entities using or distributing pricing algorithms to submit detailed reports to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) or Attorney General upon request, detailing development, data usage, and algorithmic rules.

Mandates certification of report accuracy by a high-level corporate officer.

Ensures confidentiality of submitted reports, allowing information sharing only between the Department of Justice, FTC, and National Institute of Standards and Technology.

Imposes civil penalties for violations, including fines and injunctive relief.

Presumes collusive behavior in antitrust cases involving certain uses of pricing algorithms, allowing for rebuttal and assigning joint liability.

Obligates disclosure to customers and employees when prices or terms are set by algorithms, including specifics on price discrimination and third-party algorithm developers.

Directs the FTC to study and report on the impact and prevalence of pricing algorithms within two years, including potential consumer harm and benefits.

column2: To require a briefing on the national security threats associated with Chinese autonomous ground vehicles operating in the United States.
column3: HR6896, 2023, Chinese autonomous ground vehicles briefing requirement.
column15: Require the Secretary of Defense to brief on national security threats from Chinese autonomous ground vehicles by March 30, 2024. Mandate inclusion of details on data collected, dual-use technologies, and military use by Chinese entities.
column16:
Require the Secretary of Defense to provide a briefing by March 30, 2024, on national security threats from Chinese autonomous ground vehicles in the U.S.

Mandate the briefing to address vehicles near Department of Defense bases and sensitive U.S. Government facilities.

Specify inclusion of information on data types collected by these vehicles and dual-use implications of their technologies.

Include analysis of how the Chinese Communist Party or People’s Liberation Army could use collected data for military planning.

column2: “Managing Active and Reserve Tech Talent Effectively Act of 2023”
column3: MARTTE Act of 2023
column15: Establishes robust AI and coding skills infrastructure in U.S. Armed Forces. Requires career field codes under Cyber Workforce Framework. Mandates assessment and tracking of skilled personnel. Obligates strategy development for combatant commands. Calls for reserve component policies. Requires implementation updates.
column16:
Establishes a robust human capital infrastructure for computer programming, coding, and AI skills within the U.S. Armed Forces.

Requires the development of career field occupational codes aligned with AI and coding competencies under the Department of Defense Cyber Workforce Framework.

Mandates the assessment and tracking of personnel with AI and coding skills.

Obliges the military departments to develop and execute a coherent strategy for presenting these skills to combatant commands.

Tasks the Secretary of each military department, in consultation with relevant officials, to implement the policy and submit implementation plans within 180 days.

Calls for similar policies for reserve components to leverage civilian-acquired AI and coding skills.

Requires updates on policy implementation in the Department of Defense's budget justification materials until all milestones are met.
