column2: AI Leadership Training Act
column3: AI Leadership Training Act
column15: Establishes an AI leadership training program for executive agencies. Requires annual training on AI capabilities, risks, and ethics. Mandates topics cover AI basics, risks, and constitutional issues. Obligates updates biennially. Demands participation metrics. Permits Congressional oversight. Sets a 10-year sunset clause.
column16:
Establishes an AI leadership training program for management officials, supervisors, and other designated employees in executive agencies, to be developed and implemented within 18 months.

Requires annual training to cover AI capabilities, risks, safety, ethics, Federal Government requirements, and best practices related to AI procurement, use, testing, evaluation, and auditing.

Mandates program topics include AI basics, benefits, risks, data significance, AI system failures, continuous refinement, risk mitigation, organizational considerations, and constitutional risks related to AI use.

Obligates updates to the program every two years to incorporate new AI information and ensure compliance with training requirements.

Demands metrics to measure participation and feedback for program improvements.

Permits Congress to request detailed information about the program materials and responsible personnel.

Encourages interaction with experts from various sectors as part of the training.

Sets a sunset clause for the program 10 years after enactment.

column2: Supply Chain Mapping and Monitoring Act
column3: Supply Chain Mapping and Monitoring Act
column15: Establishes the Supply Chain Resiliency and Crisis Response Office within 180 days. Mandates the Under Secretary to map, monitor, and model supply chains. Requires collaboration with various stakeholders. Involves continuous monitoring and quadrennial reports. Authorizes $500 million for 2024-2028.
column16:
Establishes the Supply Chain Resiliency and Crisis Response Office within 180 days to monitor and enhance supply chain resilience, especially for critical industries and goods.

Mandates the Under Secretary to map, monitor, and model supply chains, identifying gaps and vulnerabilities.

Requires collaboration with federal agencies, private sector, labor organizations, and international partners to strengthen supply chains and prepare for shocks.

Involves continuous monitoring of supply chain resilience, diversity, and security, and mandates quadrennial reports on supply chain resiliency and domestic manufacturing.

Authorizes $500 million for fiscal years 2024-2028 to fund these activities, ensuring up to 2% per fiscal year for administrative costs.

column2: Autonomous Vehicle Accessibility Act/AV Accessibility Act
column3: Autonomous Vehicle Accessibility Act/AV Accessibility Act
column15: Cites the Act as the “Autonomous Vehicle Accessibility Act” or the “AV Accessibility Act.” Defines key terms. Prohibits states from discriminatory licensing of Level 4 or 5 ADS-equipped vehicles. Mandates a study on improving accessibility. Authorizes $5,000,000 for the study.
column16:
Cites the Act as the “Autonomous Vehicle Accessibility Act” or the “AV Accessibility Act”.

Defines key terms including “disability,” “public transportation,” and “ride-hail ADS-equipped vehicle.”

Prohibits states from issuing licenses for Level 4 or Level 5 ADS-equipped vehicles in a manner that discriminates against individuals with disabilities, in accordance with the ADA.

Mandates the Secretary of Transportation to commission a study through the National Academies to identify changes needed in public transportation infrastructure to improve accessibility for individuals with disabilities using ride-hail ADS-equipped vehicles.

Authorizes $5,000,000 for the completion of the accessibility infrastructure study, available until expended.

column2: Computer Science for All Act of 2023
column3: Computer Science for All Act of 2023
column15: Requires the Secretary of Education to award grants for expanding computer science education. Mandates access for all high school students within five years and progression from prekindergarten. Limits equipment purchases to 15%. Authorizes $250 million annually for five years.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Education to award grants to states, local educational agencies, and eligible Tribal schools for expanding computer science education.

Mandates grant recipients to provide every high school student with access to computer science education within five years and ensure a progression of computer science education from prekindergarten through middle school.

Requires the use of grant funds for teacher training, expanding access to learning materials, and reducing equity gaps in STEAM education for underrepresented groups.

Permits grant funds to be used for building regional collaborations, hiring instructional personnel, and disseminating effective practices.

Limits use of grant funds for equipment purchases to 15%.

Authorizes $250 million for fiscal year 2024 and the following four fiscal years.

Requires grant recipients to report biannually on the use of funds and student demographics.

Mandates the Secretary to report to Congress within five years on program expansion recommendations.

column2: Protect Working Musicians Act of 2023
column3: Protect Working Musicians Act of 2023
column15: Grants Independent Music Creator Owners immunity from antitrust liability for collectively negotiating with Dominant Online Music Distribution Platforms or companies using generative AI. Requires nondiscriminatory negotiations. Ensures no involvement of third parties. Stipulates no alteration to existing antitrust laws.
column16:
Grants Independent Music Creator Owners immunity from antitrust liability for collectively negotiating music licensing terms with Dominant Online Music Distribution Platforms or companies using generative AI.

Defines "Dominant Online Music Distribution Platform" as entities with over $100 million in annual music-related revenue and specifies exclusions.

Defines "generative artificial intelligence" as AI systems generating novel media based on prompts.

Requires that collective negotiations among Independent Music Creator Owners be nondiscriminatory, not limited to price, and directly related to negotiations with Dominant Online Music Distribution Platforms.

Ensures that collective negotiations do not involve parties other than Independent Music Creator Owners or Dominant Online Music Distribution Platforms.

Stipulates that the Act does not modify, impair, or supersede existing antitrust laws beyond the specified provisions.

column2: Cooper Davis Act
column3: Cooper Davis Act
column15:
Requires electronic communication service providers to report fentanyl, methamphetamine, or counterfeit substance crimes to the DEA within 60 days. 

Subjects providers to penalties for non-compliance. 

Obliges DEA to review and share reports, with annual outcome publications. 

Exempts broadband providers.
column16:
Requires electronic communication service providers and remote computing services to report to the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) any knowledge of crimes involving fentanyl, methamphetamine, or counterfeit substances.

Mandates the report to be filed within 60 days of obtaining such knowledge, including detailed contact and relevant information about the involved accounts.

Allows reports based on reasonable belief and includes optional additional information like geographic location and complete communication data.

Subjects providers to criminal and civil penalties for failing to report or submitting false reports.

States that providers are not required to monitor users or the content of communications proactively.

Obliges DEA to review and potentially investigate reports, sharing them with other law enforcement agencies as needed.

Mandates the Attorney General to enforce these requirements and take measures for data minimization.

Requires DEA to publish annual reports on the number and outcomes of reports received.

Exempts broadband internet access service providers from these reporting requirements.

column2: Countering Adversarial and Malicious Partnerships at Universities and Schools Act of 2023
column3: CAMPUS Act
column15: Requires the Director of National Intelligence to identify Chinese institutions supporting the PLA and Military-Civil Fusion. Mandates annual reporting to Congress. Prohibits DoD and federal research funding to entities contracting with identified institutions. Restricts classified information facilities. Allows visa denial. Reduces foreign gift reporting threshold. Authorizes grants for Mandarin instruction with Taiwan. Prohibits Department of Education funds for K-12 schools contracting with Chinese entities.
column16:
Requires the Director of National Intelligence, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, to identify Chinese institutions of higher education supporting the People's Liberation Army and Military-Civil Fusion strategy.

Mandates submission of an annual list of these identified entities to Congress.

Prohibits Department of Defense funding for research, development, testing, and evaluation to entities contracting with identified Chinese institutions.

Restricts facilities from hosting or storing classified information unless they certify no active research partnership with identified institutions.

Allows the Secretary of State to deny visas to students or employees of identified institutions.

Prohibits Department of Education funds for K-12 schools contracting with entities domiciled in China.

Authorizes grants to U.S. schools to support Mandarin language instruction and Chinese cultural programming in partnership with Taiwan.

Prohibits federal research funds for entities contracting with listed Chinese entities.

Lowers the reporting threshold for foreign gifts to institutions of higher education from $250,000 to $50,000.

column2: Deploying American Blockchains Act of 2023
column3: Deploying American Blockchains Act of 2023
column15: Designates the Secretary of Commerce as the principal blockchain advisor to the President. Requires policy development on decentralized identity, cybersecurity, AI, compliance, and fraud. Instructs U.S. blockchain leadership promotion. Mandates advisory committees. Directs best practices dissemination. Obligates stakeholder consultation. Requires annual congressional reports. Terminates program after seven years.
column16:
Designates the Secretary of Commerce as the principal advisor to the President on blockchain technology and related applications.

Requires the Secretary to develop policies and recommendations addressing issues such as decentralized identity, cybersecurity, AI, regulatory compliance, and fraud reduction.

Instructs the Secretary to promote U.S. leadership and competitiveness in blockchain technology through a Blockchain Deployment Program.

Mandates the establishment of advisory committees with diverse stakeholders to support blockchain adoption.

Directs the Secretary to facilitate the development and dissemination of best practices for blockchain technology.

Obligates the Secretary to consult with private sector stakeholders and disseminate research on blockchain technology.

Requires annual reports to Congress on activities, recommendations for legislation, and emerging risks and trends in blockchain technology.

Terminates the Blockchain Deployment Program seven years after enactment.

column2: National Mesonet Authorization Act
column3: National Mesonet Authorization Act
column15: Establishes the National Mesonet Program within the National Weather Service. Requires leveraging commercial, academic, and non-Federal data. Targets improved environmental observations. Mandates integration of diverse weather observations. Provides assistance for mesonet systems. Forms an advisory committee. Obligates regular Congressional briefings. Allocates funding for 2024-2028.
column16:
Establishes the National Mesonet Program within the National Weather Service to improve weather observation and forecasting.

Requires the program to leverage commercial, academic, and other non-Federal weather data to enhance coordination across sectors.

Targets improved environmental observations to support baseline forecasts and warnings, and to enhance numerical weather prediction performance.

Mandates integration of greater density and types of weather observations, including local and regional networks and satellite constellations.

Provides financial and technical assistance for State, Tribal, private, and academic entities to build or upgrade mesonet systems, contingent on agreements to share data.

Forms an advisory committee to recommend improvements and expansions of available data.

Obligates regular briefings to relevant Congressional committees on program activities and progress.

Allocates specified funding amounts for fiscal years 2024 through 2028 to support the program's implementation and expansion.

column2: Food and Agriculture Industry Cybersecurity Support Act
column3: Food and Agriculture Industry Cybersecurity Support Act
column15: Establishes a food and agriculture cybersecurity clearinghouse within the NTIA. Requires the clearinghouse to provide resources, support, and materials. Mandates best practice consolidation into voluntary recommendations. Instructs consultation with various stakeholders. Directs a federal cybersecurity study. Sunsets after seven years.
column16:
Establishes a food and agriculture cybersecurity clearinghouse within the NTIA to provide publicly available online resources focused on cybersecurity for the food and agriculture industry.

Requires the clearinghouse to offer in-person or virtual support, updated FAQs, and materials for small businesses on critical cybersecurity protections and ransomware response.

Mandates the consolidation of public and private sector best practices into voluntary cybersecurity recommendations for the food and agriculture industry, including continuous monitoring and ransomware attack responses.

Instructs the Assistant Secretary to consult with private sector, federal agencies, trade groups, and civil society organizations in implementing the clearinghouse.

Directs the Comptroller General to study and report on federal efforts to improve cybersecurity in the food and agriculture industry, evaluating effectiveness, resources, coordination, and potential risks of coordinated attacks.

Sunsets the section seven years after enactment.

column2: Know Your App Act
column3: Know Your App Act
column15: Requires covered companies to publicly list each app's primary country of origin. Mandates filtering options for countries of concern and data disclaimers. Obligates developers to notify changes and certify information. Enforces warnings and app removals for non-compliance. Establishes reporting and appeals processes. Directs annual listing of countries with government control laws. Limits enforcement to stated provisions. Authorizes Attorney General to enforce compliance.
column16:
Requires covered companies to publicly list the primary country of origin of each application on the app store page with prominent display.

Mandates that covered companies provide an option to filter out apps from countries of concern and display disclaimers if data could be accessed by a foreign government.

Obligates developers to notify covered companies of changes in country of origin or beneficial ownership and certify the accuracy of displayed information annually.

Enforces a series of warnings and potential removal of apps for non-compliance by developers.

Establishes a reporting mechanism for potential violations and provides an appeals process for app removals.

Directs the Treasury and Commerce Secretaries to annually list countries with laws enabling government control over applications, making the list publicly available.

Limits enforcement and regulatory authority to provisions explicitly stated in the Act.

Authorizes the Attorney General to enforce compliance through civil action.

column2: Advancing Automation Research and Development in Agriculture Act
column3: Advancing Automation Research and Development in Agriculture Act
column15: Establishes a competitive grant program for specialty crop mechanization under the Department of Agriculture. Mandates cost-effective automation technologies. Requires connectivity, autonomy, and cost-effectiveness. Specifies prototype development and commercialization. Allows diverse entities to apply. Allocates $20 million annually.
column16:
Establishes a stand-alone competitive research and extension grant program under the Department of Agriculture to advance mechanization and automation for specialty crops.

Mandates projects to create or improve cost-effective technologies that reduce manual labor and increase efficiency in crop production, resource management, and processing.

Requires projects to promote the adoption of mechanization and automation technologies by emphasizing factors such as connectivity, autonomy, and cost-effectiveness.

Specifies projects to accelerate automation through prototype development, in-field trials, and rapid commercialization.

Allows grants to be awarded to federal agencies, universities, research institutions, private organizations, and other eligible entities.

Mandates a competitive grant process based on scientific peer review and industry relevance.

Requires annual consultations with the specialty crops committee to review procedures, objectives, and grant awards.

Allocates $20 million annually from the Commodity Credit Corporation to fund the program starting fiscal year 2024.

column2: Combating Cartels on Social Media Act of 2023
column3: Combating Cartels on Social Media Act of 2023
column15: Requires assessment of social media use by transnational criminal organizations within 180 days. Mandates submission of a National Strategy within one year. Proposes improved cooperation, intelligence, and law enforcement. Establishes centralized reporting mechanism. Instructs consultation with various entities. Mandates semiannual reporting. Designates specific official for intelligence management.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to assess the use of social media and online platforms by transnational criminal organizations for recruitment and illicit activities within 180 days.

Mandates submission of a National Strategy to Combat Illicit Recruitment Activity by Transnational Criminal Organizations on Social Media and Online Platforms within one year.

Proposes improvements in cooperation between government entities and social media operators, enhanced intelligence analysis, and proactive law enforcement efforts.

Requires establishment of a centralized mechanism for reporting recruitment efforts by transnational criminal organizations to the Department of Homeland Security.

Instructs the Secretary to consult with various federal, state, and local entities, as well as social media companies and experts during strategy development and implementation.

Mandates semiannual reporting on the implementation of the strategy and its progress to appropriate congressional committees for five years.

Designates a specific official within U.S. Customs and Border Protection to manage intelligence related to recruitment activities and to facilitate voluntary information reporting from social media operators.

column2: Advanced Aviation Integration Act
column3: Advanced Aviation Integration Act
column15: Designates the Deputy Administrator of the FAA as responsible for advanced aviation integration. Requires FAA office coordination for safe integration. Mandates biannual workforce reports. Establishes the Office of Advanced Integration and the Advanced Aviation Coordination Unit. Authorizes interagency coordination.
column16:
Designates the Deputy Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) as the executive responsible for advanced aviation integration.

Requires coordination across FAA offices to ensure safe operation and integration of advanced aviation systems, including policy, rulemaking, and workforce planning.

Mandates the Deputy Administrator to report biannually on workforce requirements and recommend staffing and budget resources.

Establishes the Office of Advanced Integration, headed by a Director, to oversee advanced aviation system responsibilities.

Creates the Advanced Aviation Coordination Unit to promote safe integration, improve certification processes, and develop standards for advanced aviation systems.

Forms working groups on unmanned aircraft systems, advanced air mobility, and safety technology integration within the Coordination Unit.

Defines "advanced aviation system" broadly to include unmanned aircraft, powered lift aircraft, and various advanced aviation technologies.

Authorizes the Secretary of Transportation to facilitate interagency coordination to support advanced aviation integration.

column2: Solving the Border Crisis Act
column3: Solving the Border Crisis Act
column15: Resumes border wall construction, requiring the Secretary of Homeland Security to restart halted projects. Prohibits contract cancellations before January 20, 2021. Requires lifting COVID-19 suspensions 120 days post-emergency. Mandates plans for potential influxes. Disapproves asylum officer adjudication rule. Amends Immigration and Nationality Act for alien return or detention. Establishes minimum staffing levels, including 25,000 U.S. Border Patrol agents. Ensures funding for detention facilities. Mandates a report on mitigating border encounters within 60 days.
column16:
Resumes border wall system construction, requiring the Secretary of Homeland Security to restart halted projects and honor previous agreements.

Prohibits the cancellation of contracts related to border wall construction entered into before January 20, 2021.

Requires the lifting of COVID-19 related suspension of entries and imports not earlier than 120 days after the termination of the public health emergency.

Mandates submission of plans to manage possible influxes related to the termination of COVID-19 suspensions.

Disapproves the rule allowing asylum officers to adjudicate credible fear claims, maintaining exclusive authority for immigration judges.

Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to require the return of aliens to contiguous territory or detain them for further asylum consideration.

Establishes minimum staffing levels for various immigration and border enforcement offices, including 25,000 U.S. Border Patrol agents.

Ensures funding for sufficient detention facilities to comply with mandatory detention requirements.

Mandates a report within 60 days on how the Department of Homeland Security is mitigating border encounters.

column2: Air Tour and Sport Parachuting Safety Improvement Act of 2023
column3: Air Tour and Sport Parachuting Safety Improvement Act of 2023
column15: Requires the FAA to issue a final rule mandating safety management systems within 24 months. Prohibits commercial air tours without a part 119 certificate after three years. Mandates new regulations for flight safety training within three years. Convenes a rulemaking committee for flight data standards. Directs the Administrator to submit reports and issue rules based on committee recommendations. Requires the FAA to improve the operating certificate process and report on its efficiency. Authorizes necessary appropriations to implement the Act.
column16:
Requires the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Administrator to issue a final rule within 24 months mandating safety management systems for certain operators under part 135 of title 14.

Prohibits, beginning three years after enactment, commercial air tours without a certificate under part 119 of title 14, unless meeting specific temporary exceptions.

Mandates new or revised regulations within three years to incorporate controlled flight into terrain and in-flight loss of control avoidance training for certificated commercial air tour operators.

Convenes an aviation rulemaking committee to develop standards for flight data monitoring, terrain awareness, and traffic avoidance for commercial air tour operators.

Directs the Administrator to submit reports and issue proposed rulemakings and final rules based on the aviation rulemaking committee's recommendations within specified timelines.

Requires the FAA to improve the process for obtaining operating certificates and report on the efficiency and resource needs of this process.

Authorizes appropriations as necessary to implement the Act.

column2: Advanced Aviation Act
column3: Advanced Aviation Act
column15: Redesignates the Office of NextGen as the Office of Advanced Aviation within 1 year. Appoints an Associate Administrator. Coordinates rulemaking for advanced aviation. Establishes an Office of Advanced Integration and an Advanced Aviation Coordination Unit. Redesignates the William J. Hughes Technical Center. Establishes an Aviation Innovation Program. Defines "advanced aviation systems."
column16:
Redesignates the Office of NextGen as the Office of Advanced Aviation within 1 year.

Appoints an Associate Administrator to oversee the Office of Advanced Aviation.

Coordinates rulemaking and approval processes for advanced aviation systems' standardization, certification, safety, and integration into national airspace.

Establishes an Office of Advanced Integration to manage responsibilities related to advanced aviation systems.

Forms an Advanced Aviation Coordination Unit to promote safe integration and certification of advanced aviation systems.

Redesignates the William J. Hughes Technical Center as the William J. Hughes Technical Center for Advanced Aviation, responsible for research, development, and integration of new aviation technologies.

Establishes an Aviation Innovation Program to evaluate and integrate new aviation-related technologies into the national airspace system.

Defines "advanced aviation systems" to include unmanned aircraft systems, counter-UAS systems, powered lift aircraft, and related technologies.

column2: Research and Development Program on New Approaches to Data Analysis for Aviation Safety
column3: Research and Development Program on New Approaches to Data Analysis for Aviation Safety
column15: Establishes a FAA NEXTOR III program to develop AI-based aviation safety analysis. Requires collaboration among institutions, industry, FAA, and NASA. Prioritizes human factors and automated aircraft design improvements. Authorizes $20M annually from 2024-2029. Terminates after 6 years.
column16:
Establishes a new research and development program by the FAA’s NEXTOR III to develop new data analysis approaches for aviation safety.

Includes use of new algorithms and AI methods for analyzing various data sets such as weather, equipment performance, flight delays, safety incidents, and communications.

Requires collaboration among Consortium member institutions, aviation industry partners, FAA units, and NASA’s Aviation Safety Reporting System for data sharing and testing.

Prioritizes understanding human factors contributing to aviation safety risk, including fatigue, distraction, workload, organizational culture, communication, and adherence to safety procedures.

Seeks to improve the design of highly automated aircraft to reduce mode confusion and increase awareness of flight parameters.

Authorizes $20,000,000 annually from 2024 to 2029 for program execution, including grants to participating institutions and FAA units.

Terminates the program 6 years after establishment.

column2: TORPEDO Act of 2023, Sec. 6 (Reporting requirements on efforts of the Department of State to implement the AUKUS partnership)
column3: TORPEDO Act of 2023, Sec. 6 (Reporting requirements on efforts of the Department of State to implement the AUKUS partnership)
column15: Mandates the Secretary of State to report on AUKUS partnership implementation within 90 days. Requires details on Australia's submarine-related goals and contributions. Instructs strategy integration. Demands export control process improvements. Requires ITAR changes assessment. Obligates annual briefings to Congress.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of State, in coordination with the Secretaries of Defense, Commerce, and Energy, to report on the Department of State's implementation of the AUKUS partnership within 90 days of enactment.

Requires the report to detail Australia's progress on various submarine-related goals, including infrastructure, workforce training, and basing support.

Instructs the report to assess Australia's submarine contributions to U.S. defense objectives and provide a strategy for integrating AUKUS and U.S. submarines.

Mandates reporting on U.S. export control processes and recommendations for improvements to facilitate the AUKUS partnership.

Demands an interagency report on changes to ITAR and export control regimes to enable defense item exchanges among AUKUS members and Canada.

Requires an assessment of efforts to enhance collaboration in AI, quantum technologies, cyber capabilities, and other advanced defense areas.

Obligates the President to brief Congress annually for seven years on AUKUS implementation progress.

column2: TORPEDO Act of 2023,  Sec. 12 (Expedited release of advanced technologies to Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom through the foreign military sales program)
column3: TORPEDO Act of 2023,  Sec. 12 (Expedited release of advanced technologies to Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom through the foreign military sales program)
column15: Requires the Secretary of State to list pre-cleared military technologies for Australia, Canada, and the UK within 90 days and annually. Expedites Foreign Military Sales processing. Mandates anticipatory release policy for key capabilities. Requires policy review and update.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of State, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense, to compile a list of pre-cleared military technologies and platforms for sale to Australia, Canada, and the UK within 90 days of enactment and annually thereafter.

Expedites the processing of Foreign Military Sales requests from Australia, Canada, and the UK.

Mandates the creation of an anticipatory release policy for key Foreign Military Sales capabilities, including AI, hypersonic missiles, cyber capabilities, and quantum technologies, with a presumption of approval.

Requires the review and update of interagency policies to incorporate these anticipatory release provisions.

column2: Rail Worker and Community Safety Act, Sec. 13 (Equipment Inspections)
column3: Rail Worker and Community Safety Act, Sec. 13 (Equipment Inspections)
column15: Requires the Secretary of Transportation to issue regulations within 12 months. Prohibits train movements from switchyards before brake inspections. Allows only Qualified Mechanical Inspectors to sign off on inspections. Ensures AI or camera-based inspections require verification.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Transportation to issue regulations within 12 months of enactment.

Prohibits the movement of trains from switchyards before completing all required brake inspections.

Allows only Qualified Mechanical Inspectors to sign off on inspection forms for locomotives and rail cars.

Ensures that inspections using AI or camera-based systems under part 215 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, require verification by a Qualified Mechanical Inspector.

column2: HOME Act of 2024, Sec. 7 (Identification of Unfair Screening Practices)
column3: HOME Act of 2024, Sec. 7 (Identification of Unfair Screening Practices)
column15: Mandates the Secretary, FTC, and CFPB to collect information on unfair tenant screening practices, including algorithms. Requires identification of practices hindering rental access, focusing on background checks, adverse notices, and income sources. Obligates annual reporting to Congress.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary, the Federal Trade Commission, and the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection to jointly collect information on unfair practices in tenant and applicant screenings, including the use of algorithms.

Requires the identification of practices that prevent access to or retention of rental housing, focusing on tenant background checks, adverse action notices, and tenant income sources.

Obliges the submission of an annual report to Congress detailing the information collected under the program.

column2: PAID Act, Sec. 3 (Requirements for Private Passenger Automobile Insurers)
column3: PAID Act, Sec. 3 (Requirements for Private Passenger Automobile Insurers)
column15: Prohibits insurers from considering gender, education, and ZIP Code for eligibility or rates. Requires biennial FTC submissions on non-discriminatory practices. Mandates public access to underwriting rules. Exempts compliant individuals from liability. Clarifies violations and preserves enforcement authority.
column16:
Prohibits private passenger automobile insurers from considering certain factors, such as gender, education level, and ZIP Code, in determining insurance eligibility or rates.

Requires insurers to submit information to the FTC within one year of enactment and biennially thereafter to demonstrate that their practices and algorithms do not disproportionately impact any customer group based on protected characteristics.

Mandates public availability of underwriting rules and rate filings, disallowing them from being proprietary trade secrets.

Exempts individuals from liability if they prove they maintained reasonable compliance procedures.

Clarifies that using prohibited factors to influence insurance premiums constitutes a violation, affecting eligibility, rebates, discounts, and other policy terms.

Preserves the authority of Federal and State agencies to enforce prohibitions against unfair or deceptive practices.

column2: Free Credit Scores for Consumers Act of 2024
column3: Free Credit Scores for Consumers Act of 2024
column15:
Expands definitions of "credit score" and "educational credit score" under the FCRA. 

Requires CRAs to provide detailed explanations of score calculations and disclose differences and limitations of scores. 

Provides free credit score disclosures with annual reports. 

Mandates lenders to give free consumer reports and scores before loan agreements. 

Requires CFPB to issue final rules within two years.
column16:
Expands the definitions of "credit score" and "educational credit score" under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA).

Requires consumer reporting agencies (CRAs) to provide consumers with detailed explanations of credit score calculations, including key factors affecting scores.

Mandates CRAs to disclose prominently the differences and limitations of credit scores and educational credit scores on their websites and in related materials.

Provides consumers with free credit score disclosures along with their free annual consumer reports upon request.

Requires private educational lenders, motor vehicle lenders, and residential mortgage lenders to provide consumers with free copies of any consumer reports and credit scores used for underwriting before signing loan agreements.

Mandates the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to issue final rules to implement these amendments within two years of enactment.

column2: Examining Educational Redlining in Lending Act
column3: Examining Educational Redlining in Lending Act
column15: Requires the Bureau to annually assess educational data and automated processes in creditworthiness determinations. Mandates coordination with agencies and stakeholders. Examines risks and impacts. Obligates reporting to Congress within 60 days. Requires public disclosure. Defines key terms.
column16:
Requires the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection to assess the use of educational data and automated processes in creditworthiness determinations annually.

Mandates coordination with executive agencies and civil rights stakeholders for these assessments.

Examines the risks and disparate impacts of using automated or algorithmic underwriting processes.

Obligates the Bureau to report findings and recommendations to Congress 60 days post-assessment.

Requires public disclosure of assessment findings, lists of covered persons using educational data, and those employing automated or algorithmic processes.

Defines key terms, including "certain educational data" and "covered person," with references to existing legislation.

column2: Veterans Appeals Efficiency Act of 2024
column3: Veterans Appeals Efficiency Act of 2024
column15: Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to submit an annual report on remanded claims. Mandates technology use for tracking claims. Ensures claimant access to deferral reasons. Authorizes appeal aggregation. Obligates compliance with remand decisions. Grants supplemental jurisdiction. Directs a study on common questions. Requires a timely claims assignment plan.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to submit an annual report on the average length of time remanded claims are pending.

Mandates the use of technology to track and maintain information on specific claims for benefits, including those continuously pursued, in the National Work Queue, or pending a hearing.

Ensures claimants can view reasons for claim deferrals or suspense dates in the National Work Queue.

Authorizes the Chairman of the Board of Veterans’ Appeals to aggregate appeals with similar questions of law or fact.

Obliges the Board to ensure substantial compliance with its remand decisions, allowing waivers if sufficient evidence resolves underlying issues.

Grants the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims supplemental jurisdiction to review eligible claims and remand matters for addressing unaddressed issues or inadequate decisions by the Board.

Directs a study, potentially using AI, on common legal or factual questions before the Board and mandates a report on the findings.

Requires the Secretary to develop a plan for timely assignment of claims and submit it to Congress.

column2: Contraband Awareness Technology Catches Harmful Fentanyl Act
column3: CATCH Fentanyl Act
column15: Mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish pilot projects within one year to test technologies enhancing nonintrusive inspection at land ports. Requires testing of at least five technology types. Sets termination five years post-enactment. Requires reporting to Congress.
column16:
Mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security, through the CBP Innovation Team, to establish pilot projects within one year to test and assess technologies enhancing nonintrusive inspection systems at land ports of entry.

Requires testing of at least five technology types, including artificial intelligence, machine learning, and quantum information sciences, to detect contraband, illegal drugs, and threats.

Identifies effective enhancements based on detection accuracy, efficiency, integration capability, cost, safety, and mobility.

Allows private sector input on commercially viable technologies.

Sets termination of pilot projects five years post-enactment.

Requires reporting to Congress within three years and after project termination, detailing effectiveness, recommendations, cost plans, and performance analysis of tested technologies.

column2: No AI Audits Act
column3: No AI Audits Act
column15: Titles the Act as the “No AI Audits Act”. Limits the IRS's use of AI for audits. Requires IRS AI guidance to follow rule-making procedures. Prohibits AI-initiated audits unless AI meets NIST explainability principles. Mandates Comptroller General audits of IRS's AI use. Stipulates IRS investigations must be initiated by a staff investigator. Defines "artificial intelligence" per the National AI Initiative Act of 2020.
column16:
Titles the Act as the “No AI Audits Act”.

Limits the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) use of artificial intelligence (AI) for audits or investigations.

Requires any IRS guidance on AI for audits to follow rule-making procedures under Section 553 of Title 5, U.S. Code.

Prohibits the IRS from conducting audits or investigations initiated by AI unless the AI meets explainability principles set by the National Institute of Standards and Technology.

Defines "artificial intelligence" according to the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020.

Mandates the Comptroller General to audit and report on the IRS's AI use, including a cost-benefit analysis and the impact on taxpayer rights.

Stipulates that IRS investigations or examinations must be initiated by a staff investigator, with documentation including the investigator's contact information.

column2: Methane Emissions Mitigation Research and Development Act
column3: Methane Emissions Mitigation Research and Development Act
column15: Requires the Secretary of Energy to implement a methane emissions program. Mandates cooperative agreements for technical assistance. Establishes public resources for best practices. Supports research into emissions quantification technologies. Forms a research consortium. Requires annual reporting. Authorizes appropriations.
column16:
Requires the Secretary of Energy, in consultation with the EPA and other federal agencies, to implement a program for methane emissions detection and mitigation research, development, and demonstration.

Mandates cooperative agreements with state/local governments, higher education institutions, and for-profit entities for technical assistance in preventing and responding to methane releases.

Establishes publicly accessible resources for best practices in pipeline systems, production wells, storage facilities, and emission reduction technologies.

Supports research into technologies for accurate methane emissions quantification, including improvements in data analytics, machine learning platforms, and Lidar detection technologies.

Forms a Methane Emissions Measurement and Mitigation Research Consortium to prioritize research, facilitate data sharing, and develop cooperative leak detection and repair strategies.

Requires annual reporting to Congress on the Consortium's activities, findings, and progress, and a merit review after five years.

Authorizes specific appropriations for the Secretary of Energy and Secretary of Commerce to support these initiatives through 2029.

column2: TAME Extreme Weather Act
column3: TAME Extreme Weather Act
column15: Mandates federal agencies to use AI for extreme weather adaptation and resilience. Requires NOAA to develop AI weather models and datasets. Directs NOAA to explore advanced AI for forecasting. Tasks NOAA with technical assistance. Establishes AI programs for wildfire detection and emissions monitoring. Instructs the Department of Energy to optimize energy grids and ensure public access to AI models, while protecting security interests.
column16:
Mandates federal agencies to use AI to adapt to extreme weather, improving weather forecasts, electrical grid resilience, resource deployment, and public-private partnerships.

Requires NOAA to develop and curate an Earth system reanalysis dataset, build on existing datasets, and develop AI weather models.

Directs NOAA to explore advanced AI applications for weather forecasting, including data assimilation and model emulation.

Tasks NOAA with providing technical assistance on AI weather models and developing best practices and public datasets.

Establishes programs using AI for wildfire detection, emissions monitoring, and illegal wood product tracking, requiring dataset curation and public access to AI code and data.

Instructs the Department of Energy to optimize energy grids using AI, develop environmental review documents, and ensure public access to AI models and training datasets, while protecting national security interests.

column2: AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024
column3: AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024
column15: Requires disclaimers on AI-generated political ads. Defines key terms. Mandates clear AI use statements. Establishes safe harbor guidelines. Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act with fines up to $50,000. Directs FEC to issue regulations. Applies post-enactment. Requires FEC compliance reports.
column16:
Requires the inclusion of disclaimers on political advertisements containing content substantially generated by AI.

Defines "covered communication" and "generative artificial intelligence" for the purpose of the Act.

Mandates that disclaimers must clearly state the use of AI in creating or materially altering the content.

Establishes safe harbor guidelines for what constitutes a "clear and conspicuous manner" in disclaimers for image, audio, and video communications.

Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to include penalties for violations of the disclaimer requirements, with fines up to $50,000.

Directs the Federal Election Commission (FEC) to issue regulations within 90 days of enactment.

Applies the new requirements to communications made after the enactment date, regardless of FEC regulation status.

Requires the FEC to report on compliance and enforcement within two years and biannually thereafter to Congress.

column2: Preserving Telehealth, Hospital, and Ambulance Access Act, Sec. 105 (Report on Wearable Medical Devices)
column3: Preserving Telehealth, Hospital, and Ambulance Access Act, Sec. 105 (Report on Wearable Medical Devices)
column15: Mandates the Comptroller General to assess wearable medical devices within 18 months. Requires analysis of treatment accuracy, examines AI benefits and challenges, and proposes policy options to enhance benefits and mitigate challenges.
column16:
Mandates the Comptroller General to conduct a technology assessment of wearable medical devices within 18 months of the Act's enactment.

Requires the report to include an analysis of the devices' potential to accurately prescribe treatments.

Examines the benefits and challenges of using artificial intelligence to augment wearable medical devices.

Proposes policy options to enhance benefits and mitigate challenges in developing or using such devices.

column2: National Wildland Fire Risk Reduction Program Act, Sec. 7 (Responsibilities of Program Agencies)
column3: National Wildland Fire Risk Reduction Program Act, Sec. 7 (Responsibilities of Program Agencies)
column15: Mandates NIST to research wildland fire impacts and coordinate federal fire investigations. Requires NSF to study fire risks and influencing factors. Instructs NOAA to improve fire understanding and establish a Fire Weather Testbed. Directs FEMA to support risk assessment tools. Tasks NASA with wildland fire research and monitoring. Instructs EPA to investigate fire smoke impacts. Mandates DOE to enhance energy sector resilience.
column16:
Mandates NIST to conduct research on wildland fire impacts, firebrands, novel materials, and performance-based mitigation tools.

Requires NIST to coordinate federal wildland-urban interface fire investigations and develop methodologies for assessing fire impacts on communities.

Directs NSF to support research on wildland fire risks, tools, technologies, and the social and economic factors influencing fire risk reduction.

Instructs NOAA to improve wildland fire understanding through research, weather forecasting, data interoperability, and high-performance computing.

Tasks NOAA with establishing a Fire Weather Testbed and supporting extramural research on wildland fires.

Requires FEMA to support community risk assessment tools, public outreach, and best practices for fire-resistant construction and response.

Directs NASA to support wildland fire research, modeling, data systems, and the development of novel monitoring tools.

Instructs EPA to research wildland fire smoke characteristics, impacts on air and water quality, and communication of risk reduction strategies.

Mandates DOE to develop tools for energy sector resilience to wildland fires and coordinate data resources for improved fire understanding and prevention.

column2: Community and Hydropower Improvement Act, Sec. 4 (Approach to Environmental Review)
column3: Community and Hydropower Improvement Act, Sec. 4 (Approach to Environmental Review)
column15: Amends Section 2403 of the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to enhance environmental review procedures. Requires FERC to cooperate with agencies and Tribes. Mandates consideration of ongoing environmental effects. Obligates impact evaluations on fish species. Encourages open-sourced models. Directs hydrologic impact assessments. Necessitates innovative solutions. Requires periodic technical conferences. Stipulates precise evidence citation.
column16:
Amends Section 2403 of the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to enhance environmental review procedures.

Requires the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to cooperate with federal, state, local agencies, and Indian Tribes in preparing environmental assessments or impact statements.

Mandates consideration of ongoing and reasonably foreseeable environmental effects of projects, excluding nonrecurring past effects.

Obliges FERC and cooperating entities to evaluate impacts on fish species and consider appropriate mitigation strategies.

Encourages the use of open-sourced technical models for environmental impact assessments, ensuring their validity and accessibility while protecting intellectual property and proprietary data.

Directs FERC to account for hydrologic alterations over the project license term and assess their impacts on public uses and regional benefits.

Necessitates consideration of innovative solutions and emerging technologies to meet regulatory responsibilities cost-effectively.

Requires periodic technical conferences to evaluate new methodologies and technologies for environmental impact quantification.

Stipulates precise citation of evidence in environmental review records to support findings on material facts.

column2: Border Act of 2024, General Provisions Title
column3: Border Act of 2024, General Provisions Title
column15: Allocates $170 million for AI-driven autonomous surveillance towers for border security. Prohibits funds for non-autonomous tech. Defines "autonomous" as using sensors, onboard computing, and AI. Mandates quarterly performance reports. Requires open competition for innovative AI tech. Obligates detailed expenditure plans. Instructs cost-benefit analyses before seeking Department of Defense aid.
column16:
Allocates $170,000,000 for the procurement and deployment of autonomous surveillance tower systems using AI for border security.

Prohibits the use of funds for non-autonomous border security technology.

Defines "autonomous" systems as those utilizing sensors, onboard computing, and AI for identification.

Mandates quarterly reports on the performance and impact of border security technologies, including AI-driven non-intrusive inspection technology.

Requires acquisition of innovative technologies through open competition, integrating AI and machine learning to improve performance.

Obliges U.S. Customs and Border Protection to submit detailed expenditure plans for autonomous systems, including deployment timelines and sustainment costs.

Instructs the Secretary of Homeland Security to conduct cost-benefit analyses before requesting Department of Defense assistance for border operations, including AI technology impacts.

column2: To establish a Joint Autonomy Office in the Department of Defense, and for other purposes.
column3: HR3168, 2023, Joint Autonomy Office Establishment
column15: Establishes the Joint Autonomy Office in the Department of Defense, responsible for coordinating and accelerating the adoption of all-domain autonomous systems for operational users, and for developing a Department-wide classification framework for autonomous capabilities.
column16:
Directs the Secretary of Defense to establish the Joint Autonomy Office in the Department of Defense, responsible for coordinating and accelerating the adoption of all-domain autonomous systems for operational users, including through the adoption of commercial and defense best practices

Requires the Office to implement an all-domain enterprise autonomous systems software development and testing platform across DoD's classification levels, including an all-domain data acquisition and curation process to build and manage datasets; these datasets and platforms should be released to various services and acquisition programs as they mature.

Requires the Secretary of Defense to ensure that the Office has unlimited access to existing datasets regardless of classification level, and to introduce security protocols to protect data shared with or maintained by the Office.

Requires the Director of the Office must establish a Department-wide classification framework for autonomous capabilities, considering the complexity of autonomous systems, the necessity of human supervision or control, their applicability to various warfighting domains, and costs; the Director must submit this framework along with an explanation of its criteria and requirements to Congress, with updates released no less frequently than once every two years.

Requires the Director to develop and implement plans to standardize planning, resource and integration of autonomous capabilities across the Department; this includes a report assessing the Department's current efforts which identifies acquisition, training and evaluation gaps, as well as recommendations to address these.

column2: Healthy Technology Act of 2023
column3: Healthy Technology Act of 2023
column15: Authorizes artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies to prescribe pharmaceutical drugs if approved by the State involved and the Food and Drug Administration
column16:
Amends the definition of 'practitioner licensed by law to administer such a drug' in Section 503(b) of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, to include artificial intelligence and machine learning technology

Authorizes AI and ML technology to prescribe pharmaceutical drugs if approved by the State in question, and if approved by the Food and Drug Administration 

Requires such AI and ML technology to be approved by the Food and Drug Administration through conventional channels, including having to provide 90 days' premarket notification if this is deemed a new device
